"Their pizza is in the top 10% of Seattle pizza joints. Their salads and sides are always top notch (the brussel sprouts I had last night were very tasty).But the best part for me is that our two girls (ages 2 and 3) can roam in the play area right next to our table.It's a great place to watch a game as well. We go there for Husky games. So if your case has an opening that's just wide enough for the new Lightning connector you won't be able to use this adapter without taking off your case--pretty annoying.  I made this mistake and had to make a second trip back to the Apple Store to exchange it.  On the flip side, this cable is kind of annoyingly small so your phone may not lay flat on the table next to your old speaker dock.  Sigh.  But at least it works, and $40 is cheaper than a new speaker dock."		"I'm looking to buy a vacuum specifically to pick up dog fur from car interiors, any recommendations?" Since joining on March 2nd, Alex has chimed in over 20 times on Yabbly! Talk about a power Yabbler!Q. Tell us about yourself!Well, more than a lot of things, I am a geek at heart. As a producer/videographer I spend a lot of time in front of a computer editing videos, writing scripts and animating graphic. I also build civilian drones, so I spend a lot of my time flying, fixing and adding features to my drones (unmanned aerial vehicle). I am the other half of a team that makes On Screen Displays and other tools for prosumer UAVs. I also host the Urban Drones show on uStream where a live feed a drone is broadcasted live and other drone enthusiasts watch the live feed, ask questions and participate in the show by sharing their knowledge and tips. Aside from that, I've been working on bringing an iPhone5 case to market via crowd funding. I'm hoping that this case will help people take better looking pictures and video.Q.  Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?About 80% of my shopping happens online; Even if an item is offered locally, I get a weird satisfaction out of getting it from a website. So I spend a big part of my shopping time reading customers reviews. I think Yabbly makes the review reading process a little bit more personal because in a way, you get to understand a little bit more the point of view of the reviewer and get to participate and understand the reason why that person gave a thumbs up or down to a particular product.Continued at http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/03/11/meet-alex-yabbler-of-the-week/"		"What products / books are out there for parents looking for a way to better communicate with their kids about their future (i.e. college, ca"	reer)?		"Tip:  If you use a cheaper VOIP conference bridge/speaker-mic at work at have bad sound quality, put something under it.  "	We have remote folks on our team that we use Webex/go-to-meeting to connect to. Our ClearOne conference bridges are good pieces of hardware but if they are used on some hard surfaces like a glass top table there can be some huge echo off the speaker. Putting something soft like a hat under it solves this problem and helps improve communication immensely!		Does Yabbly have location chose? cause i can't see who need help if there question is not for my region. The disturbance Tuesday took place at a depth of about 1 kilometer, the USGS said.Government officials and security analysts had little doubt about the cause of the quake."		"BMW X3, Infinity X37, Audi Q5, Acura RDX, Lexus RX350? "From http://joshuawise.com/horndis#available_versions you can install and be running tethered in a few minutes.  I found that tethering over WiFi was fairly problematic, though I was using a 2-1/2 year old MB Air and a 5 year old MB Pro as targets.  Both are in the group of laptops that are having WiFi problems with Mountain Lion, even Lion.This form of tethering seems quite robust in comparison, as I barely get a VZW signal at home yet this connection seems really solid.This worked for me with a VZW Galaxy S3 with latest over-the-air firmware in it, a late 2011 MB Pro, and Mountain Lion.  With only the first bar lit for cell signal strength, http://speakeasy.net/speed measured 2MB/s down and 6 MB/s up.  I imagine a better cell strength would yield a better speed."		"Is Epic Mickey 2 for the Wii any good? If so, where's the cheapest place to buy it?" Will you jailbreak?	"Jailbreaking allows running apps on the iPhone that Apple hasn't certified or doesn't allow in the store, by opening up to Cydia apps http://cydia.saurik.com/  Things like-  A blocker for texts and calls from abusive callers & texters.  - The F.Lux color temperature changer for people whose melatonin is impacted by the wrong type of light at night.  - Allowing your iPhone or iPod to be a USB thumb drive- An easy swipe-to-access on/off controller for WiFi, BlueTooth, etc.And a whole bunch of other things.  NOTE: this is not unlocking"", recently made illegal via the DMCA in the US.  Unlocking is using a phone that's locked to one network, say AT&T, on Verizon instead."					"Untethered means the break stays in place when the phone is rebooted.  Tethered means a reboot has to be connected to a computer in order to preserve the jailbreak."""			What are good services for soliciting/aggregating user feedback from a mobile app? "Congrats to Katie (@air_conditions) for being selected as our Yabbler of the Week. Since joining on March 11th, Katie has managed to achieve a balanced Global Karma ? what an awesome Yabbler!Q. Tell us about yourself!I am a 47 yr old wife and mom who loves living in Seattle and enjoying all the amenities of a non-suburban lifestyle. My hobbies range from free-form dumpster-diving to 4-leaf clover accumulation (I once collected 17 in one hour!) I love to write and I am learning to geocache and I occasionally yarn bomb something.Q. Everyone is busy these days. Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?It seemed like a forum that was encouraging to someone like me who likes words. I mean, I had to create a paragraph that was compelling enough to pass muster just to get in. I liked that. It set a nice precedent.Q. If you could be asked one question on Yabbly that hasn?t come up yet, what would that be and why?I would love someone to ask me my opinions on the process of aging and/or living frugally or how to raise kids in a really urban environment (read: no yard) . I know at first glance it seems like I wouldn?t be able to review any products within the parameters of these queries, but I think I would, actually.Q. What?s been the most helpful Yabbly you?ve seen or participated in so far and why?I have liked the parenting questions a lot. I wish I would have had Yabbly when my kids were tiny!Continued at yabb.ly/DADcWU"		How can we make it easier for you to be notified of new Yabbles?	"Right now, we're feeling pretty good about how to keep people updated about threads they've started or participated in (especially after we ship our new notifications center for mobile web and iPhone app).  However, one thing we've not been as good at is letting Yabblers know when a new thread is published that is probably of interest to them.  We include some of these in our weekly email digest but that's often after the thread has gone a bit stale.Any feedback on the idea of sending the app a push notification or sending non-app users an email if a really awesome thread emerges that they've not seen or participated in yet?Clearly, the spam risk is huge so that's why we're asking first.  As an example, what if we only did this if it was in your most active topic category, it was from a Member who had provided you with a helpful answer to one of your questions in the past, we know you've not seen it yet, and we'd never notify you of more than 1 per day?Our gut feeling is this needs to be opt in and users need to set the criteria for when they get notified of new threads using a combo of who posts, topic, keywords, number of responses already, and max notifications/day.  Thoughts?"		"So, what does everyone think of vine?"	"So, what does everyone think of vine?"		What should I order at La Spiga? I am going there now.	What should I order at La Spiga? "Congrats to Katie (@air_conditions) for being selected as our Yabbler of the Week. Since joining on March 11th, Katie has managed to achieve a balanced Global Karma ? what an awesome Yabbler!Q. Tell us about yourself!I am a 47 yr old wife and mom who loves living in Seattle and enjoying all the amenities of a non-suburban lifestyle. My hobbies range from free-form dumpster-diving to 4-leaf clover accumulation (I once collected 17 in one hour!) I love to write and I am learning to geocache and I occasionally yarn bomb something.Q. Everyone is busy these days. Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?It seemed like a forum that was encouraging to someone like me who likes words. I mean, I had to create a paragraph that was compelling enough to pass muster just to get in. I liked that. It set a nice precedent.Q. If you could be asked one question on Yabbly that hasn?t come up yet, what would that be and why?I would love someone to ask me my opinions on the process of aging and/or living frugally or how to raise kids in a really urban environment (read: no yard) . I know at first glance it seems like I wouldn?t be able to review any products within the parameters of these queries, but I think I would, actually.Q. What?s been the most helpful Yabbly you?ve seen or participated in so far and why?I have liked the parenting questions a lot. I wish I would have had Yabbly when my kids were tiny!Continued at http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/03/18/meet-katie-yabbler-of-the-week/"		Mom needs a hearing aid	"Has anyone helped their parents look for hearing aids? Everything else that I've seen there was lower in cost than lowes and HD. "		"What impressed me the most and why I'm writing this is that they made a mistake on my order and charged me too much. I didn't notice because what I had paid was so much lower than I was expecting in the first place. "Link: http://store.thelaundress.com/merchant.mvc?Screen=CTGY&Category_Code=1-DETThis may sound a little odd coming from a dude but I've never had to go to a dry cleaner thanks to their products. Their specialized laundry detergents are made from natural biodegradable ingredients without any harsh toxic chemicals, like ones typically used in the dry cleaning process or ones found in your standard detergent (their detergent is soap-like and safe to touch), meaning they'll be gentle to the fabric of your garments and won't cause any fading. My clothes also usually come out smelling fresh and super clean.The only downside: their stuff is a little bit pricier than what you'll normally buy at stores, but you will get a generous amount of detergent per bottle. You can also check on Amazon for pretty high praises for their products.What I'm current using: Denim Wash, Black/White Wash, Signature Wash and Wash & Stain Bar."		"Looking for a privacy screen for a Macbook Air 11 laptop.""" I could not find an nCase iPhone5 cover but found this Splash Cruiser which got 4.5 stars from 48 reviews on Amazon.  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005SE9IIS/ref=oh_details_o03_s00_i00I have no idea who wrote these reviews but can tell you this cover is fundamentally flawed.  According the Amazon description, The unique 2-piece slider design of the Cruiser makes installation and removal convenient, and locks in firmly in place for a secure fit."""					"The reality is the 2-piece slider means the case is in two pieces cut horizontally so there's a bottom part and top part and the slide together.  The problem is when you pull the phone out of your pocket the darn thing comes apart.  When you hold the phone to unplug your headphones, it comes apart.  Also, there's a seam when you hold it your hand.  DNB :-("""			"If you wanted a bigger house but can't afford to buy, would it be nuts to rent?" "I know you can search for any NYT article headline on Google but that's a pain in the butt (esp from mobile) and after years of mooching off of them knowing their paper subscriptions are plummeting, I figured if I give to NPR, I might as well subscribe to NYT since I read their articles daily.From now till 11/27, you can sign up for their digital access plan for $1.88 a week which then goes to $3.75 after 6 months.  You can cancel anytime.  http://www.nytimes.com/subscriptions/Multiproduct/lp7750.html?adxc=199741&adxa=318872&page=homepage.nytimes.com/index.html&pos=Middle4&campaignId=3HJF7"		Anyone have strong recommendations on AirPrint capable printers? "The usual penlite batteries last approximately 2-3 months in my Magic Mouse. I decided to buy some rechargeable ones to be done for ever with buying batteries (always forgot to buy new batteries).. I bought cheap rechargeable batteries that had more Amps, but a little lower voltage (1,2) , and they were surprisingly empty in one/two weeks. It seemed that the lower voltage of rechargeable batteries AND the old Chemical Technology made them more vulnerable for self-depletion with time. So I read some reviews and bought Eneloops. These work almost the same as non-rechargeable penlite batteries (lasting for approx 1,5/2 months in my Mouse). And recharge in one evening.The question now is what rechargable batterie can last for the same 2-3 months in my Magic Mouse. Or which one is just the best price/quality combination. What brand should I always go for? (currently very happy with Eneloop) So it should probably be above 1,2V and have above 2000mAh juice."		Where is the best place to see fireworks on July 4th in Seattle or on the east side?  	Where is the best place to see fireworks on July 4th in Seattle or on the east side?  		Recommendations for a small cordless vac to keep in the car? Thanks in advance guys		TIP:  I bought a Vitamix and am loving it!	"I grew up with a mom who juiced in the 80s, we needed a new blender, and I wanted something that would help me cook healthy whole foods quickly and easily with minimal clean up.  The Vitamix is really making me happy.  The clean up is as easy as they say which is so wonderful.  Just turn it on with some soapy water inside, rinse it out and it's clean!  In terms of nutrition, my kids ate asparagus soup last night.  While they will eat straight asparagus, they ate much more of it in soup form.The only downsides I can see so far are that you need ice to use it properly.  The motor moves so fast that it will actually heat your food after 5+ minutes of blending.  So if you want a cold drink/not to kill your nutrients, you need to include ice in the mix.If you want carrot/apple juice you have to buy a bag to squeeze the blended mixture through to get a juice that isn't thick because those two foods are so dry to begin with.  The other alternative is to put in a lot of water/ice in to thin it out.You can make quick frozen yogurt with frozen fruit and yogurt, or ice and fruit.  This is great for a quick and healthy"" dessert.  "					"It also chops which is something I hate to do manually.  On QVC they also grated cheese, I haven't tried doing this yet, but it would be great to do this for homemade mac and cheese."""			What is the best electronic rice cooker? You can use your NEX lenses (E-Mount) with this camera. I own a Sony SLT A55 and a few lenses (A-Mount) and then I hoped I could find an adapter which would fit on that camera and work with my lenses. The Costco travel advisors are fantastic -- the lady I spoke with had been to several of the resorts and had a lot of unbiased opinions and advice.  When I mentioned one of the resorts I was considering she was to the point: If you can afford to stay here, stay here."""					"I spent about an hour and a half going through details, options, and dates to get exactly what we wanted (she spent 20 minutes alone trying to make sure we'd be in one of the nicer rooms).  She found the resort map (which was hard to find on their site) to figure out what special request we could put in as far as selection of specific room based on our preferences.  She looked up on Trip Advisor room suggestions from other guests, too.  When booking flights she had already brought up Seat Guru for the plane and gave suggestions/talked about that.  She also mentioned when I wanted to stay for 9 nights that 10 would be the exact same price, so we got an extra night for free!"						"Admittedly, I already research a bunch of that stuff myself, but it impressed the hell out of me how much time she put in to making my reservation as good as possible.  If you aren't someone who can dump a lot of time into figuring things out, they'll spend a lot of time doing it for you."						"Also, they weren't pushy at all.  She didn't even expect me to make a reservation at the end of our talk about places to stay, just mentioned it'd be good to book soon-ish (the resort is small -- it only has 22 rooms -- so that's pretty solid advice)."						Prices were on par with everywhere else and some places you even get an extra Costco benefit (we got a spa credit only for costco members).						"Their travel agency is a real division of costco -- they're travel agents that are also costco employees, it's not just subcontracted out."""			Is anyone else having trouble updating your Hotmail account payment info? I mean, I had to create a paragraph that was compelling enough to pass muster just to get in.  I liked that. It set a nice precedent.Q. I know at first glance it seems like I wouldn?t be able to review any products within the parameters of these queries, but I think I would, actually.Q. "http://www.amazon.com/dp/B003X26PMO/ is a really amazing little unit (see picture).  Tiny thing, it works on PPC OS/X 10.4 and 10.5, and on Intel OS/X 10.4 through 10.8.  I have an older MBP that was getting very flakey on WiFi, something in common with that model according to a lot of forum posts.  For $12.10 at Amazon, this was a real bargain.  Good security (WPA2, make sure your passphrase is not words in a dictionary and is 18 characters or longer).  Setup took maybe a minute, the signal strength is way better than the built-in WiFi ever was.Just be sure to disable the laptop's WiFi for safety.  Go to http://airlink101.com/download/awll5088.php for the freshest drivers."		"What clothes to bring for a six month trip visiting hong kong , Singapore,London,Dublin,Edinburgh,return Seattle May 1st,2013. This is what makes you drowsy and ready to sleep.  Here's the lesser known bit: bright light can wipe out Melatonin in your body.As popularized in the LA Times: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/04/ipad-kindle-ebook-sleep.html there is a connection between nighttime use of an iPad and sleep problems.   This can also be seen with laptops and other displays.A company has put out a piece of software, F.Lux, that changes the color temperature (if you want to know what that is, I can go into that) at sunset/sunrise.  This changes the color from bright to mellow, removing the melatonin-destroying frequencies that would otherwise keep some people up at night.Young'uns and some others seem pretty immune to bright displays (I happen to be).  Others are quite sensitive (my wife is).  If you're interested, http://stereopsis.com/flux/ is the free software (Mac / Linux / Windows / iOS) that changes the color temperature for you.  I've got it on all the machines in my house, including iPad and iPhones.  Helps my sweetie sleep."	"Here's something not well known to many folks: the human brain (pineal gland actually) produces Melatonin.  This is what makes you drowsy and ready to sleep.  Here's the lesser known bit: bright light can wipe out Melatonin in your body.As popularized in the LA Times: http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/04/ipad-kindle-ebook-sleep.html there is a connection between nighttime use of an iPad and sleep problems.   This can also be seen with laptops and other displays.A company has put out a piece of software, F.Lux, that changes the color temperature (if you want to know what that is, I can go into that) at sunset/sunrise.  This changes the color from bright to mellow, removing the melatonin-destroying frequencies that would otherwise keep some people up at night.Young'uns and some others seem pretty immune to bright displays (I happen to be).  Others are quite sensitive (my wife is).  If you're interested, http://stereopsis.com/flux/ is the free software (Mac / Linux / Windows / iOS) that changes the color temperature for you.  I've got it on all the machines in my house, including iPad and iPhones.  Helps my sweetie sleep."		Sponsored: Anyone try one of these Vegas supercar rentals before? Instead of your programs, applications, or data running on or being stored on your device, much of what happens takes place on the Internet.   That is not to say that it also does not happen on your device; in fact, many ?Cloud? solutions use a mesh of both local and Internet based resources to complete their tasks.  What do I mean by devices?  Computers, tablets, smart-phones? pretty much anything that connects to the Internet.You are probably already using the ?Cloud? and did not even know it.  Most email services are cloud based.  Gmail, Hotmail, Yahoo! Mail, and Apple?s iCloud are cloud based email services.  This is why you are able to access your email no matter what device your are on."		What's the difference between Trending and Featured?	What's the difference between Trending and Featured?		Having trouble logging in to our iPhone app? "Congrats to @VincentBarr for being selected as our Yabbler of the Week. Vincent has chimed in on over 25 posts over the three months!Q. Tell us about yourself!I?m Vincent.Vincent is a late 20-something who writes autobiographies in the third person, really enjoys dancing (recreationally), once leaped from a ski lift as he realized he was headed back down the mountain, and lives in New York. He?s a curious person, interested in a lot of things, and vague, at times.Professionally, he spends his time on SEM with 10gen, maker of MongoDB, and in business development with Earndit, and exercise rewards app. He is a strong admirer of urban art, a lover of deep house, a recovering muralist, and recently calculated his Amazon Reading List to discover that it exceeds his lifespan. Bummer.His avatar is Calvin and Hobbes because ? you guessed it ? he really likes Calvin and Hobbes (and doesn?t like headshots).Q.  Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?In a nutshell, I spend time on Yabbly because it helps me make good decisions. I trust the community, learn from it, and feel an odd sense of satisfaction when I?m answering a question that might be able to help someone else.When I first tinkered with Yabbly, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the community?s responses. For me, performing due diligence on product decisions and specific technology uses means 10-15 browser tabs open, mild frustration, and more questions. Yabbly dramatically reduces the time it takes me to gather information to make a good decision, and provides valuable recommendations and considerations that I might not have thought of. Few communities do that, and even fewer do it well.Continued... http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/03/03/meet-vincent-yabbler-of-the-week/"		Is there a way to change my screen name? Grab yours now :-)	"We?re excited to introduce a new feature that will make it much easier to mention and identify other Yabblers in a post or response!  Imagine you see a post for which you know another Yabbler might have a great response, or you are composing a new tip and want to make sure another Yabbler sees your great choice. The first step to make that possible was to make it easier to identify members. Today, we?ve launched unique member names to make that a reality, so you can claim your name today (lots of first names are still available)!If you noticed your username was updated since the last time you logged in, that?s probably because you had a duplicate name. We used to allow duplicate names (we had literally dozens of Michaels) but that won?t really work if someone wants to tag one specific Michael in a post or response. To straighten-out this whole mess we had to assign placeholder names, so we added Yabbly adjectives like ?thoughtful,? ?helpful? or ?empowered? to remove duplicates. Best of all, if you like your member name, you don?t have to do anything: You can keep the name we?ve already assigned to you or update it if you think of something better that?s available. Just go to the preferences page from the Yabbly website (it?s the little gear icon at the top right of the page).  While you?re there, please add a bio as well so your fellow Yabblers know a little more about you!Let us know what you think and we apologize for the inconvenience to all the Michaels out there!"		"INFO: for Geeks, Mike Arrington is back at TechCrunch. "Here's how each works.  Concierge: If you need help constructing your post, just give us a call, we'll talk it through, and we'll help you compose your question and post it from your account so you can just sit back and let the answers come to you!  This is great for new members but also something seasoned members can use if they're on the go and need a hand.  (206) 747-7218.Ask for a Friend: Have a friend who could use help on Yabbly?  Your first option is to send them an invite and suggest they ask on Yabbly.  Your second option starting today is to ask on their behalf.  On the Yabbly.com website you can now post a question but cc"" a friend.  We won't publish their mail of course but we will send them a notification asking them if they want to opt in to receiving updates on that thread."					"Hope you like these new features and as always, please share your feedback and suggestions!"						"-Team Yabbly"""			Good dentist with great hygenists? "Hi Folks, we're experimenting with a new service called Yabbly Concierge.  We used to call it Yabbly Buyer Research but that didn't seem very human or friendly.  Our current vision for Yabbly Concierge is to look at well-formed, relevant, and interesting questions from Members that have not gotten any helpful responses after one of two days.  In those instances, we will ask our Concierge team to do some online research across at least 3 different sources and see if they can lend a hand.We envision a world where 99% of Yabbler decisions are informed by fellow members of the community so think the YC as more of a velvet safety net than a core feature but it's still consistent with our mission of helping the world make great decisions and ensures that most Members will always get at least 1 helpful response within a day or so.Lastly, as the Community grows, our YC team may not be able to get to all member posts that haven't had a response after 1 day.  In those cases, we may take a little longer to jump in or may not be able to at all :-(  Hopefully that will be rare because we get to most or the Community hits the Needs Love feed.  However, in keeping with our Karma principles, we will give priority to Members with the highest Yabbly Karma (as a reminder, the best way to get Karma is to provide responses to people which are marked helpful by other members).Any thoughts?"		What should I buy a Samsung or Apple computer?	What should I buy a Samsung or Apple computer?		We are expecting our first baby in October and are looking for advice on what items make sense to buy used versus new. Tell us about yourself! I have been living in Roseburg Oregon the past two years and will be moving back to Olympia WA this week.  I lived in Colorado for 23 years.  Received a degree in Communication at Colorado State University in Fort Collins.  During those years I ski raced, pursued technical climbing and mountaineering after attending a mountaineering school in Vail run by a 10th Mountain Division alumni.  I also managed restaurants in Denver.I moved to Seattle in 1986 and worked in technology for 22 years.  These days my primary interests are nature photography, barbless catch and release fly fishing, hiking, cross county skiing, traveling the western US and  model railroading.Q. I don't mind spending the extra money on something that will last 25-30 years with only routine maintenance and standard wear fixes.I hate the fact that we pay 200-250 Dollars a month from April to September for lawn service and another 350.00 per year on Snow Removal. I was skeptical at first, especially given the online reviews (many people complain about the battery life) but fits our needs perfectly.  The vac head is strong enough to pickup crumbs and all the white dog fur our little buddy leaves behind, leaving dust pickup to the swiffer pad.  It runs about 8-10 minutes on a full charge which is enough to sweep our living room, kitchen, and bathroom floors all in one go.  Ultra maneuverable, lightweight, and a huge time saver."		Anyone heard of Lat56 luggage? Because its very design was intended to not allow sweeping changes?" I?ve been in the pharma/biotech industry for the past 8 years, so I?m a sucker for innovation. On the weekend you can find me working on my Pilates instructor certification, drinking way too much coffee, trying out new vegetarian recipes, eating Mexican food, and enjoying the Emerald City with my husband.Q.  Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?I Yabble because life is busy, and I don?t always have time to search for answers online or read a million product reviews. I can ask a question and get quick, meaningful, helpful answers.  In short, it makes my life easier and cuts down on decision-making time.Q. What?s the biggest decision Yabblers have personally helped you with? Was their advice spot-on?Most recently, Yabblers helped me choose a birthday gift for my friend?s 2 year old son.  I don?t have kids, so I was completely clueless!  A few Yabblers even included links to toys, so it couldn?t have been easier for me.  I went with Thomas the Train, and he was over the moon happy.Continued at http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/03/25/meet-susie-our-newest-yabbler-of-the-week/"		Tips/Tricks for used car shopping? You?ve seen her around on Yabbly as @Lynn-experienced ? she's helped out on over 40 posts. Check out her profile (http://yabbly.com/profile/6714/lynn-experienced) to read about the best web design mockup tool, how to handle bedwetting kids, and recs on the best franchise to buy for <$100k. Congrats Lynn!Q. Tell us about yourself!I am a Research Psychologist.  Most people ask what that means.  It means I really like studying human behavior but prefer measurement and data over one-on-one counseling to help people.  My former classmates would certainly add that it was a good decision on my part as they have seen my counseling skills.  My husband and I run a small research and consulting firm for the senior living industry.  We have three kids, all with single digit ages.  In my spare time, I enjoy reading, exercising, planning events, and trying new recipes.Q. Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?When the kids go to bed, I read or surf the internet.  One day I clicked on the Yabbly ad on Facebook and a friendship was born.  I really like helping people and often have to restrain myself from answering a Yabbly post when I don?t have what I think is a meaningful contribution.  And occasionally I find myself in the market for a new product, or just need an outside perspective on something, so I call on my fellow Yabblers for help.  It?s very interesting to read about all the decisions people are trying to make.  Sometimes I have no idea what a person is asking about, so I look up the product and learn something new.  For example, someone asked about ?Das keyboard?. "We just made it a lot easier to share a Yabble with specific friends on Facebook as a direct message, on your Facebook timeline, or followers on Twitter from the Yabbly website. "Our newest Yabbler of the Week is Andrea, also known as @1Baybreeze. Since joining in March, Andrea has given her advice on over 20 posts ? including on posts about the Apple TV vs. Roku 3, tips for useful baby registry items, and even useful note taking apps. Congrats to Andrea!Q. Tell us about yourself!I am a Jersey girl that absolutely LOVES technology and gadgets. I love reading about and keeping up with all the latest tech news, and I?m the ?go-to tech support? person for my family and friends, and sometimes even my co-workers (depending on how involved the issue) By no means am I am expert, though I?m pretty good at finding solutions. I?m such a geek that I have a Dropbox folder where I save all sorts of tech tips, computer problem solutions, and shortcuts for all sorts of programs & apps. This way if I or someone that I know has a PC problem and cannot access their PC, I can look it up on my phone or tablet from my cloud storage folders.Q.  Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?Yabbly seems like a great alternative to some other similar sites out there. I really like the fact that when one requests an invite, one has to instantly write a very detailed review, on the spot, of a product/service that they love. I think that can help somewhat to try to weed out some people. I know that when I really like something, I always tell ALL of my friends and family about it, so I?m always making recommendations and always helping people find things. I enjoy helping others, and if my advice can help them, all the better. So far, I feel that fellow Yabblers are very similar in that they like to help others, so it?s a great community for sharing ideas and recommendations.Read the rest at http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/04/15/meet-andrea-technophile-and-yabbler-of-the-week/"		Has anyone in the Seattle area used Straighttalk Wireless? We are having  a lot of fun with these and highly recommend especially for kids. Once hardware is installed you can download the app to either your iOS or Android device. Once connected (Zigbee bulbs and wifi to phone), you can do a number of things to customize each light by selecting one of 16 million colors. The preset scenes are nice for reading"", ""relaxing"", ""concentrating"", etc... Best of all, these work with your existing switches and turn on/off like regular lights. Default setting is no far off of my halogen down lights at 2950K. More info here: http://www.meethue.com/en-US"""		What's the strangest kids' show you've been subjected to as a parent? Since joining on March 24, Oakie has chimed in on over 30 posts ? with responses to questions about 21st century shoes, high-quality Bluetooth earpieces, and even tips on getting special Comcast deals. Congrats Oakie!Q. Tell us about yourself!I?m a USAF veteran and currently work for a DoD contractor with an acute gadget addiction. Fortunately i get to work mostly from home and spend most of my off time with photography, working on cars and racing motorcycles.Q.  Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?I discovered the app through the iOS app store and figured it?d be a great way to apply some of my experience with consumer electronics after spending a week or so perusing the website.Q. What type of questions/categories do you enjoy helping out with the most, and why?I mostly stick to the Tech section but I have been known to wander about the Home, Travel, and Auto sections.Q. You?ve got a magic wand that will allow you to add one feature that currently doesn?t exist to Yabbly. What would you add and why do you think it would make Yabbly a better place?A reply function that allows one to address their responses to other responders, allowing the branching out of information that may not necessarily help the thread starter, but may provide information to all others involved who may be interested.Read more at http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/04/08/say-hello-to-oakie-yabbler-of-the-week/"		"TIP: Linksys EA4500 Wifi Router.  Delightful setup, nice range, nice form factor."	"My many years old Linksys router died and wanted to upgrade so got the EA4500.  Set it up last night.  Took about 5 minutes, the hardware has a nice rubbery covering and is very small form factor (the pic makes it love 3X as big as it really is), and the software to manage was brain dead simple like creating guest network, parental controls, etc.  Also the power is really strong, we have it on first floor in the home office and with the door closed, up on third floor I get full bars and streaming is solid for Roku over wifi."		Where can I get the best Malaysian food in San Francisco? The disturbance Tuesday took place at a depth of about 1 kilometer, the USGS said.Government officials and security analysts had little doubt about the cause of the quake."		Best bang for the buck air purifier please! Jeff has asked some great questions and has responded to over 20 posts, including advice on gaming PC hard drives, tips on kid-friendly things to do in Boston, and recs for the quietest dishwasher. Here?s to Jeff!Q. Tell us about yourself! I honestly thought about starting this off like the story of Steve Martin?s character in the movie, ?The Jerk?.  But I am just a normal 42 year old guy living in the suburbs of Cleveland , where I am trying to be a great husband to the Love of my life, a good Dad to the kids, a person who friends and family can count on, and a stronger believer in God?s plan for my life.  I am an IT Consultant working to help implement and optimize Healthcare Electronic Medical Record Systems for Hospitals.  Prior to this job, I worked as an Emergency Room Nurse for 13 years.  I used to be an adrenaline junky who is completely happy now spending 10-12 hours a day staring at a computer screen.  I love to be outdoors and this year my wife and I have plans to plant a huge garden planted from seeds we started ourselves.  The whole family loves to be outside.Q. Everyone is busy these days.  Why did Yabbly make it on to your list of places to spend time?It seemed like a great way to get real-life advice on products.  I am a huge supporter and subscriber of Consumer Reports but their testing and recommendations seemed to lack any personal human impressions of the product.  They have a very technical approach.  Yabbly allows me to find information that incorporates applications in real life with personal experiences from the Yabbler, whether positive or negative.  On the other side of the spectrum, I am a bit of a jack of all trades.  I know enough about quite a few topics to be dangerous and am happy to share my experiences.Continued at http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/04/01/happy-birthday-to-jeff-yabbler-of-the-week/"		Should I get AppleCare for my new iPhone five? "I use this box as both a home theater server and a raid1 storage box. The two primary packages I run (xbmc and netatalk) have feature sets under Wheezy that I find pretty compelling (AirPlay under xbmc and lion compatibility under netatalk), but I don't want those features badly enough to risk corrupting my raid1 data. Basically, if I have to occasionally reboot, it's not a big deal, but if I'm at risk of data loss on /dev/md0, it's a huge deal. If you've ever dreamed of going to Egypt and seeing the Red Sea and you have a young family then you will love this	The Four Seasons Sharm el Sheikh has this ridiculously good deal going on called the Young Family Package. Dont worry about the unrest in Cairo - Sharm is thousands of miles away from all the political unrest and after the unfort bombings they had in 2005 I got the sense from talking to the staff that the govt is doing everything to keep this resort city open. Basically I booked an 8 night trip over Christmas for just ?250 a night. Now thats probably an amazing deal for a standard room at a Four Seasons right ?!@ well they automatically upgrade you to a 2 bedroom suite with a tiny kitchen and washer and dryer.. they throw in breakfast.. even daily laundry for the kids.. and to top it off 3 hours of free babysitting - EVERY day!! you honestly cannot find a better deal - at a 5 star hotel no less. We had such a good time- I extended my trip for another 3 nights on the eve of our departure! You can probably get even a better deal - scary right! - if you book thru an agent who can prob get wholesale prices and pass on part of the discount. Just Go ! and you can thank me later :) http://www.fourseasons.com/sharmelsheikh/offers/young_family_escape_package/		Favorite smoothie recipes? And has anyone noticed milk going bad sooner than usual?"""	"I always thought it meant that the milk was guaranteed to stay good up to one week past the sell by date. Lately, our milk has been going bad well before the sell by date (e.g. a 7 days before). I finally got frustrated by this and took it back to the store (Trader Joe's) and was told that my understanding of the sell by date is incorrect. I was told the milk is guaranteed to stay good up to one week after it is opened, not one week past the sell by date.I'm guessing this is prolly the correct definition of the sell by date, but I've never experienced so much milk going bad so early. Anyone else been seeing this lately?We drink organic homogenized whole milk."		Looking for a waterproof winter hiking boot (men's and/or women's) for my wife and I to hike in and/or use with snowshoes. Here's a way around it."	"Google announced a few months back that starting this year, they will no longer support Gmail via Exchange server or push notifications on iOS. What this means for you is if you're a Gmail user on iOS, receiving Gmail through the Mail.app will only be through fetch.Current Gmail users who have Exchange set up will still receive push notifications, but once you buy another iOS device, you will lose access to Exchange.There are 4 ways around this: 1. Use the Gmail app for iOS. This app is the only app that is guaranteed to provide push notification of your Gmail inbox.2. Purchase a Google for Business subscription. This will maintain your access to Google's Exchange email service.3. Dump your Gmail. Not a great decision especially if you archive all of your mail on the service. Most of all, changing what may be your primary email address is a HUGE inconvenience.4. The Big Workaround: Next, I will detail how to get around all of this so you can get push notification of incoming emails by transparently moving to a new service and still get to use your Gmail account.If you have an iOS device, you have an iCloud email address. Go to the Gmail website and open Settings > Forwarding and POP/IMAP > Forwarding. Click on Add a Forwarding Address"" then input and verify your iCloud email address. Once verified, select ""Forward a copy of incoming mail to"" and choose your iCloud address in the dropdown menu. Choose ""Mark Gmail's copy as read"" then click ""Save Changes"" at the bottom of the page."					"On your iOS device, go to Settings > Mail, Contacts, Calendars > Fetch New Data > Advanced > Gmail and select ""Manual"""						"Go back to Settings > Mail, Contacts, Calendars and scroll down to ""Default Account"". Choose ""Gmail""."						"Now your Gmail will show up in your iCloud inbox, with push notification of new mail, but all sent emails will use the Gmail server and look like they came from your Gmail account to your recipients."""			How do you pick a flight ticket/ hotel booking website? "We?re excited to introduce a new feature that will make it much easier to mention and identify other Yabblers in a post or response!  Imagine you see a post for which you know another Yabbler might have a great response, or you are composing a new tip and want to make sure another Yabbler sees your great choice. The first step to make that possible was to make it easier to identify members. Today, we?ve launched unique MemberNames to make that a reality, so you can claim your name today (lots of first names are still available)!If you noticed your username was updated since the last time you logged in, that?s probably because you had a duplicate name. We used to allow duplicate names (we had literally dozens of Michaels) but that won?t really work if someone wants to tag one specific Michael in a post or response. To straighten-out this whole mess we had to assign placeholder names, so we added Yabbly adjectives like ?thoughtful,? ?helpful? or ?empowered? to remove duplicates. Best of all, if you like your MemberName, you don?t have to do anything: You can keep the name we?ve already assigned to you or update it if you think of something better that?s available. Just go to the preferences page from the Yabbly website (it?s the little gear icon at the top right of the page).  While you?re there, please add a bio as well so your fellow Yabblers know a little more about you!Let us know what you think and we apologize for the inconvenience to all the Michaels out there!"		"Meet @Jim, our Yabbler of the Week!"	"Jim has been one of our most valuable Yabblers and just provided his 98th Yabbly response so he?ll be in the 100+ response club in a few days Here?s a bit more about that Jim, the guy that recommended those awesome kitchen cleaning sponges, iPad keyboards, and engagement ring diamonds Q. Tell us about yourself!I am a nerd of a few varieties.  I?m a software engineer, so I spend most of my life in front of a computer.  Or iPad.  Or cellphone. I started programming back in the day on my trusty old TI-85 calculator.  You could hack it to run assembly code and make interesting distractions from math class.  Later, I got in to web development and created a few web properties as a way to tinker around with the ideas bouncing around in my head.  When the dotcom bubble burst, and profitability was harder to come by I went back to college, graduated, and moved on to working for Microsoft and then Google.Despite being very smart, I am very dumb.  This is why Yabbly is very useful to me.Outside of typing, a few years back I got involved in performing improvised comedy around Seattle.  I've done a handful of shows aroundtown in Seattle, which is host to a vibrant community around the art.  If you haven?t seen a show, you should!  Continued on the Yabbly blog here... http://blog.yabbly.com/2013/02/04/meet-jim-yabbler-of-the-week/"		"I'm looking for a cabin in Mt. Hood, OR. Karen Wolfe (photographer at KarenWolfe.com) was kind enough to share with me her pov on Ross!  Here is her ema	"Good news Matt.  Karen Wolfe (photographer at KarenWolfe.com) was kind enough to share with me her pov on Ross!  Here is her email to me: Ross Lake is a beautiful peaceful place to spend time.  If you are into a little adventure this is the place to visit for sure.  The adventure is mainly in how you get there.  First you are picked up at the Diablo Dam area by boat, then there is a ride on the back of a flat bed truck which then ends with another small boat ride to the resort, right to the front door of your cabin.  There is no store at the resort so you have to pack in all your  own food supplies and gear for your stay.  They are all too happy with helping you transfer your loads throughout the travel to the resort.  The adventure of getting to the resort will take about an hour.  Once there it is peaceful and incredibly beautiful.  You can rent a boat to fish or explore the lake, and there are many hiking trails etc.  I found the people and the guest were quite friendly and it appears the guests come to the resort every year.  We were told, more than once, we were lucky to get a cabin because most guests book the next year?s stay on the day they leave.  I love it!"		It wasn't but I'll def add it to the roadmap. Microwaves and hair dryers were the common blowout culprits since they drew more than 1000 watts each typically.  Nowadays I used the 2000 number as my gauge for how much electronics I should put on one circuit, regardless of how old or new the building is.  This DeLonghi one on AMZN advertises some pretty low wattage at the low and medium settings:  http://amzn.com/B000A33B1C"		"Wes, 2000 watts is actually high for a 15 amp circuit, which is the typical rating for most circuits in homes.  15*120=1800 (ass"	"Wes, 2000 watts is actually high for a 15 amp circuit, which is the typical rating for most circuits in homes.  15*120=1800 (assuming a power factor of 1 for simplicity).  In general it's best to avoid getting close to the limit, since surges can easily trip a fast acting breaker.  A 20 amp circuit would be okay with a 2000 watt max load, as long as the equipment isn't highly inductive (think motors)."		A quick search online (since I have zero personal knowledge here) seems to show a consensus that age two is the upper limit.  Se	"A quick search online (since I have zero personal knowledge here) seems to show a consensus that age two is the upper limit. Just do it"" seemed to be, on the sites I found, the suggested process.  As always, IANAP (I am not a parent) so YMMV."								"I've dealt w lake city guys n they were fine. It's sh	I'd side with going cold turkey and erasing all evidence so you won't be tempted to give in during a moment of weakness. It's short-term pain versus a drawn-out bleed. Sam let us know what u end up doing!		"There are products to apply to neutralize the dog urine spots, check most any pet store.  The problem in lawns is particularly n"	"There are products to apply to neutralize the dog urine spots, check most any pet store.  The problem in lawns is particularly noticeable with females, in dogs they have a higher concentration of urea (uric acid in Dalmatians).  This excess of nitrogen causes the burnout area and the immediately surrounding grass to be greener and taller (the part getting optimal nitrogen).  Here in the Northwest, our soils tend to be carbon rich (good for weeds) and nitrogen poor (also good for weeds).  That's why a high N fertilizer will green up and make your lawn grow and help keep weeds down without herbicides.  Look on fertilizer labels, you'll see three numbers, N-P-K.  That's Nitrogen, Phosphorous (great for root formation, usually found in higher levels in fertilizers for new lawns), Potassium.  Picture (with Cliff as a very young pup): http://whitecliffodover.net/Cliff/large-18.html"		"And solutions could have pictures too; do A and see this, do B and see that."	"And solutions could have pictures too; do A and see this, do B and see that."		Thx for the advice on the neutralizer idea. I usually try to spray some water right after she goes but not always.  I'm gonna start a new thread on fertilizer!		"I've found over time that while Scott's was a great fertilizer to use on the other coast of the country, for me Lilly Miller fer"	"I've found over time that while Scott's was a great fertilizer to use on the other coast of the country, for me Lilly Miller fertilizers have done much better in the Seattle area.  And if I'm good about getting dandelions out by hand, there's very little need for a weed killer with just the fertilizer put down.  Moss is a different story - Iron is the key to getting that, but watch out for rust stains."		What do you think about adding in something on the page? This law is a good step towards helping the environment. We are also not the only county who is starting to enforce this type of law. I think the main question (a"	"If he can get in front of the same recruiters and has a solid resume, I think he'd be competitive.  I think the main question (admittedly a very basic one) is whether Wharton undergrad has its own career services office.  If all of U Penn undergrad has the same information sessions, on-campus interviews, etc., then I think he's fine since corporate recruiters tend to want smart, nice, but driven ppl.  So I guess I'd say any program's brand equity and network pull diminishes rapidly once the person gets the interview.  After that, I'd argue it's a tie breaker but not a huge deal.  I remember doing undergrad recruiting and overweighting the Harvard and MIT undergrads' at the resume review stage but after that, if a really smart guy happened to be from Wiliams, Wesleyan, Penn, or even Colby, we'd focus more on how they did in the interviews than the pedigree.  Regardless of Wharton or U Penn normal. I think his best bet is to network like hell and avoid going through the recruiters in the first place ;-)"		"Years ago when I lived in Magnolia, it was wide open till a bit before 9." He will be at a disadvantage relat	"I went to Penn undergrad and did not go to Wharton.  I then successfully went into business.  He will be at a disadvantage relative to the Wharton undergrads for many of the finance-heavy positions at hedge funds, asset managers, investment banks, etc.  He will have every opportunity to compete effectively for more corporate positions in various other industries.  He will have the meaningful negative of competing with more focused Wharton undergrads for the corporate positions, but this will likely be more than offset by the greater number of opportunities he'll see by virtue of being on that campus and having access to that recruiting process.  The key, other than the obvious need to maintain a strong academic record, will be to take as many Wharton courses as he can and to learn the language of business and recruiting so he comes across as business-minded and business-savvy despite his liberal arts degree."		"I'd think checking with people in the size company he's interested in would be worthwhile. This brings to mind the early days of Slashdot, when karma points (that's"	"What pool would they come from, the donor's directly?  This brings to mind the early days of Slashdot, when karma points (that's what they were called) above 25 or 30 (don't recall exactly) gave the member a score of excellent"".  Some people accumulated, by highly moderated posts, karma scores in high numbers.  Some then auctioned these accounts off, which results in spammers and scammers getting hold of accounts that would take a long time to wind up negative, thus assuring them of higher initial posting scores.   In other words, think about how whatever points and rewards system you create can be gamed, because somewhere someday someone will do it."""		I use the GasBuddy app.  Love it. We happened on our strategy"" completely by accident. "		"Our son was also very attached to his pacifier and also used it only for sleeping. We set a deadline--in our case, his third birthday--and gave him about a month's notice that he would be old enough to not have a pacifier after that time. He happened to sleep with a stuffed bunny. Well, Bunny's birthday arrived two weeks ahead of our son's so Bunny lost his pacifier two week's earlier than our son. This meant that for two weeks, our son had the experience of comforting his best buddy through the loss and experiencing it vicariously. When he gave over his own pacifier on his birthday, I think he felt prepared for it."			"So for us, advance notice and a ""pretend"" trial run worked (note with his younger brother, losing the pacifier was barely an issue at all"	" kids differ!)."""		"I just feel like they asked the question wrong! These are two of my favorite spots, and quite diff"	"Hi Matt, I'm a travel blogger for GirlsWhoGetAround based out of Seattle. These are two of my favorite spots, and quite different actually. What makes Lake Chelan one of our favorite spots is Kelly's Resorts. Like Ross Lake Resorts, it seems more fitting to call it a retreat than resort. Kelly's resort has basic and charming cabins in the woods about a 10 minute drive from town. It's family owned and they are incredibly friendly. We enjoy the outdoor BBQ at Lake Chelan Winery, the view at Bensons, breakfast at Campbells, and the Sunshine Farm Market--especially during Harvest Season--hayrides, petting zoo, and pumpkin patch for kids, wine for us! Of course, the lake offers all kinds of activities, and town has little shops and a few restaurants if you're not just going for wineries. Lake Chelan is especially nice when there's an event. I'd check the calendars and see if anything' s going on. The town is always more festive then. Ross Lake is more isolated definitely offers a unique experience, but it depends what you're looking for and how old your kids are. (I think I read you were bringing kids?) It's right in the middle of mountains and kind of an adventure. You can boat around during the day, but I recommend leaving early. After 11am the current can get stronger and make coming in more difficult. Not a big deal but good to know. Ruby's arm is calmer than the main lake and a nice little day trip with waterfalls and a couple places where you can pull off for some lunch or to stretch your legs. If it rains, hiking is a better option, and there are some nice trials. I made a video on my last trip to Ross Lake here and give a little cabin tour:http://www.girlswhogetaround.com/2012/07/11/a-girls-getaway-ross-lake-resorts/I also wrote a little about it here:http://www.girlswhogetaround.com/2011/10/06/backcountry-beginnings-in-washington-3-spots-that-will-convert-the-reluctant/#more-279I hope that helps! Don't hesitate to ask if you've got any questions that will help with the debate! "		"Hi Matt, It's Beth from GirlsWhoGetAround again. I just noticed you guys weren't bringing kids. We have a joint account and credit c	"I'm surprised to read people critique separate accounts as if they indicate a bad marriage. We have a joint account and credit card (which we put most purchases on to earn miles), but we also have separate accounts. I find that having separate accounts is great. If either of us purchases something selfish, that cost is the purchasers responsibility alone. He doesn't need to know how much I spent on shoes, I don't need to know how much his video games cost. We share most expenses equally and pay off our credit card in full every month. This also makes gift giving more special. I can't imagine it any other way and I think our marriage is stronger for it - less to argue over financially."		"We also have joint+ separates. My guess is the reasoning behind this is that bldgs that have internal valet service which includes laundry, tipping doesn't occur (a tip during the holidays is appreciated) so external laundry vendors need to stay competitive by keeping the same expectations?  But certainly if you're in a walk up and non-doorman bldg, then a tip is customary and the amount is at your discretion. Very good idea.		I've literally went through 5 different flat screen LED Samsung in the past month before finally settling down for my current 55	"I've literally went through 5 different flat screen LED Samsung in the past month before finally settling down for my current 55-inch 3D flat screen Smart TV (UN55ES6580). The reason I went through this many is due to the fact that most backlit Samsung flat screens (Plasmas and especially LCDs/LEDs) are notorious for screen uniformity issue. What happens is when you watch a movie in a dark room you'll start to notice 'clouds' (http://guide2lcdtv.files.wordpress.com/2008/10/clouding.jpg) in dark scenes (they are extremely visible especially if you increase/max out the backlight setting) that'll interfere with your watching experience. This is a widespread issue with most backlit Samsungs that have Edgelit feature and the problem came from the monitor's backlight that 'bleeds' into the screen panel. If you're lucky, some Samsung flat screens will not have this issue but this almost depends on which specific box you'll pick at the store (luck of the draw). I love what Samsung did with their technology, it's the slimmest, most light-weight beautifully-designed TV out there (way more so than a Panasonic) with sharp/crystal picture where blacks are actually blacks, but it sure was definitely exhausting to finally find a Samsung with the least clouding issue."		"@Ferd needn't be plasma, just a big flat screen for the main entertainment room."	"@Ferd needn't be plasma, just a big flat screen for the main entertainment room."		"Tom, my choice then would be a projector onto a nice screen.  That way, the projector can be changed out as technology marches o"	"Tom, my choice then would be a projector onto a nice screen.  That way, the projector can be changed out as technology marches on - for example, the upcoming QFHD standard (Quad pixel density of current systems) will move us from 1920x1080p to 3840x2160p, four times the pixel count of what's now called HD.  With a projector based setup, only the projector would need to be changed out.  With a flat panel based system, the entire panel must be replaced."		yes.	yes.		"A Foster is #1 in all formats. It's a great amino acid for humans, but in the case of these drinks, what it does is r"	"Both have Taurine as a major ingredient.  It's a great amino acid for humans, but in the case of these drinks, what it does is reduce the cardiac stimulation that the caffeine would otherwise induce.  Thus it's masking some of the impact that you'd get from the same amount of caffeine in coffee.  5-hour energy also contains Tyrosine, an amino acid that, taken at supplement levels (such as in a drink like this), can raise blood pressure significantly in many people.I'm assuming no one is going near the Aspartame (Nutrasweet) versions, the toxicity is getting pretty well known about that stuff."		"Ferd,  thanks much." I've been in the solar industry for	"Installing solar on your home or business is one of the best investments that you can make. I've been in the solar industry for 6 years. When I first started, the average residential install cost more than $10/watt of system capacity. Today average installed cost is half of that. Places like Seattle have been slow to adopt because of misinformation about the technology. Seattle's sun exposure is lousy compared to places like Arizona but it's very similar to Germany and Germany is the number one solar market in the world. For a good ROI, solar irradiance is one of only 3 necessary factors- (1) solar irradiance; (2) cost of electricity; and (3) government incentives. Germany scores high on the latter two which is why they have installed the most solar worldwide. The best ROI in the US isn't in California, Florida, or Arizona...it's in New Jersey for the same reasons. Furthermore, most people fail to consider the relative importance of solar irradiance itself. Yes, it's one of the three key factors that contribute to the ROI of a system but how much better is a sunny"" place than a ""cloudy"" place? California is one of the best. We get the equivalent of 5.5 peak sun hours per day. New Jersey get's the equivalent of about 4.2 peak sun hours per day. Therefore, California is only about 24% ""sunnier"" than New Jersey. Rain clouds and fog make solar panels less efficient but they still work. Come to San Francisco, and you'll see we have systems everywhere."					"But does that mean solar is a great investment for everyone..everywhere? The ROI isn't going to be as good in Seattle as in San Francisco or Los Angeles but that ROI is virtually guaranteed. You may find some derivative instrument out there that yields a higher return but a photovoltaic system is less risky than a US Treasury Bond. Yearly weather patterns are remarkably predictable. As long as the sun rises in the morning and sets at night you are going to earn what you expected."""			http://www.xconomy.com/seattle/2012/05/25/zulily-shipping-arm-8-weeks/ shows 5million as of May	http://www.xconomy.com/seattle/2012/05/25/zulily-shipping-arm-8-weeks/ shows 5million as of May		Awesome. For safety purposes, ropes should not exceed 65 feet in length. http://www.skitube.com/ski-tubes/towropeguidelinesarticle.cfm"		"I find when are kids are whiney there's something else going on like they're tired, sick, hungry, or just need some reassurance." Things to note: if you are used to using g++ or g	"ML is working fine for me on my main machine; I haven't put it on others yet.  Things to note: if you are used to using g++ or gcc from the command line, the new XCode doesn't install the command line tools by default.  To get them, go to XCode / Preferences / Downloads and select to install command line tools.Also: X11 is no longer distributed by Apple, they open-sourced the Quartz version of X11.  Go to http://xquartz.macosforge.org/landing/ to get the installer.Other than those differences, no problems yet."		"End of a cycle is good if you're going to hold on to a vehicle though, the kinks are pretty much worked out. Ultimately, the bank bet on you paying and the value of the property going up before they sold the loan to someone else.  This isn't like the old days when you go to the bank on main street and the lender is the same guy you see at church and honestly wants you to be do well.  Moreover, banks are a business and a strategic default is a business decision.  Nothing personal."		Not sure who the best is. Juicing	"^^that was me... somehow published my answer and logged me out. So anyways... none of the nutrients are lost in cooking. Juicing filters out the fiber, but you get way more veggies and nutrients in (who could actually eat a whole bunch of kale, 15 carrots, a beet, etc in one sitting?!). The only hassle is the pick-up, but the more you do it, the faster it gets!"		"My mom told me if u blend and juice too much ur digestive system gets lazy"" bc is doesn't have to break down fiber or mash up t"""	"My mom told me if u blend and juice too much ur digestive system gets lazy"" bc is doesn't have to break down fiber or mash up the food itself. For kids, that'"	"Fiber is mostly dealt with by your teeth, so yes juicing has some impact in that your teeth don't get exercise.  For kids, that's particularly significant.  My grandfather was a dentist for most of the 20th century - his observation was that people who grew up in the 19th century had far more space in their jaws for teeth, but the softer diet of the 20th century led to less chewing hard things as kids, therefore smaller jaws, and the need to remove wisdom teeth.  He insisted that my sister and I chew rubber dog bones till we were about 5 (they taste horrible BTW).  My sister refused; she has had all her wisdom teeth out.  I was younger & curious, and I still have every tooth."		I just installed it and honestly can't tell the difference.  but I guess $20 is the price you pay for not caring ;-) #quiet	I just installed it and honestly can't tell the difference.  but I guess $20 is the price you pay for not caring ;-) #quiet		This is war. It tries to dry things by using the concept that the stainless steel walls will lose heat fa	"We tried a Bosch and sent it back.  It tries to dry things by using the concept that the stainless steel walls will lose heat fastest, causing the moisture to precipitate out and have the water collect on the walls of the interior.  However if you have stainless steel pots/pans/dog bowls in the load, they are in free air, so they lose heat faster than the walls do, so they collect all the water.  Thus loads in the Bosch when we had it came out with all the water on and in anything stainless.  That's when we went with the professional Miele which has a heated dry cycle."		"Came across this article describing the different Seattle neighborhoods. We traveled with our son who was 10 months old at the time. My wife is from Kailua and I've been to Hawaii a few times before. I would avoid Waikiki beach and hit up some of the lesser traveled beaches. Kailua beach (http://bit.ly/T3hlnp) is great for younger kids. The ocean is fairly calm there and the beach is nice and sandy. Hanauma Bay (http://bit.ly/yPYGoC) is great for kids... they get to see fish up close. Go during the week and get there a bit early so you can get parking.. Once the park is full they will turn people away. Polynesian Cultural Center (http://www.polynesia.com/) it's one of those touristy things to do.. You can learn about polynesia and get a luau out of the way at the same time :DTake a drive to Giovanni's Shrimp truck (http://bit.ly/MyPUOx) on the North Shore.. Good eats. Then on the way back hit up the Dole plantation and get some Dole Whip icecream... (http://dole-plantation.com/) Eat at Zippy's! It's like a Hawaiian Denny's. Pick up a few Zip Pac's and take them to the beach for an easy picnic. I also recommend the chilli and Saimin. 2 Lessons learned this last trip... If using spray sunscreen.. make sure to rub it in.... or you'll end up looking like a tiger/zebra. Make sure to bring shade for the little one. We ended up making a makeshift sun cover out of clothes hanging on backpacks and stuff. Eventually stopped by a hardware store and got some pvc/fittings and some cheap fabric at walmart.  If you're going to buy souvenir chocolates/coffee/nuts... go to walmart.. It's way cheaper than anywhere else."		"I grabbed Finges""... Not planning on using the account. Just want to make sure someone else doesn't grab it. I use my gmail acc"""	"I grabbed Finges""... I'm a Hawaiian ex-pat so I can add a little bit more color on some things.Hanauma Bay is really"	"Awesome answers from Chris.  I'm a Hawaiian ex-pat so I can add a little bit more color on some things.Hanauma Bay is really great, the tide pool setting is super safe for kids and there are lots of fish to see.  They have been trained by the people feeding them over the years (good and bad, I guess) so they'll get very close.  Big thumbs up for less crowded beaches like Kailua, Waikiki and other tourist spots are disasters.  Too many people, and too much trash in the sand.  My recco for kids would be to try an area at Waimanalo beach park called Sherwood Forest:  http://oceansafety.ancl.hawaii.edu/v/2.0/?i=oahu&shid=3&bch=waimanalobay .  There is a natural sand bar out in the water that provides some tide control and be a pseudo-pool wall if any trouble arises and the trees are nice shade for a picnic.Big YES to Giovanni's Shrimp truck, amazing.  While you're there you can hit up Matsumoto's Shave Ice:  http://www.matsumotoshaveice.com/ .  It's far out there and still gets a ton of tourists, but it's legit.  Ice cream + red beans (azuki) upgrades are very worth it.And I miss Zippy's.  Open 24 hours, safe, and has really good stuff.  Definitely try the chili (it's Hawaiian style, a variant on Cincinatti style chili), the Zip Pak bentos, and the saimin.  Kid friendly flavors if the family isn't super adventurous with their palette.  If you need souvenirs I'll suggest Target and Costco as alternatives to Walmart.  Target's stuff is a little on the kischy side but it's decent, but Costco has big boxes of chocolate, aloha shirts, and other specialty items at very good prices.  And you can gas up a rental car for way cheaper there too."		"If using credit card, use one that doesn't charge transaction charges for foreign exchange (recommended for hotel and meals). There is a reef in the ocean that blocks the tides so it's poor for surfing and bodyboarding but great for lounging and casual stuff.  For Waimanalo park, stick to the southern end where Sherwoods is.  (1) the main park area on the North end has a semi-permanent camp of beach bums now so might be less fun there, and (2) the Sherwoods end is closer to the US Marine Corps base.  The Marines actively clean up the sands and park area since it's used by their base personnel, so the area is very nice."		"Fogo cups. We actually didn't plan to hike that far but once we saw the quaint floating string of cabins smiling at us from the Diablo Dam - we were drawn to it.   It seemed wonderful, especially for a family or a group, and it is no wonder they are booked up through 2013 and they have dozens of plaques from fishing groups that have been visiting every year for 20+ years.   But, we were still happy to go back to our campsite at Colonial Creek campground.   It was actually one of the better kept campgrounds we have visited and it has the benefit of being under a think canopy of trees surrounded by mounts....so we ended up sleeping in much later than usual for a camping trip.   So we would also recommend Colonial Creek. The S-Voice only gave me a weather report for the next six days."						"Last I did ""what is my current address"".  Fail on both.  Tried ""what is my current location"". However, as a car lover, I totally empathize.  In fact, I was building a BMW X1 the other night on their site (secretly of course).  So here's my advice, if you love cars as much as I do, it's not a purely financial decision.  Furthermore, if you find the car you have isn't meeting your needs, life is too short for driving around in a car you don't love.  Now, on to the fun part.  I would seriously consider the A4 wagon (or Avant as I believe they call it).  The Outback doesn't feel very fun -- if you go Subaru, one must consider the STI.  I'd recommend an EVO but it's pretty small in the back and the trunk is non-existent (but it has better performance than the STI).  Other options are the MINI Countryman S which is a blast to drive and AWD.  I love cars."		"We just went through this so here's my two cents.  1. Make the private vs public decision and run the numbers and do your re"	"We just went through this so here's my two cents.  1. Make the private vs public decision and run the numbers and do your research to make sure you want to commit to the expense and potential drawbacks of private schools.  For us, we decided to bet on the power of early education and the power of small classes/nice facilities/similarly minded parents as a predictor of adult success and know that it might not matter, felt it was worth the investment.  2.  We live in Seattle so for pre-school there are only a few that take 3 year olds.  We looked at Evergreen and UCDS and a few others but only applied to those two.  We also heard good things about Bertschi and Meridian.  Pre-K (4 and older) you get a lot more options but I can't speak about those since we ended up going to Evergreen (UCDS did not admit us).3.  It's a numbers game.  There are very few open spots because siblings consume most of the spots.  They also try to gender balance so that could make it harder still.  It's very common to apply for Pre-S, Pre-K, and K before getting in.  Cast a wide net.  I think you need to do the tours many many months in advance so you'll be looking at the 9/2013 enrollment class. 4.  You have to do a lot of stuff like mandatory tours, parent essays, child interviews, parent interviews, etc.  Be prepared to put a lot of time into it -- like college.  5.  Try and socialize your kid to get used to seeing strange kids so that when they go to group observation, they're not weirded out.  But don't let the kid know it's a big deal lest they close up.  In fact, we both took our son to Evergreen's interview but I took him to UCDS alone and I wonder if that had something to do with his comfort level and how much he let them see his true personality.That's off the top of my head.  Feel free to ask follow ups."		Goldberg's in Bellevue is pretty good!	Goldberg's in Bellevue is pretty good!		"Thanks Ferd, that is definitely telling. My biggest need for Siri is to give me means to add appointments to my calendar and rem"	"Thanks Ferd, that is definitely telling. My biggest need for Siri is to give me means to add appointments to my calendar and reminders to do things. At our previous house,  the developer cut down second-growth trees and sold the l"	"Good soil is hugely important to a good lawn.  At our previous house,  the developer cut down second-growth trees and sold the lumber to clear space for the development, then scraped off and sold the topsoil.  Once he built a house, he'd throw down a few inches of topsoil then sod the front yards, leaving the back bare for the homeowner to deal with.  The soil in back was so poor that even weeds took years to start growing there - it was near pure clay, so drainage was quite poor.We put down four inches of topsoil and sod, but due to the poor underlying drainage, that yard was never really good.  We tried putting several tons of sand on and working it in, to get the clay to drain better, but it was incremental improvement only.  I never got that yard to a good state.  I think it would have required a pretty major project to do so.Proper drainage is very big.  Do you know how far down the rocky, sandy belt goes?"		"these are amazing point of views. i would agree that vibe"" is what ultimately determines if the place is right or not. amazing """	"these are amazing point of views. i would agree that vibe"" is what ultimately determines if the place is right or not. amazing how all this could feel like college all of a sudden. it also seems like if you make it a great deal, it would be to your kids. so as much as you can it appears you should handle it as just another thing. this also raises another question, how important is it to live nearby your kids' school? i may just post another question on this..."""		I think you should be willing to drive 30 mins (in traffic) to the school that is the best fit -- I know some that drive 45 mins	I think you should be willing to drive 30 mins (in traffic) to the school that is the best fit -- I know some that drive 45 mins or more. For banks/institutions/corporations that engage in large enough amounts where the transaction costs can be spread out it might make more sense.  Also, depends on your reasons, such as hedging where you want to limit exposure to USD (short USD, long AUD - ie if paid in USD and AUD is your home currency?) or pure speculation (you expect for some reason that USD will weaken against AUD?)  I'd be curious to hear about a new way to invest in currencies for individual investors, it could be useful for ex-pats working abroad."		"Tom, sounds like you got developer-typical for this area.  Generally there are a lot of rocks, there was glacier activity down t"	"Tom, sounds like you got developer-typical for this area.  Generally there are a lot of rocks, there was glacier activity down this way and that leaves a lot of them behind, or so I've been told (I am not a geologist!).  Our current house was built at the site of an old dairy, so while there's a lot of carbon in the soil, at least there's soil.I'd say you need to get some quotes to see how much it would cost to do various levels of preparation: 1) remove a foot of soil, add in a layer of sand with drain pipes, then a layer of soil, then seed or sod.  Probably mucho bucks2) strip off what's there, add some topsoil (try for high nitrogen / low carbon), then seed or sod.  Probably less ghastly than #1.3) do a yearly cycle of aeration, fertilize with a high-phosporus (new lawn) fertilizer to encourage root growth.  If you hit drainage problems, put down a couple of inches of sand each spring.If it were me, I'd bring in some contractors and say what would you do to this if you were going to guarantee <insert your metric for a great lawn> each year for the next 2/5/10 years?""."""		"So many variables.
