I'm no currency trader, but my view would be"	"Currency trading by anyone other than a very sophisticated trader is quite tricky.  I'm no currency trader, but my view would be the USD is likely to strengthen as a safe haven currency if global troubles (Eurozone, China slowing) continue and likely to weaken if a global recovery takes hold and risk tolerance rises.  I would expect a global slowdown to continue to weigh on commodity prices, which are the driver of the Aussie economy and the AUD exchange rate.  If an otherwise strengthening USD in such a scenario puts further pressure on those global commodities priced in USD, it would compound the pressure on the AUD.  So, in theory, if you think we're looking at a prolonged global slowdown, I like the long USD / short AUD position.  Alternatively, if you think we're out of the woods, I would like the opposite.  But I wouldn't be comfortable personally putting either trade on without researching where those currencies have been in the short and midterm past, to determine whether the effects I'm describing are already expressed in the exchange rate.  Furthermore, determining when to put the trade on is often easier than determining when to take it off.  Very, very tough to play in a market like currencies without great expertise and tremendous focus (reading headlines and watching screens all day)."		I guess I like the glass door and Frigidares got top marks from CR. Silicon Valley has a broader spectrum, less single-focus."		"To get the big white dog fur out, I've found that using a powerful shop vac (like http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00376WU2U) plus a ru"	"To get the big white dog fur out, I've found that using a powerful shop vac (like http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00376WU2U) plus a rug rat (see pic) is pretty effective."		"Thanks for sharing. Usually around 2-3 percent per year i	"Dirt that is left to build up on modules does have an impact on the output of the system.  Usually around 2-3 percent per year if left unattended.  Of course it varies.  I have seen systems in places like Palm Desert, CA that were caked brown only 3 days after being cleaned.  Of course, with all the rain in Seattle you are not likely to see any measurable drop in output.  Just make sure there are no leaves collected on the modules.  If the modules are going on a flat roof rather than a pitched roof you will want to tilt them at least 10 degrees.  This tilt is more important to allow for run-off then it is for increasing the efficiency of the modules.As for sizing, the average PV module today is rated at about 240 watts.  So for a 10kW system you would need to install 42 of them.  These measure about 66 high x 40"" wide.  So you need a sizable piece of roof.  I don't ever think in square footage terms because roofs are remarkable different shapes and only ""usable"" roof space matters.  This is roof space that faces either south, west, or east and has no obstructions (chimneys, vent pipes, skylights, etc).  Before you go assuming you need a 10kW you need to look at your consumption.  Unless you have a plug in vehicle (or intend to purchase one) there is no point in oversizing the system because you don't get paid for excess production.  In a net metering situation your excess production rolls over from one month to be used the next.  But if you havent' used it by December 31st- it's gone.  Look at your last 12 months of electric bills.  Your monthly consumption is measured in Kilowatt Hours (kWh).  Add that number for the past 12 months and divide it by 365 days.  This will determine your average daily consumption.  If you post it I will show you how to calculate what size system you need.  This way the other Yabblers can read it too."""		Ferd that was Phil. In the state of WA the PV reimbursement rules are: http://www.seattle.gov/light/Conserve/cgen/cv5_cgen5.asp#net metering  Also see the incentives in the state of WA: http://www.seattle.gov/light/Conserve/cgen/cv5_cgen5.asp#incentivesOur roof is pretty big, and has unobstructed south, east, and west surfaces, about a 30 degree pitch.  In fact that's part of our motivation - the south and west paths to the summer sun are unfiltered, so the house bakes in the summer.  Having A/C run off solar would be a big gain.  The rest of the year, running all my computers makes our electric bill a good bit higher than most folks around us.My power provider's web site is down for maintenance right now or I'd answer you for the KWH.  I'll post it tomorrow when hopefully their site is back up.One other question - is the power generated a linear relationship between # of photons and # of electrons?"		"Ah that makes much more sense, thanks"	"Ah that makes much more sense, thanks"		"Zach, I'm hitting my network hard trying to find you an answer. This is one "	"Zach, I have been using the Garmin Forerunner 405CX for the last 8 months.  It looks like a real watch- size wise.  This is one of the reasons I chose it because some of them are just too bulky.  It comes with a separate velcro band if you are more in to that type (I am).  It is water resistant but I don't wear it while I swim.  This is the exact one:  http://www.amazon.com/Garmin-Forerunner-405CX-Sport-Monitor/dp/B0025UHKNS/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1344840980&sr=8-1&keywords=garmin+forerunner+405cx.  I bought it with the heart rate monitor which I use in training almost every day.  What's great about the Garmin watches is they give you all the data you could possibly want and are relatively easy to use.  With this one the main screen gives you Overall Time, Distance traveled, and real time Pace for that interval (which I set to 1 mile but it's adjustable).  With one touch you go to a different screen that gives you your current heart rate.  They all come with a little chip that's like a mini flash drive.  You plug it into your computer and leave it there.  When you get back from your workout, the watch senses the little chip and wirelessly downloads the workout to your page.  This is an example a recent bike ride I went on: http://connect.garmin.com/activity/196829908.  These workouts save to your page and can be shared via social media.  The one drawback to this and other Garmin watches is the battery life.  I do long distance triathlons and this battery never lasts more than 7 hours.  If most of your workouts are shorter than that this is the watch for you. If you are doing several a day or workouts/races that go longer than 7 hours that battery life becomes an issue.  I use the watch for both running and cycling.  I hope this helps."		Hi Phil - average daily consumption is 98.6 KWH/days.   Obviously higher consumption in hot months.  Thanks in advance!	Hi Phil - average daily consumption is 98.6 KWH/days. Super stoked to hear that Costco has a high-end one.  @Tom, the older style Essence head Sonicares have a notorious flaw that is well documented on the Internets.  Brushing runoff will leak down from the head and into the large chamber below the rubber seal where the magnetic mech is.  The moisture, darkness, and nutrients from the toothpaste and other stuff from your teeth leads to the growth of some nasty looking stuff in the chamber.  It isn't mildew and doesn't smell, but is super nasty and scares people.  The newer ProResults style heads get rid of the large hollow chamber and get big thumbs up from people on the web."		"I love this idea. I listened to it and fount i"""	"On the Media"" (http://www.onthemedia.org/) did a show on objectivity in the news about a year ago. I listened to it and fount it interesting. The main takeaway I had was that it's not really possible to be objective. The best thing you can do is to understand your news sources, so you can take each of them with the correct grain of salt. That said, I think NPR does a pretty good job of being as objective as possible."					Here's a link to the OTM segments:						"http://www.onthemedia.org/tags/objectivity/"""			"I LOVE the POTUS channel on XM. However, I have pretty much given up on finding one news source and just consume news from a portfolio approach.  I have bonds (MSNBC), equity (CNN), and alternative instruments (FNC).  After reviewing all three, you usually get a sense of the range of opinions and perhaps get even smarter at calling BS on both sides."		Very Yabbly of you Jim. I.e., flawlessly executing a flawed product strategy is a bit like winning every battle in Vietnam but losing the war.  So even if your role is project management, I'd spend solid cycles making sure you understand and agree with the product strategy (which I'd define as the answer to the question what problem are we solving, for who, and why are we gonna be so special?"")."""		Update: I ended up targeting the International District figuring some people wouldn't think of it and that there would be too mu	"Update: I ended up targeting the International District figuring some people wouldn't think of it and that there would be too much traffic close to the stadium. Mistake #1 was that my idea was in no way original and many others were already there. Mistake #2 was that all the pay lots were full (not as many in the ID) because it was so close to game time. So we ended up doing street metered parking but it was still a close walk so it ended up being 40 minutes door-to-door. Big problem was that street parking has a 2-hour limit, so we had to leave the game early. I think Wes had the right idea, should have just targeted parking close to the stadium and paid the fee. Lesson learned, listen to the yabblers.Side note: A few minutes after I get home, my Android phone dings - It's Google Cards (new feature in Jelly Bean), telling me the Sounders won 2-0. I had done a maps search earlier that day, and of course my phone was at the stadium during daytime. So Google used one or both of those signals and determined I would be interested in the outcome of the game. Which was of course both awesome and creepy.Thanks for the tips everybody!"		I would recommend against the big island. I now have one in my kitchen and one in my bedroom - awesome to just play music from your phone and have it fill the house. And it's amazingly easy to set up (once I hooked it to a NAS) - never a problem with updates, etc. If I have a bbq in the backyard, I just unplug one of them and stick it outside, plug it in, and it's ready to go. Hard to pay so much for what looks like a glorified boom box, but I love it."		I second Sonos.  Outstanding	I second Sonos.  Outstanding		I tend to choose less popular choices that give the same performance at a lower price point. However there will be less to choose from lens-wise and community support wise. I'm currently shooting a Sony SLT-A57... I think it's one of the only DSLR's that shoots 1080 at 60 frames progressive. I'm much more into Video than photography though... that's what pushed me towards the Sony's.		"Poom, What type of photography are you interested in? landscapes? portraits? sports? Agree that Volcanoes National Park is too much driv"	"If you're adventurous, I'm a huge fan of the Kohala Coast on the big island. Agree that Volcanoes National Park is too much driving, but kayaking & snorkeling by the Captain Cook monument is amazing -- pods of dolphins will come feet from your kayak, and the reefs are pristine. The unmarked Mile 69 beach is gorgeous too, and lots of Sea Turtles nest by the beach near Kahlua-Kona. Not much in the way of nightlife or restaurants unfortunately, but while our kids loved the Grand Wailea on Maui, the big island is where everyone wants to go back. As long as you're self directed and willing to go beyond they really touristy stuff, I think it's the place to be."		Thank you ALL for the great advice!!! One is Discover Escape (http://www.dailymarkets.com/creditcards/escape-by-discover-review/) and the other is Am	"I use two cards. One is Discover Escape (http://www.dailymarkets.com/creditcards/escape-by-discover-review/) and the other is Amazon. Amazon is great just like Tom described but I do find Discover to be much more flexible in terms of their rewards (miles) and card usage.  You earn 2 miles for every $1 you spend on everyday purchases, and these points can be redeemed toward any airline ticket, hotels, or travel-related expenses. These are extremely easy to redeem and it's done through their website.There's also no foreign transaction fee on the card since it's Discover (unlike Visa and Mastercard) so you can use it in countries like Canada without incurring 3% of the transaction cost (great if you travel a lot). Furthermore, the miles can also be used to purchase from Amazon.com (100 miles = $1) like the Amazon points. Last but not least, Discover tends to be generous and very lenient when it comes to bumping your credit limit, much more so than Amazon.The only two downsides to Discover is first, there is a $60 annual fee attached to it, but I find their miles to completely compensate for this fee since you do earn it the miles rapidly if you keep using the card. Second, I find that businesses do not accept Discover as widely as they do with Visa and Mastercard- so if you eat out a lot this may not be such a great idea if this will be your first and only card. I do use it as my primary card and I use Amazon for places that don't accept Discover."		Dude from Wisconsin	Dude from Wisconsin		Triple X in Issaquah. I've never had the pizza there, I always get one of the pasta dishes, like spaghetti and meatballs. Great for kids and the whole family -- in fact it's a great place if you have a large party of 8 or 10 people. They give the kids pizza dough and flour to play with while you wait for your food. Love the salads there - comes with chickpeas and olives and other stuff in addition to the usual lettuce, tomato etc. Spaghetti is great. Chianti bottles hung from the ceiling, super low key and friendly. Go to the one in Pacific Beach though -- I don't think the other locations are as good. Perfect for dinner after a day at the beach. If definitely want pizza though, try Hoboken Pizza (also on Garnet I think) up about 10 more blocks away from the beach. Enjoy and have fun!"		+1 for Blue Moon.  I'll nominate something different -- Seastar seafood restaurant has a delicious kobe (wagyu) slider with perf	"+1 for Blue Moon. For a compan	"I've used really complex systems at Microsoft and Google and a third party system at my last company (400 person).  For a company <20 people, I wonder if you need a formal service.  I'm sure there are some startups doing it.  In my experience, the best system I've used was a quarterly email where I'd write my top 5 likes about the person, my top 3 wishes, and whether they were not meeting, meeting, or exceeding expectations.  I'd send it to the employee and BCC my HR contact and we'd be done.  If you do go the SAAS route, I'd probably look for simplicity, workflow management, reporting, archiving, etc.  But again, it would have to be really lightweight to avoid feeling like doing your taxes which then begs the question why use it until the Company gets so big that you kind of have to have it (especially for stack ranking, legal risk mitigation, and multi-tiered management structures)."		"Yeah, the goal would be for peers to give feedback as well. If you are asking whether it is worth $140	"Leica is a very venerable optics brand and produces top of the line camera & lenses.  If you are asking whether it is worth $1400, you are most likely not in the group of enthusiasts who can tell the difference.  A Canon G11, G12, or Panasonic Lumix DMC-LX5 works fine for you at a fraction of the cost (<$500).  A lot of the mirrorless compacts such as the Fuji suggested above works well also -- with interchangeable lenses.If size is not an issue, I would go with a traditional DSLR (all pros use these for serious shots).  Canon 5D Mark III ($3500) is great, so is the Nikon D800E ($3200) -- both are full frames.  At sub-1000 range, Canon t4i / t3i are great.  The most important is to get good lenses : for Canon: the L"" series such as the 24-70 (~$2000) or prime lenses (< $500)."""		The ones at Jefferson park on beacon hill look nice. I found that using good fitting (tight) m	"I used to have issues with blisters when breaking in new soccer cleats for paintball.. I found that using good fitting (tight) moisture wicking socks helps a lot. I purchase a set of Nike Dri-fit socks (http://bit.ly/P4fpMQ) along with any new cleats. These socks have Left/Right markers for your feet and fit snugly... this allows for less fabric rubbing. I've also had good luck with Bodyglide anti-chafe sticks... (http://bit.ly/OYiKY8). Used to use this when breaking in new Snowboard/Ski boots. As for the blisters themselves... Taping over them works... I've used superglue to close them up on hikes... make sure to get some antibiotic like Neosporin on them when you can."		"Do what I did - create a persona on FB not connected to anything else. You aren't allowed to leave your car insid	"We went there a few years ago and took a walking tour -- which I strongly recommend.  You aren't allowed to leave your car inside the park unless you are part of a sanctioned tour group.  95% of those tours involve sitting in some kind of vehicle most of the time.  Our tour involved staying in a small camp in the middle of the park with a few other couples and then hiking out to different areas nearby.  We saw all kinds of wildlife, including an up close and personal encounter with a lion.  We were walking single file, I was second in line behind the lead guide, and the lion, a young adult, crossed our path, about 10 feet away from me.  It was pretty amazing!Anyway, I strongly recommend going to Kruger, and South Africa in general.  While Cape Town is one of my favorite cities in the world, Johannesburg is an unredeeming place that I would avoid unless you like shopping malls and the feel of an armed camp (the movie District Nine"" captures this very well)."""		"I like the American Express Optima card.  No annual fee, automatic cash rebate 1-2% (depends on type of spending, but no hassle,"	"I like the American Express Optima card.  No annual fee, automatic cash rebate 1-2% (depends on type of spending, but no hassle, no process to redeem any points) and Amex's customer service is top notch.  If you pay with amex and don't get the service/goods you were promised after making a reasonable attempt to resolve with the vendor, you dispute the charges thru Amex and they will suspend the charges until they investigate and correspond with the vendor on your behalf.  Some other nice free perks like if your purchase is stolen or lost within 60 days or so, amex will replace.  Downside is they impose the 2 or 3% transaction charge on international charges that involve foreign currency conversions."		"I asked a friend, and he suggested moleskin."	"I asked a friend, and he suggested moleskin."		"Yes, exactly."	"Yes, exactly."		Citi Forward card is a decent deal if you want to deal with Citi's Thank you program. If you redeem the thank you points for Gif	"Citi Forward card is a decent deal if you want to deal with Citi's Thank you program. If you redeem the thank you points for Giftcards... each point is worth a penny. If you use the Thank you points for anything else it ends up being $.0063 per point... Interestingly enough if you do alot of Amazon purchasing... the Citi Forward card is a better deal than the Amazon card. The Forward card counts Amazon as a book store and you end up getting 5 points per dollar spent at amazon.. and as long as you redeem those points for Gift cards... you end up getting %5... You also get 5% at restaurants... which for me when I was younger was pretty awesome.If you're going for your first card I would get the VISA purely on the fact that it's accepted in many more places than your Discover... I used to have an AMEX and often had to pull out my VISA to make purchases because the AMEX wasn't accepted everywhere. It'll be the same for Discover."		"Not so much a feature, but after I answer or look at a question, when I go back to the list it would be nice for it to keep my """	"Not so much a feature, but after I answer or look at a question, when I go back to the list it would be nice for it to keep my spot"" rather than having to scroll all the way down. Some of the stuff I do with my kid, Mikeel (he's 13 months and 28ish pounds now).. 1. Get into lower squat position.. pick up Mikeel... perform squat thrust.. then push him above my head. Lower and place him on the ground.... Continue until I'm exhausted or Mikeel runs away. 2. Baby weight kettleball swings. Grab Mikeel and swing him up... like I would doing a kettleball swing.... once again.. continue until I'm exhausted or Mikeel runs away.3. Baby weight squats... backpack mode... I throw Mikeel into one our back carriers (Ergo or Kelty carrier) and I just do some squats and walk around... 4. Airplane! I lay on my back... legs bent at knees... I sit Mikeel on my feet, hold his hands and lift him with my legs... and say WEEEE! Airplane!"""					"5. When Mikeel can balance on my back.. I'll take him for ""Horsey"" rides and do some kid weighted push ups. "						The great thing is... as I get stronger... Mikeel gets heavier... so it's always a good workout.  I do variations on this stuff everyday... not only am I getting a workout.. It's playtime with dad for Mikeel. 						"There's plenty of ways to get ""Excercise"" with out having to go to the gym or run outdoors. I mostly"	"Another good option is Capital One's No-Hassle Cash.  It gives 1.5% flat cash back (1% now, .5% yearly in a lump sum).  I mostly got it because it's one of the few Visa/MC that have 0% foreign transaction fees (saved me nearly $100 when I went to australia).I also have a chase freedom which nets me about 1.5% based on their bonuses which change quarterly.One thing to watch out for is tiered rewards -- this is common on Discover and Amex (though the ones above do not appear to be tiered).  For example, a typical discover card you only earn 1% after spending $5000; prior to that you earn .25%.  This can have a significant affect on your overall cashback rate if you aren't a high spender.(Also fyi, the optima card is no longer being offered to new members)"		"Thanks, everyone! Q&A is just the mode for 	"I think Yabbly is more about small communities of people helping each other versus a Q&A site per se.  Q&A is just the mode for how Yabblers help each other versus our core focus like on traditional Q&A sites.  Opinions are a big part of it, I think an even bigger one is relationships based on mutual assistance between users.  Hope this helps and thanks for stopping by to check us out!"		"Thank you for bringing this to our attention. In terms of the returning the item, we do not have a specified time-frame. I think comparing Yabbly to other Q&A sites is like comparing apples to oranges. They're both fruits b	"This is a great question. I think comparing Yabbly to other Q&A sites is like comparing apples to oranges. They're both fruits but in the end, you actually get totally different flavors and benefits. In a Q&A site or forum, the values you're getting is generally in the form of opinion-based answers from resident established experts. In Yabbly, you're socially engaging with a bunch of passionate folks who actually will go out of their way to help you (ie. leveraging their networks outside of Yabbly), especially since the focus of the platform is to constantly encourage and reward its users for helping one another. So the values you're getting from Yabbly are not only quality answers, but also the factor of goodwill/relationship-investment behind it (Wow this person helped me out, I want to do something in return to help this person out in the future, and Yabbly is a place for me to easily do it"")."""		Not sure if they have soft but Molly Moon's has amazing ice cream. It's a great idea to build credit for your business in your business' name, so I think using a personal credit card would bypass an important benefit to opening a credit card. Rewards are a nice perk, but I would stick to an AmEx or other business card. I would think about personal risk and guarantee also if you are considering using personal cards for business purposes, as well as the temptation to commingle your personal and business transactions (which you should avoid at all costs)."		Thx Indinero advisor! There's a built-in document viewer that handles PPT and PPTX files. I don't know it handles complex animations, but for simple slides it does the job very well. They are technically a vessel which requires a lifejacket to be available, but if you are above a certain"	"SUPs are a ton of fun. They are technically a vessel which requires a lifejacket to be available, but if you are above a certain age you do not have to wear one. Because of this most people carry one and strap it to the board but do not wear one. Comfort wise, the waist floatation will be better. But keep in mind that the traditional life vest is more likely to keep your head above water if you are knocked unconscious (lets hope that doesn't happen!) . I am not promoting to NOT wear one, as it is personal preference and personal assessment of swimming skills. Have fun out there!"		"Personally, doesn't mean much to me. The amount of diversification achieved through these low costs in	"Index and mutual fund investing are definitely the way to go.  The amount of diversification achieved through these low costs investments along with the investors ability to incorporate many broad asset classes make these investments the most logical choice.  I would argue there are advantages to the use of low cost mutual funds form passively managed fund companies like iShares and Dimensional Funds (DFA) over strictly index funds.  One example of the benefit of using a mutual fund comes up in the reconstitution of the indexes.  Each year a group of companies that comprised the S&P 500 Index Fund for example, will fall under the market cap to be included in the index and a group of companies will be added.  The index fund by a function of their investment policy statement will be forced to sell a number of companies from the index and/or buy a number of companies strictly because they need to maintain the index allocation.  Companies falling out of the index generally will have price declines and the companies coming into the index will have price appreciation.  So what has happened is the index fund company will sell at a discount companies in their index that are not a part of the S&P 500 and pay at a premium the companies they need to purchase for the index.  This reconstitution represents a cost that is not printed as part of the operating expense ratio but is manifested in lower returns.  DFA on the other hand will allow for benchmark error and as a result does not pay these costs simply because of the need to reconstitute the fund.  As I said this is one such example of some of the benefits of a mutual fund over index funds.  The most realistic allocation likely comprises a mix of mutual funds, ETFs and ETNs.  For example I use Vanguard ETFs for the Emerging Markets and International asset classes but use the DFA Funds for most of the US positions."		"You bring up an interesting point Katie:While some of the more obvious costs of an investment strategy may consist of a fund"	"You bring up an interesting point Katie:While some of the more obvious costs of an investment strategy may consist of a funds operating expense ratio and the fees charged by an advisor (readily published and available) there are less obvious costs as well.  Many of these less obvious costs fall outside of the investment vehicles and are paid out of total wealth.These costs might include: lack of appropriate diversification (not globally diversifying), tax inefficiency, lack of monitoring (not rebalancing the portfolio), opportunity costs, emotional errors (selling to cash when the market has bottomed), and not correctly placing assets.  For example with asset placement, many investors believe that they should place stocks that are likely to appreciate rapidly inside of a tax advantaged account rather than the bond portion of their portfolio.  In fact, it is generally advantageous to place bonds in your tax advantaged accounts because the coupon and interest payments are paid at regular income tax rates vs. stock appreciation at long-term rates (assumes care in not realizing ST gains)  In a taxable brokerage account, you can sell out a loss position and swap in a nearly identical fund to harvest"" the loss while not having been out of the market in that asset class."					"Unfortunately many times the people who would most greatly benefit from working directly with an advisor do not do so until later stages in life, for example, just prior to retirement.  Many financial planning concepts can be of most advantage if implemented with long time horizons."""			"Ok. John Carlson, the owner and primary guy, is very nice, friendly, and will tell you when something does or doesn't make sense to do.  He had the opportunity to do more work than he did in our house (repairs could have been more extensive), but he told us that was unnecessary.  He did only what was genuinely needed.  We went from the way the builder did the floors, a water-based finish that had very low durability, to a 3-coat Swedish finish. There are tons of good independent (and public!) schools, but those parameters could really help narrow it down.  The application process at independent schools can vary from fairly mellow and with decent odds (especially at smaller schools), to fairly involved and with generally low odds (at schools like UCDS).  Also, when evaluating schools, try to talk to some of the parents of kids who already go there -- I think this can be very helpful to get an overall sense of the attitudes and perspectives in that school's community (and to us, it seemed like each school was different).  Also, regarding class sizes -- I don't think the difference in teacher-to-student ratios between public and independent schools is *necessarily* as huge as it would at first appear (though obviously, in general, there is a difference).  At the local public school that I toured, they appeared to be very resourceful at getting a second adult into many of their classrooms -- teaching aides, parent volunteers, special ed. aides, etc.  Good luck!"		"Previous poster here -- if you are looking for *preschools,* one issue to consider is the long waitlists. So I highly advise that you refrain from any physical activity that keeps sending impacts to your back until it heals completely, otherwise you'll risk this pain becoming an on-going issue which could build up into something permanent since your body never has a chance to heal it properly. Lastly, you may want to consider increasing your intake of Vitamin C & E, both of which are known to aid with post-exercise tissue repair and reduce pains associated with muscle/joint damages from exercising. I am no medical expert and since our bodies operate differently, you may want to consult with a professional physician before taking my last advice. :)"		I'm glad ur being proactive @Poom. I can't compare to private, but I had a decent experience and here are a few things I "	"I grew up in public school in Sacramento. I can't compare to private, but I had a decent experience and here are a few things I think contributed to that:1) Advanced classes - in Elementary school there was the accelerated class (called GATE - Gifted and Talented Education - at the time) and that was good. Don't know status of those programs these days but in my day there was just one school per district that offered it, so many classmates traveled. In high schools there's of course advanced placement.2) School flexibility - Not something public schools are known for so maybe I lucked out. But they let me take math classes above my grade level, let me test out of filler classes like home economics, and eventually let me skip out of school early to take classes at the local college. I would have been incredibly bored without this.3) Diversity - I went to school with immigrants, gang bangers, poor kids, kids from dysfunctional families. This was by far a more positive than negative experience (notwithstanding the occasional school stabbing!) and is my biggest worry about sending my kid to private school (that she only interacts with rich white kids).Hope that's some food for thought on what you might look for in your schools!"		I can tell you from experience you don't mess with back pain. Don't try to push through it or you could end up on your back unab	"I can tell you from experience you don't mess with back pain. Don't try to push through it or you could end up on your back unable to get up for days at a time. If you think it'll heal on it's own, try walking or doing intervals (run for 1 minute, walk for 1 minute) just to the point where the pain is being caused. Consider that the source of the pain is your posture - I had this problem jogging and a physical therapist helped me. The therapist mostly helped me understand my body, how to have good posture, and how to stretch. Stretching is important. I went to Olympic Physical Therapy (http://www.olympicpt.com/therapists_bio.asp?pg=2&pdx=163&zdx=3) and Elizabeth fixed me up but it was also a lot more expensive than I expected (about ~$200/hour, partially covered by insurance)."		"Yes very true, I mentioned: for a taxable brokerage account, to illustrate some other costs"" investors pay that aren't simply o"""	"Yes very true, I mentioned: for a taxable brokerage account, to illustrate some other costs"" investors pay that aren't simply operating expense ratios or management fees.  In this case you are completely correct tax loss harvesting would not be beneficial in the 401k question for the original thread.  Your point that past performance does not predict the future certainly proves to be true.  There has been some interesting research over the years regarding the success of Morningstar ratings in predicting the performance of funds.  Here is one article that discusses the ratings: "					http://articles.marketwatch.com/2010-05-28/investing/30741585_1_mutual-funds-star-rating-star-ratings						"Of the 248 stock funds with five-star ratings at the start of the period, just four still kept that rank after 10 years. The 218 domestic stock funds with the rating typically lagged their category averages over the period -- not just the benchmarks, but other mutual funds. The exceptions were 30 foreign large-cap funds, which had a 10-year annualized return of 1.44% compared with their category average of 1.32%.In other words, it's not just that five-star funds don't, on average, continue to lead their peers, but they actually do worse in subsequent years.The worst performers were small-cap growth funds. The category's 29 five-star funds in 1999 lost an average of 3.6% annualized over the next decade. The category overall was up 0.6% in the period.""Great convo here!  IMO this thread underscores my point about hiring a fee-based advisor.  This stuff doesn't feel like DIY mate"""	Great convo here!  IMO this thread underscores my point about hiring a fee-based advisor.  This stuff doesn't feel like DIY material.		To search for a word	To search for a word		Hyatt Place on 6th Ave N is a good compromise.  http://seattledowntown.place.hyatt.com/hyatt/hotels-seattledowntown-place/place/	"Hyatt Place on 6th Ave N is a good compromise.  http://seattledowntown.place.hyatt.com/hyatt/hotels-seattledowntown-place/place/index.jsp  Otherwise, Hotwire is one of my favorite hotel sites and can usually get you a 4 star place for less than $200."		"I haven't been there since grad school but I will say Legal Seafood is my favorite. ABSOLUTELY not suggesting using past performance to predict"" future performance or as a way to select """	"Yes, I need to clarify.  ABSOLUTELY not suggesting using past performance to predict"" future performance or as a way to select funds.  Sorry, I assumed people knew not to do that. I just find the analytics and data that Morningstar provides at a glance to be convenient rather than having to calculate or compile it myself.  As for financial advisors, I think for many people, it makes sense to hire a financial advisor and have them manage your overall asset allocation and to properly diversify for best after-fee, after-tax results.  Speaking only about a 401(k), achieving diversification may not be that easy, especially when factoring in transaction fees.  Even for the wealthy, there are annual contribution limits to a certain extent which I why I lean toward the Index Funds or ETF route for the average person.  But there is no general right answer, depends on one's specific situation."""		I met a sports medicine doctor who tis also a 9 time ironman. He wrote a great book on dealing with running injuries. Positano:  Re"	"You will have plenty of food options in Italy, especially in the amalfi coast where the vegetables are fantastic.  Positano:  Restaurant Il Ritrovo is in the mountains but ask your hotel concierge to call them and the restaurant staff will pick you up and bring to you and from the restaurant.  Great food at a much lower cost of what restaurants in Positano will charge.  Must try the fresh-made lemon granita from the vendor by the bus stop.  Ask anyone in town, they will point you to his granita cart.  Go for a boat ride to Negano island for lunch.  The zucchini and pasta is popular and fried zucchini squash flowers are usually good. Capri:  If possible, try to go for a boat ride around the island.  The vantage point from the sea is different from doing it by foot on the island and you get to see all the different caves that you only only see from boat.  Try to skip Grotto Azura's crazy wait and waste of time if waves are too rough you don't get to go in.  The emerald grotto near Amalfi is bigger, nicer and wait lines are not nearly as bad as Azura Grotto.  Pick out custom made sandals to be created while you wait (but a little pricey).  R. Buonocore is an amazing bakery in Capri.  Try to take a ferry or bus to Ravello - stunning.Florence - try the Ribolitta soup.  Reserve tickets for any museums in advance to avoid lines.  If shopping is your thing, let me know and I'll give more info."		What's Roku? 	What's Roku? 		"Tom, have you seen the NE clam chowder from Legal's at Costco?" Also these arent like the Outlets in the US ! they're fitted out like the normal Prada and Gucci stores.. staffed with similar people you'd find in the regular stores... but at crazy prices - Sure you know this but you get to claim any tax (VAT) back so its even cheaper !"""			Vivian and Joe thank you so much for the great recommendations! The one's I'm familiar with are sold "	"I'm no expert, but my general sense is that timeshares are not a good financial decision.  The one's I'm familiar with are sold in large blocks (~20 or 30 years) at what seems to be a good price.  However if you do the math on the time value of money over that period of time, it doesn't look so great.  Add to that the (sometimes hidden) fees each time you book and the risk that you won't actually use all of your slots (who really knows what their vacation preferences and needs will be 20 years from now?) and it starts to look even worse.  The ones I've seen also have large commissions for a captive broker if you decide to sell prior to expiration.   In my experience, the only positives to getting a timeshare are 1) if you get the kind that give you access to multiple locations you may have some convenience value or 2) if you get a really good financial deal, which usually means a resort that did not initially intend to do timeshares but was unable to sell all of its condomiums and opted to do timeshares from a position of weakness.  The question then becomes why it couldn't sell all of its condo inventory and whether there's something flawed about the resort."		Agree with Mark.  Some other yellow flags: When was the last time you heard someone rave about owning a time share?  Why do time	"Agree with Mark.  Some other yellow flags: When was the last time you heard someone rave about owning a time share?  Why do timeshare sales centers pressure the crap out of you to buy and offer all kinds of crazy incentives to get you in the door?  Now, if they had a 5 year commitment time-share product, I'd be tempted.  E.g. if Westin said you can pre-purchase $25K of credits for $12.5K, I'd seriously consider that."		"I made these for my daughter's birthday last year: http://www.giverslog.com/giftguides/?p=2829You can fill them with popcorn o"	"I made these for my daughter's birthday last year: http://www.giverslog.com/giftguides/?p=2829You can fill them with popcorn or goldfish or, like I did, the less sugary version of lucky charms from whole foods. Specifically, I'd consider the following:1.  Assuming the job doesn't "	"My main advice is focus on the city and not the job.  Specifically, I'd consider the following:1.  Assuming the job doesn't pan out and I need to find a new one in that city, how hard would it be to find a job I loved at a company I loved and how does that compare to where I am now and where I could alternatively move?2.  What's the culture, values, and vibe fit for me and my family with this new city?3.  Could I see myself living in that city for the next 10+ years?Overall, I think it may be tempting to focus on the current offer (salary, bonus, job scope, etc) when in reality, you'll be re-orged, promoted, or change companies within a few years anyway.  The key thing is if/when that happens, are you in the middle of a desert or are you in a employer rich environment that's within a community that you and your family would love.This is advice I wished I had gotten when I last moved.  I focused almost entirely on the company and offer and didn't realize I was really accepting an offer from (and making a commitment to) the city.  Luckily, it has worked out well for us but the city I'm in now (Seattle) has grown a ton and diversified its employer base considerably since 2002 when I accepted an offer from Microsoft to relocate from Boston."		Airbnb.com is affordable. We started hosting in our spare room this past summer and have been happy with the whole process.	Airbnb.com is affordable. We started hosting in our spare room this past summer and have been happy with the whole process.		Yogurt covered pretzels. If you read any car mags, this is the gold standard for s"	"Ahh, an executive sedan for slippery roads.   1.  BMW 335 Xdrive.  If you read any car mags, this is the gold standard for sports sedans.  Here's the thing.  I test drove it and honestly, it just didn't have the grunt I was expecting.  Don't get me wrong, it was super smooth and solid, it just didn't feel as tossable as my MINI turbo.  There's also an issue IMO opinion with the BMW 3 series in general and that is it's becoming a very popular choice of females.  So if you're a female or male who doesn't care about driving a female's car, this is not an issue but for me, I wanted something that was a bit more masculine.2.  Audi S4.  A bit more grunt than the 335 Xdrive, great engine, it's like a velvet hammer.  Like the 3 series, the S4 is a bit bigger than I'd like which I find makes it less zippy and tossable in in-city driving.  I think I like the lines of the 335 better than the S4 (esp with the M sports package) but you might find the interior and less cookie cutter S4 to be more up your alley.3.  Mitsubishi Evolution MR.  This has no right to be compared to the first two from a high brow heritage pov but I did anyway (and ended up buying one).  The main thing about the Evo MR is it's kind of stealth power.  It goes to 60 in under 5 seconds, has AWD with yaw control, and basically eats corners up for lunch.  It however is not nearly as nice inside as the Audi or as gorgeous as the Bimmer.  You can also get an evo fully loaded for low 40s which would be prob about 10K less than the 335 or S4 fully loaded.  4.  Cadillac ATS.  This was not available when I was buying but has gotten rave reviews coming in at comparable performance to the first 2.  I kind of like it because you don't see as many people driving these as you will the 3 series and Audis.  5.  MB C300 4Matic.  Less common than BMW's but perhaps not as agile.6.  Subaru STI.  Like Evo but a bit more boy racer and no auto (I commute in stop n go so wanted a daily driver with dual clutch auto)."		"I would echo the rec for the Audi S4.  The Audi AWS is as good as any I've seen, the car handles beautifully and of course the e"	"I would echo the rec for the Audi S4.  The Audi AWS is as good as any I've seen, the car handles beautifully and of course the engine is very punchy.  I owned an older model, but the 2013 is getting good reviews.  Another option would be the Infiniti G37x.  Almost as fun to drive as the Audi, although it doesn't have quite the same rock-solid handling and the fit and finish are also of lower quality -- however, on the plus side it's ~$10k cheaper."		"I started watching them with our son at 4. I bought a Star Wars story book and sticker book for my son when he was 4.  That way I could intro	"Something else to consider... I bought a Star Wars story book and sticker book for my son when he was 4.  That way I could introduce the characters and concept, but I could control the plot line.  He was excited about the robots and ships and lightsabers.  He understood that the mean looking guys were the bad guys.  But I didn't have to worry about anything being overly scary or having to explain mature stuff like (spoiler alert) Darth Vader being Luke's father.  He was so into it that we later got him Star Wars sheets and a comforter for his bed.  And he still hasn't seen any of the movies (he's 5 now), but he doesn't even know they exist.  I think this will also make him less likely to be scared when I do show him the movies, because he already knows a bunch of the characters and will expect to see a bunch of the bad guys."		"If you do NOT want to have constant light saber fights in your living room, do NOT let kids watch StarWars. Watch out for maintenance fees and housekeeping fees too.  When it all adds up in the end you probably pay as much in fees as you would to stay at a nice resort in the same area without the initial investment.		Oh and Tom - here's a tailored video for you about why YOU need an iPhone 5. In other words, FB doing better"" or ""worse"" as a company monetizing its users is only part of answer to the question of whether the stock price will go up or down.  The other part is what current level of expectations are already priced in to today's price.  Just because it's far below its IPO price doesn't mean it's cheap. It should be more about the fundamentals of the company. My stint at Google imprinted on me that the market is often not aligned with fundamentals. I was there for four years and the Google stock went from 600 down to 300 back to 600 and then down to 300 again when I was leaving and now it is is back above 600. It is hard to believe the fundamentals of Google changed so dramatically, so many times, in a relatively short period of time. I think technology stocks, especially new ones, are more cyclical because the underlying financial models are so dependent on high growth - a small change in those assumptions can have a huge impact on the stock. It seems, at least to some degree, FB stock has been battered and it is possible that the next bit of good news could send them surging again. I agree with Tom though that it should be invested in after you have a diversified 401K. I am considering buying a small amount just for fun and because I think they will bounce back."		"If I had to pick one fun stock, I'd have to go with FB. In general, I have found on multiple bets that if you like the underlying fundamentals (and I mean strategy, competitive advantages, and unique assets as opposed to financial statement fundamentals) AND the market gets irrationally disappointed b/c the company didn't meet unrealistic short term expectations and thus gets beaten down, that's a wonderful time to get in.  I can think of a few times this paid off well for me when I used to trade my brother's speculative account."		"Tom, if you don't get it with the order, then (according to the web site) you have to go into the store to show that it isn't da"	"Tom, if you don't get it with the order, then (according to the web site) you have to go into the store to show that it isn't damaged to activate AC. You can see goal progress through the day by an array of LED lights on the band that's like a fill bar which get progressively lit up as you approach your daily goal.  But to see intraday progress you need to synch over bluetooth (one click on the band and one click on the app)."		I bought NB Retro 576 running shoe (http://4.bp.blogspot.com/_mhcm27eF548/SCuHhHoOmxI/AAAAAAAAM04/WZ5ioU3yFIA/s400/new-balance-r	I bought NB Retro 576 running shoe (http://4.bp.blogspot.com/_mhcm27eF548/SCuHhHoOmxI/AAAAAAAAM04/WZ5ioU3yFIA/s400/new-balance-rc576d-brogue-6.jpg) recently to replace my Adidas that was quite worn out from all the mileage. Holders earn points for free nights in Starwood - we have found that 9000 points (typically valued at $90 cash back) gets us a $200-$300 room.   We use it as a supplemental card and we love how it changes the economics of a weekend getaway to a big city or a longer vacation.   We stayed at some fab places in Hawaii and downtown Chicago. I use the miles as reward points on Amazon.com in addition to redeeming any travel-related purchases with them (airfare, hotels, etc). Also it's 2 miles toward $1 on any purchase, and if you buy from Discover.com shopping mall then it's 3 miles for $1. The only potential downside to this card is the annual $60 fee, but it pays off for itself every year (especially if you travel once or twice per year) if you use it as your primary card."		Also - speaking of the customer support for Discover. In my experience, the child needs to have one reference person who speaks ""only English"" """	"I agree with the earlier the better."" In my experience, the child needs to have one reference person who speaks ""only English"" and others who speak (in our case) ""only German"" with him/her, so there is consistency. Bilingual public education has been a big failure here in Texas, with the result that students sometimes speak and write  both languages poorly. Our son was 9 months old when my job was transferred to Germany and 4 years old when we returned. He has a Spanish-speaking nanny for 8 months in Houston. Then he had a German-speaking nanny and went to a British nursery school twice a week for 2 years. We relied on the excellent German Saturday School here in Houston after we ""repatriated"" from Germany and many of our Houston neighbors sent their kids to the Chinese Saturday School. Both schools were very accommodating when sports and music lessons conflicted. So all the kids in our neighborhood got the message that a second language was part of your heritage and part of who you are as an American. Even though it's a hassle to read that good night story in a foreign language, it will pay big dividends later on when the kids are more empathetic and more thoughtful because they do have experience in another language."""		I think invite only makes sense when you want to tightly control who accesses your functionality. Then I realized (like smoking) it was as much a habit as an addiction.  I just like having access to a coffee cup and I learned that expresso-based drinks generally have 1/3 the caffeine of coffee-based drinks.  And size matters.  For example, at Starbucks, a tall (12 oz?) has one shot of expresso, while a grande (16 oz?) has two and venti has 3 shots (20 or 24oz?).  So to limit my caffeine without going decaf which is also has 1/3 the caffeine, I just get 1-2 tall drinks a day or when I get the venti, I ask for 2 shots instead of 3."		Better to be clear about what your wishes are so that those who survive you don't have to guess in addition to dealing with the 	"Better to be clear about what your wishes are so that those who survive you don't have to guess in addition to dealing with the loss. A master document that provides a list of account numbers, where they are located, along with any necessary passwords kept along with a copy of your will (to be held with your lawyer or in a safe deposit box) can be extremely helpful for those left behind to handle your affairs."		"Tom, your messed up ying-ying plate of charred kobe and ketchup salmon sashimi has me gagging. I don't think it's rude for one-of-a-kind 5-star restaurant to refuse any requests that will change the essence or the spirit of the dish that they are trying to serve to the customer. When you dine at restaurants of this caliber, remember that food itself is the soul of the overall dining experience that defines the place that you dine at (changing their food is the same as getting food from another restaurant), and for that reason, you're also required to invest a certain amount of faith in the skills of the chefs and trust that they will do everything they can to prepare the most delicious meal for you, even if this meal may lack or include certain ingredients that you may or may not be accustomed to. Now for chain restaurants, due to the more 'scaled' nature of the meal production, I believe they should be a lot more flexible and willing to accommodate your request to change certain ingredients.That said, I also believe every restaurant should have a secret menu item that only regular customers know about and can customize to their liking."		"@Tom, no opinion on beef or fish... I wasn't selling my soul but rather providing them my style"" in a service. Usually the commission request came because they liked something else that I did and they wanted ""my style"" with a particular subject. Sometimes this was fun (the request/commission was interesting) and sometimes it was quite painful as the subject was insanely boring or something that I had no interest in painting. Commissioned artwork becomes more of a design matter than artwork of passion or something that I would like to do on my own. Apps snap open. LTE makes downloads unnervingly fast; saw speeds over 1meg/sec from the iTunes Store. Facebook chugs on a 4, is instant on a 5. Camera chugs on a 4, is instant on a 5. The buttons are in the wrong place. It's a matter of millimeters, if that, but my muscle memory from 27 months of a 4 is working against me. I'm sure I'll adjust, but it hasn't happened yet. Letterboxed apps look dumb. Especially in landscape mode, where the app is letterboxed and the keyboard opens full-width. A lot of the big guys have already updated (FB, twitter, Kindle...) but plenty more haven't (spotify, Starbucks, a couple of others I use daily or more). I'm glad I updated. As previous owners of an SUV, the following advantages"	"We own an Odyssey, after much consideration of the minivan vs. SUV route. As previous owners of an SUV, the following advantages stood out to us:1. With small children, we don't need to collapse seats to get kids into the back row. They can simply walk through without having to take out the car seats from the middle row. Major time/effort/energy savings here - especially if the kid in the back can self-buckle.2. A minivan sits lower to the ground, so smaller kids are able to enter the vehicle by themselves.3. Sliding doors are a big deal, especially as the car gets wider. Smaller parking spaces in the city are complimented well by a door that has a 6 profile instead of the necessary 20"" to get the kids out of the back."		4. Automatic sliding doors are great for little kids or parents with full hands. Minimul effort and it is guaranteed to close properly and not be left ajar.			5. The van is made for kids. There are many cup holders and features added just for kids - unlike the SUV which doesn't seem to be designed with a kids-first mentality. Even American made minivans don't seem to be kids-first.			"6. 2nd Row captain's chairs are great for when you have an additional adult to transport. Extra comfort, yet separated a bit from the kids in the next seat over."""			"Hi Bo.  Curious, how is your Odyssey in the snow? So I couldn't invoke POA for my Mom from Washington, because the document, drafted in NJ, had a Notary that was signed by the attorney, without a seal.  The bank here refused to invoke the DPOA because, in the elegant words of the bank, there aren't any bumps on the Notarization"".  "					"My suggestions are: if you have DPOA, then get added to the bank accounts as a co-signer.  Then there's no delay and no hassle, the DPOA can be processed at leisure.  And second, make sure the DPOA is usable in both the parent's and executor's states."""			"I am an owner and a renter and did essentially what you propose. At the end of the day, look at the net amount spent on housing "	"I am an owner and a renter and did essentially what you propose. At the end of the day, look at the net amount spent on housing after taking into account mortgage, rental income, and rent and see if it is within your budget. And, as your sense tells you, in certain markets it can be cheaper to rent than to own. It is particular true in hotter markets like Seattle or SF and especially true if you are considering a shorter time period since transaction costs for ownership are so high. Zillow has a few nice articles about price-to-rent ratios that are worth reading.But, you also have a choice as to whether you 1) rent out your house or 2) sell your house and invest the equity into other assets (and your landlording time into other pursuits). The price to rent ratios also are helpful in this decision. In my case, Ann Arbor home prices are so low that I can do much better financially by renting out my house then selling it, even after taking into account the home expenses, landlord time, and extra taxes (check if your area has different property taxes for investment properties). It can be seductive to convince yourself that just because you can cover your mortgage with rental income that it is a good deal to rent out your house. The seduction deepens if you happen to love your house (in which case - all bets are off - keep the house). But, if you are concerned about the financial end, I would do the math and compare where you would be in five years if you rent out the house versus selling it and investing the proceeds in a mutual fund that gets 5% per year. You might be surprised with the result."		Yes.   One thought though - move the helpful button closer to the end of the tip/response so it is looking right at you when you	"Yes. I've even seen this happen in the summer if we do a bunch of errands and buy groceries at the beginning of the trip.  It seemed to cut the freshness lifespan materially.  Another cause could be if it's left on the counter too long when you're serving.  Lastly, you may also want to turn down the temp in your fridge :-)"		Thx Ian. I used this site when I originally researched juicers. http://www.consumersearch.com/juicers. However, I don't use it very much anymore and instead favor my high speed Vitamix blender. http://www.amazon.com/Vitamix-1363-Professional-Series-Platinum/dp/B000RRKQKA/ref=sr_1_2?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1349056322&sr=1-2&keywords=VitamixI can for example mix Kale, Soy Milk, Spinach, Flax Seeds and it shreds everything until it is easily drinkable. However, if you opened it on the ""sell by"" date, t"""	"The sell by"" date is the last date the store should be selling the product.  However, if you opened it on the ""sell by"" date, then you have a few more days until the milk is no longer ""good"".  But there are some milks that are highly pasteurized that have ""sell by"" dates that I've seen that were as much as 2 months away.  If you open the milk now and the ""sell by/expiration date"" isn't until two months from now, I think the milk would go bad about a week after you open it, not two months from now.  I think Horizon Organic milk is one of the brands that has really long expiration dates.  Haven't read tbe article posted by Ferd but I do tend to avoid the highly pasteurized milk products."""		I checked and did not notice it. In doing that, I created a new email account just for that new FB account.  Now that new account just got mail offering cheat codes for a FPS game from Steam.  This is why I don't trust FB, they have leaks.  I've reported this issue repeatedly to one of the high level tech guys I know there, and I'm sure he passed it on.  But here's a fresh example.My advice: only put on Facebook things that you are completely comfortable with having ANYONE see ANYTIME.  Facebook does not have a paranoid attitude to security based on what I've observed, unlike Amazon for example.  FB is closer to Hotmail (which has similar leaks)."		"The only raw milk I've seen here Stella is by doing a cow share"" where a farmer lets you part-own a cow or cows, then provides """	"The only raw milk I've seen here Stella is by doing a cow share"" where a farmer lets you part-own a cow or cows, then provides you a service of milking your cow for you. "					"So as a rule, yes the media will dramatize whatever they're covering, politics or anything else. NFC has been found to have a LOT of security"	"I've got lots and lots of security questions about that.  First, NFC is mentioned.  NFC has been found to have a LOT of security holes, so the fact that this can use NFC indicates the company is not security paranoid.  I am.Second, all someone has to do is steal your phone, mount the phone as a disk on a laptop (trivial to do), then read all the data on it.  It's quite possible that could be a way to easily get in to your home.Third, Bluetooth was never intended as a secure protocol, so the fact that the primary interface is BT would be worrying to me.Bottom line: I need to know a ton more about this before considering it.  Disclaimer: I'm a nut about security, people who are not might not care about any of this."		"As long as you can search two words, then the word search could also function as a topic search"	"As long as you can search two words, then the word search could also function as a topic search"		"Oh man Ferd, I think you were saying what my gut was telling me. What's a more likely scenario?  1) Steal your phone; mount it on their computer; read the data on it; f"	"So, lets be honest.  What's a more likely scenario?  1) Steal your phone; mount it on their computer; read the data on it; figure out where you live; take it back to your house; wait for you to leave; break in?2) Just break in.If you have something in your house that is awesome and worth stealing someone will get in and steal it if they want.  If someone doesn't know whether or not you have something awesome in your house worth stealing they may break in anyway and steal it.  Thieves don't go through your door anyway unless it's unlocked.  They'll crawl in through pet doors, go in through windows, etc. So really the question is--is it more convenient for you than a key?  If so, go for it, and put a passcode on your phone.  My house was robbed and they didn't go in through a locked door.  My friend's house was robbed twice--neither time through a locked door and the second time they had a security system...didn't matter.Pretty sure most neighborhood thieves aren't going to go through all that trouble.  6 houses were hit on my block in one night.  Not a single window was broken, no doors kicked in...if your house is reasonably secured there's likely one just down the street that's not.That being said, I bought a home security cam system from Costo for under $300...4 cameras, records to DVR, motion-activated if you want it, night vision....and you can check in on your house from your phone or the web at any time.  From discussions with officers, that's actually the best deterrent right now, because a video can potentially prove that someone is in your house even if you don't catch them, and that can make something into a felony instead of a misdemeanor.  That is automatically a bigger problem and something that most home burglars won't take a chance on."		I was in a similar situation and everybody told me that Verizon was vastly superior but I decided to stick with AT&T and it's ac	I was in a similar situation and everybody told me that Verizon was vastly superior but I decided to stick with AT&T and it's actually been fine so far. SO in summary, they're comparable in number of areas covered and not covered.I'd say walk around areas where you really want coverage with your AT&T phone and a friend who has Verizon. There are almost 10 million 	"The CDC thinks raw milk is 150 times more likely to cause food-borne illness than pasteurized milk. There are almost 10 million people drinking raw milk regularly, but dairy (raw and pasteurized) accounts for merely 1.3% of all food-borne illnesses per year. So you are definitely increasing your risk by choosing raw milk, but regular consumption is by no means a guarantee that you will get sick. http://blogs.worldwatch.org/nourishingtheplanet/the-raw-milk-debate/"		I love cinnamon couscous with coconut milk for breakfast	I love cinnamon couscous with coconut milk for breakfast		"Remember the old Sharper Image"" store in Bellevue Square, I think Jim Zorn was an investor?""" In the absence of controlled trials, I think this is enough to say that raw milk is riskier than pasteurized milk. But I agree with Ferd that if you drink a cup of raw milk right now, the absolute risk of becoming ill is still quite small - even though the relative risk has increased."		"Napa, Ca"	"Napa, Ca"		"This article has info on IPS displays, including how to get relatively inexpensive, high-quality displays imported. The days of just changing some letters to make password"" int"""	"Just remember that length is the key to good and great passwords.  The days of just changing some letters to make password"" into ""P@ssw0rd"" are gone.  Crackers now have pre-computed tables of the hashes of billions of possible combinations of letters and numbers for smaller passwords with substitutions."					"A very good visual explanation of this (and no don't use the password he shows in here, something like 5% of people have done just that!):"						"http://xkcd.com/936/"""			That may not actually be the end - read what Mike Arrington found out: http://uncrunched.com/2012/08/26/my-undead-credit-card/	That may not actually be the end - read what Mike Arrington found out: http://uncrunched.com/2012/08/26/my-undead-credit-card/		"Yikes, that's just evil. Once a series of $50.00 charges were on	"Once mine was gotten by a server at a Vietnamese soup restaurant in the Int'l District.  Once a series of $50.00 charges were on it, which Chase didn't notice till I told them.  Once I have no idea how it was taken. I use a password hasher that does a trapdoor (one-way) encryption so each site also has a unique complex password.  Yet my card has been compromised about once a year.  I believe there are way more compromises of online sites than get in the news.  The only card I've ever had compromised is the one for online use."		"We're not sure. While I'm working on something else (exciting stuff like spreadsheets or powe	"I like to have the iPhone in the dock on my desk. Using it to show incoming things (like a sourcer finding a resume) vs mails that are not urgent (HR newsletters e.g.) allows me to quickly react or ignore, without using up any pixels on the mail screen."		asdf	asdf		Thanks Tom. I know their security around CC's well, and it's probably "	"Poom - Amazon to my knowledge has never been cracked on the CC side.  I know their security around CC's well, and it's probably the only site I trust to store my CC number.  Obviously I can't reveal the details in a public forum, but they are doing it right.  Another proxy I use is: I run my own mail server at home.  I generate a new email address for every site I deal with.  If I get spam to one of those email addresses, that's a pretty strong indication they've been hacked.  I then put them in the untrusted site"" column.  How do I know I've not been hacked?  The one time I know I was, about 14-15 years ago, my mail server went so wonky it was like it turned on a siren.  Since then, if anyone got in (past my ICSA certified firewall, IPS, and other barriers) to get all my email addresses, I'd get a zillion instead of one broken."""		I worked out of the StartPad offices for about six months. Economically, I dont think you are going to get much better deal than office share places like Surf Incubator.   Considering location, office build out, building amenities in, building amenities out, these types of spaces are an excellent bargain.  If you simply just need to rent out a private office from a larger company and share the resources (phone, copier, reception, etc) there are also quite a few options, but they tend to be a higher cost.  Regus is an excellent option as well, but it is significantly more expensive.   There are some small offices that are relatively inexpensive in Pioneer Square, but I think you would also need to increase your budget. A brief phone call regarding options in various sub markets and their rates might save you some time. On the mobile device side for example: http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9231448/Galaxy_S3_hacked_via_N	"NFC is not secure.  On the mobile device side for example: http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9231448/Galaxy_S3_hacked_via_NFC_at_Mobile_Pwn2Own_competitionBy banking level encryption"" are you referring to SSL?  That one link in the chain is fine (at 128 bit, but some sites still use 40 bit).  It only takes one hole to break into a system.  Taking over the phone using NFC would be sufficient to get all the information needed to get into your home, and NFC data stealing can be done just by being near your phone."					Security is as strong as the weakest link.  NFC is a proven weak link.						"And while Lockitron's FAQ on security has a much better story than some sites, I could not find a statement that they're doing continuous external penetration testing.  It's not hard to set up, we do it where on a regular basis.  There's also no mention of passing OWASP https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Main_Page standards on their site http://www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=site:lockitron.com+owasp&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8"						"So while their writeup is very well done, key aspects of ensuring and auditing security are missing."						"Thus I consider them insecure, since constant vigilance is required to maintain security.  And as security dudes say, even that is not a guarantee."""			"Or for high Geek factor, my usual watch these days, complete with a touch screen: http://www.tissot.ch/?mod_collections65/produc"	"Or for high Geek factor, my usual watch these days, complete with a touch screen: http://www.tissot.ch/?mod_collections65/products_661/scroll_0"		"Lots of stuff by the Beatles - yellow submarine, when I'm 64." We've stayed in South Kihei both times and rented condos but explored different areas of the island. We like having a kitchen so we can prepare snacks and drinks, plus having the extra room is nice to kick back.  Of course, we are also into 'getting deals' and this seemed like the way to go.  If we wanted to 'do it up' and not be concerned about price or having our own kitchen, I recommend The Four Seasons.  The beach is the nicest, the restaurant options are the best and it is close to other amenities in Kihei (5 minute drive north).  If you don't have a desire to be near amenities then I think your best bet is Kaanapali Beach, where there are numerous hotels and excellent beaches. The nearest area with amenities from hear is due south to lahaina. Short drive, about 15 minutes or so."		Are you looking to replace the stereo or do you want a wireless solution using what you already have or? My iphone has blue"	"1) I use a 'bose soundlink bluetooth'. If you don't have bluetooth in your ipod, then you can simply plug in. My iphone has bluetooth so it is wireless. The system will play for a couple hours without needing to be plugged in. I can adjust the songs and volume with my iphone wirelessly.  The sound is surprisingly exceptional considering the size of the speakers it is coming from.  It really fills in a room.2) The other set up I have is an AppleTV connected to my home receiver.   You need to have a wireless network in your house, the receiver must have an optical jack.  AppleTV connects to receiver.  (My receiver is nearly 10 years old and has an optical jack). I set my receiver volume on fairly high. Then play all my tunes on my iphone, which wirelessly pushes to appleTV, which pushes it to the receiver. I can then control everything from my iphone from anywhere in my house wirelessly. Works great and is super easy once it is set up."		Have you checked out Bell & Ross watches? A classic shot, of course, is at Leavenworth and Lombard looking up the corkscrew portion of Lombard "	"Russian Hill neighborhood. A classic shot, of course, is at Leavenworth and Lombard looking up the corkscrew portion of Lombard St.  The lighting is best in the morning.  For another classic shot, walk up Lombard to Hyde St, turn left, and then walk down the left side of Hyde to about the third parking space up from Hyde & Chestnut.  With a 200mm lens, frame your shot to include Alcatraz in the upper background, but focus on the center of the intersection.   Wait...   Eventually you'll hear the cable car coming up Hyde St. (it runs about every 10-15 minutes). It's not visible until the last few seconds - so be ready. As soon as it crests into the intersection fire away. I recommend at least 1/500 of a second to stop the action. Use a polarizer to cut the glare off the bay and to darken the sky and you should get a nice compressed shot of the cable car, Alcatraz, and San Francisco Bay in the background. Something like this maybe: http://www.blipfoto.com/entry/1490957"		"For the average user, it will just depend on what your preferences.  Recently made the switch from droid to IP5. Back in the early 90's a major weak point of Windows is that it"	"THe multi-tenant feature is good, and at the same time, ironic.  Back in the early 90's a major weak point of Windows is that its underlying architecture was not meant for multi-tenant (the message pump for example).  Unix was truly multi-user.  Now we have iOS, based on OS/X, based on FreeBSD, a flavor of Unix.  And the iPad isn't multi-user, while the Surface is.  Great call by MS."		"Thx Ferd, not sure what that means but I suppose the $500 question is: would you buy a Surface now?" I would also HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend Pilates. You will be amazed at the core work (pilates focuses on the 'powerhouse') and how you work muscles you didn't even know existed! There is also a huge focus on the stabilizing muscles (those you don't really work at the gym or if you're running), so your Pilates work will complement your other exercise and activities. I love it so much I'm getting my teaching certification! There's quite a few studios in Seattle so I would recommend trying different ones close to where you live until you find a studio and teacher you love. If you've never done pilates before, I would recommend private sessions. I guarantee that you'll fall in love with it!"		"I really enjoyed it. The install to Windows 8 from Windows 7 is incredibly awes	"I spent some time on Saturday installing Windows 8 on my main laptop. The install to Windows 8 from Windows 7 is incredibly awesome. You get 3 choices... 1) Keep your Apps/Data... 2) Keep your Data.... 3) Delete everything and start from scratch. I initially opted for option 1... and had Windows 8 running comfortably with all my apps/data intact. There were 2 apps that weren't compatible and the installer pointed this out. I eventually decided that I wanted a fresh machine and did option 3.. You can reinstall Windows 8 at anytime... without any media at all. Just go to the settings and refresh Windows. As far as the transition from Windows 7 to Windows 8... The transition is a little harder than from Win98->XP-> Vista->7... but it's an easier transition than Windows -> Apples OSX or Windows -> Linux. I find myself using the Tile"" view more for consumption... and the classic desktop more for productivity. "					Initially not having the Start menu was offputting... I don't normally use the start menu as I use Launchy to run my applications. However not knowing how to get to things such as the control panel was strange.... The new charm menu and it's search functionality is pretty awesome... I'm about 48 hours into my Windows 8 journey and I'm feeling pretty good about. it. 						"I do recommend that people learn the hotkeys... they make things run very smooth once you get a hang of it."""			"Interesting point.  I'd refine his remark: the Surface is trying to horn in on the MB Air territory and the iPad - essentially, "	"Interesting point.  I'd refine his remark: the Surface is trying to horn in on the MB Air territory and the iPad - essentially, the market is dividing as maturing markets do.  What was once the only major segment (desktops) became two (desktop, laptop).  Now desktops are bifurcated - component style and iMac all-in-one style.  Portables are now dividing into luggable (MBPro 17 was one), actual laptop (retina MBPro), thin (MB Air), big tablet w/keyboard, small tablet/reader, big phone, regular phone.   All of those exist now and there seems to be room for all.  The net losers are the desktop and the luggable, the winners right now are the big phone/small tablet and the big tablet / small thin light laptop."		"Thanks Chris, good info. My one tip to ad"	"I've had a good experience with Ikea mattresses too, especially when you consider the value per dollar ratio.   My one tip to add is almost a Do-Not-Buy for Stearns and Foster mattresses.We purchased a S&F pillow top from Macy's last year and it has been pretty underwhelming.  Double the cost of anything I've used previously, and while the initial comfort was great it very quickly degraded -- there are significant impressions in the pillow top where we sleep (my wife and I are average-sized folks) that make it much less comfortable to lie on now.  The 10 year S&F warranty is a sham here; the fine print says that impressions in the top up to 1.5-2 inches deep are totally within spec as little as 6 months into the life of the mattress.  This is a ridiculous level of degradation IMO that I did not see in my older cheaper mattresses.There are lots of rip-off report stories on the web about S&F and their warranty""."""		"I had the opposite reaction:  I felt it was a surprisingly BAD movie.
