It's ver"	"@Stella and I have a latex mattress that is amazing. I can sleep on anything, but I've felt really spoiled in this one. It's very comfortable, and keeps movements local (e.g. I can stand on my side and my sleeping wife will not notice).They're a little pricy, but we lucked out and got ours on CL. I'd generally not get a mattress on CL because of the cleanliness factor, but latex is safe because it doesn't carry a lot of the germs and other bad things that can live inside of mattresses.The only downside is that it's really heavy and kind of floppy when you have to move it."		"How about dinner at one of Tom Douglas' places in Belltown (maybe Palace Kitchen), live music at Triple Door, followed by drinks"	"How about dinner at one of Tom Douglas' places in Belltown (maybe Palace Kitchen), live music at Triple Door, followed by drinks at ART Lounge."		Both the desserts and the soups are also stellar. I also am week with regards to spice level...I generally can't eat anything from Thai Tom's.  Than Brothers has the best pho on the Ave in my experience.I was frankly impressed with Wing Central--both their wings and their beer selection.  Big Time has good food and beer as well as shuffleboard--can't go wrong there.  Aladdin's Gyrocery right next door is also fantastic and open till super late."		"I have this jacket:http://www.rei.com/product/813741/the-north-face-varius-guide-rain-jacket-mensIt is made very very we"	"I have this jacket:http://www.rei.com/product/813741/the-north-face-varius-guide-rain-jacket-mensIt is made very very well, and while it seems a bit heavier it's actually very breathable and the pit-zips are nice.  I can't remember the exact material of the inside but it's really comfortable--the basic rain jackets are waterproof but feel gross and sticky if you sweat at all, so while this jacket seems slightly bulkier than those, it's actually way more comfortable to wear.  I'm currently wearing this:http://www.rei.com/product/833083/rei-mont-range-jacket-mensWhich is great--down-like material in the body with wind resistant arms and hood...pretty breathable and warmer than a standard rain jacket.  I've been wearing it around and have been completely dry and warm--but I haven't been out in the rain for extended periods so I can't yet say if it'll keep you dry standing at a bus stop for a half hour in downpour.  It's also on sale right now for $79 which is a pretty good deal for a high quality jacket.  The one thing I found with my TNF Varius is that it's not really very warm at all...so you will want to have a good long-sleeved shirt or something on underneath in Jan-Feb."		I like Skagen watches. In physics,  blue == high color temp, yellow/red = low color temp, b"	"Color temperature is a term that's always kinda bugged me.  In physics,  blue == high color temp, yellow/red = low color temp, based on BBR (black body radiation).   But in common usage, cool"" is bluer light, and ""warm"" is yellower light.  LEDs now are pretty wide spread in spectral choices.  I have some very blue ones in the back yard on motion sensor, and some nice mellow near-candle color ones inside as background lights on a sunset offset timer.   Most are spec'd with a color temperature, choose the ones you would like.  "					"Personally I'll wait for V2 of the Apple ones."""			"Ferd, do you feel like Apple's selling an item in it's retail stores exclusively is a somewhat tacit approval of the quality of "	"Ferd, do you feel like Apple's selling an item in it's retail stores exclusively is a somewhat tacit approval of the quality of a product?"		Agree ppl seem to talk about Hipmunk a lot now. I told CU to implement that for a team that had a lot of tactical"" work and it paid off handsomely (still using it there).  However, I overall suggest it's better to have a single backlog that includes tactical and strategic work, though that puts a heavier burden on program managers.  It's quite typical that people on a highly tactical team get more frustrated and have higher turnover, since they can't look back over a year and point to major accomplishments of their team. At home I put them by a small     fan when I get home.  At the office, under my desk, but with room to get some air.3) If walking on streets, look for shoes focused on walking, not running, since the soles are     done a bit differently.  Trail shoes will wear out sooner on pavement, since the soles are    a softer rubber to work well on dirt trails."		"After going through countless vacuums (uprights and canisters) we settled on a Sanitaire canister, model S3681. And when we had the house renovated we noticed that every worker carried a Sanitaire for cleaning up after themselves. The size is great but the vacuum power absolutely sold us.  We had 2 yellow labs that shed a lot and this vacuum gets everything. I like the horsehair dusting attachment the best. It never scratches and it picks up everything. I keep buying Fitbits (seven so far including one for my mother and one for my sister) because they are great, small, and they work well to keep you motivated.  The newest Fitbits are nice improvements over the first two versions (both of which are still very nice devices), primarily the Fitbit One (it also has a vibrating alarm feature so you can wake up silently, a feature they borrowed from Up, and syncs via bluetooth to the website).For the sleep pattern, it is pretty much unparalleled for a device of that cost and size (the newest one is  2.0 x 0.75"" and has a nice silicone holder, and a wristband that you can use at night if you sleep in the nude -- otherwise just clip it to whatever you're wearing) and it is very accurate.  I tested using several devices at once for a few nights sleep and it was just as accurate as the expensive systems."					"Once you get into bed press the button on the Fitbit for two seconds and it now knows that you are either (a) going to sleep or (b) timing a specific activity to mark at the website (free membership to the site and all its features with the device).  As you sleep the Fitbit monitors your movement the same way the Wii controllers work, micro movements.  It gauges your active movement (awake), or lack of movement (sleep, and if for longer than a certain period of time, REM sleep), based on that.  Less movement for longer equals better sleep, more movement / twitches / etc. means you were active.  The chart for sleeping looks similar to the chart for activity, flat for when you got pretty good sleep (little movement) and active spikes for when you moved (rolling over counts as movement).  I wrote a review about it at my site if you're interested, including a sleep chart from the previous version of the device:  http://goo.gl/b9RJ6"""			"I've had the normal mattresses everyone gets from a local retailer, no one really knows the firmness, etc. and they were fine.  "	"I've had the normal mattresses everyone gets from a local retailer, no one really knows the firmness, etc. and they were fine.  I heard amazing things about memory foam so I entered into that realm with a 4 memory foam topper for my ""old"" mattress to give it new life.  I ordered the 5.5 lbs version (quite firm) and it was great for about a year but the mattress provides the base and the one I had was sinking.  So I figured why not go with a memory foam mattress, got a 10"" queen and put my topper on it and it was great for the first few nights ... then my back started to hurt.  I figured it was just getting used to it so I stuck with it for a few months.  I found it incredibly hot all the time (memory foam does not breathe) and my back hurt.  "					"I then stayed at the Los Angeles Athletic Club for a week for training and had the best sleep I've ever had.  So I called them and asked them what their mattress was, they looked it up and it was one made just for them, but after some research I found the non-commercial equivalent: Queen Serta Perfect Sleeper Regal Suite Firm Mattress Set."						"The important thing with this particular mattress is that it is flippable.  Most aren't.  Which means you'll only get half the life you would normally.  Keep that in mind!  This one also has steel reinforced edges so when you sit on the edge of the bed, it doesn't sink.  That adds years to the life."						"This particular mattress, on a hardness scale of 0 = bare floor and 10 = cloud, is a 3.  And that's perfect for me -- however, I still put my 4"" memory foam topper on it and it is a nice firm, but cushioned, sleep every night.  No back issues at all.  I ordered it online from us-mattress.com for $869 and that included a box spring (I chose low profile), a bed frame, and free white glove delivery."						"My recommendation is figure out how hard you like your bed, find one that's harder, soften it up with a memory foam topper (4"" is ideal because it keeps its form longer), and buy online."""			I've always had issues with running shoes causing arch pain because the arch supports are apparently made for someone else's foo	"I've always had issues with running shoes causing arch pain because the arch supports are apparently made for someone else's foot.  The only shoe I've found that I can wear without any issues what so ever -- and that I can run 10 miles in without any pain, blisters, anything -- are Vibrams.  They are the barefoot shoes and they require that you alter your running form to a more natural gait but I've found I can run faster and longer with them.  They require an instore fit because they are made to fit your toes -- not just your foot.  But once you know your size you're set.  They also make various types so if you do a lot of water sports you can get a pair you can wear in the water and on land, if you hike a lot you can get ones that have more tread for hiking, etc.  They also afford you a lot better traction and maneuverability because you can use your toes to your advantage -- great for hiking, running up or down hills, and running on uneven surfaces.  They're worth a try."		"I second Craig's List -- and specifically, if you can, look for an industrial one that can do up to a 10% incline (the most expe"	"I second Craig's List -- and specifically, if you can, look for an industrial one that can do up to a 10% incline (the most expensive industrial made for gyms will only go up to 15%).  You'll only ever want to go up to 8% because beyond that you cause knee damage (from 2%-5% you actually relieve pressure from the knees somewhat and force it to the ankles, but from 6%-8% you add a large degree of pressure to the knees so extended periods at that steep of an incline is not good for your knees).  Good treadmills that can do that type of incline (15%) usually run around $2,500 since they're made for gyms.  I found mine (NordicTrack EXP 1000, which does a 1-10% incline, 1 mph - 10 mph) on CL for $250.  It is heavy -- I cannot emphasize that enough.  One person cannot carry this unless they are a body builder.  I was able to move it in pieces alone, but once it's together (this kind folds up for easier storage), it's huge, bulky, and you'll need two people to move it.  I believe it weighs around 350 lbs so keep that in mind if you have stairs you have to move it up/down.However, it is a great machine, even though it's around 10 years old.  So keep your eye out for something similar (though more recent), with a good track record for not breaking down (research online).With treadmills you really do get what you pay for, the parts are very very expensive so put out the extra cash at the start and save yourself in the long run."		sonia agree bing lack of alerts is lame.  this is what happens when great startups get acquired :-(	sonia agree bing lack of alerts is lame.  this is what happens when great startups get acquired :-(		"Learn jQuery first, add Ajax -- that gives you the foundation for Sencha, then add in Objective-C for iDevice app development, a"	"Learn jQuery first, add Ajax -- that gives you the foundation for Sencha, then add in Objective-C for iDevice app development, and finally add in Flash (yeah, yeah, I know - but trust me on this).  Not Flash as in action script but Flash as in Flash Developer.  Adobe has made ways where you can turn your jQuery apps and/or Flash apps into apps that will run on all devices - iOS included.  Cross screen development in just a few steps (one app development process = iOS native app and Android native app and web app.  Highly recommended.That covers all devices.My experience comes from having actually done all of that."		"Ask her twin or best friend what he/she thinks your wife would like.  DON'T GUESS!Women tend to talk about these things with"	"Ask her twin or best friend what he/she thinks your wife would like.  DON'T GUESS!Women tend to talk about these things with people they're close to and those they're close to will want their family member / friend to be happy and excited and they'll love that they had a part in her happiness.  Women also tend to drop hints constantly about what they want, but they can be cryptic.In which case you may want to consider giving your wife a pass for one day - one day where you will do anything with her, for her, go anywhere with her, eat at any restaurant, you are hers for the entire day.  If she asks for a massage, you do it.  If she wants to be alone to read, you're out of sight.  If she wants you to fix that damn window, you do it.  Anything she wants.  The trick to this is to either (a) tell her a week before hand to come up with a list so she has time to figure out the gist of what she wants to do so you can plan it all -- thereby guaranteeing that she gets to do exactly what she wants or (b) present it to her on the day of and she gets to come up with it all spontaneously.  You can also make it so she can use that voucher"" on another day.  Present it to her with a card (handmade if possible, even if it's messy, she'll think it's thoughtful) and a little bell and tell her just to ""ring"" you whenever she wants you (this is the cute feature)."					"If she chooses not to use it that day, plan to do something for her -- dinner out is easy and you can do that any night, but what about inviting her closest friends over (that she enjoys spending time with) and cooking them all dinner, or hiring a private chef to do so (not as expensive as you'd think, check with local cooking schools)."						"While it's nice to plan a spa day, dinner out, etc. if she's not feeling it that day then you've just made her feel obligated to do it all.  Maybe she doesn't like people touching her feet or massaging her.  Unless you know she enjoys those things, it's a big risk."""			"I've created custom Wordpress sites using the Project Manager, Table Reloaded, and Events Manager plugins for teams (among other"	"I've created custom Wordpress sites using the Project Manager, Table Reloaded, and Events Manager plugins for teams (among other plugins). But without knowing that information here are three factors to consid	"Ferd is right to ask what your purpose for the machine is. But without knowing that information here are three factors to consider:1) Mac vs Windows Cost: Macs keep their value, Windows machines don't.  Expect to buy a new Windows machine every couple of years which will equal the cost of one Mac.  In addition, a Mac can be resold for almost full value, Windows machines can be donated to someone.2) Mac vs Windows Functionality: they'll both do anything you want, except gaming and iOS development (for the most part).  Windows machines are better for gaming because they're cheaper to upgrade to get enough memory, etc.  You need a Mac to do iOS native development.  Macs will play games though, just more expensive to upgrade -- especially when it comes to the laptops.3) Mac vs Windows Flexibility: a Windows machine will only run Windows.  You can dual boot to another OS (Linux) if you want but you can't dual boot to Mac.  A Mac on the other hand gives you three machines in one,  Mac, Windows (using Parallels), and Linux if you want it.  So you get much more OS flexibility with a Mac than a Windows machine.With those things in mind that should help a bit.  I have several Windows machines (HP and Dell) and several Macs (desktop and laptop) -- I even have a Mac from 1998 that still works and gets use regularly whereas the Windows laptop from the same time is a brick.If you go with a Mac, look at refurbished ones from Apple or from Craig's List.  They are workhorse machines and you can get a good as new"" used, whereas Windows machines are best bought new."""		yabb.ly/18wfXq - I have these and love them.  They are easy on and off when wet (important).  I need to be able to walk in all w	"yabb.ly/18wfXq - I have these and love them.  They are easy on and off when wet (important).  I need to be able to walk in all weather for the dog, so i use them from fall to spring (live in Boston). They are great in the rain and snow and are very comfortable."		Marmot! Quality for price is unmatched.  I like their style and colors too.  They have a lot of cool colors like Arc'teryx but f	"Marmot! Quality for price is unmatched.  I like their style and colors too.  They have a lot of cool colors like Arc'teryx but for half the cost.  I used to work at REI in college and have seen my fair share of jackets, they always seemed to be the best value.  Some jackets can be overly or under technical.  Marmot seems to have found a nice mix.  Good for an around the town jacket that can double as a ski/snowboard jacket but doesn't need to get you up Rainer. There is a Marmot store in Bellevue on NE 8th and Bellevue way or REI is always a great choice too.  Hope this helps!"		"Wordpress, but if you don't know what you're doing, your site will get hacked.  Wordpress is not maintenance free, plugins need "	"Wordpress, but if you don't know what you're doing, your site will get hacked.  Wordpress is not maintenance free, plugins need to be updated often weekly, the foundation program needs to be updated monthly usually, and the site should be monitored constantly.You need to keep it updated, backed up, and need to know how themes affect functionality and what functionality you need.  You also need to know how to speed it up for your visitors, which plugins will do what you need (like contact forms), how to create special areas if you need them, how to incorporate ecommerce if you need it, etc.It may be worth consulting with a developer to get their insight.  Paying someone $1,500 / year for maintenance (for them to backup and maintain your site's back end so it doesn't get hacked) and $2,500-$5,000 for development of a secure, custom, and monitored site can be worth it.  Once your site is hacked it's hard to restore it properly.If you have a business, any web design / development is a business write off as a normal business expense, keep that in mind.  And if you pay for cheap when you first do it you'll pay again in six months or a year.  Your website represents your business ... if you pay for cheap or free that's how you'll look.I've been doing media work for 15 years and my clients range from individuals to Fortune 50 companies.  I offer all my clients the ability to spread their payments over 12 months so they can afford a safe, secure, easy to manage, and reputable site that represents them accurately to their customers.  Most companies won't offer that, they just want to get your money and run.  Find someone who wants your business to succeed and will recommend things accordingly -- not just stuff to get more money."		I have a fitbit and really like it overall. The difference is in the amount of storage the boxes have -- the"	"There are two basic models: a 4GB version, and a 250GB version. The difference is in the amount of storage the boxes have -- the 4GB is enough for save files for games, but I'd really recommend springing for the 250GB. There are a lot of free demos and quality downloadable games on XBLA that will quickly eat up the 4GB of space. There are expansion hard drives you can buy but they are expensive ($120 retail for a 250GB drive) and stick out of the USB slots on the XBOX like a sore thumb.4GB is $199 base, and the $250GB is $299 base price. There are a TON of bundles available that will save you a few bucks compared to buying all the parts separately. The savings are usually pretty even between the bundles, so my recommendation would be to take a look at them online and in-stores and see which ones fit your family's needs the best. If you're set on getting the Kinect for dancing games, for example, the Kinect bundle will do you better than getting the one with shooter games that may be inappropriate age-wise for your son.The 360 is a great platform for Netflix streaming. If you're going to do a lot of watching-only activities you should consider picking up the TV remote: yabb.ly/33iZTR. It's nice to have TV power, XBOX controls, and volume all wrapped up into one device so you don't have to power on and off the controllers.Accessories for the XBOX are a bit pricier than the Wii but I think you'll get a lot of value from the system.  Also the video quality is passable if you have an older TV, but the improvement is very noticeable if you use the HDMI connection with a digital/HD capable television."		"Whoops the link for the remote got broken when I copied and pasted, here it is again:  http://www.amazon.com/Xbox-360-Media-Remo"	"Whoops the link for the remote got broken when I copied and pasted, here it is again:  http://www.amazon.com/Xbox-360-Media-Remote/dp/B005FMLZQQ/ref=sr_1_cc_1?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1351794056&sr=1-1-catcorr&keywords=xbox+remote"		I agree with Shan. I've synched it on my iPhone, iPad and  laptop with OS Mt. Lion. (I haven't tried any of the others.) I've got the 1Password extension uploaded to Chrome & Safari, and have it generate long complicated passwords with random characters for my most sensitive logins.I've also added the contents of my wallet and my husbands wallet (i.e. Credit Card info and customer service numbers), including PDFs of our insurance & property records. Came in handy when we were travelling and lost one of our credit cards. I originally set"""	"After 6+ months of extensive research & testing, I decided to purchase a 10 memory foam from an eBay retailer. I originally set out to purchase a (really) firm mattress but after laying on nearly every possible mattress type (sealy, tempur, sleep #, etc.), I felt the memory foam or tempurpedic would offer the best combination of firm comfort."					"I decided to purchase from eBay because the name brand mattresses seemed overpriced, considering they did not develop the foam technology. I used their website to compare features vs. the beds being sold on eBay. It was and still is one of the best decisions I've ever made. I've since helped several (6+) friends with online memory foam  mattress purchases, all to glowing reviews."						"I'll admit, for some there may be drawbacks like the following: "						"1. The mattresses do sleep warm, but I've gotten used to it. Plus, that extra heat comes in handy during the winter and on otherwise cold nights."						2. Memory foam mattresses aren't typically flippable but I rotate mine 2-3 times a year and that has helped immensely.						"3. For some they ""feel"" soft but it's actually the mattress conforming to the exact shape of your body so you sleep flat (or natural). It's a soft on top, firm on the bottom combo. The best of both worlds (in my opinion)."						"I can still recall my first night with the new mattress, waking in the same exact  position I fell asleep in and the feeling of never having felt so rested the following morning."						"Something to remember: the average person spends 1/3rd of their life in bed (sleeping), so you should purchase the best mattress possible every 8-10 years. For me it has made a world of difference. Rarely a morning passes that I wake not feeling rested. No matter what  you decide, find the absolute best mattress technology that suits your needs and don't hesitate to bring that mattress home, no matter the cost (obviously try and find the best deal possible). You'll thank yourself in the long run."""			Weather Underground gives you micro-climate radar displays and readings from anyone with a weather station near you. A	"Apple also just shook up the management and organization structure which should help them get back on track for high quality.  Apple has let themselves move into time-based releases instead of ship-when-it's-done releases, which is unfortunate.  Tim Cook seems to have gotten the message and I have faith that he'll steer the ship back in the right direction.  The Surface is a slick device, but I thought the whole point of Windows 8 was to unify things across all experiences and from my understanding the existing Suface still only runs a fraction of what the rest of the Windows 8 ecosystem is supposed to...so to me that's a big failing on the initial Surface product.  And from my understanding the Surface Pro is going to be pretty spendy.  As Ferd pointed out it really depends on your usage.  Given that you said you're an IT Pro that might skew a recommendation towards a MS product which has more customizability"".  But you also said you want to have all the apps that you've already invested in from iOS.  Honestly a pretty good option to consider is an iPad 2 or a refurb as they're on the cheaper end and you can still get warranty protection on them.  If you want the latest and greatest screen and speed then the newest iPad revision is pretty awesome.  I think with the Surface you're betting on MS getting it right in a big way and having everything play nicely as they advertise.  But Microsoft has a history of putting out platforms and building marketplaces only to abandon them completely.  I think the Surface is still a risky choice right now, although a pretty one."""		"Ok went with Brixens.  They have a great doc Martin look, feel great. I	"Have 2 layers that together with your base shirt will be sufficient for the coldest likely temperature + plus a rain jacket. This is now a Sundance theater and will be pretty cool when it is renovated. I saw Looper there a couple weeks ago and they're a ways away from completing (starting?) the renovations. I saw Good Will Hunting and Fight Club here.The Guild 45th (further west on 45th from The Metro, past I-5). This is a great medium size theater (I think there are 2 or three screens). It has a nice intimate feel to it. I always look for ways to get back to this theater. I say Eyes Wide Shut here.Seven Gables (small indie films 50th & 12th). Very small theater, I think it's only a single screen. This has a very small indie feel to it. I saw American Beauty here.The Varsity (on the Ave south of 45th). I'm not sure if this one is still around. Anything on the Ave can always have a shady element to it, and this is no exception. I saw Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas here. The Neptune (45th and Brooklyn). Huge, one screen theater. Great for a summer blockbuster. I saw several movies here, but I can't remember what they were.The HUB (on campus). There were always cheap, good movies playing in the theater in the HUB. Not sure if it's still around. I saw Jim Gaffigan there, but that wasn't a movie. I think I saw There's Something About Mary here."		Yes you can do the keys. Some other regions of reds and whites you want to try are California, Washington, France, Spain, Italy, Argentina, Australia, South Africa.i'm not a big one on having to match food and wine. i go back to the advice above. drink what you like. you may find it more interesting to follow your own pallate than the conventional wisdom""."					"enjoy!"""			"wait guys... dyson, it totally rocks!!! my 3yr even knows how to use it and every time after dinner is done he goes for it and h"	"wait guys... dyson, it totally rocks!!! my 3yr even knows how to use it and every time after dinner is done he goes for it and helps clean up the floor with it. when the car needs some help, we bring it there and gets the job done. it's light, no bag, the rechargeable batteries have been lasting for a reasonable amount of time and it comes with 2 power settings. i bought it about a year ago and have never had issues with it. last but not least, i think it has a cool looking design..."		Interesting. If you want an apartment building or a condo, then agents could assist. Agents ge"	"I think it depends on what you're looking for. If you want an apartment building or a condo, then agents could assist. Agents generally steer you that way since that's what they can get paid on (from the owner)...but they won't show you everything available. If you're looking to rent a house, townhome, or a condo, then you're better off starting with Craigslist (and other sites that you will gather as you go through Craigslist). I ended up getting a 3/3.5 townhome in Ballard for less than some friends are paying for their 2/2 condo or apt. However, agents do help in giving context to the areas....but then again, that's what Yabbly could also help with!(Condos were mentioned for both since agents do have access to some condos, but not all...depends on the owner)"		Only other comment I will add is that you shouldn't assume what a retailer won't be able to resell. It's plugged into a generator panel which is hard-wired into the standard electrica	"I have a gas generator in a housing outside. It's plugged into a generator panel which is hard-wired into the standard electrical panel. If the power goes out I can run the furnace fan, refrigerators and some selective lighting throughout the house. It will run for about 24-hours on 5 gallons of gas.If I didn't have the generator panel hard wired in I probably wouldn't have bought the generator as its not nearly as useful if you have to run extension cords into it."		@MLodish where did u end up going?	@MLodish where did u end up going?		"If there is a chance of power outage in your area, the few hundred investment might be worthwhile. I did not have a generator, but did have the foll"	"After the Kentucky ice storm a few years ago, I was without power for 27 days. I did not have a generator, but did have the following which made it bearable: An indoor gas heater that connected to the propane cylinders used for grills, oil lamps, a radio with batteries, two gas cooking burners that screw onto the small cans of gas, a solar panel with connectors I could use to recharge phones, large pots that could be used for heating water. I have since added a crucial piece of equipment that quickly disappeared off the shelves...a coffee pot that can be used on a cook stove.Something else that people don't think about...during major power outages, we become a cash only society...keep a reasonable amount set aside."		I aggree with Roberto also. Could be more significant, and the only way to know is to get the detailed diagnostic code.  If you don't have a way to do that yourself (very very few folks do), then a trip to someone who has the diagnostic gear needed is a good idea.  Better safe than sorry."		"My car's maintenance light goes off every 4,000 or 5,000 miles as a reminder to change my oil. Super cheap, and you can serve it over ice with a twist of lime.  No"""	"An awesome white wine is New Age"" which is from Argentina. Super cheap, and you can serve it over ice with a twist of lime.  Not traditional but it is one of the most refreshing whites I've ever had w/o being overly fruity.  I think your price range is totally fine for finding good wines.  If you're trying to get into reds but find a Cab is too strong for your pallet try a lighter wine like a Merlot...or a Malbec.  You can get some really good Malbecs for about $10USD that are flavorful but not too powerful--something you can pair or just drink alone.  "					I agree with all the above advice about just try things and go with what you like--I have an extensive wine collection full of $30-100 bottles but my go-to is almost always a $10-12 wine..You can find some really great tasting stuff that you can drink without feeling like you spent a ton of money--but that doesn't taste like Carlo Rossi either.  						"Another area to explore is Rose.  It's kind of more of a summer wine but if you get the Sangiovesse (?)-based ones you can get some good fruit flavor without being syrupy, and also without committing to the heaviness of a full red.  "						I find that normal Chardonnays tend to be too buttery for me--if that's the case for you seek out ones done in steel instead of oak.						"Eastern Washington wineries also offer some unique grapes at affordable prices.  Check out Caterina, Cave B, Townshend, and Lonesome Canary.  My favorite higher-dollar wines come from Silverado Vineyards and Cosentino Wineries out of California."""			"Very neat Chris, I was looking at these and have been super tempted by the geek factor. The COE is very competitive - demandi	"The summer camps are not too hard core. They are designed to accommodate all skill levels. The COE is very competitive - demanding both physically and mentally. My kid loves it, but probably not for everyone.My philosophy with my kids and sports (or really any activity, musical instrument, etc) is that the better they are at it, the more they'll enjoy it. So, we try to find things they like and then push them a little bit to work hard at it and get better. I figure if you're going to do a thing, do it well or do something else.Coerver is definitely for kids who want to work hard to get significantly better at soccer. To get started though, I would recommend getting the kids into your local recreational league. When we lived in Seattle, my oldest played for the Woodland Soccer Club: http://woodlandsoccer.org. And when they were younger, both boys played at Lil' Kickers: http://www.arenasports.net/lil-kickers-overview."		"Having owned all of them, Xbox seems to be the best all around all-in-on game and media center. What the industry calls Qualified, Mid Qualified and Non-Qualified.  So depending if the card is debit or a rewards card or a corporate card you will be charged a different rate and transaction charge. That's just how the system works. Make sure you know the pricing for each tier of pricing.On top of that, there are also end of day batch charges, monthly minimums, annual fees and cancellation charges.  If you need to use cc's on your shopping cart, that can be an additional monthly charge and transaction fee.What I have seen is that banks take advantage of their relationships and usually have worse rates than online merchant banks.The easy answer is if you plan on charging over $10k a month, shop around.  Anything less, go with PayPal as Deb suggested."		I LoveToHate and even I stay out of political discussions. I'm happy to take follow up questi	"I actually moved from Boston to Singapore back in 1999 for a job opportunity for a few years. I'm happy to take follow up questions but here's some thoughts off the top of my head.1. It's hot. Really hot. Like on the equator, high humidity, etc. So you just need to mentally prepare yourself for that (the good news is everywhere is air conditioned).2. You'll be find with english only. Some cabbies are harder than others but everyone knows the english names of major locations.3. The food is amazing. Make sure you hit all the hawker centers and food courts -- do not be one of those expats who only eats at Taco Bell and McD's ;-)4. Travel. Try to explore Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, etc. These are all weekend trips.5. Live near the shopping district so you won't need a car and have access to taxis and subway.Overall I liked it a lot (actually met my wife there!). The main thing I missed was the lack of political discourse but since we just had an election here, you're probably all set for now :-) #quiet"		"If those jeans hold special memories for you, bring them over to Adam Tailoring & Alterations on 206 S Jackson St.  He's the bes"	"If those jeans hold special memories for you, bring them over to Adam Tailoring & Alterations on 206 S Jackson St.  He's the best, and most affordable, go-to tailor in the area."		Awesome reco. Here are a few things to note...I have 2 wireless signals in my house, 1 old-school (legacy) up to 2.4ghz, and the other broadcasting at only 5ghz. This thing was able to connect to the 5ghz signal! That was a nice surprise. Also, the screen is very crisp and the colors are brilliant. The navigation leaves something to be desired, but in fairness, I haven't really tinkered with that too much so it may be possible to do some customizing there. The only real bummer so far is that you can't play back movies (e.g. .m4v) that you upload to it, even if you bought the DVD. It seems that the only way to acquire movies for it is to buy them (again) so unless I find a way around this (not likely), I won't be using it much for movies. They should have something like Apple's itunes that you can use to transfer media that you own. I can upload movies to my iPhone4 but not this thing. If anyone knows of a way to do this, please weigh in and let me know. Just got back from my sister's wedding. Oct to Feb is monsoon se"	"I'm from Singapore and have been living in US for 10 years. Just got back from my sister's wedding. Oct to Feb is monsoon season so there are limited diving trip available in Malaysia. However, if you can make it out to Thailand, Krabi island is known for good diving site. When in Singapore:1.) It's a multi-racial country, so you can experience different food. Indian, Malay, Chinese, Paranakan, Indonesia and fusion. Hawker center or coffee shop is a great place to go for everyday affordable and decent food (entree S$3-5). Food court is mostly air-conditioned but cost more ($5-10). 2.) You can basically get to almost anywhere by either bus or subway or both, using pre-paid tap card. When going up escalator, stand to your left, unless you are in a hurry. It's rude to block the right side of the escalator. If you are taking a cab, it could cost easily $10 for 15-20 min travel time. Peak hours surcharge can double the fare, especially If you are going to the city, there are some other charges (ERP) as well. It's not a stroller friendly city if you are commuting by subway or bus. When travelling in cab, there is no car seat provided so if you are safety conscious, you may want to rent a car while you are there. 3.) Sometime it's not uncommon to hear people using English, Mandarin and dialect all in one sentence. Mostly commonly used local sland is singlish. Just add la or lo to the end of the sentence. I'm going to be late la. When someone says not bad"", it means pretty good. When someone says ""very good"", it means extremely good. It's ok to address cab driver or bus driver as Uncle or Aunty but just make sure that you are using it appropriately (not on someone younger, 20's)"					"4.) Nice places to visit include Sentosa Island, Garden by the Bay, Marina Sand Bay Water show (evening), Singapore flyer, Zoo, Jurong Bird Park and the Water Park."						yabb.ly/1Xiz6j			yabb.ly/qFlBwJ			yabb.ly/WpW2vC			( yabb.ly/ba1sUb)						"5.) You can usually find a neighborhood pool quite easily unless you are living in the city. They have much bigger neighborhood swimming facility (toddler, adult and Olympic pool) all in one place than in Seattle. "						"6.) It's a really hot and humid county, so dress light. The exchange rate is around US$1 to S$1.2-$1.3. It's also pretty safe country and people are willing to help with direction. So, feel free to ask. Thats my favorite. Durian price can range from as little as 50 cents to nearly a hundred dollar per kg. Make sure to go with a local friend so that you will not be overcharged. Once durian is opened, the fruit stall owner expects you to pay for it. So dont let them open it unless you really want it. Make sure the seller weigh the durians before you agree to ""test"" the durian. Always try the first durian before ordering more. "						5. If you're looking to process credit cards in person, you might consider looking at Square (www"	"It really depends on your needs.  If you're looking to process credit cards in person, you might consider looking at Square (www.square.com).  If you're just starting off and have low volume, PayPal is a good way to go.  PayPal's fees will eventually eat you up as your volume increases and you'll need to consider other alternatives.  As with any business, higher volumes mean lower prices.The nice thing about starting with PayPal is that many people prefer it even if you have other options available, so you can just add on an additional processor when your volume grows.  PayPal also allows international purchasers more easily than some merchant processors.On thing to keep in mind is that PayPal has very strict policies on following their policies so you'll want to carefully review their terms of service and respond to any customer complaints quickly.  PayPal has a bit of a bad reputation for just shutting off merchants with little warning.  I'd make a habit of sweeping your money out of PayPal and into your bank account frequently to avoid them freezing any funds."		"I found the iPad to be the best childrens console.  I have a 2 (almost 3) year old, and the intuitive touch screen makes for a g"	"I found the iPad to be the best childrens console.  I have a 2 (almost 3) year old, and the intuitive touch screen makes for a great user experience.  The number of apps is staggering, and most of them are very cheap.  Especially given the amount of time they will be played, even 2 dollars makes for a great value.One downside is that it is too easy for them to click an add, or get into an app that you don't want them to be in."		In most vehicles in my experience a steady maintenance light doesn't indicate an immediately serious problem.  If it flashes the	"In most vehicles in my experience a steady maintenance light doesn't indicate an immediately serious problem.  If it flashes then you have a more urgent situation.    You can also reset this light yourself pretty easily (just Google your model year and reset maintenance light.""  It usually involves holding down a button while turning your key.   The good news here is that if it's a real fault it will come back on.     In fair disclosure, I'm not a mechanic but with three kids who abuse their vehicles I've gone through a lot of this kind of thing!"""		Are you a contract developer or an employee? All stories should be defined in such a way that when it is ""done"" its value can be displayed."		"Make sure that you don't ever move stories backwards in the queue.  Part of kanban is to discourage too much thrashing, and it is important to keep items in the queue where they were abandonded to get an idea of what is happening.  "			"Any issue that is found with a story that is ""done"" and has been demoed should be tracked as a bug and as a separate story."			"Make sure that your process matches what your process *IS* not what you want it to be.  Once you get kanban around the way you currently work, you can then gently guide the process toward the direction you want."			Be careful with your WIP limits roughly between 1.5x - 2x the number of engineers is a good starting point.			"JIRA green hopper is the tool that I used when managing this.  Although, make sure that whichever tool you use to manage stories is easily visible and modifiable."						"If this is helpful at all, let me know.  There are a few other challenges groups experience when switching over."""			"Hi Kembo:  Here's my 2 cents based on the info in this yabble.1) I think it never hurts to get additional streams of income "	"Hi Kembo:  Here's my 2 cents based on the info in this yabble.1) I think it never hurts to get additional streams of income so long as you're prepared to accept the tradeoffs in terms of your personal and family time since it will be mostly evening and weekend work.2) Starting an agency (versus just taking on one-person projects from time to time) is a much bigger deal since you'll need to invest time in sales and account management and employee management.  If this isn't something you're prepared to do, I'd stick with being an independent contractor on the side but not try and create an agency"" per se."					"3) Be really careful about not violating any non-compete agreements as well as not letting your day job's work quality suffer.  If you lose your primary job because of your side job, you might be even less financially stable than before!"""			"We had a great time in San Diego back in September of 2009. Don't share a computer"	"Be very, very careful to use nothing from your primary employer for anything but work for that employer.  Don't share a computer, a reimbursed internet connection, etc.  Typically your work for a regular employer is a work made for hire"", and if you use any asset they provide or compensate you for, it belongs to them unless there is a written contract saying otherwise."					"Also be very clear about what your employment contract states - are you allowed to ""moonlight""?  As Tom says, if you don't inform your current employer and they find out, you could put the larger income stream at risk.  And it's a lot harder to get a job when you aren't currently employed."						"Have you considered either taking courses (Cousera is great!) or otherwise picking up new skills that would get you a better, higher paying job for your primary job? Our son started at around 3.5 and we had him on it for almost a year but recently stopped doing it because w	"Agree with Steven.  Our son started at around 3.5 and we had him on it for almost a year but recently stopped doing it because we found the lessons to be very mechanical and rote and he wasn't really learning to read as much as perform these mechanical tasks.He is also a very physically active kid so getting him to sit still at the table for long periods of time doing these exercises was really hard for him and us.  We have since moved to a new approach which has been vastly more effective.  We created our own flashcards with each letter of the alphabet (took scrap paper, drew them, he colored them) and now I make words with the cards and he tries to sound it out.  We try to make it fun so as an example, we start at the bottom of the steps and each time he gets a word right, we move his dinosaur up one level until he reaches the top so he can eat the sheep.  We're now moving to having him write"" words by me saying a word and he finds the right cards to write it in order to unlock stars for his toy fund, etc."""		"Not sure as we're not beer drinkers. My parents were pretty adamant about me finishing a set number of sheets	"I tore through a lot of Kumon math worksheets as a kid. My parents were pretty adamant about me finishing a set number of sheets before going to play. It was rote.. and brute force. I hated every minute of it growing up.. but in retrospect.. I appreciated it. It doesn't help you learn new concepts.. but it's great practice once you understand them. I don't think kids get enough time to master the skills once they understand them. Since a lot of math is built upon previous foundational  knowledge not having mastery of a previous skill makes it more difficult to understand what you're trying to learn now. Kumon helped me get the mastery part down."		"As an audiophile, I'll quote the usual audiophile reaction to that: friends don't let friends buy Bose [except those quieting h"""	"As an audiophile, I'll quote the usual audiophile reaction to that: friends don't let friends buy Bose [except those quieting headphones]""."					"Seriously, they're a triumph of marketing over quality. I know their commercials are corny but their staff actually knows what they're t	"I found it worth the trip to go to Video Only.  I know their commercials are corny but their staff actually knows what they're talking about and lots of times their deals are pretty close to what you'll get at Best Buy.  Furthermore, they actually run the right high-quality HD signals and such to the TVs so you get a true comparison.  Lots of times the signal they're running to the TVs at Best Buy or Fred Meyer are split fifty ways and degraded so you can't really compare the picture quality.  I initially went there thinking I'd just do my research but ended up purchasing through them (the Bellevue store).  And for me, you can do a ton of research but you'll end up finding that TV X is better at this one feature and TV Y is better at another feature--but in this case seeing really is believing.  I actually purchased a TV that wasn't on my initial list because to *me* it looked the best and worked for my living room."		"Jason-I bought my last TV from the Video Only in Bellevue and was really happy with not only their product knowledge, but also"	"Jason-I bought my last TV from the Video Only in Bellevue and was really happy with not only their product knowledge, but also their ability to work with me on price as well. New generation "	"For me, it would depend on where I would be positioning the TV, which media I would be using it for and budget.  New generation Plasma's do not suffer from burn-in like first gen, and offer some really crisp blacks and color.  They are great for movies, but can suffer from reflective glare due to the glass screens.  LCD's are great all around and have a matte screen which reduces the glare significantly.  They have improved their contrast ratio and though not as crisp, they offer nearly the same picture reproductions as Plasmas do.  They also offer a great response time, which is perfect for gaming on them.  They are also slimmer (LED TV's can be too thin, if such a thing can be said) than Plasmas as well.I prefer Plasma TV's if only because I find the Panasonic VT series to offer great 3D reproduction."		"yes, the only casino/hotels they'll be going into will be mandalay (shark reef), mgm (lions) and vdara (staying there because it"	"yes, the only casino/hotels they'll be going into will be mandalay (shark reef), mgm (lions) and vdara (staying there because it's a smokeless/casinoless hotel with kitchens and washer/dryers and it's next to bellagio/noodles). Personally, I'd not put anything there.  Skydrive is very convenient, but there are indications of a basic security hole deep in the authorization processes in Hotmail / Passport / etc. that SkyDrive relies on for authentication.  I use that for some small things that I'm not concerned about.  There are too many people who've had Hotmail compromised who use very strong passwords for me to trust that.For security I'd pick GDrive or Box, depending on your preference for big vs small companies."		"This is a really tough area for radio reception.  Multipath is pandemic on FM bands, and AM stations are generally given such di"	"This is a really tough area for radio reception.  Multipath is pandemic on FM bands, and AM stations are generally given such directional patterns that signals are tough to keep strong as you drive around - the patterns were laid out long before the population density got to where it is."		"My Galaxy 3 is on VZW, I get near zero reception at home, while AT&T on my iPhone 5 is 3 bars. Getting from answering a question back to Trending is not a smooth transition.  If I answer a question for someone, I would like to go back to List of Trends at the place where I left off.    The thing I have noticed is the need to start getting people with similar profiles together.  Answering randomly for people to get them on your Karma list won't get your questions answered.  If your question is drowned out by the on-slaught of incoming questions from the world, you will likely not get your questions addressed.  Wouldn't it also be cool to be able to aim a question at certain people you know or groups you have created?  Is there an API soon? I still absolutely love the case but may end up	"Note that the white case continues to become light blue more and more each day.  I still absolutely love the case but may end up going for a different color at some point (maybe blue!?)--they only had black and white at the Verizon store.On another note--this particular case, and likely many others, will not work with the Dock to Lightning connector.  The case has two cross-bars that go between the mic, Lightning port, and speaker on the bottom for added strength.  The Dock to Lightning connector wants to be flush against the bottom of your phone. This is something to consider when buying cases in general I'm finding if you still want to use old accessories like speaker docks.  I found a work-around by exchanging the connector for the one that includes a few inches of cablehttp://store.apple.com/us/product/MD824ZM/A/lightning-to-30-pin-adapter-02-m?fnode=45Which suckily is $10 more, but lets me plug in to all my old stuff without having to take the case off my phone.  Just something to be aware of when case and cable shopping.  Maybe I can save someone a 2nd trip to the Apple Store."		"I believe my friend just used DriveSavers http://www.drivesaversdatarecovery.com...he got back nearly all of his data of"	"I believe my friend just used DriveSavers http://www.drivesaversdatarecovery.com...he got back nearly all of his data off a RAID array but it costs him over $2K. Its not bigger or bulkier than our iphone	"We bought  an Olympus Tough TG-820 12 MP iHS Shock & Waterproof Blue Digital Camera .  Its not bigger or bulkier than our iphones so you don't feel like you're hauling a big camera around.  I upgraded the memory card and can now store 2000 pictures on there.  We also have an older Canon Digital Rebel SLR.  Honestly, the picture quality of the Olympus Tough is better, way more megapixels and sensors, but you create better photos with the Canon because you can use optical zoom lenses.  And the biggest issue - imperceptible shutter delay on the Canon, slight delays on the Olympus.  You have kids.  Those delays drove me crazy when our kids were little.  The Canon's aren't bad, but if you are waiting for the exact moment take a picture, and you end up missing it due to delay, that's very frustration.  The other advantage to the Canon is you don't get the red eye issues which just seem unavoidable in small point and shoots.  If you're not going to be hauling the camera around a lot, I'd go online and find a used Canon body - they are readily available for around $300, and then get a small multipurpose lens (35-105) also widely available as used lenses for about $100. In the end, I think the red eye issue and the shutter delay issue rule out point and shoot"" cameras if you're primary purpose is take pictures of your daughter.  But if you need a camera which can go in a purse or a pocket, and have software to fix the red eyes when that does happen, those little cameras like the Olympus Tough series are very convenient and easy to use. Their refurbished products are just as good as new and you pay less.  Buy directly from them and you still get the warranty, etc.  And I recommend getting the extended warranty (like SquareTrade, though Apple has gotten smart and is offering their own comparable product).If you want something small just for word processing and viewing the internet though, honestly, go with a little Netbook and get a nice 24 display.  You'll pay around $200 for the netbook and $150 for the display and $30 for an external DVD burner/reader. Both protect the phone completely and handle drops and splashes of water.Also - if you don't already have it, get the extended warranty from either Apple or SquareTrade so you can get a new iPhone for $50 if anything happens to yours.Make sure to Google the case to find the cheapest price though as they can range greatly. Viruses however would c"	"totobobo claims their mask traps particles down to 0.3 microns, which is enough to block most bacteria.  Viruses however would consider that an enormous hole, as they're 0.01 micron typically.  That would be like a hole 180 feet in diameter for a six foot tall person.  As far as pollution goes, take a look at this chart, especially the bottom two rows: http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/particle-sizes-d_934.htmlAs you can see tobacco smoke, rosin smoke, and combustion products go down to 0.01 microns, the same size as the virus particle - that mask would not block those at all.My guess is it's probably a help for larger particulates.  But blocking a gas like CO?  Not a chance.  CO2 is 0.00065 microns, CO would be smaller than that.  That mask would be irrelevant.  Think about it - if it could block CO, it would block O2 pretty well too.  That would not be healthy would it?"		I tend to think corporate donors are basically marketers. If she's indoor then I'd say don't wo"	"Hi Marita, I think this highly depends on whether your cat is an outdoor or an indoor cat. If she's indoor then I'd say don't worry about getting an insurance as long as she's getting vaccinated, getting her regular checkups, exercising on a daily basis and you're picking the best diet for her (ie. wet food instead of hard food). However, if she's outdoor (and a very active cat) you may want to look into some options since she will be more exposed to common but dangerous viruses to cats, such as feline leukemia virus (FeLV). I rescued my indoor cat and he's been with us for over 1 year without insurance. We take him to the vet on a regular basis and he's quite healthy."		@Scottywazzu - I don't think I knew about the Cyber Monday deal. I think I'm going to go with the Fire HD. Another factor to consider is her age, if she's older and you believe that she will likely need some type of treatment in the future, then pet insurance might be a good idea (providing that you read all the fine print per Tom's comment). And in addition to the basic coverage, I also pay a little more for some coverage on basic wellness.  I did this sin"	"I use VPI.  And in addition to the basic coverage, I also pay a little more for some coverage on basic wellness.  I did this since my dog was 12 weeks old.  Insurance is prob one of the few things you purchase, hoping that you don't actually have to use it.  My initial thought process was that I didn't want to have to focus on the financial aspect in case something serious were to happen to my dog.  One of those low probability but big impact kind of situations.  My dog is only 4.5 years old and has had one ER incident but you would be surprised what just one incident could cost you in bills (easily a few thousand).  I'm not sure about a cat and how costly typical vet bills are where you live but I have been reimbursed in excess of what I pay annually for pet insurance (approx $400 annually).  In the year that we had to take him to the ER, insurance helped to cover a major portion of the expenses.  Also, double check but if you wait until the pet is older, the annual premium will probably be higher.  They factor the age of the pet when calculating the premium."		"As for my reimbursement experience, my vet will submit the claim for me directly to VPI.  VPI then emails me as soon as they rec"	"As for my reimbursement experience, my vet will submit the claim for me directly to VPI.  VPI then emails me as soon as they receive the claim and I usually get the check within a couple of weeks.  I have also been very late in submitting claims (before I knew my vet would do this for me) and VPI honored all the claims.  It's pretty clear what is covered and how much you get reimbursed.  I wouldn't count on insurance to cover basic wellness visits, more for unexpected things that happen with your pet."		Take advantage of your staff and board. What happens if my house burns down you may ask? They have a number of different types of cloud storage solutions that would likely better accomodate your 200GB+ space requirements.  Go to the URL above and click on the AWS Products & Solutions"" pull-down menu and you'll see what I mean.  Depending on the type of storage you opt for it could be a mere fraction of the price of the consumer services...after all, the consumer services are built on AWS and they need to make some money!"""		"I have an iPad3 and Nexus 7, and distinctly prefer the Nexus 7 for its size and convenience. BUT...the batter life on the iPad is much better and the bigger screen is nice when you want to see more.I would recommed that for kids especially, the $200 Nexus 7 would be a better purchase than a $500+ iPad - especially considering it sounds like you're already familiar and invested in the Android ecosystem."		"I have the iPad3 and recently aquired a Nexus 7. "					The HD Hero2 right now is being blown out at Costco and other retailers as GoPro just released the Hero3--but for an 8 year old the features of the Hero2 should be just fine.  Here's why I think it would be good:						*  Very aggressively priced			*  Uses standard SD cards (so no proprietary memory cards)			*  Cheap and plentiful accessories available at numerous retailers			*  Very high quality video (Hero3 is even better...Hero2 is not awesome in low-light but great everywhere else)			*  Practically indestructible			*  Super easy to use - only 2 buttons						"I don't know if the 8 year old is a boy or a girl but I could think of tons of useful situations for both where a small, lightweight, super durable camera would be awesome.  These things take abuse and keep on going.  The included waterproof housing turns your bathtub into an underwater video stage and is great for summer days at the pool or beach.  Their mounting systems work with helmets and bikes so your kid can become an outdoor adventure videographer in minutes.  The wide-angle feature lets them make hip looking videos.  It charges via USB so you can plug into any computer or standard USB charger for home or the car and top up the battery.  And additional batteries are cheap.  "						If your kid starts to get advanced there are ways to hook up external mics and accessories.  You can also link numerous cameras together with the WiFi BacPac (built-in on the Hero3) and control them with an iPhone.  If you drop them (I do and I'm 30...I can only imagine what an 8 year old could do to a camera) you can pretty much assume the camera will be just fine.  The cameras can do high speed frame rates for slow motion video.						"I haven't played too much with the software that came with it since I've already got video editing software, but it seems to be decent.  The only real drawback is that out of the box there's no LCD screen--that's an add on which may be necessary depending on what kind of filming your kid likes.  But if it's going to be strapped to a helmet or your bike you don't really need a screen.  I bought one but only use it about half the time."""			"Everyone, let's flood tom's inbox!" So, if a member who responds similarly to me responded to a thread since I last logged in, then I see that thread when I next log in.The second thought is to make the experience of giving Yabbly personalization information fun. So, instead of thinking about putting a bunch of checkboxes under the account settings, think about some kind of game, some kind of beautiful visual interactive experience, where it is fun to play with, organize, trim, and add to the themes/nodes of my Yabbly experience.For a simple analogy, check out areyouahuman.com, a company my friend started that took the painful experience of entering data into a captcha and turned into a fun game. For an example off the top of my head, imagine a simple game where the top themes of my thread appear as colorful balls moving slowly around a space and I have to grab the balls and put them into three different bins that say Love It"", ""Hate It"", ""Don't Care"". Or, to play on the Owl theme, maybe they are owls that are flying around and I need to grab them and put them into nests or on limbs of a tree."					"Not saying any of those ideas are Yabtabulous, but you get the general idea. If personalization is going to be key, and I think it will, make that an experience in itself."""			Kindle Paperwhite has the same front-lit display technology (which reduces glare typical of a computer screen) as a regular Kind	"Kindle Paperwhite has the same front-lit display technology (which reduces glare typical of a computer screen) as a regular Kindle. "	"A few things to note:- It was sold in the US in 73-74, then discontinued here because it couldn't meet 1975 safety standards.  Those standards have gotten way stricter since then, so it's nowhere near as safe as anything current- It's based on the Karmann Ghia floorpan.  I had a Ghia, and had to have the seat rails removed and re-welded further back to be able to drive it (I was barely 6' tall at the time).- It's air-cooled, a great thing in warmer climates, no worries about radiator fluids- You could get run over getting up to speed, the 0-60 doesn't quite match Thor.  I saw one site saying 23 seconds to get to 60.- Top speed is 68mph- New it was rated at 21mpg."		"And if you want one anyway just because:- make sure compression is very similar on all four cylinders.  If not, you have at le"	"And if you want one anyway just because:- make sure compression is very similar on all four cylinders.  If not, you have at least a head gasket problem, perhaps a full rebuild in your future- The usual things: brake lining, evenness of tire wear (indicator of alignment and/or inflation pressure problems), play in steering, fade in repeated braking, shocks, clutch.- Crash history.  Those frames are pretty easily bent compared to some.- Watertight - can it go through a car wash and not leak?  Check around doors etc."		My brother had a Mini Cooper and I found it to be very nice and suprisingly spaceous. I usually desire to have something like this on hand to send to the dozen or so friends who want to purchase a ""good camera"" for the holidays.  The main idea is that the camera has very little to do with photography compared to learning technique.  I like to recommend some books on photography and then suggest a more advanced compact camera instead.  These cameras are more affordable, have most of the same features as an SLR (manual control, RAW file format, etc), and are far easier to carry around than an SLR + lenses.  People then usually ignore this recommendation and spend a ton of money an SLR that they won't use after a few months because it's too big to carry around and the pictures aren't any better than those they take with their current camera because they never actually tried to learn photography.  "					"I better stop my ranting.  If you've weighed the pros and cons and decided that you want an SLR, I can look for some good deals on kits that would suit you well, depending on your budget.  Alternatively, I can recommend some pretty awesome advanced compacts that would be an excellent stepping stone to an SLR.  The one I have is used constantly, while the SLRs now sit in the house except for paid work."""""			Bose is overpriced because they are over-marketed.  The only product of theirs that is decent is their noise-canceling headphone	"Bose is overpriced because they are over-marketed.  The only product of theirs that is decent is their noise-canceling headphones.I just wanted to chime in with another vote for Sonos.  It's expensive-ish, but super-high quality, well-polished software that runs on many devices, supports a ton of services, and sounds great.  If you ever expand your music footprint their ability to synchronize music cross-player is top notch (so, no echo sound from timing issues).It took me a while to buy a sonos system because of the cost (I am very cheap), but I have zero regrets.  It's that good.  It honestly feels like an apple product in how it just works."		"For airport trips I usually used Eastside for Hire (they're not just for the eastside, in spite of the name).They tended to "	"For airport trips I usually used Eastside for Hire (they're not just for the eastside, in spite of the name).They tended to be less expensive than other services, showed up reliably, and were decent.  They were cheaper than shared-van shuttles."		I just put some vinyl planks in my studio this past week and will be putting it in my basement over the concrete and throughout 	"I just put some vinyl planks in my studio this past week and will be putting it in my basement over the concrete and throughout the rest of the house because I like it that much after now seeing it installed and using it.I've used carpet tiles and currently have indoor/outdoor carpet in my basement.  The indoor/outdoor is okay if you like carpet, but put a moisture resistant pad under it otherwise it's just really hard - you'll want to vacuum very regularly because stuff just goes right through it.Carpet tiles are a huge waste of time, they slide all over, they're a real pain, especially on uneven floor.  They're really only good for small spaces unless you glue them down. Now the vinyl planks, they lay easily and quickly, are water resistant and okay in slightly damp conditions (like in a basement), have padding built in, float on top of the floor so they're easy to remove or even just to remove a piece (no glue needed).  The go down quickly, can be cut with a box cutter and snapped to trim or cut with scissors for around doors and such.I'm very happy with mine.  I chose vinyl specifically so it would float over an original hard wood floor to protect it, and because I can use bleach and other chemicals on it without worrying that it's going to cause problems.  My floor wasn't perfectly even but with how easy these cut, it was a breeze to put down.I got mine from Home Depot (order it online) for $1.89/sq ft (order 20% more than you need simply because of how they are set up to accommodate one another when piecing -- and I strongly recommend staggering the layout. I didn't in this room (see the picture) and while it looks good, staggered would have looked a little bit better.Vinyl planks also give you the ability to do a really fancy lighter or darker colored border around a room then fill it in with a different color wood"" in the center.  You can do quite a bit with it.  And the stuff I used is guaranteed for 25 years.  "					"If you're doing a big space, consider having Home Depot install it for you, I think it's around $400 to install through them.  Otherwise expect about two hours per 100 sq ft for one person to do it."						You'll need a straight edge and a box cutter and that's it.						"This is the one I used: http://www.homedepot.com/Flooring-Vinyl-Flooring-Resilient-Flooring-Resilient-Vinyl-Planks/h_d1/N-5yc1vZbzjz/R-202885477/h_d2/ProductDisplay?catalogId=10053&langId=-1&storeId=10051#.ULu2p4c8CSo"""			"You might want to consider Airbnb, you can rent it out by the day/night, week, month, or longer." They also offer a discount for homeschooling languages.http://www.rosettastone.com/homeschoolAnd that way you can all learn the language(s) at once.  It's also worth considering sign language if you can -- too few people know it and it's a very valuable skill as an adult.For language value, in the US, you'll want: English, Spanish, French, Mandarin, Cantonese, Japanese, Italian, German -- in that order (for popularity and usefulness around the world).  If you want to give them the option to go into government work then add Arabic."		"Even Target and Walmart have some really nice curtain selections, all the supplies in one place without breaking the bank and sh"	"Even Target and Walmart have some really nice curtain selections, all the supplies in one place without breaking the bank and she can take them with her easily."		I have used Snapfish for years. This naming system is pretty universal throughout King County, though some cities (Kirkland, Kent, others) make their own number schemes on street and avenue names."		"About D3 - it's great, and hugely needed especially in northern latitudes.  For dosing, consider that one hour of full-body expo"	"About D3 - it's great, and hugely needed especially in northern latitudes.  For dosing, consider that one hour of full-body exposure to sun at the equator yields about 20,000 units of D3 production by your skin.    Most multivitamins might have 400 units, far less than a useful amount.  Some supplements are 50,000 units, that's 2-1/2 hours of exposure at the equator.  I'm no doctor, but even that amount could well be safe for an average or larger male."		"If you have a Play-It-Again sports store in your area, they are a great place to pick up lightly used equipment. What I'd suggest is a dual-band route such as Tom posted above, set up the 2.5GHz transmitter as one network,"	"I assume 802.11n?  What I'd suggest is a dual-band route such as Tom posted above, set up the 2.5GHz transmitter as one network, with is 11n with b/g fallback.  Put anything that can't do pure 802.11n on there (11n disappears as soon as anything on its network is 802.11b or g).  Then put the pure 11n equipment on the 5Ghz network to get max speed from them."		"I have several non-profit clients and I often counsel them on fundraising.  The best way to get a solid commitment from orga"	"I have several non-profit clients and I often counsel them on fundraising.  The best way to get a solid commitment from organizations is to first create a one page professionally designed (front and back if necessary) very visual (not too text heavy) document that shows what your organization does, what the event is, when it is, who the audience will be, what your past events have raised, what they've funded, what you hope to make at this event, what you hope to fund with the proceeds from this event, how the person's company will be advertised, what previous people have donated and what they've raised with those donations, and what you can give them in return (if you're at 501(c)3 you should be giving them a donation receipt for their donation in kind).Make sure contact information is on the document with a direct contact not voice mail, not an answering service, not the main line -- a direct line to the person who can say yes or no to a donation.  You do not want to waste the business owner's time.  Make sure to include a final date for their response and state that you will call them to follow up three days before that date (and do it).  To do that you'll need their business card and the contact person's name.  This provides accountability and gives you a nice contact list for future events.Then you take that printed document to as many businesses as you can -- IN PERSON -- and you give them a quick one to two minute statement about what you're doing and that you don't want to take up too much of their time now so if they can review and let you know what they are willing to donate (don't push them to donate on the spot) -- for a donation receipt in kind (this is big, if you are a 501(c)3 this can help you immensely) -- and that you'll follow up with them.  Leave them with the original printout and one extra (or ... make it so the one you give them has a piece that can be torn off and shared with someone else) because business owners know business owners and ask them to share your information with another business that they believe would be interested and would benefit from your event.While I know someone mentioned direct mail, it's expensive and most solicitations sent out that way get tossed in the garbage immediately.  If you show up in person, smiling, with a good attitude and importantly an attitude of Your time is valuable and I will leave this with you and contact you later."" you're more likely to both be remembered and actually get a donation."					"And once you do get a donation, follow up with the companies that donated and tell them thank you, include a couple of photos of the event or a link to a page or blog entry on your company site that documents the event.  Tell them how much you raised so they know what they did was right and so they have a bit of incentive to do it again and get others to do it as well."						"If you need any additional info about any of the above let me know.  This is stuff I do for a living. :)"""			"Make sure to take many photos of it and any certification you have of it and keep those in a safe place, most people forget to d"	"Make sure to take many photos of it and any certification you have of it and keep those in a safe place, most people forget to document what they have insured.  Including serial numbers, original receipts, etc."		Sort of.  My understanding is that Americans can go legally if a part of a pre-arranged tour.  Still feels like more trouble tha	Sort of. That is usually a property developers"	"if you wanted to buy something in your 20s, I would look at a home / investment property.  That is usually a property developers would love to buy, but the permitting process will take longer than they can afford.  As a young home owner you can live there instead of renting, go through the permitting process, and then sell the property as a permitted development at a substantial gain.  Way better than just buying a house to live in.  This is how I bought most of my homes in my 20s.  I am surprised more people don't do this in their 20s"		"Unless you want to get into having multiple rental properties, and becoming a pro at managing rentals ... being a landlord can v"	"Unless you want to get into having multiple rental properties, and becoming a pro at managing rentals ... being a landlord can very expensive.  Also the learning curve can cost you.  I would sell, take the equity, and either buy or rent the home you need for your family.  It is always nice to be the owner of the home, but there is no shame in renting, until you can buy the home you can afford and meets your needs."		Thx Kiel!  Here's a related Yabbly.
