But there are certain things that point and shoots don't do.  You can't throw on a (rea	"I agree with Jim on many of the points.  But there are certain things that point and shoots don't do.  You can't throw on a (real) telephoto or macro lens.  You can't always do the diverse shots you want.  You can't take 3-10 frames per second on some cameras (though more point-and-shoots are offering this).  And while you can adjust some controls you don't have complete control with a point-and-shoot (I don't know of any point and shoots that would let you put them on a tripod and take a super long starry night exposure for instance).  But as Jim pointed out--most folks don't ever take their SLR out of automatic mode, and those photos do turn out just as crappy as the compact cameras on auto.It's not so much about the camera but what you want to do with it.  I believe a recent cover of Time magazine was shot by a professional photographer using an iPhone 4S--so it really depends on the situation and what you're doing.I think Canon makes some of the best and most feature-packed point-and-shoot cameras.  They use common storage cards so you're not locked into proprietery stuff (remember the Sony MemoryStick?).  And you can often override certain things and play with exposure and such.  It's most important though to know how to take a good picture.  It doesn't matter if you're using an iPhone, a compact camera, or an SLR--if for instance you're at a concert and you take a photo and think you should use a flash, regardless of the device you're using you won't see much other than the blown out heads of the people immediately in front of you.  But I've seen people do it time and again with all levels of camera.One of the best photos I've ever taken was with a disposable 35mm camera--but I had a pretty good idea that I'd be able to get the shot I wanted based on my photograph knowledge which had been developed over years of taking lots of BAD photos and understanding what it takes to make a GOOD photo.  Knowing where to focus, how to focus, and how to override the auto controls to get what you want makes all the difference in the world--regardless of what camera you're using.  That being said, for SLRs I'm Nikon through and through.  They just make really durable and reliable equipment and have great lenses.  I second the suggestion to go to Glazer's downtown.  Their staff is super knowledgeable and in my experience doesn't automatically steer you towards any one product."		Cheap is stuff like elance or odesk. But if u want a more accountable option I'd find a local web development agency.	Cheap is stuff like elance or odesk. But if u want a more accountable option I'd find a local web development agency.		Recent Yabble: http://yabbly.com/m/question/935/recommend-a-photo-book-printing-service	Recent Yabble: http://yabbly.com/m/question/935/recommend-a-photo-book-printing-service		Got a good web development agency you can recommend in Seattle? If the direction comes after the street name, the stre"	"If the direction comes before the street name, the street runs east/west. If the direction comes after the street name, the street runs north/south. The directions are determined by using downtown as the center of a 3 x 3 grid.Therefore you can come to the intersection of 10th Ave E (North/South) and E Pike St (East/West), but you'll be hard pressed to intersect NE University Ave with W 45th St.That is also why you can start on Pike and end up on E Pike, without changing streets. As you move from downtown to Capitol Hill the East"" designation kicks in. But since the street runs East to West, it's ""E Pike"" and not ""Pike E."""""		This thread should get u started but feel free to ask follow ups below.  http://yabbly.com/question/965/i-am-looking-for-an-air-	This thread should get u started but feel free to ask follow ups below.  http://yabbly.com/question/965/i-am-looking-for-an-air-cleaner-that-is-good-at-removing-particle-pollen-mold-dust-and-chemical-fumes-allergens-from-the-air		My suggestion - get the Roku that uses a gig e-net hard wired connection and use that.  It'll work better than most wireless ins	"My suggestion - get the Roku that uses a gig e-net hard wired connection and use that.  It'll work better than most wireless installations.Staying wireless there are lots of things to point out here.  First, wireless is maxed at 54Mbps (802.11g), 72Mbps (802.11n in a realistic 2.4GHz world), or 150Mbps (802.11n in 5GHz).So the first question is: is your router capable of 150Mbps in 802.11n in the 5Ghz band?  Many are not, they're 2.4G only.  Using a wireless hotspot, I've only seen those in 2.4GHz.Second question: how many base stations can you see from your computer, do you see lots of networks?  If so, there's a lot of interference.  You're unlikely to get max bandwidth for anything over wireless.Since streaming HD movies takes a pretty good amount of bandwidth, how will Sprint react when you have tens of gigabytes per month?  Unlimited"" rarely really means that, I'd bet Sprint would be unhappy."					"Only the Roku 2 XS has an Ethernet port on it, so for future-proofing, I'd get that regardless."						"And according to some sites, the Roku 2's don't even support the 5GHz channel."""			"I really like Tom Bihn, http://www.tombihn.com/CTGY/laptop_bags.htmlI have one for my iPad (original) and my MBAir (13).""" This is a lot of money for a substantial ring.)"						"Ideally you want to find the stone size that looks good on your future partner's ring.  I went ring shopping with my future fiance before buying a ring, she tried things on, and we got a good idea that way.  She liked stones of one size more than bigger stones -- they just started to look worse and gaudy after a certain size."						Try to get GIA certified diamonds	 they're more strict than EGL (and a small lie on a certificate could seriously mean thousands of dollars in price difference.)					"I'd also highly recommend NOT paying for things you can't see.  At some point, clarity and color differences are invisible to the naked eye -- but still cost a HUGE premium."						"I purchased an I-Clarity / VS1.  These are sort of on the border: they're in the invisible to naked-eye territory, but just barely.  Looking at the ring: it sparkles, it's absolutely clear, and basically looks perfect.  Yet if I had bought a ring with higher clarity / 'less' color it would have been over double the price and would have looked exactly the same to the naked eye."						"One other tip: often diamonds just under an 'even' number (ie, 1.23 carats versus 1.25) are less expensive, because people do searches for 1.25+ carats.  So, if you figure out a size, sometimes going a tiny bit smaller saves you several hundred dollars."""			"I may very well go with the Cruising"" option. There's nothing like spending the weekend driving around and looking for free pil"""	"I may very well go with the Cruising"" option. There's nothing like spending the weekend driving around and looking for free pile of woods. :) """		"Thanks for the feedback, @rschroed. I can't tell you how much we appreciate it!"	"Thanks for the feedback, @rschroed. I can't tell you how much we appreciate it!"		LoopNet (www.loopnet.com) is probably a good place to start. Some girls prefer quality over size and some want the biggest stone within the budget and care less ab	"Depends on the recipient. Some girls prefer quality over size and some want the biggest stone within the budget and care less about color or inclusions. Some girls want the diamond and what it represents to them. Some are horrified by the price and would rather get an alternative stone. These days it can be anything you want, sapphire, moissanite, opal, I have even seen pearl. It depends on what she likes since it will be her wearing the ring a llong, long time.       Whatever you choose, make sure SHE loves it. I would prob stay away from pearl or fragile stones. There are so many colored stones available. Heat treated or oiled will cost less than untreated colored stones.  If you go the diamond route, using a dealer will cost almost half of going retail. Look at the rappaport diamond reports for the current going rate for diamonds so you don't pay too much of a mark up. "		LOL.  Thx Roy!	LOL.  Thx Roy!		"Wow, super helpful!  Thanks so much!" That's a real lasting symbol of your life together -- designing what you'll both wear every day.Then work together with a local artisan or online artisan to create a ring together that you'll both love and that you'll both have a hand in designing.  This is much more unique and much more of an heirloom than a generic diamond ring.A really good example of this is this artist on Etsy: http://www.etsy.com/shop/WingedLion?ref=seller_infoHe makes absolutely incredible rings that anyone would adore.  Especially because it wouldn't be like every other engagement/wedding ring.  And he can do an engagement and wedding band set, and even design your ring.Something like that would make anyone the center of attention because it will be something completely unique.Remember to insure whatever you get."		"Super Flexible File Synchronizer (Syncovery) - $60 for one professional package that will install on any OS (Windows, Mac, Linux"	"Super Flexible File Synchronizer (Syncovery) - $60 for one professional package that will install on any OS (Windows, Mac, Linux) and you can install on multiple machines.It's a mouthful but it is the best file synchronizing and file backup system I've found.  CNet agrees: http://download.cnet.com/Syncovery/3000-2242_4-10204345.htmlI even wrote an article about it: http://daniellefavreau.com/2011/04/backing-up-your-data/They offer a free 30 day trial, and the 30 day trial wasn't just for 30 days.  It was for 30 uses.  Which ended up being a couple of months for me.  More than enough time to tell me that it was more than worth it to purchase.The software works on Windows machines, Macs, and Linux.  It can also back up or synchronize files from laptops, desktops, external hard drives, flash drives, and even online storage.  It supports various Internet protocols, including FTP, FTPS, SFTP/SSH, WebDAV, SSL, HTTP, and Amazon S3 web storage.  It can even compress or encrypt while backing up.I have profiles set up to copy from my primary 1 TB portable hard drive to three separate external hard drives: another 1 TB portable hard drive (Mac compatible), and two 2 TB external drives and most recently between several 3 TB hard drives and several computers.  I even have it installed on all of my machines (Windows, Mac, and Linux) with just the one license so I can keep everything up to date easily.  There are a ton of options you can set with how you want the SFFS to run, an exact mirror, copy from one side to the other, copy from both to both, smart tracking, and so much more.I set up the 1 TB > 1 TB to only sync a single folder (with many sub folders) from left to right and right to left  Ignoring deleted files on the left or right, and asking me when files are the same date but different size.  I have it set to run in attended mode so I can approve the updates if anything is to be deleted or over written. It looks at both sides, builds a file list, compares the dates/times, and sizes, then runs the program.And as it runs it tells you if files are larger than what theyll replace so you choose if they get over written or not (this is crucial if you have a corrupt file on your primary and are backing it up and you might over write a good copy).The 1 TB > 2 TB is set to copy from left to right and never delete anything on the right, but move files and folders if they are moved on the left.I ran the profiles for the duration of the trial and had absolutely no issues.  Everything copied perfectly.  And those backups came in handy a few times when one of my external 1 TB drives became partially corrupt from being detached incorrectly.Restoring files to the corrupt drive was simple, just connect, and run the profile.  So don't think of this as just a way to send data to S3 but also a way to back up everything locally and remotely.  Which you should always do since even S3 isn't fool proof.So whats the cost of all of this convenience? $60.  Thats it.  A one-time fee and you have a file backup program that will work for any and every situation you could possibly encounter.  And on all of your machines.I get nothing for recommending this software.  Try it for 30 days.  You have nothing to lose, and you may even save your data."		I have the same trouble with my 5 yr. old daughter versus her 6 yr. old brother.  A giant floor puzzle.  A bracelet maker. I'm also quite a foodie...  heres the rub as they say he	"It's your lucky day- I am the unofficial London rep of Yabbly ! ha ha ! I'm also quite a foodie...  heres the rub as they say here - if you want cool/ trendy to hang in - I dont think they will be hole in the wall places.. and if they are the food wont be any good- the vibe n the scene might be but def not the food....  my first recommendation if this is ur first time to Lon is NOT to convert the prices into USD ! it will just depress you - accept that you will be paying in Pounds what you would pay in Dollar.. once you stop converting everytime you look at the menu - the more enjoyable the trip will be :) it took me 2 years to achieve this state of zen i'm referring to ! as far as recommendations.. cool ones that arent Michelin Star rated are unfort all American type restaurants so the appeal to you might be lost - but if ur missing the good ol USA and want to pay double the price- I would recommend Pit Cue for BBQ - (BBQ is pretty new in this town) .. this place is tiny and theres usually a 1 hour wait - as you wud expect for a hole in the wall they dont take reserv :( www.pittcue.co.uk/another great place is Burgers and Lobster www.burgerandlobster.com/thats all they serve.. the best Lobster in Lon bc they ship them from Maine / NovaScotia.. the local lobsters just arent as meaty or sweet as the ones from Maine. As far as the hip n trendy restaurants - these are mostly pan asian or sushi - its been like this for 10 years... for good people watching.. in house DJs... check out Nobu (Berkeley), Hakkasan (Berkeley - ground floor near the main bar), Zuma - you can eat the bar and I people watch - I can go on and on .. but why dont u let me know what cuisine you fancy the most and I can try to point you in the right direction."		Simplenote (www.simple-note.appspot.com) is...well simple. Do you happen to know what kind she likes?  She might just like how pearls look without caring you much about details. In which case look for pearls with a nice sheen/glow and smooth finish. But if she is really into them then perhaps find a mikimoto if there is one near you. The salespeople are generally very helpful and willing to share their knowledge.  I'm not necessarily suggesting you buy from there, just get some info from the salespeople. "		Thx all I'm gonna test drive these options and circle back with learnings. I went to Tahiti for my honeymoon and the hotel water taxi took us onshore one day .. coincidentally you literally needed to walk thru the store to get into town ! funny thing is that we spent over an hour there looking at pearls - if you had asked me this question i prob cud have given you a much more educated answer! but I think the important things to focus on once you've narrowed the color down is to look for the shiny ones ! the ones with a smooth (small look bumpy) finish .. I wud also put them behind a white piece of paper and black piece..  I think also your wife;s skin tone might affect the reflection you're pearl is giving off so something to bear in mind. Mikimotos def have the brand ..but if you ask me - its hard to tell the difference... I got my wife a big strand of small pearls that you could wear in diff lengths - basically you could wrap it around your neck in different configurations .. I think turned out to be a pretty versatile gift ... happy hunting .. my last piece of advice - dont get caught up on how the damn pearl was made and how talented the grafer needs to be to create that 1 in 99 million perfect pearl ... you buy into this -even if its true -and you will start justifying the crazy costs.. and quite frankly no matter how much you spend on a pearl, you might as well get a diamond... diamond trumps pearl any day... so basically dont spend a lot on them pearls :) (paid for and sponsored by the Diamond Jewellers Association!)"		"@rschroed, we just released a new version with auto-selecting. I do like that it syncs with all my devices.  I didn't like that (at least in t	"I've been using Evernote off and on for awhile.  I do like that it syncs with all my devices.  I didn't like that (at least in the past...not sure now) it couldn't do seemingly simple things like giving me check-lists for a todo.  So I found I had numerous apps for tasks vs. notes.  Maybe that's changed now.  I just downloaded Penultimate and have liked it so far.  I like to doodle and draw and make arrows and circles in my notes.  That's why no matter what I've always gravitated back to the red full-sized Moleskine notebooks.  I am getting this stylus soon though and I hope it'll let me switch to digital:http://adonit.net/product/jot-pro/I have the normal fat-black-tipped stylus, probably from Targus or something that was $15 at Office Depot.  It's too hard to write though with precision I've found.  The Jot Pro is more like an actual pen tip.  My notes in Penultimate looked like I was back in 5th grade again.  I'm lefty and write illegible as it is...this was more like writing with a crayon.  So I'm really hoping that a fine-tipped stylus will change things.  Definitely really interested to hear if you find something that lets you actually move away from the note pad.  I like too that with Penultimate you can change the paper"" style to grids, lines, etc.  And they offer other paper formats (not free of course) for lots of other tasks...I'm going to be using the Music in-app download to tab out new songs for my band.  I won't be able to give an update on the stylus though till after Christmas :)"""		I had a great experience with Ebay. We paid 20% of the appraised value for my engagement ring. I will try my best to describe though it is best to see it in action. The key is to have a good, quick emcee."						"People sit in a circle and you have one person as the ""emcee"" who sits in the middle. The emcee randomly looks at a person (let's call them person A), addresses them by name, and then asks a question, any question. For example, ""Hanna, what did you have for lunch today?"""						"At that point, the person to the left of person A has to respond to the question without A) answering the question or B) asking another question.  AND, person A is not allowed to respond to the question."						"So, the person to the left might say ""The man petted the dog at the park"". If he/she said anything related to food or asked what the emcee had for lunch then he/she would be out of the game for that round."						"But, what also might happen is Hanna may get confused and also respond to the emcee. If Hanna does that she is out of the game for that round."						"If the emcee is good, quick, and funny, then the game moves really fast and people started getting confused easily, responding in ridiculous ways, and so forth."						"The round ends when the last person is left in the circle who has not got out and then that person becomes the emcee."""			Sonicare (ProResults). Agree with Jim about the moist. I got like a $9 coupon off from Costco for their brush head (pack of seve	Sonicare (ProResults). Agree with Jim about the moist. I got like a $9 coupon off from Costco for their brush head (pack of seven $35). Don't throw away Costco direct mail coupon. Sometimes they do have some good deals. 		 Oops sent that by accident!  One of my other fav rest in Lon is also on that street. It's a French steak rest which of course u	" Oops sent that by accident!  One of my other fav rest in Lon is also on that street. It's a French steak rest which of course u won't be able to enjoy but it's called Relais de Venise. They literally only serve steak n chips. No reserv.  There's another hidden gem on that street called Tomoe for great sushi. You will b surrounded by Japanese bizmen so u will know its legit. This is trad no frills sushi. Go downstairs n sit at the bar. For another amazing, Japanese go to Jin Kichi in Hampstead. It's prob 30 min from where u r but amazing grill. Get the grilled mackerel. I liked it so much I had it again for dessert. U will smell like a robata grill but sooo worth it. U need to book n once again rec the bar.  Old school cheap n cheerful Indian u have to go to Lahore Kebab House. The one near Aldgate. No ambience what so ever. They refurb a few yrs ago n now it looks like a college caf. It's sterile as anything but the food is damn good n dirt cheap. For high end Indian go to Amaya in Knightsbridge. Get the scallops. Oops forgot abt a great Fish n Chips right next to Woodlands, Golden Hind has been a fav for years.                     Another awesome Food Street that many people overlook is Charlotte St in Bloomsbury area. It has every cruisine. For one of my fav Fancy French places go to Pied a terre. Really good n not stuffy. Groupon always has deals. Across the street is Roka. If ur alone eat downstairs. It's more of a lounge but u can get the same menu. Same owners as Zuma. The thing about Charlotte St is that most of the people u meet will actually b from Central Lon. If u stick in Piccadilly u will find a lot of people who tech live in London but typically they've come into town for a big night out. If you like real n i mean authentic Szechuan- only one place for you Bar Shu. U can't do this on ur own or u will end up only getting a couple of dishes. Their sig dish is the sliced fish fillets ( remember in Lon the T ain't silent!) in boiling oil with dried Szechuan pepper corns n chilis. My other fav dish is their marinated cockles- basically clam. Good Eating !!!"		Hmm for some reason my first part didn't get posted. There's so much information, it's definit"	"I proposed to my now-fiancee back in late August and went through this exact exercise. There's so much information, it's definitely easy to feel overwhelmed. I went from deciding I was going to propose to having a ring custom made in my hand within 28 days. It was an insane process, here's what I can offer up as suggestions.1. Depending on your future fiancee's taste, that will dictate your price point. Eg: if she does not wear a lot of jewelry, you likely will not want to get a ridiculous carat size for the stone; if her hands are larger than average or she is really tall, you probably want to err on the side of caution and get a larger carat. I found that the 2 months salary rule of thumb was too costly and would likely get me something too flashy for my lady.2. Start doing your shopping in person to get a better gauge for pricing, stone sizes, differences in the 4 C's"" and overall style that you think she'd like. I ended up using local shops (both big box and small boutique) to get some first hand experience with what was more important to me before..."					3. Purchase your stone online. I ended up finding a really good deal on BlueNile and had it overnighted to me to meet my tight schedule. The value you get on that site (cannot vouch for others) far surpasses what most local stores will provide for you. Even the boutique dealer I ended up having custom craft the band explicitly told me to check on BlueNile for a stone.						"A decent amount of what I said is somewhat repeated in the previous posts already, just throwing in my $.02. I've since learned that having it on your wrist is a constant reminder to be more active since it's so easy to track your progress.  The things I know the Fitbit excels at which I wish the Fuel had was the elevation, sleep, and more granular data reporting.  I'm guessing my ideal will be Fuel 2.0 but in the meantime, I've found the Fuel to be a bit of a game changer for my lifestyle and habits!"		I bought this lunch container for my 4 year old son. It's easy for him to open and it has a divider that is flexible for you to 	"I bought this lunch container for my 4 year old son. It's easy for him to open and it has a divider that is flexible for you to move around if you need to separate fruit and crackers. They are pretty durable and i have been using it for 6 months. Just put in the dishwasher and the stains will come off easily. The stainless steel can be separated from the plastic piece if you need to use the lunch container for two kids to share food. I have tried out a few and find this the most toddler friendly. The only down side is that it's not big so if your child eats alot, you may have to get two of these, which is what i did. It's also not microwavable.http://www.amazon.com/Fresh-Baby-Easy-Divided-Green/dp/B004PVUHGC/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1355116379&sr=8-4&keywords=toddler+lunch+container"		"Joe, this is amazing, I'm thinking ill have to go back soon to check out all the places you mentioned. hey, knowing you know"	"Joe, this is amazing, I'm thinking ill have to go back soon to check out all the places you mentioned. hey, knowing you know so well the scene, what is your take on this other places...  hakkaan, bar botanist, samba nope, Zuma, bar at the Canought hotel, bar at Savoy hotel, wright brothers, Amaya, le petite Maison... got these names from some other friends. putting them here so we can perhaps keep this as a nicely curated list for yabblers. cheers!"		"Hey Mike, is it still available? I will try to give you my take on the ones you've heard of - hakkaan, I think you're prob talking about the Chinese restaurant - Hakkasan - This place is great for Chinese food -close to Cantonese style .. let me put it this way - it looks more like a club but it was authentic enough that I brought my mom there (ps - I'm Chinese). I recommended the newer one to you which is off of Berkeley Sq.. but the orig is just as good... bar botanist, This is not really a place you go for food...its a restaurant that has a nice bar scene on Sloane Sq.. so end up meeting lots of expats, bankers and trust fund children of the above ..still a great scene but I think its more of a place in the summer when it spill out into the sidewalk and all of the windows are openned up ... samba nope, dont know this one Zuma,definitely a scene -its one of my orig recommendations.. sit at the bar and you will meet bankers and a lot of Mid East Tourists and American Tourists.. it can be slightly a slightly older crowd ..  bar at the Canought hotel, think the barman got some award .. but its prob more for pre dinner drinks. unless ur eating in the neighborhood dont think you need to make  a special trip just to have a drink at this bar.bar at Savoy hotel,Savoy has a great name but seems to attract American tourists from Ohio. enuff said. wright brothers, dont know.Amaya,this is the high end Indian I recommended.  le petite Maisondecent food -but you go more  for the buzz...Ok as far as your last question-  casual dinner and which one for a dressy/more formal one? unfort this really depends on what you're looking for and what cuisine you're really looking for - I know you're a veggie and dont want American .. so I'm going to have to give you a couple For Casual - I assume you're from the North West.. so I have to go with some mad good Indian and authentic Szechuan - stuff that I dont think the NW is necc known for - (sorry peoples)..  so hit up Lahore Kebab and Bar Shu..for a more formal dinner - I'm also going with something I dont think the NW has in spades.. nuevo french .. The Square, Pied a Terre,and for Seafood let me add to my fav seafood - J Sheekey !! best best seafood.. its part of Caprice Grp which also owns Scotts which is another Seafood restaurant - but I 've always found Scotts to be too old for me (I'm 42) and a bit sterile .. for some reason celebs still like to be seen there .. but what do they know about food !! ha hah ... To be J Sheekey is to Lon as Le Bernadin is to NY... world  class fish restaurants.. J sheekey is much more low key and relaxed by the way ,, feels more like ur dining in a pub. ok - I gots to go back to my day job.. Joe"		Made in Italy...great pizzas in Chelsea	Made in Italy...great pizzas in Chelsea		DONE! Mine is an MBP4,1 (http://www.everymac.com/systems/apple/macbook_pro/specs/macbook-pro-core-2-duo-2.5-17-early-2008-penryn-specs.html) and a lot of people on various forums are having the same problem.  So if you've got a 2008-2009 MBP or a 2010 MBA, think twice before going to ML.My other boxes love ML."		"Make sure you visit the glow worm caves, they're pretty neat. http://www.waitomo.com/waitomo-glowworm-caves.aspx I also enjo"	"Make sure you visit the glow worm caves, they're pretty neat. http://www.waitomo.com/waitomo-glowworm-caves.aspx I also enjoyed a quick jaunt to Waiheke Island where they have a few nice vineyards and it's a quick hop skip and a jump away from Auckland. http://waiheke.aucklandnz.com/ Ride the dunes on a wakeboard on 90 mile beach. They become part of our x-mas decor and the kids (and adults) love to look at them over and over.  Nearly everyone send a paper photo card now so it is worth the effort.  Vipin - I'm against the e-card. I will also uploaded to FB closer to x-mas for the FB friends who don't make it on my snail mail list.  If you want to go totally electronic I'd suggest a quick web video or slide show over a more static e-card. You can do that by connecting it, then right click on My Computer and choose Manage"" then go to the ""Storage"" selection on the left and click on ""Disk Management"" and let us know if you see the drive in there (you should be able to recognize it by its size in GB).  If you see it, post in here and state what it says ""Healthy"" is what you want to see."					"If you don't see it, then there may be something wrong with either the drive or your machine."						If a tower desktop system you can remove the hard drive from the external case and mount it inside the tower desktop as a secondary drive.  I'd check Craig's List for someone that can do that for you.  It's a pretty simple thing (you can even check local colleges for someone who can do this).						"Before you do any of that though, you may want to see if you can connect it to someone else's computer to make sure the drive still works.  Any machine should be able to recognize it."""			"Copywriting and SEO Copywriting are two different things. You have to wait 30-60 minutes afte"	"I own several beautiful natural pearl jewelry pieces, and honestly -- they are a huge pain.  You have to wait 30-60 minutes after putting any lotions, makeup, cream, etc. on the skin before putting the pearls on, after you wear them you have to clean each individual pearl before putting them back into a padded case for storage.  They lose their luster easily if they encounter sweat, perfume, hair products, etc. so make sure she has all she needs to keep and store her pearls once you gift her a beautiful set.And, that said, they are beautiful, and I understand why your wife would like them.  I have many sets of real pearls, though I wear my fake pearls much more often because they just don't require such delicate care.I recommend, rather than go through all the trouble mentioned above to start her collection, and without going broke, in all seriousness, visit Kohls right now (kohls.com) and search for freshwater cultured pearls"".  I recommend the convertible necklaces because she can wear them several different ways or a multistrand necklace because it looks quite nice compared to the more traditional single strand -- and get a pair of earrings to go with the necklace.  "					Right now you'll pay around $80-150 instead of $200-400 for a gorgeous pearl necklace and around $35-80 for a pair of earrings (or do a convertible necklace and a pendant/earring set to give her two beautiful options).						"If she likes those -- and wears them often -- then get into buying her other pearls and spending more if you really want to.  But honestly, speaking as someone who knows more than most people about jewelry (hell, I'm even writing a book on it) ... real pearls are a huge pain to wear and care for.  Don't spend more than you really need to on her first piece and try to go for cultured pearls."""			"You don't just need a programmer to build a website, you need a team of people: a graphic designer, a web designer, a web develo"	"You don't just need a programmer to build a website, you need a team of people: a graphic designer, a web designer, a web developer, an interactivity developer / programmer, a usability expert, a marketing expert, etc.While one person can do all of that -- it's rare.As for cost, it depends what you want.  I've billed out sites from $3,500 to $150,000 depending on the client and their requirements (most CMS sites run around $5,000-7,500 plus maintenance and hosting).Keep in mind that your job doesn't end when the site launches, you need maintenance on a daily/weekly/monthly basis.  You have to learn how to upload new content and media, how to update some of the code unless you have maintenance to cover it.  You need to know how to track if your site is doing well, if it's searchable, if you're using a CMS (like Wordpress) you need to know if it's up to date and protected against hackers.  If you are offering online services or sales then that's a whole new realm of work and capabilities.There's no easy answer to this, and don't limit yourself to people in your immediate area.  I have clients around the world, Canada, Japan, Brazil, USA, Australia, etc. and I'm in the middle of the US (I own a multimedia company and have been in the industry for 15 years).Location is irrelevant these days, find someone who can do what you need and more importantly, who can support it long term.Make sure they are insured (if they screw up your content and you have to honor a deal to clients, they should be liable for it), ideally members of something like the Better Business Bureau so you can research their complaint history if they have one, ask them to provide current references to clients you can actually talk to, and to show you live sites that they've done.Do your homework -- in the tech world you get what you pay for.  If you want to see some sample hourly rates you can find mine at http://discretiondesigns.com/about/rates/Note that mine reflect the level of my skills and my staff.  We design and develop multimedia for clients from individuals to Fortune 50 companies -- and we guarantee our work.  Few companies will actually do that.That should give you a bit of a foundation for where to start."		"I see them both as mild spam, honestly. Live music, zipline over the street and you can't get better play at cheap table games anywhere else in Vegas.2) If you like exotic cars, check out Exotics Racing out at Las Vegas Motor Speedway, you can drive cars most of us will never even get to see in our lifetime.  Last time I did it, I drove the Lambo Superleggera and several friends drove the Ferrari 458 Italia.  It's fairly expensive but a serious thrill."		"Restaurants! As far as shows, you don't generally go wrong with any of the Cirque shows, and Blue Man Group is also surprisingly entertaining. If you're in the mood for steak and don't mind traveling off the strip Del Frisco's is excellent.  The best meal of my life I had with my wife at Joel Robuchon -- ultra amazing French food.  The smaller/faster/cheaper A'telier is great too but if you can spare the time (and money) the formal sit-down Robuchon is a winner.And on the total other end of the food spectrum, the California hotel in downtown LV has the most legit Hawaiian food this side of the Pacific.  Aloha Specialties, on the second floor of the casino, is somewhere we stop by at least once a trip every year for the past 10 years.  Real good poke, spam musubi, plate lunches, etc.  There is even a Hawaiian style ice cream shop (Lappert's) right next door."		I've not heard of a way to lock the position of apps but you can prevent deletion and a few other things. Both work incredibly"	"I use Udder Cream (walgreens, walmart) for my hands and face and Bag Balm for my feet and sometimes hands.  Both work incredibly well and are made for farmers -- but don't get turned off by that, if you want something that will moisturize and keep your skin amazing use these.  They are both very inexpensive and just try them for a week and you'll see.  I've tried everything from $1 tubes to $50 tubes of cream and ultimately these two are what I always return to.  The Udder Cream soaks in quickly and doesn't leave any greasy feel, the Bag Balm can leave a bit of a residue for a few minutes but it soaks in and stays in and provides a nice protective barrier."		"Good questions. The problem I'm trying to solve is to make it really easy for lots of people to see my current free/busy availa	"Thx Kielnation.  The problem I'm trying to solve is to make it really easy for lots of people to see my current free/busy availability, reserve a slot or a few, for a proposed meeting, have those reserved slots show as busy for the next person looking to schedule, and then inform me of the requests, let me accept or decline, and then add it to my calendar.Doodle does a decent job of this in conjunction with Google calendar (my main calendar) but some people find it confusing, they often mess up the time zones, and it's multiple clicks for me to accept a time and have it added to my calendar.  In fact, every month I miss a meeting because for some reason it didn't add the event to my Google calendar (mostly i think because of the multiple clicks and a poor mobile experience).So my dream solution is for Google Calendar to have an appointment booking feature built in (which I don't think they have).  Second best is a service like Doodle that syncs with Google Calendar but has a frictionless user experience."		"Thx Poom.  It's a fair point.  I think the rub is Latest is completely open so as we grow the community, we'll start to see a wi"	"Thx Poom.  It's a fair point.  I think the rub is Latest is completely open so as we grow the community, we'll start to see a wider range of questions -- some which are really awesome (detailed, specific, lots of context, preferences, and active participation from the original poster) and some less so (vague, not very practical nor thought provoking, etc.)...So having everyone see literally all the posts may be a less enjoyable experience than hitting the Featured list first, browsing Latest, and then maybe looking at a My list (maybe just from Yabblers you follow, from topics you love, or with keywords you've submitted as most important to you).The other point is we may auto-feature MVP Yabblers who have a lot of karma since we assume they'll have great posts and if they need help, it's fair to give their questions some more exposure since they've given so much to the community before.We're still in experimentation mode so very open to ideas here!"		"Hey Zach, I have a few ebooks written by Joanna Weibe that I received with an ebook I bought a while back. Also some old film has gotten brittle, and may require slowing the film chain to get the less pliable sections through without further damage.The more recent and better shape your film is in, the less these concerns are relevant.  I have some 1930-1950 16mm films that have been in the family a long time, two have been transferred, and it's not cheap"		Thank you!	Thank you!		"I like ahava hand cream. More importantly those unsubs	"I have a Nexus 4 and it is a remarkably solid phone at VERY reasonable price - $249 8GB/$299 16GB. More importantly those unsubsidized the prices points for the phone w/o a contract. It currently is only available on T-Mobile and ATT GSM networks.It isn't a 4G"" or ""LTE"" handset - its HSPA+, a step below the network performance of 4G/LTE networks. However my uses are similar to yours, and I haven't felt the phone had fallen short. Moreover, the absence of a 4G/LTE seems to have increased the battery life by 20-30% depending on usage over the previous Nexus handsets."					"Lastly, its unadulterated Android OS, no . If you can connect to a WiFi network at work, d"	"LTE will drain battery faster than other connections with the current chipsets.  If you can connect to a WiFi network at work, do so, it'll help conserve battery.  Try to select one that has JB (Jelly Bean) rather than an older version (Ice Cream Sandwich, Gingerbread, etc.).  JB has two versions, 4.1 and 4.2.  There's a big advantage to 4.2.x, it has measurably better protection against malware built in."		"@Dawn, nope, that's indoor only. Branches of Newtown Savings Bank are located at 39 Main Street, Newtown; 228 South Main Street (Sand Hill Plaza), Newtown; 68 Stony Hill Road (Route 6), Bethel; 211 Greenwood Avenue, Bethel; 99 Federal Road, Brookfield; 30 Main Street, Danbury; 535 Monroe Turnpike, Monroe; 477 Main Street (Route 25), Monroe; 194 Leavenworth Road, Shelton; 815 Bridgeport Avenue, Shelton; 1450 Southford Road, Southbury; 685 Main Street South, Southbury; and 926 White Plains Road, Trumbull.Credit card donations may be made at https://newtown.uwwesternct.org.For more information, please call 800-461-0672."		"If your hands are really dry and cracking, you first need a lotion that has an acid in it (lactic acid) http://amlactin.com/ or "	"If your hands are really dry and cracking, you first need a lotion that has an acid in it (lactic acid) http://amlactin.com/ or (alpha hydroxy) http://www.drugstore.com/eucerin-intensive-repair-extra-enriched-hand-creme-with-buffered-alpha-hydroxy/qxp148952 to bust through the layers of dried skin and then you can use these oil and protective (bag balm) lotions to protect your skin from additional damage."		Jergens makes a good cheap one. Turned off cellular data and wifi on iPhone and didn't open laptop or watch any tv from 	"I took a digital sabbath this weekend.  Turned off cellular data and wifi on iPhone and didn't open laptop or watch any tv from Friday at midnight till Sunday at 3PM (it was originally supposed to be till Monday but I wanted to get a head start on some work).Some tips:1. Of all the screens, the mobile phone is the most soul sucking since you're always on-call"" and even if you're walking the dog, you can get a app notification, email notification, or be tempted to look something up on an app.  Turning the cellular data off was kind of amazing for me.  I'd done that when traveling before but doing it in your hometown takes centerdness to a whole new level (I think my kids liked it too)."					2.  The laptop is something we're glued to so not having that was awesome.						3.  I'm not sure how important it was to cut off my TV time.  I kind of feel like that's relaxation time when you can just sit back and chill.						4.  I think there is a point of declining returns.  I plan on doing this every week but just going from Friday at midnight till Sunday when I wake up versus trying to do an entire weekend.						"5.  I did ""cheat"" by reading a ton this weekend on my Kindle Paperwhite.  I'm not sure if that counts as screen time since it seems so much more cerebral than stuff on your mobile phone or doing email on the laptop.  I may cut off the Kindle as well on the d.sabbath next weekend just to see."						"Overall, a really great exercise in slowing down time and actually focusing on the task at hand versus trying to look at crap on your phone incessantly.  I think the impact on your peace of mind, the ability to focus on the family, and a sense of cleansing are all wins.  "						"Ultimately, it's probably b/c mobile anything is like most things in life -- good in moderation :-)"""			"We have been using the free alternative offered by Microsoft, Microsoft Security Essentials, for a few years, it has been proble"	"We have been using the free alternative offered by Microsoft, Microsoft Security Essentials, for a few years, it has been problem free for us. I have a variety of external monitors for my"	"Some quick questions - what's your big monitor, or, what connections does it take?  I have a variety of external monitors for my MBP.  The Thunderbolt output can drive DVI, double DVI, displayport, or HDMI.  I think it can drive the analog VGA but not certain of that.Second, what printers?  Easier to answer that question with specifics known.For timing on Mac models, http://buyersguide.macrumors.com is a very handy page, it tells you where in each product's life cycle we are.General tip, regardless of what hardware or OS: get lots of RAM.For IE only apps there are several choices:- Run a virtual machine, either with Parallels or VMWare Fusion.  Both work very well, especially if you've got a core i7 chip.- Run Bootcamp, allows you to boot into Windows.  I found Windows 7 was fastest on my iMac, faster than native Dell machines with better specs.- Remote Desktop into a Windows machine not currently in use, run IE there.- Crossover from http://www.codeweavers.com/compatibility/search/?name=internet+explorer&search=appI suggest the last is the easiest in many ways, but get someone with a Mac to try out the sites you need IE on to be sure it works in your exact case."		"Thanks Ferd,Monitor is HP2711x -- after i posted i did see a vga adapter on apple's website, I assume that would workPri"	"Thanks Ferd,Monitor is HP2711x -- after i posted i did see a vga adapter on apple's website, I assume that would workPrinters are a Samsung CLP 315w and HP Laserjet 1536Based on the macrumors page you sent, a new Macbook Pro would be introduced in the next 3-6 months which is good.Re: Ram, yes I would definitely want at least 8, perhaps 16Can I run an iOS app on a MBP? that would actually solve my need for IE. If not ya I could probably figure out a simple enough way.Maybe the next version Macbook Pro will have LTE and touchscreen.Based on this, would you go with the Apple or Win8?"		"The HP2711x will take HDMI and DVI-D, so you're definitely covered there.  Avoid VGA, as it's analog there are more cable and co"	"The HP2711x will take HDMI and DVI-D, so you're definitely covered there.  Avoid VGA, as it's analog there are more cable and connector sensitivities.  Go for HDMI to ease the HDCP (movie copy protection) issue.According to https://discussions.apple.com/thread/4189204?start=0&tstart=0 the CLP 315w is no problem.  And the HP looks fine too (in general Apple's really good at HP printer support).I've got two Macs (iMac, MBP) each with 16G of RAM, it's a nice level to have.Currently iOS apps don't run on OS/X except under emulation as a developer (which for most people means no"").  "					"The Mac approach is the external touchpad rather than a touchscreen, I'd be surprised if they went touchscreen (but I've been proven wrong before for sure!)."						"I personally don't care for the Metro interface.  Back in the late 90's, Microsoft made Windows CE for PDA's and very small computers (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casio_Cassiopeia#Cassiopeia_E-10).   There they tried to take the desktop experience (start button, menu) to the handheld.  This never worked all that well, as the success of Windows Phone 7 showed over the older Windows Mobile 6.5 approach."						"Now Windows 8 is doing a mirror image of that, taking the Mobile presentation to the desktop.  Personally I think the handheld and desktop experiences are fundamentally different, and each deserves its own User Experience.  MS disagrees, so I'm not going to Windows 8.  And I'm keeping my workplace free of Windows 8 for as long as possible, the re-training cost for non-geeks is high and the return is low."						"So based on my biased opinion as outlined above, I'd go Mac."""			"awesome, thanks for all the great advice"	"awesome, thanks for all the great advice"		This is my cheerful Pandora station. http://bit.ly/OYjNMr  Hope this helps! She feels like the iPad is too big and really enjoys being able to hold the Nexus 7 in portrait mode with one hand.  Now I can't get it out of her hands!The only thing I am disappointed in is the battery life.  Had a full charge at 6pm on Friday evening as was at 10% on Monday morning and I wasn't using it heavily at all, maybe the same or less as the iPad and I charge my iPad maybe once a week.I still prefer the iPad, but this definitely has it's place in the house, especially for the gadget lover."		Doodle has come a very long way from when they started and from a UX perspective have gotten much better. I think we can all agree the main appeal here is the coolness factor (which is ultra high).  Of course, it's less carbon (in"	"1.  I think we can all agree the main appeal here is the coolness factor (which is ultra high).  Of course, it's less carbon (indirectly as Ferd points out) than a gas guzzler but no cleaner than a Leaf and probably only slightly better than a Prius.2.  If you accept that #1 is the primary motivator, it just comes down to how badly do you want to be the first one in town in a Tesla S and how redundant is this versus a critical path vehicle for the household.3.  Personally, I think I'd only buy if it was a tertiary car that I could afford to have in the shop for repairs and recalls a couple times a year for a week or two at a time.  Or I'd wait 6 months to see how the first batch performs in the real world.  I am nervous around Jaguars so gotta believe a first gen Tesla sedan choc full of bleeding edge tech could make Apple maps look good ;-)Buying first gen Roku is one thing, worst case scenario you switch to comcast or throw in a DVD.  Having a Tesla S crap out on the way to work seems like a major PITA if not a potential accident.All of that said, if I had a four car garage, already had 2 normal cars, I'd be tempted to get a Tesla but probably not the S base since it's not very fast and I'd expect a Tesla to be more performant so would have to get the 85Kwh model or the Performance model.  Otherwise, it's just a nicer looking Leaf ;-)However, if you're gonna pay $70K for the second-best Tesla S that is still slower than an Evo, and assuming you agree it ought not be a critical path car (you'll have a sedan and SUV as your primaries), why not get a Cayman S...So my answer is it's too early to buy one IMHO unless it's your 3rd or 4th car and you just love the idea of an electric car and are ok with turning down much faster and more reliable alternatives for the same price just because (or more likely because you already have those and are building out a small stable of toys which is totally awesome)..."		"To add to my previous post, an e-card is a good alternative to dealing with the post office when the intended recipient is outsi"	"To add to my previous post, an e-card is a good alternative to dealing with the post office when the intended recipient is outside of the US. For example, it could be the about same travel time from Northgate to Alderwood as it is from Northgate to downtown, depending on time of day/traffic, etc.If you're used to the Nordie Santa though, you may notice that the set-  though nice and inviting- is not as elaborate. But they are always very nice and patient with kiddos, there's a Starbucks kiosk 100 feet away (when my wife and I take our brood, one of us will hold the place in line while the other makes the 'starbucks run'), and you might even save a few bucks off of Seattle Santa pricing. When you're ready for an oil change next"	"Great list @Nathan!One other possibility is worn rings leading to low compression.  When you're ready for an oil change next, check the oil to seen if there's a sheen on it from gas getting into the oil, that would indicate a need for a ring job.  Or you could have the compression tested.Also remember Seattle is in the mandatory Ethanol added region during this season due to the probability of inversions.  Ethanol is a lot less efficient (kcals/mole) than gasoline, thus all of us will get lower mileage this time of year (except Diesel)."		"@Nathan, are you running 32 bit or 64 bit WIndows 7? Don't let the small decisions take up too much time, then you'll feel rushed on larger decisions.2. No matter how frustrated you get at a situation, forgive at the end. It's easier than holding onto any negative feelings that could cloud your thoughts.3. When purchasing items, don't let the idea of having to be the one who has it all"" get to you. Really consider if what your looking to purchase will benefit your life and how long you will use it. Otherwise, if you find you don't need it, but have the income for it, save it instead for something more worthwhile to your life, such as an experience of going somewhere new."""		"Hi Jim, there was a thread a while back here http://yabb.ly/rmSl3R so feel free to take a look and maybe post any follow up ques"	"Hi Jim, there was a thread a while back here http://yabb.ly/rmSl3R so feel free to take a look and maybe post any follow up questions to this thread!"		"Just installed about a week ago, 2nd gen, really nice so far.  Install took maybe 10 minutes plus some touchup paint where the o"	"Just installed about a week ago, 2nd gen, really nice so far.  Install took maybe 10 minutes plus some touchup paint where the old thermostat was bigger than the nest.You can go here http://store.nest.com/#compatibility and they will help you figure out if your system is compatible with the Nest thermostat.The best part so far for us is the ability to control the temp on your iphone or computer.  Setting the schedule and changing it is so easy since it is on your phone or computer, I think I prefer doing that rather than letting the Nest try to figure things out.It will definitely save us energy, and hopefully within a year or so have paid for itself...plus we get to enjoy the convenience benefits.It also detects relative humidity so that is a nice to have.Just like all thermostats, one drawback is they only sense temp in that area of the house...you can get more than one nest  and put them in different areas of the house, but that would get quite expensive.  When bedroom doors are closed at night, this creates variances that would be nice to be able to program rules for...but without a sensor in each room it is not possible.It has been fun checking the current temp and so far I have been checking the energy usage chart each day.One other thing that I can't believe most older thermostats don't have, the Nest allows you to set both the Heating and Cooling temperatures...so  you can say I want the temp to be no lower than 70 but no higher than 76, and Heat or Cool will automatically kick on to make it happen."		"I guess a Volvo is kind of similar (from that part of the world, a bit quirky). The cost of living is famously hi	"I think the San Fran area is just in a class by itself in terms of entrepreneurial resources.  The cost of living is famously high and competition for talent is murderous.  Ultimately, I think the entrepreneurial ecosystem is so strong there that if you had to move some place (ignoring switching costs for you and your family which may be considerable), it's the sun of the tech solar system.After SFO, there's NYC which as you know is considered to be on a roll.  Then you have the second tier.  These places will give you critical mass of investors, lawyers, engineers, product folks, designers, etc.  That's where Seattle, LA, Boston, Chicago, etc. come in to the picture.   WRT to Seattle in particular.  I am quite pleased so far.  You can get a nice house with 4BR's and 3,000 sf that's fairly new and 20 minute drive from downtown for around a $1M.  Public schools in some neighborhoods are considered among the best in the country.  We also have nationally ranked private schools.  Lots of smart people (most literate city in country) and top engineers and business folks recruited from the top grad schools by MSFT, Amazon, Starbucks, etc."		"1. Implementing Getting Things Done philosophy (GTD) remains the best investment in productivity I have made thus far2. The "	"1. Implementing Getting Things Done philosophy (GTD) remains the best investment in productivity I have made thus far2. The book Power of Full Engagement"" recommends taking breaks on a regular basis at an hourly, daily, weekly, year level to maintain peak performance."					3. Lifehacker.com is chock full of incredible time-saving tips. My most recent favorite is a quicker way to peel a hard boiled egg by cracking the ends and blowing it out of its shell.						4. I wear a beard and shave my head not only because it is the only look for my balding head but it also cuts down on shaving and going to the barber. Consider it.						5. Cutting out foods with a high glycemix index (anything processed or with a lot of sugar that breaks down easily) increased my energy levels significantly.						"6. My wife and I have laminated strips of paper with our favorite recipes. Before we head to the store, we grab 3-4 recipes. It makes meal planning easy."						"7. Inspired by the clean and serene interiors in Japan, my wife and I reviewed the ""problem areas"" in our apartment and came up with simple ways to de-clutter and keep it clean without thinking. Goes well with GTD.						"9. SaneBox (free trial)			"Email takes up a considerable amount of time, especially when not managed well. I'm really impressed with how well this application sorts my emails into those I should read now versus those that can wait. It also has some neat features to remind you to follow-up on a sent email if you have not received a response after X [amount of time]. "						2. RescueTime (free)			See how and where you spend your time on the Internet. 						3. SelfControl (free)			"After you identify where you spend an embarrassing amount of unproductive time, use this to block distracting URLs for X [amount of time]. The best part: once you set the timer and block a URL, you CANNOT access it until X [time] has elapsed (though I am sure there are workarounds). "						4. Wunderlist (free)			"I have blown through a lot of to-do apps and methodologies, and finally settled on this one. "						5. Typinator (Mac	 Not free)		"Type faster. I have b	"My rule of thumb for flying toward Asia is ... avoid USA based airlines because the standards of service have dropped. Korean based, Cathay Pacific, Singapore Airlines are a great experience.Flying to Australia ... Just take Virgin Australia.  Economy plus is excellent.  Economy is great."		Thanks Nathan! It's quite inexpensive, good quality, and good support.  http://www.callcentric.com/The only bad"	"I really like Callcentric.  It's quite inexpensive, good quality, and good support.  http://www.callcentric.com/The only bad thing is it's a little tough to understand their plan structures at first.  They sell incoming and outgoing services separately, so you'll need to figure out which two plans work best for you.They're especially good if you don't want a lot of minutes (you will save a *lot* over similar services, like vonage, if you don't use a lot of minutes).  For unlimited plans they're still a bit cheaper, but the difference isn't as huge.Another option is getting ooma.  My mom has it (she uses a lot of minutes) and it's awesome.  You buy the device and from then on you're only responsible for taxes & fees.  Unlimited minutes, you can port your number, etc.  You can see what your monthly cost would be here: https://go.ooma.com/tax_calculator  (For me, it's about $5 a month for unlimited minutes).  Upfront cost is usually between $100-$200, though.I, personally, hate vonage.  They're expensive, their tech support is pretty bad, and lately they've been doing what I consider somewhat misleading marketing ($10 A MONTH! then in tiny print: for the first month then $30 thereafter).  But, basically, you can do a lot better than vonage.FINALLY another option is Google Voice via a special VOIP adapter.  There's this thing called the Obi100 (also the 110).  It hooks through to google voice and gives you, basically, completely free incoming and outgoing minutes through google voice.  It's pretty sharp.  A little trickier to set up than the ooma, but pretty solid.  Lots of good reviews.  http://www.amazon.com/OBi100-Telephone-Adapter-Service-Bridge/dp/B004LO098O/(You can port a number to google voice now, too, so it's possible to use your current number)."		And one more thing: since you're using DSL you might want to ask your phone company about what the cost difference would be for 	"And one more thing: since you're using DSL you might want to ask your phone company about what the cost difference would be for naked DSL"" (aka DSL without phone service).  They might jack up the price significantly, so it's something to take into account."					"(For my mom in Illinois, the price only went up $5 a month.  Not huge considering what 'real' phone service costs these days.)"""			I like gaining access to a new community for advice. For your price range, you can get a great house (even in the city; in the city you'd "	"I'll put in a little bit for Seattle too.  For your price range, you can get a great house (even in the city; in the city you'd get a smaller house/yard but still a nice place).Property taxes are insanely low, thanks to the state constitution capping them at 1% plus levies.  Seriously: my house in Seattle is appraised at 4x the value of my mother's house in Illinois and she pays double the property tax as me.Plus, no state income tax is fantastic.  That is huge, especially if you live in NYC now (between city & state taxes, that's almost 10%).  [And sales tax, one of the primary income sources for the state, isn't much/any higher than NY.]  There have been attempts at passing an income tax but they've failed.  Even the more aggressive ones had tax rates that were at most half of what NY or CA have.The only -- only! -- downside of Seattle is it's depressing as hell.  It's overcast 9 months out of the year -- usually without break -- and that gets old, fast.  I've realized how bad it was even more now that I've moved out (to NYC)...  I love Seattle but worry I won't be able to put up with the dreary days of non-Summer.(Seriously, even if you don't care that much about weather...  it's depressing.)"		"For the singles or newlyweds without kids, I've grown to really like my Dish Drawer dishwasher. The biggest adjustment was getting used to having to have the water turned up all	"I own a property with a tankless water heater. The biggest adjustment was getting used to having to have the water turned up all the way to get hot water. This is because the unit that I have only turned on when the minimum flow requirement had been reached. This is not an issue when taking a shower, but if you want a slow stream of hot water, you've got to turn the flow up all the way, then turn the flow down to your desired flow rate (and eventually you'll have to turn it back up because once the flow drops the heater will stop heating the water).I ended up installing a small local water heater under my kitchen sink to fix this flow-rate problem.I'm not sure this has anything to do with my tankless water heater, but some faucets take a very long time to actually get hot water. I'm pretty sure this is caused by a poor installation.Also, I had issues where my kitchen sink could not even cause a flow to turn on the water heater, so it was actually impossible to get hot water without also turning on the hot water in another faucet. This was fixed by cleaning out the aerator. (The small local water heater also fixes this problem.)In the end, my *feeling* is that tankless water heaters are great, but a relatively new technology and it will be another 10 - 20 years before they're as solid as standard styles. And when I say technology"" I don't just mean the unit itself, I mean installation, expectations, interaction with appliances, etc.."""		We gave University Village a try. I haven't been to other santas so can't compare. It was an hour wait on the Saturday before Ch	"We gave University Village a try. I haven't been to other santas so can't compare. It was an hour wait on the Saturday before Christmas, not as bad as I feared. Santa had a real beard and was mellow. 35 bucks for a single digital photo, and I think about 10 bucks more if you wanted a print. Seemed alright to me."		"alright Yabblers, here it is.... my report from this past weekend in London... first of all big thanks to Joe and Ellie for "	"alright Yabblers, here it is.... my report from this past weekend in London... first of all big thanks to Joe and Ellie for their recommendations, it was one of my best trips ever to London...in general, if you are thinking of hitting any popular or high-end restaurants make a reservation with at least a week in advance if not more. otherwise you will find no tables or only very late ones. i used toptable.com to make most of my reservations. make sure you look a the fine print, most places will charge you a no-fee or late cancelation fee. if this is at a high-end place it could be as much as the cost of a full meal.pubs - my rule, if you are thirsty just walk into the first one you see. grab a pint, it will taste better than trying to find any particular one. most good ones are always busy, so just walk in, order and drink. i stopped by a number of them but never stayed longer than a pint or two before moving on to the next place/activity. friday night, didn't make any reservations as i wasn't sure if jetlag was going to allow me to be operational during the day/night. i stayed in piccadelly and made a reservation to go to Spice Market. this one was not part of the lists but ended up being a good place. the hamachi sashimi was outstanding, the other plates were good but not spectacular. the place is kind of a scene. not only because it is in piccadelly but also at the W hotel. saturday night -  at night, as recommended, made a reservation to go to Hakassan, great place indeed! first impression is of arriving into a clubby restaurant, people dressed up (casual smart as they call it), loud music and blue/green lighting across the place. once you get to your seat they have a long list of cocktails, all very well done. the food was also great and the chef was very good at making sure my food didn't have any of the ingredients i'm allergic to. while i'm sure there are other Cantonese restaurants in the city serving great food, this place is worth if you want to check out its trendiness. before dinner we went for some cocktails at the bar from the Canought Hotel. good place for grabbing a cocktail and transition into a fun night.sunday day/night - i discovered a place with really great lebanese food. it is called the Comptoir and it is in south kensington. super casual, walk-in, great menu. they have tables outside and it is a great area with a bunch of other cafes/restaurants. lunch was great. they also have breakfast and dinner.at night, L'Atellier de Jol, outstanding restaurant. the service is impecable, the attention to detail is phenomenal and the food is just superb. every dish has just the right amount of everything it is supposed to have. they are served at the perfect temperature to be able to eat and enjoy at the moment the food arrives. the list of wines has a wide range of prices and the somelier was really good at helping me pick a wine that was just right for our meal. this place has to be one of the best dinner experiences i've had in my life.monday night - after a day of walking and shopping we stop for some drinks at the bar from Zuma. didn't eat there but the cocktails were very good. the guy behind the bar definitively knew his thing by recommending drinks based on one or two questions like usual preference of drink or fruit you like. he put on a show too while mixing the drinks.at night went to Amaya. very unique experience for indian food. the service and dishes were all great. the tempo for bringing all the food is well timed and allows the enjoyment of every plate without feeling rushed or long waits between dishes. the scallops and the giant shrimp along with a number of veggie dishes were all spectacular.i hope these recommendations will help other Yabblers in their future travels to London!"		"ok, here is one of my favorite ones. one that at least i, didn't put much attention to it until i did... a toaster.right, a "	"ok, here is one of my favorite ones. one that at least i, didn't put much attention to it until i did... a toaster.right, a toaster, what would make me or anyone fall in love with a toaster? think the ability to bring your toast down or up using a servo controlled system that carefully brings your toast up or down. or how about a digital dial to help you with the level of toastiness, or maybe the ability to defrost at the touch of a botton. ok, but the best feature that won me is one of the most intuitive one of all. it is call a bit more"". for all of those like me that can't really put a metric to how much more toastiness you want in your bread, bagel, waffle, or whatever you are putting in your toaster but can totally relate to just wanting ""a bit more"" this should be your toaster."""		"http://www.williams-sonoma.com/products/precision-pro-digital-commercial-thermometer/?cm_src=AutoSchRelCooking meat was You can add your pets to it and any medica	"Rather than look online consider getting a Walgreens prescription card for $25/year.  You can add your pets to it and any medication they would give humans they will give to your pet at an extreme discount.I had a kitty that was CRF (Chronic Renal Failure) and needed sub-q injections of fluid twice a day.  That fluid is normally $22/bag and I needed a case of twelve 1-L bags, it would have cost me $264 to do that through my vet or through Walgreens normally.  With the prescription plan it cost me $26 for the entire case.Call your local Walgreens and ask them what the cost would be for the medication you need at the dosage you need using the prescription plan and they'll tell you over the phone so you can make a decision.Otherwise pretty much any pet med company online that is BBB certified is safe to use.  Petmeds being the most common.  But definitely check your local Walgreens first."		"A Marble Track, Knex, snap circuits (http://snapcircuits.net/), fort building kit"" (you can buy one or a sheet and rope and cli"""	"A Marble Track, Knex, snap circuits (http://snapcircuits.net/), fort building kit"" (you can buy one or a sheet and rope and clips work too)"""		Xmas morning only although the separation of Santa v parent gifts makes things more complicated than I'd like. The cost on Vonage had gone up quite a bit over the years & was reaching an average of $35 a month.  Ooma has an upfront cost of $150 or so, but after that the monthly cost is only taxes which is around $10 a month.  So far the sound quality & usability of Ooma has been great.  Combine that with the lower long term costs & I highly recommend Ooma."		I agree.  Sonos is the bomb	I agree. I rarely recommend photoshop because its so massive and the above-av"	"Gimp is great. It's also a sledgehammer, like photoshop is. I rarely recommend photoshop because its so massive and the above-average photographer will never use more than 10% of the features.  Basic photo editing functions are available in iPhoto (included on most macs). These are sufficient for most. The new updates to Aperture and iPhoto let you share libraries on the same machine. Try out the Aperture trial and see if that meets your need.  Bottom line: go with iPhoto first. It's got all the adjustments needed for most (dodge/burn, white balance correction, straightening, cropping, levels, etc). Go with Aperture if you're doing more than regular editing (curves, large library mgt (more than 20k pics), loup, etc). If you're going bonkers and want layers, masks and know what 'unsharp' means then go with Gimp. "		"I agree with the other Yabblers, I don't like the idea of having a better UX or giving any significant benefits or powers"" to h"""	"I agree with the other Yabblers, I don't like the idea of having a better UX or giving any significant benefits or powers"" to high karma users. If she?d rather stay in the old part of the city, the H?el Maison du Fort (http://www.hotelmaisondufort.com/) is one of the best bargains (and is ranked #3 hotel in Quebec City on Tripadvisor) in that part of town. If she wants something cheaper, the hostel in Quebec City (also located in the old part of the town) is quite nice and offers private rooms for parties from 1-5 people (http://www.cisq.org/2/hi-quebec_home.hostel). It's like drinking a piece of leather. Look for D3 instead.  It"	"The Costco uses ergocalciferol, a fungal-derived form of Vitamin D that is not particularly effective.  Look for D3 instead.  It also has a racemic (half will either clog pathways or is useless, and contains contaminants) form form of Vitamin E, plus two possible MSG sources.  I'd avoid that like it was toxic.The GNC uses the good form of D, but still the bad form of E.The Nature's plus has several improvements: not only does it have cholecalciferol (D3), it has chiral (not racemic) E, so totally usable.  It also has K2, which is good to have in balance with D3.  It's also soy free, which helps reduce phytoestrogens.  Boys are already hit with a lot of xenoestrogens, so keeping soy content low is a very good thing."		"My Chemex Coffeemaker. At this point, you have the mavens/influencers identified within a large community of people.This is valuable information from a marketing perspective.  If I were a company looking to market a product, I would want an opportunity to engage with those influencers/mavens.The question immediately becomes - what is the right way to provide that opportunity to companies without compromising the quality/objectivity of the answers?   The answer might be let's not even go there and risk it"" - just keep it fully focused on the user experience.   Note - this is the decision that Decide had to make with their platform and they are all-in on the side of the user."					"But, it is a question that will need to be answered one way or another and there may be ways to find the right balance."						"For example,  if you are looking to provide high karma Yabblers with a reward, you might consider allowing a company to sponsor a reward for those Yabblers in a specific area (and pay extra for the right to sponsor it).  This would allow the company the opportunity to engage with community-defined influencers/mavens."						"Now, to find the right balance, you may limit the targeting to a general interest area.  For example, if I am Sonos, I could sponsor a reward for top karma users in the ""product area"" but not directly to people who have responded to the Sonos speakers thread.   The more indirect influence may help strike the delicate balance."""			YES. I got this gem. An Instax Fujifilm instant camera. I didn't know I wanted one until I got it from my fiance. I'd say anything that ties products to people and even in the slightest way could be seen to influence them could discredit the people.  For example, I've been very vocal about how awful Bose is, aside from their wonderful noise-canceling headphones.  If Sonos were to offer me something, I'd lose the neutrality I have now, probably in many people's eyes.  If something like this were to go forward, I believe being overly public about disclosing special treatment would be the only way to go.  For example, if only MVP's got goodies from vendors, then being an MVP would mean that every contact from a vendor and every reply to a vendor is available to others here by just clicking on the MVP badge in their profile."		"Joanne. iPhone! It's easy to get recommended into the mid to top end of the market (just like wine) and kill your wallet without your palate being able to appreciate things fully. Take your time and figure out what you like and what you don't like.Also if you're new I'd also recommend trying out some of the blends in addition to single malts. At a blind whiskey tasting event I attended, a lowly $19.99 bottle of Teacher's Highland Cream came in second place, right behind a Macallan 18 and ahead of a Highland Park 12."		I would choose the Grand Californian with younger children. The iPhone 5 case by Speck provides excellent protection, probably the best case in that category, unless you go with one of those oversized gorilla cases.  It's all plastic so reception shouldn't be impaired.  As for your first requirement, improved battery life, there is no extended battery in the Speck case, so no enhanced battery.  m.speckproducts.com.Mophie makes a very good iPhone 4/4s combination battery pack/protective case.  Their website says an iPhone 5 version is eminent.  Not as strong on the protection side, but extended battery with minimal signal loss, in my experience."		"we have owned the t3i for a little over a week, and have managed to capture over 1,000 photos...probably because of novelty and "	"we have owned the t3i for a little over a week, and have managed to capture over 1,000 photos...probably because of novelty and our daughter's age, lots of funny moments.  we realize how little we knew about photography, as many of our photos are not crystal clear, and when we do put it on the everything automatic"" setting indoors, the flash often washes out the shot too much...but overall, we are enjoying learning the different aspects of photography, something we did not expect."""		"thanks to all, it sounds like an external signal booster for my vehicle is the way to go for that, thanks ferd.  poom i had neve"	"thanks to all, it sounds like an external signal booster for my vehicle is the way to go for that, thanks ferd.  poom i had never heard of that case protective case, really cool.  i may wait for the mophie battery case to come out and see if that will solve battery life and a little protection, but if i decide against a battery case think i will try out a moshi case. sounds like there is not a good solution for increased volume, not bad though if i can take care of the rest."		Have you looked at having a Facebook page for the business? It's great that you 	"I think a lot of Scratch DJ's that forget the musicianship and concentrate far too much on the technical... It's great that you might be able to accomplish a Flare->Orbit->Transform->Flare combo... but honestly... to the uninitiated it just sounds like a bunch of noise.There are a lot of neat things battle DJ's/Scratch DJ's do... like changing turntable speeds on a solid tone to make a melody... or beat mixing by playing drum samples to create their own beats... but ultimately its hard to get the general public to enjoy that. I came to the realization that a Turntablist is much like a drummer.. people will enjoy a drum solo... but not many want to watch an hour long drum solo. It's much easier to get popular by spinning good music in interesting ways than it is to scratch."		"Nice response. Thanks, Chris."	"Nice response.
