The data plan will depend on whether you need to make calls locally in hk or if you need to make int'l calls while in hk. Alternatively, if mobile does not allow you to swap the SIM card you can purchase a local unlocked phone for as little as $25 for use locally or about $50 for a global enables phone so you can purchase a SIM card. Transportation is really easy. Both will set you back just under $200.  The Maxi is the most stylish (the BMW of infant car seats), works with Quinny strollers, but some people complain about the thin padding, two hands required for the handle, and issues with the base.  The Chico was recently rated #1 for safety, has good looks, and is easy to install and handle.  But, some people complain about the low airflow fabric which makes it hot for some babies in warmer climates.There are many others that are fine and many parents say they ultimately made more of a deal about which brand and model than they should have.  Ultimately, so long as they have good basic safety features, are compatible with the stroller you have in mind, and most importantly -- are easy for you to carry and move in and out of the car, you'll be fine.  Just try to physically handle a few (work the straps, walk around with it, figure out the base unit, etc.) before pulling the trigger."		We've used David Liatos for many years after getting screwed by HR Block. So I would say it'll take about less than half a minute to remove and about 1-2 minutes to reinstall since you have to make sure the grip of the mount inside the CD player is tight enough for it not to fall off. Definitely an easy thing before/after car ride but I wouldn't install/remove it during your drive. Hope this helps :)"		I second chads recommendation on the Graco carseat and snug rider frame. The umbrella strollers are great but lack the shocks of some other strollers. So if the stroller will be your only way of getting around with baby, then maybe look into the city mini which folds up easily (one hand pull) which has the bigger wheels so its a more comfortable ride and can help ywith snowy/slushy conditions. You won't be able to use snug rider on snowy paths. If you get around with a car then snug rider and maclaren umbrella stroller is just fine. As a Blendtec owner, I v much appreciate the quietness of the Omega.2.  I also like the idea that I can juice and in theory get the nutrients from a bunch of veggies that would be hard to blend.  I think I can get 3-4X the veggies in a cup that I would normally blend.3.  I feel like I want to keep some of the pulp and not go pure juice but since we use the juice as an appetizer before a light dinner, this isn't a problem.4.  Super easy to clean and put together.Overall, I love this machine.  I think our kids had more veggies in one cup than they did all last year."		We had a Graco Snugride with our first daughter and a Britax Companion (retired as of 2008 - the Chaperone is comparable) for ou	"We had a Graco Snugride with our first daughter and a Britax Companion (retired as of 2008 - the Chaperone is comparable) for our second; both borrowed from friends. The Graco was less bulky, but the Britax was more comfy for the baby (she slept in it all the time!).My suggestion is to test drive strollers (go to Merry Go Round in Bellevue, or try out your friends' strollers) and see what you like best. Then do the research to find out which car seats are compatible with that stroller (you will usually have to buy a separate attachment bar). I wouldn't buy a stroller based on a car seat because you'll use the stroller for a much longer time.Like others have already said, I really like the City Mini stroller by Baby Jogger for navigating sidewalk cracks and gravel and other uneven ground. It folds flat and is easily lifted in and out of our small trunk and fits behind our front door for storage. I've even taken it on the bus and it only sticks out a little from under the seats. Their car seat adaptor is designed to fit several popular car seats including those made by Peg Perego, Maxi Cosi, Cybex, Chicco, Graco and Evenflo.Keep in mind that it will be a relatively short time that you will use the car seat in a stroller. Both our girls are tall/long and outgrew their infant seats long before their first birthdays (5 months & 8 months). Plus, even if they haven't officially outgrown"" their seats, when they get bigger it gets harder to lug those seats in and out of the car so you might want to switch to a convertible seat sooner than later!"					You should also consider how often you think you will be taking your car and how often you will leave straight from the house. I found it easier to carry young babies in a baby carrier (like a Moby or a Beco) when I was leaving without my car rather than strap them into a car seat that they are likely to want to get out of to be carried anyway.						"I'm also wondering if you already have a Maclaren? If that's the stroller you like best, then maybe you don't want to invest in a bigger stroller that is car seat compatible. You could just buy a universal stroller frame (Like a Baby Trend Snap N Go) to use for the first few months. Unlike cheap umbrella strollers, you can use most Maclaren strollers without a car seat from 6 months old because they have recline positions and headrests."""			"I can't answer this question, but I'd love to hear the answer. That chair looks really interesting."	"I can't answer this question, but I'd love to hear the answer. That chair looks really interesting."		I own both the iPhone5 and a Galaxy S3.  I just got the S3 a few days ago but here are some observations so far.  i've been on i	"I own both the iPhone5 and a Galaxy S3.  I just got the S3 a few days ago but here are some observations so far.  i've been on iPhones since the first one so I'm definitely biased and accustomed to iOS.1.  I like the size of the S3 screen and it's light weight.2.  I find the resolution of the screen to be not as sharps as the iPhone5.3.  I find the iPhone interface to be a bit easier and more intuitive but the S3 to be more customizable.4.  If you like trying lots of apps, most startups will launch with iPhone apps well before they support Android.That's all for now.  Hope this helps!"		Expanding your sphere of influence and also asking current friends to help you out. Is it in a 'good' rental area?  Is it easy to find renters and are they professionals or families?  What is your life situation?  Do you anticipate moving in next several years out of Seattle or are you pretty stable there?  Can you manage the condo on your own or are you paying someone for that?  How is your financial situation?  Do you have a pretty good excess of income every month?  Can you 'cover' a few months of the property being vacant without much trouble?  Ok... those are a few questions and now here are my thoughts... If you can keep that condo, it may be the best investment decision you ever make.  If you can have that mortgage paid for by someone else and then own it free and clear in 15-20-30 years, then the rental income becomes pure profit and most likely you will benefit from some appreciation.  Why not keep the rental, then take advantage of low interest rates now and go buy another home for yourself to live in.  Get a good deal on that and stay for a few years.  Buy in an area where it will be easy to rent in the future.  Stay in that place for a few years until you are ready to buy again.  At that point, you should have two rental properties that are paying for themselves and then you will have the home you are currently living in.  In less than 30 years, they should all be paid off and you will be making income on two of them.  Now, this is obviously assuming that the answers to some of the original questions put you in a situation where this all makes sense.  But if you can handle it, then this plan could put you in a great position in the future.  BTW... low inventory most often means prices are going to increase, not decrease... Think supply and demand.  Would love to hear your thoughts..."		"ya quite a few variables to factor in, a big one is what dave said about seattle stability.  if you think you might move, i woul"	"ya quite a few variables to factor in, a big one is what dave said about seattle stability.  if you think you might move, i would look for the best opportunity to sell it before that move date arrives. i dont like long distance landlording even with a good property mgmt company.  as far as the right timing related to appreciation, real estate is always a local issue and i dont know seattle, but some think that national money supply increases will put upward pressure on housing prices. so if you plan to be in seattle forever and have plenty of extra, stable monthly cashflow from somewhere else, i say keep it.if you decide to sell, consider who the ideal buyer would be. if an investor like yourself is the most likely buyer (and the buyer that would pay the most), then try to sell when it is already rented out to a stable tenant.  if your best buyer (the one that will pay the most) is someone who wants to live in it, then you probably want to wait until a tenant moves out and spend a little money making it retail"" ready."""		Which carrier did you get the S3 on? Here are answers to the questions:The property is currently 18mos into a 15yr mortgage. After princ"	"Thanks for the feedback! Here are answers to the questions:The property is currently 18mos into a 15yr mortgage. After principal, interest, insurance, taxes, and HODs, I'm losing $350/mo on the property. Had I done a 30yr mortgage, I'm pretty sure I would be making money.It is a good rental area, and we never have a problem getting it rented. The condo was built in 2003 and is in good repair. I live ~1 mile from the property and manage it myself. It is very low maintenance at this point.I will be in Seattle my whole life. I was born and raised here and both my wife and my families live in the area. There's a possibility we would leave for a couple years to see a new place, but I can't see a scenario where we'd be gone permanently.Financially I have 4-6mos living expenses saved up. I work in a well-paying industry and will most likely not struggle to be employed (knock on wood).I'm gonna have to chew on the idea of continuing to be a landlord. I never really set out to be a landlord... It just kind of happened through some mix of folly, luck, and hubris. After thinking about it, I think part of my motivation in selling is to simplify. My goal is to simply make my decision with a solid idea of what the tradeoffs are. At this point, I think it would be helpful to look at what it would mean (financially) to continue renting the condo 5, 10, and 20 years from now."		"Do you know about The Reptile Man?  http://www.reptileman.com/home.htmlHe was a hit with my first grade class!" Put 3.5% down and buy one more home that you can live in a couple years and then rent out. Then you can buy your dream home. Live there the rest of your life and have a couple of easy to manage investment properties that don't cost you anything and will ensure you some extra income when you retire. Some liquors need a little water,  while some are bet"	"I like to try liquor neat and then on the rocks or with a splash of water. Some liquors need a little water,  while some are better without. It's also a matter of preference. I can't say I agree with the Lagavulin recommendation. It is a well made scotch but it isn't for everyone. The nicer Irish whiskies are very smooth, those include Midleton, Jameson 18 and Redbreast (which it sounds like you're already had). It's really hard not to like these, but they are expensive. Jameson is ~$100 and Midleton is $125ish.As for scotch, I would start out with Balvenie Double Wood. It's sweet and fairly smooth, with nice flavors that are easy to identify. If you want a smokey scotch I would go for the Laphroaig Quarter Cask or Old Ballantruan. Both are very good. If you can find Scapa 16 that represents some nice light flavors and a very interesting mouth feel. Scotch can get very expensive. I think these are mostly in the $55-75 range. Some distillers sell sets, usually in small 'airplane' size bottles, that allow you to taste through some different agings. Balvenie does a double wood, 15 year and 21 year. Those can be a lot of fun.Bourbon is probably my favorite of the whiskies and what I think represents the best value in the whiskey world. I would try Elmer T Lee for a nice sweet, buttery example or Four Roses Small Batch for a lighter example($30-40's maybe). Bulleit also makes very nice bourbon and rye. It's around $25-30 and is good on the rocks or in cocktails like a Manhattan. I know this is blasphemy but while Makers seems to be most people's standard, I'm not a big fan unless mixing it with coke - that's a delicious and hard to screw up mixed drink, but a different topic. On the pricier side of bourbons (which is mostly in the $60-$80), try Prichards Bourbon or Rye, both are very good. If you can find it, try any of Buffulo Trace's antique collection, however some of those are barrel strength which mean they were never cut with water and can get near 140proof. George T Stagg and the Sazerac 18 are probably the best of the antique collection. If you're drinking a barrel proof bourbon then make sure to add ice and/or water! Those probably aren't the best place to start for absolute newbies, but they are fun.Welcome to the whiskey world!"		"Great discussion, and one more thing to think through...could you get a greater return on that money and your time landlording t"	"Great discussion, and one more thing to think through...could you get a greater return on that money and your time landlording through another investment?  You might expect 8-25% return on your equity in that property, but if you have a business that needs capital to invest in growth or inventory or whatever, you can often times get a greater return than 25% by investing in your own thing.If you work for someone else and are not a partner or owner (that would require capital investment at some point), and plan to continue that course, maybe this real estate investment, or selling the condo and investing it into a mutual fund, or selling the condo and putting all of that equity into a big downpayment on a house you live in (very simple) ...would all be options."		"my experience on this page:  http://www.foxvalleyhometeam.com/property-search.aspoverall i like the rounded corners and colo"	"my experience on this page:  http://www.foxvalleyhometeam.com/property-search.aspoverall i like the rounded corners and colors of the search area- not a fan of the purple background for no photo available- in chrome there is a left to right scroll bar (cuts off the right 10% of page)- perhaps default the location to be open in the search  menu on the left- a little slow, but that may be the fault of the data feed you use i don't know.  once i clicked around a little everything got slower.- i can't find the price on the property details page"		Oh and train going to and from airport is super efficient and economical. Takes you to major areas in hk or Kowloon and you can 	"Oh and train going to and from airport is super efficient and economical. Takes you to major areas in hk or Kowloon and you can take a taxi to your hotel from there. And we usually opt for the convenience of cabs whenever possible but the airport train is that convenient. Also when returning to airport, you can actually check your bags at IFC before you get on the airport train to airport. No struggling with any luggage to the airport!  In general it's really easy to get around since all transportation is well designed. Taxis can be difficult to get during rush hour and bad traffic, especially on hk side. At night, if your friends have time, I recommend taking the star ferry from tsim tsa tsui to hk side (or vice versa) for one of the best views of the hk skyline. Splurge for first class which is prob under 1usd so you can disembark first. There is a nice walk by the water in tsim tsa tsui at night near the ferry too. Plenty of hotels and bars there after your walk. Things are open quite late. Some malls dont even close until almost midnight. Lan Kwai fong is a bar/night life area popular with expats. You will meet a lot of people who can provide tips hit you there. For restaurants, check out a site called open rice, a much better version of our opentable with tons of reviews. "		I had a Waring Pro before Blendtec.  You can't compare them!  The size of the vessel (so you can make a few cups at a time and a	"I had a Waring Pro before Blendtec.  You can't compare them! The economics are such that the cost of the food will well exceed the hardware costs after a few months ;-). When the liquor is warm"" (vs iced) you get so much more of the rounder sweeter"""	"I definitely prefer neat with a splash of water. When the liquor is warm"" (vs iced) you get so much more of the rounder sweeter flavors. The amount of water should correspond to the proof of the liquor...100 proof needs a bit more water for example than 90 proof. And how much is really up to you and your taste...and as you develop a taste, you might like less and less water. I've seen the lightbulb go off over so many people's heads when they try a good scotch this way. They realize, ""Oh, it tastes like butterscotch!"" Uh, yep :)"""		For indoor if you don't want to use the flash I would invest in a fast 50mm lens... something like 50mm/1.8 or 1.4 if you have t	"For indoor if you don't want to use the flash I would invest in a fast 50mm lens... something like 50mm/1.8 or 1.4 if you have the budget for it. The 1.8 usually runs a little over $100 and the 1.4 runs in the $300's. It's one of the best initial lens investments if you find yourself shooting indoors in less than ideal lighting. As for editing/cataloging... I would highly recommend purchasing Lightroom from Adobe. It's resonably priced as far as Adobe software goes... it has some what of a learning curve but once you get it... it allows you to process 100's of pictures in minutes."		Thanks Chris is lightroom different than Photoshop elements batch processing function? There's this authentic"" feel (hole-in-the-wall restaurants with *awesome* food, indie cafes with great music, lively and dingy bars) to the urban life that you won't find anywhere else, especially on the East Side. Depends on how often you go out, you may save $$ in the long-run by living/spending in Seattle vs. Bellevue. Plus, your college life will be that much more exciting if you live closer to the UW- trust me on this last one. It's not just an editor but it's built to"	"@Nathan, Lightroom is specifically designed for quickly editing a lot of photos... It's not just an editor but it's built to also catalog your images. My workflow in Lightroom looks like (Timing for 200-300 pics):1. Import all photos via lightroom (2-3 minutes)2. View each photo, mark the bad ones (blurry, closed eyes, etc), Mark the good ones with how much editing they might need... 1-4. (5-8 minutes)3. Select and delete the bad ones. (1 minute) 4. Run a standard unsharp mask and contrast boost (2-3 minutes) 5. Run through the pics doing easy touchups... remove redeye/crop, mark additional pics for deletion (10-15 minutes)6. delete additional (1 minute)7. Additional Editing depending on what's needed..."		I ended up using Blurb and am pretty happy with how it came out. Since you rent it out it technically is an investment 	One other consideration is the tax implications of selling the property.  Since you rent it out it technically is an investment property and subject to gain taxes unless you do a 1031/1033 exchange which is a bit complicated and has costs associated with it as well.  Just some more to chew on.  Good luck.		"http://doebay.com/Doe Bay Resort and Retreat is sort of rustic in the sense that it's not a fancy hotel...but it's easy to g"	"http://doebay.com/Doe Bay Resort and Retreat is sort of rustic in the sense that it's not a fancy hotel...but it's easy to get to on Orcas Island and there are tons of great things to do on Orcas. I thought I'd hav	"Just curious--I have that exact same machine and it started not being able to pull shots a couple years back.  I thought I'd have to replace it, but about $80 later I had a like-new machine after taking it to Home Espresso Repair and Cafe on Phinney Ridge.  http://www.espressorepair.com/It's since gotten another 3.5 years of life out of it.  I really would like one of the Breville machines that Williams-Sonoma sells...but I can't justify the $500+ price tag when I can get my machine back to new again for another $80-100.  The Starbucks Barista can pull excellent shots if you know how to use it correctly--and my portafilter has two spouts so you can do a double shot.  My only real complaint with the machine is how long it takes to steam milk for more than about 2 people.  But again, I will likely opt for fixing up my current machine again given the costs."		"Skiing! I'd recommend Stevens Pass... it's my home mountain... the conditions there are usually much better than Snoqualmie."	"Skiing! I'd recommend Stevens Pass... it's my home mountain... the conditions there are usually much better than Snoqualmie... The snow should be softer. If you can go during the week. Saturdays/Sundays are usually really busy and the wait times for Rentals/Lifts/Ticketing can get ridiculous. Sometimes you can get a private lesson because you're the only one who signed up fro a group lesson. For your first day on the hill I would recommend doing a Package deal... Stevens Pass has a 3 Day lesson/Rental/Ticket deal called Easy-123 (http://www.stevenspass.com/Stevens/lessons-packages/easy123.aspx). You can use it over 3 different days during a season. It's a great way to get you on ski's and having fun. They also have a 1 day package that provides the same lesson/rental/ticket.  If you're going on a weekend... get to the mountain early... you'll get better parking and shorter rental lines. As far as what to wear... Dress in layers.. technical fabrics if you have them... Long sleeve tshirt... sweatshirt/fleece... waterproof shell. This will allow you take off layers if you get too hot. Buy some cheap goggles at big5/sports authority... Wear a beanie or helmet. Get a pair of thin wool socks or ski specific ones that are at least calf high... Don't wear 2 pairs of socks... this will cause you to have a bad day. Remember to hydrate well.. it's easy to forget to drink water since it's cold... you'll be surprised how much you perspire. Bite sized snickers are awesome on the lift :DOther than that.. have fun! Remember to enjoy the mountain air and the views."		"1c Franks, 1/2c melted butter, 1tsp cayenne, 1tsp black pepper, 1tsp garlic powderI grill the wings then use the sauce above"	"1c Franks, 1/2c melted butter, 1tsp cayenne, 1tsp black pepper, 1tsp garlic powderI grill the wings then use the sauce above... I would also want to target by location in certain cases as a lot of my knowledge is location specific (Ann Arbor or Seattle, for example).   I think this works well for people with particular interests, especially if people/companies want to follow the Yabble on certain products.   And, in those cases, I do think the option of a daily push makes sense.When I reflect on what topics I respond to it is actually quite a diverse range usually related to something I know.  I might have a hard time coming up with a good set of criteria off the top of my head.   So, it would be great if Yabbly helped me learn my interest set and to prune/curate it over time with little effort.For example, you might consider something akin to a follow and unfollow feature or a +1 (but perhaps a different name) that lets me signal to Yabbly that I want to see more of these types of Yabbles.  I could then over time organically prune/curate my feeds.You might also considering having a personal analytics of what types of Yabbles I respond to and then use that as a tool to help people prune/curate.   I am imagining different graphs or word clouds that visually show my most prevalent categories, topical keywords.  Then, on that page, I should have a simple way (something akin to a follow/unfollow or a +1) to signal to Yabbly what elements are indicative of my interests.   On that page, you might also give me the option of giving Yabble permission to pull my facebook interests to help Yabble do a better job of recommending Yabbles to me."		"Aside from the answers above, Amazon Prime members who have Kindle devices can also access the Kindle Owners' Lending Library an"	"Aside from the answers above, Amazon Prime members who have Kindle devices can also access the Kindle Owners' Lending Library and borrow e-books for free."		Check out Las Brujas in Miraflores. Definitely meta-tags are great to use."	"As KristinaEndrik said, basic search engine optimization rules will get you traffic.  Definitely meta-tags are great to use.Try to get mentions in topic-related high-traffic blogs with a link to your site.  The more of these you can get, the more PageRank will lift your site up the Google listings.  Submit press releases to any high-traffic site that might have people interested in your store.  Again this drives Google rank, it also is free advertising.There are SEO blogs online, find one that's appropriate to your level of knowledge and interest and start reading it regularly.  These are people who drive traffic to sites a lot, learn from them."		"I think @Tom's suggestion is a good one. We called the City of Seattle and they said th"	"Hi Ryan, our Buyer Research Team did some digging and here's what we found.1. We called the City of Seattle and they said they were doing complimentary pick up as part of the Yard Waste and Compost service for Xmas trees but that deadline has passed. They did say if you put it out next week, they'd pick it up but your building would be charged $9 (if you live in a condo, you might want to talk to the HOA).2. They said you can also bring it to the Dump in Fremont at 1350 N 34th Street and they'll take it for free till Jan 13.3. We also called the Boy Scouts of Seattle and left a message with David, who covers the Queen Anne area but haven't heard back yet since they offer a pickup service with a donation. Not sure if that's still available but their number is 206-725-5200.4.  We looked at some private junk pickup companies but they're like $50 minimum so not sure you want to go that route.5.  Lastly, you could also probably have a handyman from craigslist pick it up and bring it to the dump for you.  Probably could find someone to do it for $25 but it's craigslist so you'd be dealing with a random person.Hope this helps!"		"@amanduh_999, cool products.  since they're so visually appealing, i'd explore doing stuff on pinterest, creating a facebook pag"	"@amanduh_999, cool products.  since they're so visually appealing, i'd explore doing stuff on pinterest, creating a facebook page (and running a small Facebook ad campaign targeting women who are probably in their 20's(?) and into fashion) and maybe approaching some jewelry bloggers to see if they'd be open to doing a post about you (that last one is a long shot but worth a try -- esp if you have a nice story about your design inspiration or why you started making jewelry)."		Thx everyone! Our first Great Pyrenees was allergic to a lot of things; one time we had 	"We've tried lots of forms of the raw diet over time.  Our first Great Pyrenees was allergic to a lot of things; one time we had an endoscopy done, and 16 hours after eating the poor guy's stomach was still irritated from the meal.We put him on BARF (bones and raw food), he loved the raw chicken wings.  Over time he started showing some deficiencies, which we tried to overcome with home-made organic juicing and veggie supplementation.  He never got to real health.With our second Pyr, we tried some commercial raw food diets, but none of them really worked well for him.  We've got him on Mmillennium (yes, spelled that way) from Solid Gold right now, it has him (at age 7) romping like a puppy.  Which is quite a sight with a 120 pound Pyrenees.Overall we never found a raw food diet had any advantage over a good commercial food."		"Size preference? My mom shows them and this is the diet that most of the dogs are on..	"My dogs are on a raw diet and they are incredibly healthy. My mom shows them and this is the diet that most of the dogs are on...I go to the grocery store and ask for all the veggies that are about to be thrown away, they are not suitable for sales but they are perfect for dog food. Then I grind it all up and make small balls and put it in the freezer. I also make raw meet balls with flax and fish oil and freeze them as well. The 3 small dogs share one veggie ball and one meat ball every morning between the 3 of them. For dinner, they each get a raw chicken wing, bones and all. Never give a dog cooked chicken bone cause it is hallow and brittle and can choke them. If you have any questions feel free to ask!"		To clarify: I take out the balls each night and put them in the refrigerator to thaw for the following morning's meal. I've never been to a chiropractor but did go to a physical therapist and it was great. The valuable thing isn't some procedure they might do in the office, but what you want is someone that can observe how you walk and stand and give you tips on improving your posture and exercises you can do to stretch/strengthen the right muscles. I went for about a month, learned some great exercises, and haven't had trouble since.It's not cheap though, mine ran I think $60+ an hour at Olympic Physical Therapy even with good insurance. Keep in mind if you want to use insurance you may need a referral from your primary care doc to get it covered."		Angelina's in the Admiral Junction (http://angelinaswestseattle.com) is very kid-friendly (chalk boards in the booths) and has g	"Angelina's in the Admiral Junction (http://angelinaswestseattle.com) is very kid-friendly (chalk boards in the booths) and has good food and service. A Terrible Beauty (Irish restaurant/pub) has always treated our family well, though it can get very busy particularly for brunch on weekends."		"@Spencer, that's about what I guessed. They have significantly lower fees (from my experience) on their funds, which can make a signi"	"If possible, switch to Vanguard.  They have significantly lower fees (from my experience) on their funds, which can make a significant impact on your investment.You can get a financial advisor, etc, but remember that even if you don't directly pay them...  you will pay them indirectly through more expensive funds, load funds (funds where you pay when you buy/sell), other things like that.  Fees like that can make investments net out to a zero or negative investment!A simple choice: dump everything into an S&P 500 index fund.  Very few funds outperform in the long haul, which is what you're in for.  They're inexpensive, fee-wise, since they don't need active management on the part of your broker.You can also sign up for a service like FutureAdvisor (free) which can help you balance your investments to a risk profile appropriate for your age.Though, if you have a work 401k, which is locked in to a specific broker, you might just want to get your other investments through them anyway, for simplicity."		"First: DO NOT go through safelite, whatever you do.  They're a huge company and one of the few that manufactures their own glass"	"First: DO NOT go through safelite, whatever you do.  They're a huge company and one of the few that manufactures their own glass.  It is quite widely known to be of low quality (read: it will break on you in the future more easily).  Your windshield is a big part of your car's support system, so weak glass can have a significant impact on your car's safety.I recommend Superior Auto Glass (http://www.superiorautoglass.com/).  They came to my work to do the installation (Seattle area, so it should work for you).  They did a great job, their support was awesome and their price was by a decent margin the cheapest.  They only work with OEM glass -- which is IMPORTANT.For my 2007 TL (this was a few years back) I paid $263 installed for OEM glass.  Everywhere else wanted at least $360, some were as high as $500.  Many didn't intend on using OEM glass at their prices, either.Also, it's unlikely you'll want to claim it on your insurance, since I doubt it'd be more than your deductible.(Note: if you catch chips/cracks early enough, insurance will pay for them to be repaired -without deductible- and without affecting your premium.)Also, randomly, I searched up Quality since it was highly recommended and found this groupon that should save you $50: http://www.groupon.com/deals/quality-auto-glass"		"OK, as an update for everyone, the doodle fix now adds stuff to your Gcal but...it does not set up Gcal reminders in the event b"	"OK, as an update for everyone, the doodle fix now adds stuff to your Gcal but...it does not set up Gcal reminders in the event by default.  So you don't get any notifications and reminders if you're deep in email which sucks.I just discovered meetme.so which looks decent so will probably give that a try since enough people have trouble using Doodle, pick wrong times, and the lack of Gcal reminders is not delightful."		"Thanks all, super helpful! So if your #1 goal is note taking, I'm not convinced any tablet is optimal.  As an example, I just tried taking notes on a friend's iPad using his favorite note-taking app called Paper"" and using his fancy stylus.  I can say it was a really unsatisfying experience from a handwritten note taking pov."					1. There's a few milisecond delay from writing to seeing it on the screen.  it feels unnatural.						"So net, net.  If you want something for reading, browsing the web, apps, etc.  I think the Mini is awesome but since you called out note-taking as one of your primary use cases, I'd say you may need to be ok with potentially still using paper for note-taking even if you have a mini. Tight hamstri	"I've had lower back pain while playing sports and one thing my coach recommended was stretching out my hamstrings. Tight hamstrings tend to pull on the pelvis, as the top of the long hamstring is attached to the pelvis, so this causes a rounding of the lower back, resulting in lower back pain.Also the root cause of 99% of lower back pain (or back pain in general) problems is from muscle imbalances. This could be solves by strengthening your abs.Hope this helps!"		911 also looks like what a young Steve Jobs would approve/drive.. 	911 also looks like what a young Steve Jobs would approve/drive.. 		We love our Bionaire filter free humidifier. It's list of veggies and fruit that are the cleanest, as in fewest pesticides, and the dirtiest ones (with the most pesticides). I try to always buy organic, but when I can't I try to stick to these lists to avoid the most heavily sprayed produce and buy those organic. The estimated repair $125."					"I decided to replace based on the risk of unsuccessful repair weighed against the risk of a defective replacement.  Four years ago I went through a series of four repairs that culminated in a very inconvenient ""demand visit"" for a new phone at 8:55 pm in Portland while on a road trip."						I spoke with eight representatives across the three involved companies regarding the first repair/replacement decision. Six of the representatives stressed refurbished phones were the best way to go and even recommended I always buy refurbished phones when upgrading.  						They all explained the testing for refurbished phones is more stringent than the testing for new production line phones.						I believe your decision should be based on whether you want to pay more for a higher level of confidence in the phone.						"Screen replacement won't involve any testing to speak of when compared to going with a refurbished replacement phone.  It is one thing to replace a screen, it is another thing to wonder if a small screen shard might be floating around in the phone post repair that could cause problems."						My background includes responsibility for the blood pump assembly used in the manufacture of kidney dialysis machines.  Dialysis machines that needed repair went through far more rigorous testing than the new production models.						One downside of replacing the phone is the need to re sync data.  Of course this might be involved with the screen repair also.						I didn't go with the refurbished replacement phone the first time I needed to deal with a damaged phone and regretted it.  The second refurbished phone has worked flawlessly for 8 months.						"Hope this helps."""			"I would take a serious look at Michael's answer above for starters, I also suspect your work may be in part causing the problem."	"I would take a serious look at Michael's answer above for starters, I also suspect your work may be in part causing the problem. As is I couldn't answer your actual question with a sense of confidence.  Since I am not a physician I can only compare experiences and offer suggestions that might help."		"I find in honor of"" to be honoring someone who is living, and ""in memory of"" is to be honoring someone who has passed away. For one, teachers look at the device differently when you use a keyboard since they prop the device up and make it look more like a laptop as opposed to a phone. Second, have you tried writing important information quickly without a keyboard? It isn't fun. Third and final, any tablet is far more quiet than a laptop and small enough to fit within your personal square so that no one behind you is able to look onto your screen without looking like a creeper."		"I think this would definitely be cool and would help the Yabbly community unify a little more! One is 10 and one is 5 and nobody believes it because they look and act so young.  We switched to raw food because they had trouble properly digesting other diets.  It instantly fixed all stomach issues.  We buy Northwest Naturals lamb patties (frozen) in bulk and then thaw them for each meal.  This is the natural diet for dogs - they don't need cooked food.		"my fitness pal  for track foods and daily my personal trainer for  daily exercises and more"	"my fitness pal  for track foods and daily my personal trainer for  daily exercises and more"		I'm not sure if it's any better than YouTube but there is a year long online class on groupon for $18. Memory foam is generally a petroleum-based product, so pretty hard to qualify as green"". """	"Hi!  The short answer is not really.  Memory foam is generally a petroleum-based product, so pretty hard to qualify as green"".  Your best bet is to look for memory foams where a portion of it is plant-based (a.k.a. bio-based), typically from soy.  Even in these foams, petroleum is still the main ingredient, but it is diluted a bit by something more natural."					"PS -- If this is for a mattress, you may want to check out GoodBed.com, a research website for mattress buyers (full disclosure: I'm the founder). While they are in fact really good with kids, they are also notorious escape artists with a strong prey drive.  They are also extremely difficult to train to the point where they can be off-leash, and I've never known one to fetch a tennis ball...  Seriously:  they're a gorgeous, wonderful breed (I used to have two), but by no means easy dogs to own."		"Poom, you were right, that was the best one for the height of the war going on outside our house. That said, you'll want to be aware of two things: 1) Latex comes in three varieties -- natural, synthetic, and a blend of natural and synthetic.  Synthetic latex is a petroleum-based product, no greener than memory foam.  2) If you're after the slow melting into the bed"" sensation you get when lying on a Tempur-Pedic, you won't get that with latex.  Memory foam is a ""slow-response"" material, which is what gives it is unique feel (which people tend to either love or hate), whereas latex is not."					"For a guide with more info about latex mattresses, check here:"			"http://www.goodbed.com/latex-mattresses/"""			"@Bryan, care to share what you ended up going with? There is Re"	"Solvents aren't really great on the BBQ.One trick is to actually cover your grill baskets and grating with foil. There is Reynolds wrap specifically for the grill, but I find this a little silly since you already have a basket.I have also used the faux-self-cleaning technique of putting the empty (but dirty) grill baskets back on the grill while it's still very hot - this turns that goop into dry ash or char that is very easy to wash away."		"Hi Kerry, when I'm on the elliptical but reading a magazine, I put the fuel in my pocket. Now, purists will say this screws up accuracy (which is true) but my view is you're really trying to track your level of activity over time so as long as you always put it in your pocket when you're on the treadmill desk, I don't think that's a big deal."		"I have found that putting a simple, inexpensive lumbar roll behind my back when I sit at a desk chair has been a tremendous help"	"I have found that putting a simple, inexpensive lumbar roll behind my back when I sit at a desk chair has been a tremendous help in reinforcing good posture while at my desk at work."		I agree with Steven. It seems to have almost the same functionality as Jott. There is another alternative - the following article discusses an app named Dial2Do that does a little more than  Reqall, however there is a small monthly fee (http://www.beginnerbusiness.com/jott-replacement-voice-transcription-service).Free Memos to Self: Reqall ? If price is a consideration, and if the main thing you?re looking for is memos to yourself (and a little help organizing your life) then check out Reqall.Voice to Everything: Dial2Do ? The main advantage of Dial2Do seems to be the ability to interface with a lot more applications, the way Jott did. For the full-featured version it?s only $5.99/month (as of April 2011) which is in line with what Jott was charging.Hope this was helpful!"		"Hi @mplsdatagirl! He told me that most companies use too much soap. That makes it appear clean, but leaves a residue that actually attracts more dirt in the short term. 6 months later you are calling back for take 2. Apparently, it's kind of a scam like teeth whitening. I c"	"As a long-ago Chem major, I have to echo the principle of don't put anything on the grates that you wouldn't want to drink.  I could throw some strong solution ideas around but none of them would result in something I'd be willing to consume food from.And if you do use the burn-off method (which I personally like), try to stay away from the fumes.  Any time you heat Carbon and Hydrogen to a high enough temperature (which burning it off does achieve), you'll get some Benzpyrene (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benzo(a)pyrene) which is a pretty nasty carcinogen.  It makes changes to DNA."		My boyfriend is studying audio engineering at the Art Institute of Seattle and he says that Beats are not very good quality. (In future if @tom me on a thread I've participated in, I'll get notified).I am still thrilled with the Omega.  I just used it last night and consumed incredible amounts of micro nutrients in one single glass.As for your question, I think it _can_ be ok for a family of 5 but you'll need to set aside a good 45 minutes to make 5 tall glasses.  Partly it's the input chute being on the narrow side, partly, it's by definition a low-RPM juicer so it's kind of like a large animal chewing slowly on grass.  There's no high speed spinning like on a blender as an example.So do I wish the chute was wider, yes.  Because then I'd be able to cut apples into 1/4's instead of 1/8's but it's not really that big of a deal when you think about the nutrition you're getting (esp if your toddler is having a glass with a plate of mac n cheese) and you feel like at least he's got that cup of juice."""					"If for no other reason than the toddler consumption, it's a strong buy. For example I'm not subject to this but my wife is:Get F.Lux for your computers"	"The below is true for some people, not all.  For example I'm not subject to this but my wife is:Get F.Lux for your computers (also works on iPads and iPhones if you jailbreak), that lowers the amount of blue light coming into your eyes and destroying melatonin after sunset.  Get it here: http://stereopsis.com/flux/If that doesn't cover all the screens you look at, then try not to look at a screen after dinner at least. I've seen chiropractors, some have been amazing"	"Ashley, I think going to a chiropractor for a consultation would be a good idea. I've seen chiropractors, some have been amazing (too bad you're not in this area, I highly recommend Dr. Brent Symes, Downtown Edmonds Chiropractic); others not so great. The first visit is a tell-tale sign of things to come - if they just want you to hop on the table so they can adjust you after a 5-minute conversation, I suggest leaving. But if they do what they should -- schedule a longer-than-normal first appointment, use a non-invasive method of analysis such as checking for hot areas of your back, possibly x-rays, etc. to really figure out the extent of the issue, and THEN making a recommendation as far as whether to adjust manually or using less invasive methods such as a drop table or activator (a small, not-at-all-scary hand-held device), before making any adjustments, this could be a good chiropractor. I would post requests for recommendations on any/all social media platforms, ask around, and then research online to see what reviews say (weeding through the ones that are obviously fake of course). And ask for exercises, stretches, etc. before you leave. Usually they have hand-outs already available. Our bodies are incredibly complex and as you can see from many of the comments and your own experience, any number of things can be causing this. But in my opinion and experience, a good chiropractor is the best professional to help diagnose and treat your symptoms. They often suggest other forms of treatment and refer out to massage or physical therapists, acupuncturists, etc. etc.Sorry for the long-winded response! But I've been helped a great deal by chiropractic and wanted to get my two cents in :) - James"		One glass of red wine after dinner! A pipe cleaner (like from our 	"I've just taken all the removable parts out each time and used the little brushes ours came with. A pipe cleaner (like from our kids' craft drawer) can be helpful too.I'd heard of using rice, but I saw a warning online that you should be sure to use instant rice because the full cooking time stuff is harder than coffee and can jam your grinder. There isn't any huge reason to clean the grinder beyond brushing away the grinds unless you just want it to look really clean.I suggest just sticking with taking the grinder apart and brushing the pieces that come in contact with coffee. Unless your grinder is really hard to take apart, using rice or a specialty product seems to me like more trouble than just cleaning it manually."		"Thank you, gentlemen.  Here's the scoop. But everyone seems to have different luck--some people respond really well to chiropractic care and others don't.  I even find that I can only go in the afternoons because I'm just too stiff in the morning for my body to really move correctly from a chiropractor.  I'd give one or two a shot to see if you like them.  Some use tools like (activator or actuator or something like that it's called...it basically nudges things back into alignment) and others do manual where they actually use their hands to manipulate your body.  I prefer manual but have had success with both methods.  One thing to note is that many chiropractors try and get you into a routine...they solve your immediate problem then recommend maintenance"".  Which you may or may not like.  I usually go every 2-3 weeks for an adjustment when I'm not having serious issues.  That works best for my neck and upper back issues."					"For my lower back, I've found chiropractic only goes so far.  This is based on my particular issues--again it's different with everyone and every issue you may be experiencing.  But I found chiropractic couldn't solve all my low back issues.  "						What did help was massage therapy every few weeks (weekly at first till you get things loosened up and moving right). And I combined that with physical therapy.  When you see someone for PT they should have you come more frequently at first and then taper you off as you build the right strength and start doing the exercises and work on  your own.  I've found that the things I've learned from PT have allowed me to alleviate much of the low back pain I've dealt with post-car-accidents.  						"I now have a set of exercises for my core strength that I do every morning.  Days I am good and do them I find I have a significantly reduced pain throughout the day.  Days I skip I find myself having problems by lunch.  You'll have to force yourself into a routine but once you do you should hopefully have a lot fewer problems.  Lots of the low back pain comes from strengthening the core, as mentioned above.  It's funny how much your abs and stuff actually effect how your low back feels."						"Overall I'd definitely try PT, chrio, and massage, and see what set of things work for you.  And I've definitely found that keeping up with the exercises my PT taught me allows me to be much more pain-free in between any kind of doctor visits.  It's nice to be able to alleviate your pain yourself without meds or a doctor visit.  Good luck!"""			Maldives	Maldives		Bay Cities Italian Deli in Santa Monica	Bay Cities Italian Deli in Santa Monica		Set the time and have an earlier shower. I've had my fair share of bouts with back pain due to 	"I often find myself sitting in front of a computer for 10-12 hours a day. I've had my fair share of bouts with back pain due to poor posture. Now, nothing beats a nun wielding a wooden ruler to improve your posture, but if you don't have one hanging around, you may want to try some of these helpful tips I've learned over the years from friends and professionals:1) An ergonomic chair. I've tried the swiss ball and that is good for strenghtening your back as well, but a chair that can be adjusted will help tremendously. 2) Give your back a break by getting up and stretching periodically at least every 30 min.3) Raise your monitor. This will help to keep your shoulders from hunching4) lumbar rolls are great for the office or the car and travel well.5)Strengthen your back with exercise.(Yoga, stretching, light weights)Have a friend take a picture of you when you are sitting down working when you are not aware. This will add some insight to why tour posture is poor. Adjusting your habits and environment should help to remedy your posture problems."		Well so far I haven't noticed anything at all. It's called Balsamiq and anyone who can use PowerPoint can have decent Balsamiq concept mocks working in an hour.  You can even make them clickable.  We used them for Yabbly before we assembled our core team for investor pitches and it worked well.		"I wondered if I would hear from one of the Yabbly guys!  Thanks, Tom. I find it easier to travel without a stroller if you have kids who can walk holding hands or be carried easily.We bought one cheap one for the youngest of our Disney travelers and wished we had purchased two more for the two 4 year olds. Yes they can walk, but they will get tired after a long Disney day!Buy the most hideous pattern so that yours doesn't get mixed up with other people's strollers and/or tie something to the handle to distinguish yours from the rest.When you are done at the parks, hand the strollers off to another family who wishes they had them for their 4/5 year old!"		"June would be super hot if you go tropical. If I show someone a full schematic of an amp vs. a block diagram, I'll get very different levels of feedback.  Same in UX I believe."		"I've looked and looked over the years. It avoids any distraction created by branding	"I'd agree that low-resolution mockups are likely the best route for a first pass.  It avoids any distraction created by branding / imagery and ensures that the core concept / usability is the focus.   It also prevents you from spending wasted time tweaking refined elements of the presentation prior to actually vetting the full concept and the general UX.A tool like Mockingbird or Hotgloo work really well for this -- but you can also just buy some graph paper and a pencil and throw them together pretty easily on your own (depending on the level of presentability you're looking for).In the past, after paper prototypes I've usually moved right into quick HTML / JS / CSS alpha versions of the concept to further experiment.   This usually involves a lot of smoke and mirrors"" that involve hard-coded scenarios / responses, simply to begin to iron out the actual process and again, catchy any kinks early in the game."					"Hope that helps!"""			Hi @Megh. The key IMHO is	"There are lots of sample decks around on web.   You can find tons on Google.  Gust has a template as do others.  The key IMHO is not to get too lost in the weeds but nail the high level first.My cheat sheet is 1.) what giant problem are you solving? 2.) mocks/demo   3.) what makes u different from the other ppl solving this problem? 4.) how will u engage, acquire, and monetize users? 5.) why are you/your team suited to execute? There's plenty of other details but nailing these 5 first is top prio."		"REI is a good place to start- if I were to get a new bike to get around town, I look at the Novara Big Buzz Bike or Novara Gotha"	"REI is a good place to start- if I were to get a new bike to get around town, I look at the Novara Big Buzz Bike or Novara Gotham (it's belt drive is particularly appealing). At first it took me a while to get used to, since I usually watch movies in darkened room and the bleeding effect (grey patches of cloud on the screen) can be very noticeable on a Samsung during some dark scenes. All newer Samsung Smart TVs are affected by this light bleeding problem, but if you can look past this issue (you will eventually get used to it) then it's quite an experience to watch streaming HD, Bluray and 3D Bluray movies on the TV, especially when paired with an amazing sound system. Extremely crisp and smooth picture where black is really black. Last but not least, it's a thin and well-designed piece of furniture (at least the silver one) that really compliments my living room.There's also a 60-inch version of Samsung that I mentioned at a price that is substantially below $5K (http://www.amazon.com/Samsung-UN60ES7100-60-Inch-1080p-240Hz/dp/B0078LN0RE/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1359444962&sr=1-3&keywords=samsung+tv+60-inch). These TVs are great for watching Youtube videos if you can pair it with this keyboard (http://www.amazon.com/Logitech-Bluetooth-Illuminated-Keyboard-Smartphones/dp/B0099SMFVQ/ref=sr_1_22?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1359445710&sr=1-22&keywords=logitech+wireless+keyboard)"		"i don't see a way to set the privacy for my posts...if every post is available to everyone, I will not be using it." Whereas if you walk in with something that feels interesting, but needs some love, people will evaluate on those grounds instead.Two other quick notes:1. Balsamiq has a wireframe"" skin that allows to you turn the sketchy lines into straight ones."		"2. Balsamiq is really at its best when you use it to mockup your interfaces, but then turn to some other tool for the presentation on those mockups (PPT, Infusion, Omnigraffle, etc.)."						"Good luck!"""			I have to agree with Kiel. Another resource is SlideShare.com.For business plans templates, Sequoia has a helpful business plan template divided into 10 categories: Company Purpose, Problem, Solution, Why Now, Market Size, Competition, Product, Business Model, Team, and Financials. (http://www.sequoiacap.com/ideas)Another approach would be to complete Osterwalder's 9-point business model canvas, and you can easily pull up how others have completed one via Google. Its categories: Key Partners, Key Activities, Value Propositions, Key Resources, Cost Structure, Revenue Streams, Channels, Customer Relationships, and Customer Segments. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_Model_Canvas)"		"Rock n play sleeper , boppy, a sound machine(not the sleep sheep because it goes off after 45 minutes), oball, sleepers that zip"	"Rock n play sleeper , boppy, a sound machine(not the sleep sheep because it goes off after 45 minutes), oball, sleepers that zip instead of snap, Munchkin snack catcher"		"I've used pretty much every tool mentioned in this thread and my vote is Balsamiq, hands down. I have W8 on my personal laptop and I don't really see the point of it. Unless your Thinkpad has a touchscreen, Windows 7 is a lot better in terms of file accessibility and ease-of-use. W8 looks cooler, but it's kind of a hassle since the Start icon is now absent and is replaced by the overlay Windows 8 start. Also, I haven't found a good use for Windows Store apps yet. Reason to Upgrade:-Faster bootup/shutdown times-Cooler aesthetics-Better search functionReasons to NOT Upgrade:-Too much of a pushaway from Win7 accessibility-Traditional (non-touchscreen) laptops aren't the primary target for W8-May have to relearn basic functions"		"@Kiel, also check out Recycled Cycles in Fremont if you aren't ready to go all in $ (or you are). This techn"""	"I didn't know that almond butter helped encourage good"" sleep. It's more designed for feeling better when waking up. This technique was popularized by Tim Ferriss in his 4 Hour Body book."					"Tim Ferriss believes that one of the biggest culprits for walking up during the night or feeling crappy in the monring is low blood sugar. To prevent this, eat 2 tablespoons of raw almond butter before bed. This low-glycemic index food can prevent blood sugar spikes so you can sleep better. In fact, according to Ferriss, correcting your blood sugar level can actually make you feel as if you?re doubling up on the sleep you?re actually getting ? 4 hours can feel like 8, 6 like 12, etc."""			"Hi Folks, thx for all the great stuff. One is processor affinity, which makes cache coherency between multiple"	"Windows 8 has some under-the-covers great improvements.  One is processor affinity, which makes cache coherency between multiple cores work tons better.  Translated from geek: it should run a lot of applications faster.But the user interface is a mix of a pretty version of Windows 3.1 (think 1991) and a great phone/tablet interface.  In my department at work, I have a head of IT/Ops who gave up on 8 on a new laptop and put 7 on instead.  And a real high-performing developer who had to turn to Google to find out how to turn his new laptop off after struggling for 15 minutes.  I tried both the beta and release candidate versions, and the UX had no advantage and lots of disadvantages on a desktop.In short: Windows 8 has some awesome features behind the scenes.  But the user experience is best on a tablet.  I strongly recommend Windows 7 for people who want Windows on a system."		We did a vacation rental in the 8th arrondissement and loved it. I can accomplish most tasks in Win8 as fast or faster than I could in Win7. People who use the mouse to access the start menu to navigate will have a harder time with the transition. There are some paradigms that you need to pick up, like how to get to the different Charm menus and what they hold. How to search/open files. What was really missing from Win8 was a video/slideshow on how to use the system. There is a lot of basic functionality that could've been explained easily and would've made most people's transition much smoother... If you're willing to put in the time to learn the new Win8 paradigms... I think it's worth it to use Win8. If you're put off by having to change your work flow then sticking with Win7 will be the better choice."		"We use a First Years Ignite for travel and short trips. http://www.amazon.com/The-First-Years-Ignite-Stroller/dp/B006WM8AACI"	"We use a First Years Ignite for travel and short trips. http://www.amazon.com/The-First-Years-Ignite-Stroller/dp/B006WM8AACIt's a great stroller for the price. For a com"	"My choice would be be something like the Steiner Merlin, http://amzn.to/VqeIf9, or Wildlife Pro http://amzn.to/XatkPt. For a compact I'd hesitate on going for magnification vs. field of view. I find that I'm happier with an 8x magnification and bigger field of view. Powerful magnification with a small field of view (which you're limited to with a compact) is really hard to hold steady. I find I'm better off with less magnification - it's just so much easier to see what I'm looking at if it's not bouncing all over the place. If magnification is really important I'd consider moving up to something like a Nikon Monarch, http://amzn.to/WhNVWc. They're not huge at all and they're probably the best binoculars for your buck around. We have both the Steiner and the Nikon and my wife and I always fight over the Nikon. :)"		"I'd skip 'em both and go with Etymotic, http://amzn.to/U33HWf. It can he"	"If you want something really interactive (animations, videos, images, galleries, text, etc.) consider Adobe InDesign.  It can help you produce an interactive PDF that you can not only create to display to pitch with but you can also put it online for them to review later, or put on a drive or CD to leave with the client.You can also consider creating a mini website using something with Parallax (a technique not a program) that makes for an interactive and captivating presentation in a new way.  These can also work on mobile devices for impromptu presentations.  They aren't the normal PowerPoint"" or ""Keynote"" but they are very effective in the right hands."					"Or you could go old school - pen and paper - and give them something to actually hold in their hands.  It really depends on what your product is and who your audience is."""			"Put an ad on Craig's List or Freelancer, talk with local high school art teachers (lots of great artists in high school), put a "	"Put an ad on Craig's List or Freelancer, talk with local high school art teachers (lots of great artists in high school), put a poster up at local colleges or universities, put a poster up at local coffee shops, go outside the norm.  Unless you have a hell of a lot of money to pay a professional.Either way you go, you need to make sure you have a contract.  What's the schedule of the project?  How are things delivered?  Who gets the credit in the book?  Who gets the copyright to the images?  Who gets paid what when they sell?  Who pays for the product to sell?  What about royalties if it goes into reprints or is picked up by a publisher?Since you aren't doing it all yourself you'll want an attorney involved, specifically a contract attorney and a copyright / IP attorney."		"Concept A will be too small to see on mobile, but otherwise it's different and it makes sense . Medical technology is advancing like crazy, particularly with regard to stem cells"	"Personally, I think it's a good investment.   Medical technology is advancing like crazy, particularly with regard to stem cells.   They're already figuring out, for instance, how to regrow someone's ears, nose, and possibly even things like eyes, organs and arms by using stem cells.The key is that this technology is just starting to develop -- and there are immense possibilities of what could be done with it.   As legal restrictions open up and scientists accomplish further breakthroughs, I anticipate that stem cells (obtained from core blood) will start to have some serious implications for someone's viability for potentially life-saving (or at least life altering) medical procedures.So, obviously you'd hope that she won't need it -- but given the rate at which things are advancing, I'd say it's a good thing to preserve given if she does end up needing it, it could really help her."		I agree with the heart/star crowd. I remember at the time we did it (we did it 7 years ago for #2, don't remember even being asked for our f"	"I love these answers.  I remember at the time we did it (we did it 7 years ago for #2, don't remember even being asked for our first child) reading that it seemed for certain worth it up to age 10.  Past that there were conflicting stories about whether the cells would still be good"".  But, for me, I look at it this way.  Do I waste $150 a year in other ways (Starbucks I don't really need, eating out too much, etc).  Absolutely!  If the time came and there was even a chance these things could help my sick child, would I hate myself forever and ever that I went to Starbucks every week but didn't pay for cord blood banking?  You betcha!  So, I write it off in my mind as one of the very best ways I may be throwing away my money."""		Haleakala crater is a possibility.  Everybody goes to see the sunrise but few hike the trails into the crater.  Don't let the ap	Haleakala crater is a possibility. Despite conflicting reports on the viability of the cord 	"It's like insurance. You get it hoping you don't ever actually use it. Despite conflicting reports on the viability of the cord blood (and stem cells which can also be banked now), we rationalized that we would be more upset if we decided against doing it and found out we needed it over the scenario if we paid for the cord blood/storage and didn't need it or it turned out to be a waste of money. Also, it is my understanding that it makes even more sense when there are multiple children since a siblings cord blood might be more useful than their own cord blood if the need were to arise.  "		I recommend using an insurance broker rather than going directly to an insurance carrier. You get the best of both worlds by not	"I recommend using an insurance broker rather than going directly to an insurance carrier. You get the best of both worlds by not being the one who pays the broker but you get someone who represents you. If anything goes wrong, the broker will advise you without there being a conflict of interest - claim payments don't come from them and they wont hold back on what you are covered on, or entitled to.  Also, getting car insurance and homeowners under the carrier will often come with a discount for both. "		Agree w @vivian. To stay in a jailbroken stat"	"An iOS update will usually require a new jailbreak, as Apple tries to shut the door on jailbreaks.  To stay in a jailbroken status, it may be necessary to delay an iOS update for a few months (worst case seen so far).   The 5.1 and 5.1.1 versions took a while, folks with jailbroken phones had to wait for the break in 5.1.1.  Additionally, different teams of people do the breaks, redsn0w is one, Absinthe is another.  The current one, for 5.1.1, is the easiest I've seen.  Some redns0w breaks have been a bit more complicated to manuever."		"Hi Nathan, askteal.com has a series of short videos that will blow your mind! Try one subject on the left. There are three things I think Apple does really well with the iPhone.  1.) the hardware itself just feels better, more solid, more seamless, and more elegant.   when you hold a phone as much as we do, that matters.  it's like a honda civic versus the ford tempo.  they both have similar features but one feels more buttoned down.  2.) the app selection.  most startups build apps for iPhone first.  you'll still get all the mainstream apps on android but the coolest stuff <like yabbly> will not ship on Android till they've launched on iOS.  3.) the user interface is probably easier, more intuitive, and nicer to look at.  Do it.  "		"Hi @Brent, our Yabbly Concierge team did some research for you and can see why it's not a no-brainer.  Most offerings on Amazon "	"Hi @Brent, our Yabbly Concierge team did some research for you and can see why it's not a no-brainer.  Most offerings on Amazon seem to have a mix of 5 and 1 star reviews which is often associated with manufacturers paid reviews.The challenge with most options relate to armband fit, access to controls, and fit.So we went to a number of runners forums and found that the TuneBand seems to be a common recommendation.  People seem to be pretty pleased because it's a simple design, fits well, and has good access to nano controls.  Hope this helps!http://amzn.to/11di64W"		I did ask about this recently (since we are expecting) and was told that storing these cells is possibly less useful than was pr	"I did ask about this recently (since we are expecting) and was told that storing these cells is possibly less useful than was previously thought. That seemed weird and I did some follow-up research myself ... http://www.gizmag.com/embryonic-stem-cells-replaced-blood-derived-stem-cells/23914/Apparently, the ability to regress adult cells (taken from you or me) into stems cells has really advanced to a high enough degree that banking might be moot. In the event that stem cell therapy becomes a normal procedure - let's say sometime in the next 20 years - it is likely that we will be using adult cells regressed to stem-cell stages since most people hitting middle age at that point won't have banked cells. As with all research, the regression is just a potential path but then again so it stem cell therapy. One more angle to consider."		"I don't live in Seattle but have had great customer experience with GEICO for auto insurance. You don't get into bed for other purposes, you don't bring a screen to bed or have TV in your bedroom, and you don't read extensively (over 30 minutes) before turning out the light. I also save that quiet time after lights out to direct my mind to a complex but not over-stimulating topic, like planning my garden for spring."""		"Check out NancyMorris.com, who has some great microlearning and 1-minute audio clips. They have seeds specific to zones.   Buy a	"Check out territorial seeds in Cottage Grove Oregon and order one of their catalogs.  They have seeds specific to zones.   Buy a soil PH / Fertilizer tester so you can amend soil as needed (can be done organically).  I use organic soil mix from the local Coop here in Roseburg OR.  Expect Fescue grass in organic mixes...easy to pick out.  Leaf lettuce is an easy grow.  When I lived in Bellevue beans did well, Sungold tomatoes are amazingly sweet, they don't come in until late summer.   Do heed the notes that most seeds need 50 degree soil to germinate.  Don't plant too early.  These garden shops just love pulling in garden supplies really early knowing fully well you will plant in March and be back in a month or two to replant because you planted too cold.  __   Finally...Artichokes...yup they do great in Seattle.  They can get real large and you might want to just plant them like a bush in a bed of their own.  You cut them back and mulch them over in the fall and they come back stronger the next year.  If you let them go they produce a beautiful 6 purple flower.  Finally...I just love Icelandic Poppies.  They keep shooting up blooms nearly all spring and all summer.  The flowers don't last long but they just keep blooming like that Energizer Bunny.  I usually put a poppy plant the corners of my raised bed or in pots.  Slugs are a problem you will have to deal with. """		"If time permits definitely downtown. """			"I am a lazy gardener these days, so I go for things that I can throw in the ground around now and they'll start to grow when the"	"I am a lazy gardener these days, so I go for things that I can throw in the ground around now and they'll start to grow when the sun comes out. Peas are great, put in 20 seeds now and you'll have more than you know what to do with by June (give them something to climb when the vines get a foot long or so.I don't really plant in rows much either, I just sprinkle the seeds and then gently rake them under the soil. Beets are really hardy, they work well (chioggas are really pretty.) Sprinkle a packet of green onion seeds, and you'll have them through the fall, starting with thin ones almost like chives, and ending with big thick stalks and nice white bulbs.Lettuce is good to get going before it gets too hot, or else it tends to bolt. Don't be afraid to thin it ruthlessly, otherwise you'll have way too many heads and they won't get very big. When the lettuce is 3-4 inches tall, pick out whole plants for amazing salads, aiming to leave the strongest looking plants about 9 to a foot apart so they have plenty of room to grow."""		Hipmunk is amazing. It's said to be compact, easy to maneuver, and stable so your beginners can enjoy themselves but it's still pretty easy to maneuver at 48 pounds.  Also, brand new it's $400 so you should be able to find one used for $250 and since it's a pretty popular model, it may be impossible to find.The main complaint is it's a beginners yak so it may not be the most agile boat in the water, the cockpit is probably too open (great for ingress and egress but not for for weather protection), and the seat is not comfortable after a few hours.  Here are some links:Video of a beginner not tipping over: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x3UCaNpmkA4Detailed reviews on Paddling.net:http://www.paddling.net/Reviews/showReviews.html?prod=2403Cheapest we could find new for $379http://www.austinkayak.com/products/1258/Old-Town-Vapor-10-Kayak.htmlHope this helps!Yabbly Concierge Team"		"Ironically I haven't JB'd yet, since I had an app update and turn my 5 into a heat source. If it's unlocked, then the SIMs can be swapped around.iPhone 3GS, 4, 4S all use micro-SIMs, the iPhone 5 uses a nano-SIM.  When I got my 5, I got it using the upgrade credit"" from my wife's 3GS.  To give her my 4S and take the 5, I had to go to AT&T, where they discarded both existing SIMs and gave me new ones, tied to the IMEI."					"What's an IMEI: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Mobile_Station_Equipment_Identity"""			"First question: you say Agile"", what do you mean by that? Together, do notifications, following a thread"	"Few thoughts:Do users need and/or wants to sort posts by the latest response? Together, do notifications, following a thread of interest, and the email feed cover this need/want?Case 1: [User don't want/need to sort by latest response] New/Latest and Trending are all intuitive to me.Case 2: [Users want/need to sort by latest response] Latest Question, Latest Answer, and Most Popular/Trending are intuitive and unambiguous to me (but maybe not as attractive and concise as the current labels). I listed Most Popular here because I feel it is still a touch more intuitive and universal than trending, and since it fits the whole 2-word flow. The problem with this naming structure, though, is that it excludes Latest Tips (and yeah, I feel latest post is somewhat ambiguous, so not a good alternative). If the additional filtering elements are necessary and a value-add, another option would be to give users a little more control by adding an element with a '+' or More"" label that expands the menu from two options, New & Trending, to reveal the larger set: Latest Answer, Yabble Favorites, Yabbler-of-the-Month, etc. Otherwise, users could just stick with the core two or three (whatever you guys find people are using the most currently). "					"Last, for either case, I would suggest renaming the section header ""Popular"" to something that identifies the elements beneath it more accurately, such Sort/Filter/Find/Yabble, etc. For example, not all of the current elements are actually related to popularity, such as Latest and Recently Updated."						"Hope this helps in some way!"""			I'm a big fan of Logictech Harmony remotes. It is always best to make sure they are not touching the dirt and are planted on	The longevity of a fence depends on the posts.  It is always best to make sure they are not touching the dirt and are planted on a base of gravel to help with drainage and surrounded by cement.  Post hole cement works for this.  Pressure treated last longest but do not inhale the dust when cutting as the chemicals are not good to breath in.  Wear a good dust mask.  Cut the tops with a slant and the rain will run off and you won't need copper caps.  For the planks and styles use good redwood which will turn grey over time if not treated with a stain or preservative.  Redwood not touching dirt will last almost forever.		"Second that @Tom, I consider Hipmunk.com as a one-stop-shop for your flying needs. We'll try to hit some of these places and report back when we return!	Thx for all the great advice folks!  We'll try to hit some of these places and report back when we return!		Save your money! There are amazing (free!) resources online these days - pick any brewing method and search YouTube - you'll fin	"Save your money! There are amazing (free!) resources online these days - pick any brewing method and search YouTube - you'll find hundreds of step-by-step tutorials. Don't bother with home-espresso machines because most don't have enough pressure to make really good espresso. I personally use a insulated Boudim french press(http://www.amazon.com/Bodum-Resistant-French-1-0-Liter-34-Ounce/dp/B0093EPC3O/ref=sr_1_sc_1?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1360343799&sr=1-1-spell&keywords=younug+french+press), but AeroPress (http://www.amazon.com/Aerobie-AeroPress-Coffee-Espresso-Maker/dp/B0047BIWSK) is a great option if you are making a single cup.Back in college and high school I worked as a barista, so I can confidently tell you there are just a few simple things that you'll need to master:Water quality - filtered is best, and this is often overlooked.Water temperature - people often pour boiling hot water over their beans and scald them. The ideal temp will vary based on what brewing technique you select, but it's never a roiling boil.Time - until you become a pro use your phone to set a timer (again based on method). Too long of a brew will turn the best roasted coffee into bitter sludge.Beans - obviously the thing most people focus on, but it's actually the least complex part. Just buy quality, whole beans and buy in small batches so it stays fresh. Grind yourself just before brewing.Enjoy!"		"It might look nice, but I'd question horizontal boards in Seattle.  The top of my small sections of fence that I built last year"	"It might look nice, but I'd question horizontal boards in Seattle.  The top of my small sections of fence that I built last year have started accumulating quite a bit of moss/algae/something on the top boards and the tops of the posts.  Not a huge problem, but considering most of the rot resistant woods (cedar, redwood) are fairly soft, cleaning"" them could damage the wood.  To keep things looking nice, I'd suggest good sealant on the boards if anything, but caps sure couldn't hurt..."""		"I know, I asked their CEO to hook me up but had to guess his email and am guessing he didn't reply.
