There are rear-facing seats with 5-point harnesses in the trunk and they get a kick out of facing backward and watching the traffic as we drive.  Kind of like the old Volvo station wagon.It is a lot of fun to drive.  Instant acceleration (no lag), very responsive handling, and the regenerative braking means I don't have to put nearly as much wear and tear on the brakes.Managing everything from a huge touch screen is fun and intuitive.  Feels like an oversized iPad.  And there are a bunch of small things they've nailed (like turn-by-turn on both the touchscreen and on the in-dash screen the driver can see without looking sideways).They haven't thought of everything, and there are some small nits I have. My wife's boss had her windows replaced and recommended theccompany highly to	"I replaced windows on my house about 7 years ago.  My wife's boss had her windows replaced and recommended theccompany highly to us:  Valley Glass.  The low cost really made me suspicious but I decided to get a bid.  I also had four other major name companies bid the job.  The bid range went from $7,000 to $24,000 based on vinyl vs fibreglass and low E option(s).To me it was fairly clear the decision was vinyl vs fiberglass and the low - e option was a given.That $7,000 bid was for windows that seemed to be every bit as good as the more expensive options.  Fiberglass really increases the cost and I don't think it is worth it unless you know for certain you will be in the home 25+ years.  I eliminated fiberglass quickly.I took the $7000 option and did not regret it.  For one thing they replaced a split pane window per original home construction the other's said could not be done.   They did the installation in one day and the installation was absolutely clean and flawless.  As for service I can't say because the windows have been flawless for seven years now and a service call has never been needed.  The windows are clearly as well built as the more expensive major brands I looked at.Valley Glass is family owned since 1946.  http://www.valleyglass.net/index.phpAs an aside I believe two of the four majors are no longer in business and a third is essentially selling off valuable divisions and shutting down the rest of the company.  Valley glass is still there."		"I'm with @Jim, I'd have the hardest time if I had to go back to a VT100, or worse, an ASR33." I have always encouraged my students to rent first, just to be sure that they like the instrument.  I also encourage them to save up until they can by at least a mid-grade piece.  A $500 cello, while completely functional, isn't going to have the make-you-cry richness that you are hoping for in starting out on this new musical journey.  Find a reputable dealer in your area, get fitted with a rental for a few months, and start saving up for a good cello 6 months to a year from now."					"Congratulations, and enjoy!"""			"Big improvements, nice job!" The Roam 2 is the simplest action camera you can get. No 	"It depends which GoPro model you are considering (white/silver/black). The Roam 2 is the simplest action camera you can get. No bells and whistles, easily the best combo of form factor/versatility of mount options out there.  There is no power button. It's either on and recording or off. Huge savings on battery life. Image quality is good but not a huge step up from the original Roam. It does add 60FPS at 720p with good enough quality for web sharing but still a little rough around the edges if you want to do anything high resolution. That said, 1080p/30FPS looks good. Currently the only way to change settings or review shots with this camera model is via a USB connection to a computer.With the Hero3 family you get Wifi, way higher quality still photo mode (and video depending on the model), and the ability to change your settings and review shots (via the LCD backpack accessory which costs extra). Button controls are less than intuitive but not horrible once you get the hang of it. The white and silver editions have the same picture quality as earlier GoPro models but the Hero3 Black steps things up significantly with pretty much the best sensor/lens/processor combination out there in the action camera market. Is it overkill for filming yourself while tumbling down a hill? Probably but quality is gorgeous. It also takes outstanding still photos and includes a burst mode that Contour does not have. The biggest sacrifice is form factor. Great for auto, can mount to a bike decently, chest mount seems to be a favorite, but you look like a complete and utter tool with one of these on your helmet and you do feel it if it's on your head. The Contour form factor does is much more stealth and lends itself to be mounted on the side of a helmet or to a bike frame (don't mess with handlebar mounts no matter what your option, they all suck).It's really only fair to compare the Hero3 family to Contour's higher end offering the Contour+2. It takes everything great about Contour's form factor, gives a noticeable bump in video quality through some serious tuning, and also includes Bluetooth and an iphone/android app that can act as a viewfinder, remote control, and a place to tweak image settings in the field.It all depends on what you are looking for. Is ease of use and form factor most important (get a contour)? Are you looking to make film-quality edits or just share stuff on youtube/vimeo (GoPro or +2 former, Roam2 latter)? Is image quality the most important factor (Hero3 Black)? Connectivity and the ability to tweak settings without a computer (GoPro or Contour+2 but Contour's app and setup is way more intuitive)?Happy shredding."		Surely!	Surely!		"Kevin, super helpful! If you don't like eggplant, don't plant it (though they are reall"	"Think about the food you'll eat -- don't just plant anything.  If you don't like eggplant, don't plant it (though they are really pretty plants).The easiest plants to grow are:- tomatoes (plant several varieties and start them indoors now for proper spring planting)- carrots (plant them in the spring, dig them up in the fall)- herbs (basil, oregano, catnip, mint, sage, etc.)- coleus (for decoration)- zucchini (but only grow if you'll eat it, grows like mad)- bush beans (like green beans, or purple, they're delicious)- potatoes- greens (lettuce, spinach, etc.)- bell peppers (grow a variety of them if you like them)- hot peppers (again, grow a variety)Definitely look into square foot gardening and keep it small initially.  I speak from experience.  I turned my entire front and back yards into garden a couple of years ago -- literally the entire yards.Get a single packet of each type of seeds, get the starter pods (usually 72 per flat) and plant them now so they're ready to go into the ground in a couple of months."		"Oh - and for soil, don't do straight soil.  Do a mix of top soil, black gold compost (or cow manure / sheep manure / horse manur"	"Oh - and for soil, don't do straight soil.  Do a mix of top soil, black gold compost (or cow manure / sheep manure / horse manure), styrofoam peanuts, peat moss, and pearlite.  Get real styrofoam peanuts make the soil lighter and allow your plants to grow better by getting more air to the roots.Feed the plants once every two weeks and water them either once a day for 20 minutes or twice a day (sun rise and 12 hours later) for 15 minutes each time.  Depending on your weather conditions.And anywhere you have grass, get some white dutch clover seed (order online, it's cheaper) and spread it all over.  White dutch clover is the only clover to put nitrogen back into your soil while it's still alive.  You can mow it and it will turn into little tiny baby clover heads all over.  Great for rabbits, great for your lawn, and if you do your entire lawn you'll only have to cut it once every month or two."		"There are ways to make pillows out of clothes like that, quilts, doll clothes, all sorts of options -- but that still means that"	"There are ways to make pillows out of clothes like that, quilts, doll clothes, all sorts of options -- but that still means that those things will be around the entire time taking up space.  And you may want to think about why you want to save them.  She's six months old and you already have several items -- as she grows (over the next 18 years) she'll have many many more.It may be better to take photos of the items, create a book full of images of her in those items and the items themselves, and a little fabric swatch if you keep some of it, then pick a couple to save for her perhaps for her hope chest for her kids, and either save the rest for your next child or donate to someone else who needs them.Otherwise you're risking creating a quilt every year of things that you liked or that were memorable when photos and videos can do the same thing without creating a lot of additional clutter."		"Why not consider Airbnb? Do you live in a condo complex with a lot of wireless networks in range? Watching online video would be one of the more bandwidth heavy activities online... Netflix/Hulu/Amazon recommend 1.5-3.5mbps for best viewing. At 12mbps.. you should be able to hold 3-4 streams pretty easily.  I currently have Comcast/Xfinity in Newcastle and consistently pull down 30-32mbps via speedtest.net. Depending on your price range ($150-$400), the Premieres have up to 1080p capabilities and 1TB of space. Also, the S3 models have been discontinued, so they most likely won't receive substantial updates.Additionally, the Premiere models are getting amazingly awesome updates ? they have a unique HD user interface and support Netflix, Hulu Plus, YouTube, and Pandora. If you really like the TiVo?s capabilities, an upgrade would be the best way to guarantee a better experience. However, if you would rather go all streaming, check out the TiVo Stream (http://www.tivo.com/products/tivo-stream/index.html), or it might be a better idea to stick with Amazon Video, Hulu Plus, and Netflix ? their lifetime costs would most likely be less than a TiVo?s.Hope this helped!-Yabbly Concierge Team"		"Hi Christopher,Thanks for asking! One thing to note is that Yabbly is more focused on product questions (e.g. how does Centu"	"Hi Christopher,Thanks for asking! One thing to note is that Yabbly is more focused on product questions (e.g. how does Century Link Internet compare to Xfinity Internet?).Since we value your very detailed and thoughtful question, we looked into it for you anyway :-) Both Century Link and Xfinity provide high-speed Internet, but while Century Link tops out at 40 Mbps, Xfinity offers up to 105 Mbps.You may want to contact Xfinity and see if it offers the highest speeds in your area. Besides that, Internet speeds will always vary from advertised based on your usage and areas (https://www.comcast.com/localization/localize.cspx?Referer=%2fshop%2fbuyflow2%2fproducts.cspx%3fSourcePage%3dInternet)."		Thx for everyone's input. It's more or less the same as what you'd buy, except a few things are removed (netflix, amazon video) and RCN's VOD is added.I would say, unless you want to record a lot of tv (which it sounds like you don't if you're considering cord cutting altogether), no.The premiere feels like an incomplete product.  A lot of the menus dump you from their HD experience to the old, old Tivo menus...  it's jarring.  There's nothing really new, just a few things that are polished up a bit.  The premiere is underpowered, so it can be sluggish and laggy.It's not that it's BAD -- if you didn't have an S3, I'd say buy one.  I just don't think it's worth paying to upgrade.  (Unless you're talking about a really discounted price.)"		"Thanks Jim.  Sounds like I should hold off on upgrading as long as possible. Relational DB's can vary, for example by having the statistics sampling happen during a non-representative ETL or batch job.  The stats then cause query plans to go awry."						"Non-SQL such as ISAM tend to be much more deterministic, though a burden is put on the developer to do more work planning and implementing the access."""			"I believe deterministic access time is not of upmost importance as we're not doing anything super critical $$-wise, just video g"	"I believe deterministic access time is not of upmost importance as we're not doing anything super critical $$-wise, just video game metadata. Same with being eventually consistent - availability trumps exactness. And I can't imagine we're going to have a lot of writes happening at once."		It actually sits quite warm at that time of year -- keep in mind I'm from one of the coldest parts of Canada where -40 F is norm	"It actually sits quite warm at that time of year -- keep in mind I'm from one of the coldest parts of Canada where -40 F is normal.In Iceland the normal temperature in March in the evening sits between 28 F - 38 F.  So wear layers.  Long johns, pants, wind breaker type pants over to stop the wind (it's usually windy when there are good Northern Lights (I grew up seeing them all the time where I was). For shirts have an undershirt (short sleeve), long sleeve thermal, and a polar fleece vest / jacket (where you can take the sleeves off, or a polar fleece jacket with a vest over.  You may find you want more arm movement.And get some proper winter gloves, the US doesn't really sell good gloves except in the northern states.  Leather gloves lined with fleece or polar fleece gloves are best.  For a touque (hat) go with polar fleece lined wool.You can buy some of that there or order it online."		Thx Jess we're keeping Other for now as a catch all in case we see a lot of new types of questions which we don't currently cate	Thx Jess we're keeping Other for now as a catch all in case we see a lot of new types of questions which we don't currently categorize. They have a wide range of options, but the downside is that they require a membership. Since you?re interested in the San Juan Islands, their overnight charters would be a best bet. Seattle Boat Share (http://seattleboatshare.com/Home_Page.php) is another option that allows boat rentals, but it seems like they only have one sailboat to rent. However, they allow you to buy a ?Share Pass? which you can use to rent the boats for an entire season. It?s something to look into if the Seattle Sailing Club doesn't meet your needs.Moss Bay (http://www.mossbay.net/index.php/boat-sales-share-storage.html) also has sailboat sharing, though they don?t have any sailboats as of now (it?s probably a good idea to contact them and ask them to keep you updated on sailboat status).Be sure to look through the San Juan Islands official guide (http://www.visitsanjuans.com/what-to-do/boating) as well as the Seattle Times boating guide (http://seattletimes.com/html/outdoors/2003709864_nwwboating17.html). Hope this helped!-Yabbly Concierge"		I think so but that's what we do today. I see a difference between product-specific"" quest"""	"Jumping in late to this thread but wanted to add a couple of thoughts.1. I see a difference between product-specific"" questions and ""category"" questions.   For example, a product specific question might be ""what is the best way to increase my battery life on my new Windows 8 phone?"" and a category question might be ""I am thinking about getting a new phone, what are your recommendations?"".    I am much more comfortable (and see it as a positive and helpful thing) if Microsoft or a local mobile phone store owner responds to my Windows 8 questions and is identified as a business.   I see it as trickier and more subject to abuse if business are responding to category questions since it could result in a lot of promotional spam that makes it harder, not easier, to make a decision.   This distinction may help find a safe way to start."					"2.  I like the idea that companies should earn their way to having a seat around the campfire (and lose it if they are not helpful).  I think the karma system in place could provide a good mechanism.   I think it could be as simple as having any business response be ""below the line"" in a separate area at the bottom clearly marked as such and with a different color response and then as they earn karma through providing helpful responses they can become a ""trusted business"" who gets to respond above the line with regular Yabbly members."""			"OK, never heard back from iBattz CEO so had to order the Mophie. You need to be careful about jarring them with sharp chopping motions or knocking them into other hard surfaces when setting them down. What are you planning to use these for @Sonia ?"		"A friend who works as an executive chef won't go near them, and neither will his peers--a professional kitchen is a bumpy enough"	"A friend who works as an executive chef won't go near them, and neither will his peers--a professional kitchen is a bumpy enough place that ceramic knives have a tendency to shatter. That, and once they're dull, they're effectively useless. Steel knives--good ones--can be dropped onto counters, bumped in knife bags, and sharpened for years under heavy daily use. That said: if you can be VERY careful in your treatment of the knives--never drop one, never set it down too hard, etcetera, and if you don't use it for an hour or more each day, you won't find anything sharper, nor anything that stays sharp as long. If you drop it, you'll throw away the pieces, and in a couple years, you'll throw away the dull blade no matter what, but otherwise, you'll be thrilled. In my own relatively quiet home kitchen, I went with very good steel knives (mostly Globals, with a couple of Shuns), because I didn't want to be afraid of dropping one every time I picked it up. They're easy(ish) to maintain, and a joy to work with, but not quite as sharp as the ceramics I played with in the store. If you can live with the drawbacks, ceramics are a joy to use. "		Can you give us some more detail? Mac or PC? What do you plan on using this for?	Can you give us some more detail? Mac or PC? The knifes should feel heavy,"	"@Matti is right: Go with quality - it will cost a bit more, but you'll be happier in the long run. The knifes should feel heavy, have a full-tang (it means the metal from the blade does all the way through the handle) and carbon steel (sometimes called German steel) is the best metal. Real Wustoff or Henckles knives are hard to find at a bargain and there are licensed knock-offs, so be careful. The real ones won't be cheap. "		"Henckles makes a great sharpener, http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00006CJLM, that I've found more effective than far more expensive tr"	"Henckles makes a great sharpener, http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00006CJLM, that I've found more effective than far more expensive triple-slot electric ones like http://www.squidoo.com/chefs-choice-pro-knife-sharpenerOne I learned to avoid is Chicago Cutlery, not too expensive but very ineffective. Once you've cut with a really high-quality knife you"	"If you aren't endeared to your knives, you do not have good enough knives.  Once you've cut with a really high-quality knife you will never go back.They're expensive, but you don't really need that many kitchen knives (you can get by with 2 or 3).I highly recommend Wusthof, provided you don't get their lowest end lines (Emirilware or Gourmet).  You lose all the benefits of a high quality knife; they're simply overpriced for the Wusthof name.  The Classic line is a solid entry-level but high quality line to get.  http://www.amazon.com/Wusthof-Classic-5-Piece-Studio-Knife/dp/B0000DJZHF/You won't find them on sale pretty much anywhere, except for the occasional clearance, which is quite rare.  Even stores like Bed Bath and Beyond explicitly exclude them from discounts (though I did once have a teller give me a discount anyway!)On top of that, make sure you get and use a honing steel (you might think of it as a sharpener, but it's not sharpening the blade -- it's straightening it.)  Use it every time, just before you use your knife.  It only takes a few seconds -- swipe the blade on each side 5 times, then 4, then 3, then 2, then 1.  http://www.amazon.com/J-A-Henckels-9-Inch-Sharpening-Steel/dp/B00004RFMA/Sharpening only needs to happen once a year or even less often, if you keep your blade honed.  I'm going to go against what Ted suggests and say you should never sharpen your own knives.  It's not that expensive to have a pro do it, they have significantly better hardware, and they're not going to hurt your knives.  And you absolutely should not be sharpening your knives more than once a year, unless you damaged it."		"For a straight up printer, the Brother HL 2270DW.  I have an older model, and absolutely love it.  Refilling the toner was reall"	"For a straight up printer, the Brother HL 2270DW.  I have an older model, and absolutely love it.  Refilling the toner was really easy, too.http://www.amazon.com/Brother-HL-2270DW-Compact-Wireless-Networking/dp/B00450DVDY/It's right now on sale for $77.99, which is a really good price for it; it usually sells for around $100.  (They make a lower-end, non-duplexing printer but it's around the same price since this model is on sale.)I've never had a great experience with a wireless multi-function.  I'm not positive but I believe a main reason is there's a standard for wireless printing, but not for wireless scanning. So it relies on specialized drivers that are written by...  well, not software companies."		Have been using Mailbox and quite happy.  Very speedy.  Main use case is in trying to get to Inbox 0. If California Adventure has early entry and you are not eligible, it doesn't make sense to run over to Cars Land at opening because the early entry people will have flooded it by then. We made that mistake and the young kids I was there with had a 1 hour wait as their first Disney experience! :("					"If you can, I would suggest having one adult stand in line with all the tickets and get fast passes for Radiator Springs Racers while you take the kids somewhere less crowded like Bug's Land & Paradise Pier (our 3-6 year olds LOVED the rides there best even though they weren't the coolest for the adults)."						"Another place that was fun to do first thing was Toon Town. There are some days (non early entry days) that Toon Town opens an hour after Disneyland, so you have time to do the Dumbo ride and the Teacups (and one or two other Fantasyland rides) before heading over and being first in to meet Minnie & Mickey (do Minnie's house first, it's smaller)."						"Something I didn't remember from my own childhood trips to Disney is how every ride has something scary - even the ones intended for the youngest riders! Our kids are fine with fast roller coaster stuff, but they were really scared of the dark tunnels and moving characters (Radiator Springs Racers & Ariel's Undersea Adventure among others). I wish I had talked to them ahead of time about what it would be like and avoided rides that were entirely dark scary tunnels like Mr. Toad's Wild Ride."						It is also good for kids to know ahead of time that many of the characters are really big and that most of them can't talk.						I agree with @Albert that Ariel's Grotto is great for princess lovers and worth the price to have personal attention from up to 5 princesses without waiting in any lines! But it may be too late to get reservations at this point. Call as soon as you can if you want to go!						"It's also very good advice not to try to do too much. You are there to have fun - it's not fun if you are frustrated with kids who are melting down because you tried to do too much! Plan to stay up late once for a parade or light show, but go to bed early on the other days. Our kids benefitted from going back to the hotel mid-day for a rest or a swim so that they didn't get overwhelmed by the parks. Honestly, they liked the hotel pool just as much as the rides!"""			One annoying thing about it -- the cutout for the buttons on the left side makes it asymmetrical.  I went with the Elago Outfit.	One annoying thing about it -- the cutout for the buttons on the left side makes it asymmetrical.  I went with the Elago Outfit.		For me. The solution  for us was peer pressure from a visiting friend (two overnights in a row dry) and it also worked well to place pull-ups over underwear--contains the mess but it's not comfortable for the kids, so they are less likely to see it as OK."		"Thanks again everyone. By getting the initial part out on the stones, even if ours top off"" in the yard, it doesn't cause the burn spots.   So if your yard layout allows for a well-draining area like that and you train your pup to use it first, it can save the lawn from a lot of burn spots"""		Very helpful - thank you for these recommendations! I went to college where Winter Carnival every year hit -40 that week.  And I've worked in such wonderful places as Kapuskasing, ON which also gets kinda chilly (it's where GM's cold weather test track is). In the long run each change in temperature, humidity and light exposure really does impact a slide.  A  consideration is that JPEG files don't color correct nearly as well as TIFF's.  I would consider selecting a small group of what you consider to be the most important images and have them scanned to TIFF format.  These will be very large files.I personally would send a test set of 10 slides to perhaps three companies then to Blurb.  Make sure the slides vary in color and look for slides with lots of dust and lint on them.Here are  are a couple fairly well written reviews:http://www.techhive.com/article/2000199/the-best-and-worst-services-for-digitizing-your-photos.htmlhttp://www.macworld.com/article/1143504/outsourcescanning.htmlOne thing I noticed is use of Nikon scanners by at least one other service.  I own a Nikon scanner and they have a feature called Digital Ice that removes dust and lint spots by using pixels next to the flawed area to cover the flaw.  To me this is a plus.The closer you get to Christmas the longer the turnaround for both scanning and printing.The  test runs are as much about turnaround and how they physically pack and ship your slides.  To be honest with you the quality of scan will be a function of the individual(s) doing the work, not the company.  (Professional photographers pay Master Printers big $)My perspective is based on high end scanning and printing.  I spend about 1/2 hour per slide for a clean 4000 dpi Nikon scan with multiple passes.    I send out my A"" tier slides to be drum scanned at 10,000 DPI.  Very expensive but necessary for high end large prints."					"Hope this helps."""			I took a follow up poll last night.  My 7 year old boy liked Legoland better than WDW. That means it move the air in a 10x10 foot square (or 100 square feet) with an 8 foot ceiling through every two minutes.  If you have a 1000 square foot apartment, it could clean the 8000 cubic feet in 20 minutes, or consider it would move all the air through three times an hour. Most HEPA filters are great for dus	"My advice is to look for one that has activated charcoal since removing smell is a concern.  Most HEPA filters are great for dust and some smell but charcoal can remove smell much better. Online ordering and delivery for coffee is excellent and when you need to contact customer service they are very pleasant to deal with."					I had some issues with the foam maker which is why I had to contact customer service. They took care of my issue flawlessly.  						"There lies the dimensions of choice I believe, range of coffee and coffee makers, customer service and online ordering experience/access to refill pods. "						"Looking forward to hearing what Keurig owners think about it."""			I am a Nespresso owner as well and have to say it's super convenient but I find the quality of the espresso itself is really a w	"I am a Nespresso owner as well and have to say it's super convenient but I find the quality of the espresso itself is really a weaker version of what you'd get from a traditionally fresh brewed, fresh roasted cup of coffee or shot of espresso.  That said, we have a Nespresso in the office and it does get used but only when we don't have the time or cash to go to a coffee shop.  If we had the money, we'd probably get a superautomatic maker for the office or a burr grinder and an aeropress.  Admittedly these are slower, messier, and not as convenient as the pod alternatives but if you love great coffee, it's worth it.  One last thing, the type of Nespresso pod you use makes a huge difference.  I have found the Arpeggio is the way to go and am waiting till we go through all the others before ordering a case of Arpeggio."		"@tom, thanks for asking on status. i have not yet made a decision. We booked a 1 bedroom suite and stayed in it with our toddler and 6 year old.Upon arrival via a shuttle, there were at least 15 cast members"" in the entrance area but no one helped us with our bags. I found that a bit odd. When you see a family of 4 with luggage and strollers spill out of a van the logical thing to do is to assist them. No one bothered."					We went straight inside and the kids camped out in the TV viewing area which made a 10 minute checkin work. Nice touch. We were upsold on concierge service for $250/night which seemed like a lot based on what they described we'd get so we passed. We then proceeded to the rooms.						"The elevators are fast with 4 zooming up and down at all times and we never experienced a wait, including our first ride up. The trek to our room was long, but the room was in a quiet part of the hotel which was nice."						"Upon entry to the room we scoped it out and found that it was a nice layout. The ceilings in the hotel are a bit ""low"" compared to higher end more modern hotels, and the bathroom space was pretty small with a tiny tub and no stand up shower. But we were happy with what we found, and it proved to be a comfortable place to get away from the crowds and nap / relax."						Our first issue in the room was that the pack n play was broken. It took a few hours to get this resolved with the hotel where they first claimed they send another one up (did not) and then ran out (did not) but then after my wife called for the 2nd time we got one we could set up.						"We attempted to head out and grab a bite, which was impossible at all the restaurants, but discovered a seldom visited ""grab and go"" type place to eat past the theme park entrance by the pool. We used this place to grab cereal in the morning and so on."						"On our first morning we ordered breakfast from 6-6:30 so we could take advantage of our ""magic hour"" early entrance to the part at 7am. We got a call at 6:35 that our breakfast (coffee and pancakes) would take another 15 min. That was a bummer. We cancelled and they offered to comp our breakfast the following morning. That was nice. Turned out it was a better plan and deal to just eat breakfast around 9:30 in the park since by then the kids were famished and lunch was another 2 hours away."						"The entrance to the grand California hotel is literally in the hotel and we got to take advantage of that twice. The extra ""magic hour"" alternates days between Disneyland and California Adventure. Our 3 day pass happens to coincide with 2 California Adventure days so that worked out well."						"The line can be long in the hotel, and we got there about 10 min before the opening and got in about 10 min after opening, mainly because the process of scanning people into the park is a bit of a cludge with multiple people inspecting your card, taking a photo (or checking your photo scanned on an iPhone), checking your bags, opening a door for the stroller and dealing with general issues. The best way to describe entering the park is that it's like boarding a 747."						"Anyway, after about a day or two we really started to appreciate the hotel. It's pretty much inside the park, with entrances to California Adventure and Downtown Disney where you can walk to Disneyland or take the Monorail into the park. "						The hotel definitely felt like a really nice Marriott hotel with the price of the Ritz Carlton/Four Seasons. We did not eat at the Napa rose or the other restaurant as we always found them to be crowded with lines or reservations that were a challenge to get on late notice (this is a reminder to book all your dinner reservations way in advance). 						The pool was simply packed to the gills every day. Every chair taken. But the staff did an excellent job keeping plenty of towels available and making sure none of the dozens of kids were drowning or jumping into the pool. 						"Our kids had a great time and we'd probably stay here again. I'd be interested in trying the Disneyland Hotel since it was renovated in 2009 to compare. No one I know has stayed there since renovation, and everyone we talked to recommended the Grand Californian hands down. For the price it's hard to justify the quality of the product, but you are paying for other conveniences staying here and judging by the crowds, this hotel has no problem staying full."						I have to shout out to the housekeeping staff who were amazing. Don't forget to tip them people!						"Room Tip: If you have 2 kids under the age of 6, the 1 bedroom suites are a great place to stay (but pricey)."""			Thanks - you gave me a lot of things to think about. But a few notes of caution: 	"I have the Allen deluxe 3 bike trunk mount which fits my needs. It's affordable and pretty durable. But a few notes of caution: - I have a fin on the back of my maxima and I've noticed the clearing on the rack isn't high enough so it scratched the fin. Shouldn't have this prob if you have no fin on your car. - it's a 3 bike rack but I would never advise loading it w 3 adult bikes. It's just too much weight and may cause damage to the bikes- make sure the rods have somewhere to insert in your frame. Full suspension bikes are tricky. - i would recommend for local trips. Nothing too mountainous or bumpyAll in all it's a really affordable mount for local trips. I use it once a week and love how easy it is. But if you want something more sturdy you should look into hitch mounts which will run you several hundred. I feel like roof racks are a pain. "		"I think she's old enough to give her the choice in a matter of fact, objective way.  Present her with the options that you can l"	"I think she's old enough to give her the choice in a matter of fact, objective way.  Present her with the options that you can live with: pull ups, undies, etc. and let her decide.  Tell her that the choice is hers on an ongoing basis and keep it an open and ongoing discussion.  If presented as a choice that she is making in a nonjudgemental enviroment I think you can steer clear of the things you are concerned about (suspended progress, messages of giving up, etc)."		I have Thule 4 bike hitch mount (~$200).  Works great and can adapt to two different hitch sizes.  It is hard to carry 4 bikes b	"I have Thule 4 bike hitch mount (~$200).  Works great and can adapt to two different hitch sizes.  It is hard to carry 4 bikes but can be done with some maneuvering.  Also, you can buy  a rack to carry ski/snowboards on the back as well.   The down side of hitch mount is clearance on driveways when weight is loaded on the back and finding parking to fit your car in space confined environments (i.e. city)."		"Ah, this version is such an improvement. Any post that's flagged by a member gets reviewed and can be removed if it's inappropriate.  We've also started a new program where a flagged post may be sent back to the Member for editing if it's appropriate but just not detailed enough or slightly off topic. 2.  Our policy on promotion of self or one's own  business is if it's a response to a question and that response is detailed, balanced, thoughtful, relevant, and helpful, we're fine with a business giving it's input so long as they clearly identify themselves and their response does not get flagged by members as spammy.We're still refining policies as these use cases emerge but at a high level, our mission is to help people make great purchasing decisions.  We'll always use that mission as our north star when figuring out how to facilitate the Community as it grows."		"Call Louis Everlast Window and Door. (206) 353-2655. The salt will make any unwanted protein hiding in them ( naturally occuring worms, especially for farm-fresh produce) literally come out. Soak for about 1/2 hour - and then rinse off with normal water. Carrots - recommend scraping them off with a knife - hold the carrot above a sink with one hand ( by its bulbier top) - then with the sharp side of a knife, position it about 90 degrees and scrape agains the carrot skin AWAY from you. Turn, once the side is scraped off, and repeat till all skin is cleared off. Wash off."		"you can get the rug pads ( not the carpet pads -  rug pads look 'grippy' - as Jason, and TedB say above) - and they will NOT sli"	"you can get the rug pads ( not the carpet pads -  rug pads look 'grippy' - as Jason, and TedB say above) - and they will NOT slide on wood -  they sell for cheap just about anywhere. Here is a link to one, as an example ( looks close to a shelf liner, and also make fantastic non-slide undersides for chair cushions :):  http://www.amazon.com/Ultra-Stop-Non-Slip-Indoor-Rug/dp/B003UV3FJ4/ref=sr_1_cc_1?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1362021745&sr=1-1-catcorr&keywords=rug+pads"		"I don't know if I'm a fashionista"" but, like Macklemore, I enjoy a good thrift shop find! I tried no water b	"My son is 5 years old and he was wetting on his mattress every night that we decided to let him use pull ups. I tried no water before bed time and some other methods described above. During his 5 years old check up, our pediatrician said that some kids are just not ready and it might be a good idea to give him a break and try it again later. If not, it might stress them out. My son is eager to learn to stop peeing at night but just not able when he is in deep sleep. Our pediatrician said that he will not be concerned about it until he is 6 years old. Our neighbor's daughter who is 5 years old is wearing pull ups as well. Another parent that we spoke to will put a towel above the mattress and whenever her kid wets the bed, it's become uncomfortable and she will use the towel to clean up and change. This is to encourage her to get out of bed and hopefully over time she gets used to it and will eventually use the potty. I have not tried this yet not sure if it will work."		"First of all, I'd definitely stay off the highways and take it easy on the hairpin turns.  Second, I might take it to Les Sc"	"First of all, I'd definitely stay off the highways and take it easy on the hairpin turns.  Second, I might take it to Les Schwab and have them check it out. Say you earn 20,000 points, those points are redeemable for up to $200 in travel (air/car/hotel). You can book travel through their online website (Travelocity partner) or you can book your own travel, pay for it with your  Venture card and then file a claim to use your points to essentially reimburse yourself for up to the total points you have available. The selling point is that there are never any blackout dates. Very true, but the value of your points actually fluctuates as airlines, hotels and car rental agencies, increase or decrease their prices during the times when you want to travel. I use it more than any of my other cards because I'm a leisure traveler and don't travel for business (well not very often), so I earn points steadily and they are always available for a spur of the moment trip."		Are you looking for just task and project management? According to tirerack:Audi - less than 4/32 tread depth difference "		Porsche - 30% difference in tread depth			"Subaru - 1/4""  circumference or 2/32"" tread depth"						If you're going to be over the recommended... you can have a single tire shaved down to match the ones that are on your car. One thing to look out for (according to some customer reviews) is employees giving you attitude.PhotoBin (http://www.photobin.com/) is a service which digitizes your photos, and they seem fairly contemporary with their approach ? you mail them your photos and they?ll digitize them for you, and send you back a DVD and your photos. ClearerImage (http://www.clearerimage.com/) in Bellevue also does photo-scanning to DVD, and depending on your needs has 3 different scanning resolutions for different prices (300 dpi for $0.19/photo, 600 dpi for $0.29/photo, 1200 dpi for $0.99/photo).Bartell Drugs Photo Center (http://www.bartelldvd.com/Prints_to_DVD.aspx) also does it ? they?re a tried-and-true solution to photo scanning and usually get it done fairly quickly.Hope this helped you get a start on your quest for photo digitization. If Artizia is what you like, i think "	"Maren, is Artizia the main style that you like or are you looking for something different? If Artizia is what you like, i think you may like Zara, French Connection, Club Monaco, Mercer and Bcbg. For Zara and French Connection, they are not available in Seattle, you can get them online. I like to get my coat from Zara. It's reasonably priced and seems lower than some of Nordstrom coats. I get my work dress from French Connection. They run a little small, so you may need to order a size larger. I like Monaco in Pacific Place for their simple solid color pieces for casual or work.  Mercer in U Village has more high quality, interesting design pieces but the price is on the higher side. Some of the Brand names in Nordstrom can also be found there. When i'm looking for more of an unique piece, i would go to Bcbg. It's more pricey so i usually just buy it during sale. J Crew style is quite close to Artizia in some way and they are in Pacific Place. Have you shop there?If you are looking for something new or different, there are a few neighborhoods with a number of small boutique stores carrying vintage clothes or local designer pieces that you may want to check out like Fremont (along Evanston Ave N & N 36th St) , Ballard (Ballard Ave NW between NW Market St & NW Lone St)  and Capitol Hill (On Broadway & Pike/Pine District)If you like more high end European clothings, just walk along1st Ave from Midtown towards downtown and you will find several of them. Happy shopping!"		"I had to replace a single tire on our car (Audi Q5, AWD) when the set had about 1500 miles on it. The Aquarium is neat if you like sea life.  I'm n	"I could probably write a novel on this topic.  How long are you visiting for?  The Aquarium is neat if you like sea life.  I'm not sure it'd be on the top of my list if you have minimal time.  The Science Museum is one of the best - VERY hands on, something for everyone - a guaranteed hit, but plan to spent the better part of a day there.  Don't bother with the Childrens Museum for that age or expect them to blow through it in 2-3 hours.  Duck Tour IS great.  I would only do Harvard Yard if it is nice weather.  If you do, kids love climbing the stairs of Widener Library.  The Harvard Natural History Museum is a small gem too that kids that age will love.  It can be done quickly if you don't have much time. If it is nice weather our favorite thing to do is walk from Park Street through Boston Common (hit the playground on the way), Ride the Swan Boats in the Public Gardens, and from there hope over to the Esplanade where just west of the Hatch Shell there is a GREAT playground for your aged kids - with a 2 story climber and a zipline - yes - a short but bouncy at one end and super fun zip line, that they can do all by themselves and love.  Max Brenner Restaurant is an indulgent favorite if you want a chocolate treat.  My kids love the brunch at Cafe Fleuri which has a chocolate fountain for dessert.  Anywhere you go is educational in Boston given all the history.  I saw that they resurrected the Tea Party Museum - small if you want history, there is also the USS Constitution if they like big boats and you want educational."		"That looks like a pretty low profile tire, so the tolerances will be tighter than on a higher sidewall. Thanks!	grmeyer - I new knew those services existed.  Thanks!		We have had both types over the years and we certainly prefer the gas.  Gas is easy to regulate by sight as you can see the flam	We have had both types over the years and we certainly prefer the gas.  Gas is easy to regulate by sight as you can see the flames and determine the heat level.  Induction requires a bit more faith in that area as you only have the dial.  The pot bottoms must be completely flat so this is a must for induction so the extra expense there.  The same pots work great on gas as well.  Induction sounds cleaner but after a few years of scraping and polishing the surface we found that it became scratched and unsightly.  That was years back so the surface may be better now but not then.		I agree with EHoffanonymous.  We use SW as it flies to the places we like to go and where are kids live so that is an important 	I agree with EHoffanonymous.  We use SW as it flies to the places we like to go and where are kids live so that is an important factor to consider if choosing this card.  With their recent expanded routes through acquisition the areas covered has increased.  Their website is easy to use as well.		"We love our induction cooktop. I recently researched this when buying a new ra"	"Reliability is an issue on induction, although it has comparable control to gas. I recently researched this when buying a new range. Induction ranges (even spendy ones) have poor durability and will often completely break - the technology isn't really battle-tested the way radiant electric has been. Consumer reports did not place them highly. Gas is the most controllable and responsive but also the least efficient. "		"Agree Vincent, the privacy protection pitfalls are pretty problematic.That took care of my alliteration quotient for the day"	"Agree Vincent, the privacy protection pitfalls are pretty problematic.That took care of my alliteration quotient for the day..."		"Sorry to say that my friend who went to Munich in college didn't remember much, but he did have coaster for fifty different type"	"Sorry to say that my friend who went to Munich in college didn't remember much, but he did have coaster for fifty different types of beer."		Hi @Deanna thanks for the great question! Change the set?? never. As a rule,"	"This is from Rani who put this on the YB Facebook page:Change the tire.... WITHOUT A DOUBT. Change the set?? never. As a rule, tire tread depth should not be off more than 2/32 across the axle (side to side, not front to back). If the left one is replaced and it will make the right one more than 2/32 difference across the axle, then yes, change them both and save the good one for a spare. Otherwise, no. And don't let the tire company force sell you tires because it;s the law"" or ""company policy"". Find your lowest price on the tire. Drive to your local dealership, buy the needed tire there and ask them to price match it. I know it's a GM or Ford, they will. Don't however buy them at Walmart or Sears as they are supplied with company specific models of brands which means you can only get them in certain regions at Walmart or Sears and not outside those retailers. ALSO.... check your collision deductible.... if it's only $100 (which is the trend), then hitting a pothole that damages your tire and wheel cover, as well as the necessary replacement on the opposite side of the axle... those are covered."					"I just got a Mac and some Yabblers recommended Sophos to me yesterday. You d"	"Honestly, Jettas are nice, but if you are looking at something in the $1500 range, I would go for something made in Japan. You do not want to get into a money trap, and parts for the  German made Volkswagens are much more expensive, as is the labor. In driving a bit of an older car, you are going to have to expect for minor repairs here and there. Japanese cars are the way to go, specifically Hondas. They are cheap to maintain, run forever, and due to the mass amounts of Japanese repair shops, the labor costs are driven down by competition. Parts are cheap as well. I would go with an older Civic or Accord. they get great gas mileage as well! Hopefully that helps! I am a car person and have helped out many people in your boat. Let me know if you have any other question. "		"I agree with @John. You definitely want to get a Honda or Toyota. Cheap parts and repairs, run for ever and are more reliable, e"	"I agree with @John. Then	"@paul I have an iPhone 5 with Verizon. Their new share all plane is really good because it has unlimited minutes and texts. Then you can choose A data plan between 2GB and 10GB for an extra $20 to $80 depending on which data plan you choose. The data gets shared between all the phones on that plan. For me (I have 5 phones in my plan) 6GB is plenty for all 5 phones. This plan also includes free tethering so you can hook up you phone to your laptop and use it as a modem. Most areas that I move around have LTE speeds (south Florida) so that's another plus. You might want to check Verizon's LTE coverage map for your area.As far as android vs iOS - IMHO I think iOS is more robust. And way simpler to use then a android. To use an analogy, android is like windows and iOS is a Mac. Both work fine, but one is more intuitive the the other. At the end, the OS choice is a preference thing."		There is a write up from Elizabeth Warren (google Elizabeth warren Fresh Air interview) I think that everyone getting a credit c	"There is a write up from Elizabeth Warren (google Elizabeth warren Fresh Air interview) I think that everyone getting a credit card for the points should listen to his interview and take a hard look at all the restrictions and what I call Hooks"""		We got the Spirit Air mileage card and we racked up 40k miles in no time. It means you're not stuck to a specific airline, it means you can book whatever ticket you want.  But the simple 1 point = 1 dollar stops holding true if you use your points to book upgrades or business/first class tickets.  You can find tickets where you're getting $3 or more per point on a higher-end ticket.  So, you lose that aspect of 'real' miles.Chase Sapphire is different in that they allow you to get native miles with an airline via transfer.  Seems like a good mix of flexibility and earning.All that said, I'd also suggest you consider just a cash back card.  Cash is good for anything, and it's pretty easy to find a card that earns at least 1.5%, and some offer 5% promos that can bump rewards higher than that.  I have the Chase Freedom and typically earn between 2 and 2.5% cash back over the span of a month's purchases.  I also use the capital one cash card which earns a flat 1.5% (and, as someone mentioned above, has no foreign transaction fees which is very nice when traveling)."		I'd look at Daily Grill on 7th and Pike they have amazing burgers and comfortable atmosphere for kids.	I'd look at Daily Grill on 7th and Pike they have amazing burgers and comfortable atmosphere for kids.		"The amount of water (and, for some, pesticides and other chemicals) we pour into the ground maintaining a useless plant is -- bl"	"The amount of water (and, for some, pesticides and other chemicals) we pour into the ground maintaining a useless plant is -- bluntly -- stupid. Therefore I run my own email server (qmail based,"	"My choice for AV is to put a strong blocker on the most likely source: email.  Therefore I run my own email server (qmail based, with jms1's patch kit) with the best AV detector, ClamAV, on it.  This is the only process that's kept the PC's I have completely clean.  I got whacked by a virus once on a WinXP laptop.  It was 10 days and 14 days before McAfee and Norton could even detect it.  Had it been running ClamAV it would have been blocked, they had a definition before it got to me.  The basic problem though with any AV software is they update signatures based on people reporting infections; that means some people get infected before the definitions block it.  So a multi-layer defense in depth strategy is a good idea.  Use an email service that uses ClamAV (gmail does I think).  Then use a commercial AV on the PC itself."		"Organic chemistry major weighing in here, actually octane is not a measure of power per se.  I had a lecture in graduate organic"	"Organic chemistry major weighing in here, actually octane is not a measure of power per se.  I had a lecture in graduate organic about this topic, digested below:The octane rating is a measure of the activation energy needed to combust spontaneously under temperature and pressure.  Higher octane ratings allow the use of higher compression engines, so the combustible fuel/air mixture can be more compressed, allowing for more power when it does combust.  Thus putting a higher octane fuel in an engine will do nothing for its power unless the compression is also increased.See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octane_rating#Examples_of_octane_ratings for examples of what gives different rating."		"@Calia, there's  a startup to address a similar issue to the one you raise: http://www.geekwire.com/2012/tether-technologies-inc"	"@Calia, there's  a startup to address a similar issue to the one you raise: http://www.geekwire.com/2012/tether-technologies-inc-2/"		"Brooks, how is that turf at dealing with stubborn weeds coming up from underneath? Yet the blasted weeds find a way to get up through the landscape fabric, really getting significant in the last year or two. My defe"	"Additionally: the primary attack vectors for viruses & malware these days includes Adobe Flash, Java, and Adobe Reader.  My defense on them is to put an extension like QuickJava (http://quickjavaplugin.blogspot.com/) that provides pushbutton to enable Flash, Java, Javascript on the browser toolbar.  Surf with Java and Flash disabled, only turn them on when you hit a page you trust that has something you need that's in one of them.  Turn it off before going to another page.  This can drastically reduce the attack surface on your machine.  On a Mac, use Preview as the viewer for PDF files, it doesn't allow executable extensions like Adobe Reader does, so attacks are nipped in the bud.  I haven't looked for an equivalent on the PC, I just don't read PDFs on a PC."		"What kind of food do you like? Worked great for my daughter, my son is taking a little longer (he's 1).  But"	"I am teaching my kids to stay out of the kitchen.  Worked great for my daughter, my son is taking a little longer (he's 1).  But to me it is worth the effort because that minimizes the risk.  Sure, I'm still careful, but it is nice to cook dinner without toddlers at my feet.When my daughter turned 3, we started allowing her to come in once in a while and stand on a stool or chair.  If she fooled around or couldn't stay on the stool, her time in the kitchen was up.  Now, she's nearly 5, asks permission to go in the kitchen to clear her dishes, and loves to help us bake (with permission to go in the kitchen, of course)."		Sorry but I am being lazy ! Cars will slow down or speed up their timing, so when the octane is lower or h"	"@tedb - ah...very good to know. One thing though. Cars will slow down or speed up their timing, so when the octane is lower or higher the timing will automatically adjust (by its computer) so in practice a higher octane gas will give it just a bit more power. This is the way I understand it.@tom in that case, Arco is not a good gas to buy."		"After using both the Chase United and Marriott Visa for a while, I thought I'd look at other cards to see if I was using the rig"	"After using both the Chase United and Marriott Visa for a while, I thought I'd look at other cards to see if I was using the right one, especially considering new models like Capital One that allow you to use it anywhere. After looking at our own spend and travels, Chase United makes the most sense for us...more value than cash back and the value from Capital One. Plus, we can use the miles since we generally take longer, more expensive flights and use the 2c/mile rule. So the key is to look at your own spend and points usage to see what's right for you."		Hi @charleen great question! I'll add a few ideas:- Nothing beats Central Park on a nice day, but the Highline down on the West Side is newer, hipper, and a lot of good people watching down there.  At the terminus of the Highline at 32nd and 10th is a beer garden that friends of mine have been rumored to waste the day at hehe- If you are going out at night, NYC is fun but don't forget Williamsburg which is even more vibrant these days.  Brooklyn Bowl is a perfect place to see the hipster in his key habitat.- Foodwise, you should either go High or go Low.  For Low I mean don't forget about bagels (Russ and Daughters!), pizza (Keste or Co.!!!!), brunch (Shopsins), dumplings (RedFarm) or noodles (Chinatown) etc.  For Foodie paradise try to hit Smorgasburg in Brooklyn, Eataly in Flatiron, or Essex Market in the LES.  For High food I second Marea, Ma Peche, and Bernardin.  I also recommend Del Postos in Chelsea, Perilla in the Village from the Top Chef winner, the amazing Annisa from Anita Lo, and any of the Michael White pasta spots like Osteria."		"Green Lake Jewelry Works (which is actually located near Northgate) has some very beautiful, intricately detailed pieces. It heats up quickly, and the heat "	"We went with an induction cooktop from Thermador when we built our new house, and we love it. It heats up quickly, and the heat gets as high as we wish. We have not had any trouble keeping the cooktop clean. We wipe it down after each use with a damp rag and every few weeks, wipe it down with CeramaBrite. We mostly had cast iron (including our wok!) and stainless steel pans, so we've had no trouble with the cookware. We find that the pan is heated more evenly than with the gas stove we had at our rental; that always had a ring of extra warm area where the flame was."		"Tom, I find Norton & McAfee both become resource hogs. Alth"""	"I agree the timing adjusts with modern cars, though this is mostly an anti-knock feature more than a more power"" feature.  Although things can be done for more power, I put a chip in a BMW in the 90s that gave me about 15 bhp extra, which really moved that car along.  It required higher octane gas.  Note though that the stock chip gave no extra power when I put premium in the tank, it took the modified chip to do that."					"To get more power, these modifications the the fuel delivery systems work by adding more fuel in the fuel/air mixture to take advantage of the higher activation energy of the higher octane numbers.  That's an unusual thing to find in the stock ROM in cars, as they typically focus on fuel efficiency, not power."						"I'd love to know what cars are shipping with ROMs that do take advantage of Premium dynamically, that's certainly possible but I don't think it's mass-market typical."""			"When buying a printer, always check the replenishment costs.  Many manufacturers are moving to a razor blades"" model: sell the """	"When buying a printer, always check the replenishment costs.  Many manufacturers are moving to a razor blades"" model: sell the printer cheap, but charge a lot for the supplies to use it."""		"I'd go for Lobster Sandwiches/Rolls at Fairway Market in Brooklyn, just reopened Friday after Sandy. I recommended Tom use Sophos for his Air since they had a free version for the Mac and I have had good luck with the product on my Mac for the past couple of years. The University of Washington uses Sophos for the machines and this is where I first encountered it. I have also been using the Astaro gateway for the last few years with great results and it was acquired by Sophos a year or two ago (with no negative consequences). Now, when going to the Avast site today, I noticed that they now have a free anti-virus product for the Mac as well. I have not had a chance to try it out yet, but may give it a try since I have had such great experience with their Windows products.The big thing for me is real-time scanning. Both the Avast and Sophos products offer a real-time scanner as a part of the free offerings. They also offer email scanners, although in my case, email is scanned at the gateway so this is less of an issue. I have also found the products to remain invisible (no performance issues) unless there is a problem."		Scalinatella is an AMAZING super authentic Italian restaurant that Ryan and I LOVE. Classical, rock, dance, ?Do you want to feel the bass, or savor the stroking of the bow on the violin s"	"What kind of music?  Classical, rock, dance, ?Do you want to feel the bass, or savor the stroking of the bow on the violin strings?  How important is the apparent placement on a sound stage?  These may sound like weird questions but that helps calibrate what kind of speaker you'd like most.And the speaker is the most important part of the purchase: select the speakers, then the equipment to drive them.  Pick the speakers by what you & the other listeners like; I don't have your ears, nor does anyone else."		I also think that Netflix has greater selection. There are other, cheaper ones but the Nest is definitely the easiest to set-up as a novice and use.Had mine for just shy of a year and it does really help you save. The smartphone programming is great (as is the remote access via phone). It also does a great job of auto-learning your daily patterns. The only compatibility issues will be on certain high-voltage controls - you see that commonly in condos. I think the utility companies providing rebates (typically not a give-away) on these thermostats are making a choice about reducing their overall usage. It simply depends on the provider's priorities."		"So that's 4800 to 6000 cubic feet to fill with sound. Some of those are pretty corrosive, so use of a power chip has impact on not just the O2 sensor, but also oil lifetime and exhaust system corrosion.  I changed the oil twice as often when I had that car."					"Now I have a Mini with the JCW engine, no power chip needed."""			I plan on going to a pro tuner to mod my chip bc plan on upgrading the intake system as well :-)	I plan on going to a pro tuner to mod my chip bc plan on upgrading the intake system as well :-)		@tedb that mini looks awesome and surprisingly roomy inside. :)	@tedb that mini looks awesome and surprisingly roomy inside. :)		"Good points Alex. I worked at a community pool once upon a time that wasn't built to that standard, so it had to be filled with fluid at all times to provide a pressure on the pool walls sufficient to keep the earth from pushing the walls in.  I would like to think construction codes would dictate that, but personally I'd make sure."		"Yep, I'm tall but the Mini is surprisingly roomy for me.  @Tom, keep in mind the above discussion points about O2 sensor, exhaus"	"Yep, I'm tall but the Mini is surprisingly roomy for me.  @Tom, keep in mind the above discussion points about O2 sensor, exhaust system, and oil change impacts."		The Berliner! It also seems to work well as a daily microwave.The biggest gripe people seem to have with the oven is cleaning the inside - it?s very difficult because of the way the oven is shaped. People said that the cleaning process required them to turn the oven up to 200 degrees, turn it off, and then clean ? a long process for sure.The manual is apparently not very helpful and there is a learning curve to determine which function is more appropriate for different types of food. The oven also needs to be turned up to a very high heat to make pizza (which may require some time if you do happen to be cooking for 10-20 people). Another minor gripe people had was that the door opens downward like conventional ovens and unlike side-opening microwaves.A few other speed ovens to check out are GE?s Advantium 240 (yabb.ly/Gaoe0S), which offers similar functionality for a lower price, and AEG speed ovens (yabb.ly/hBPQNB).We hope this helps you in your decision. Let us know which one you choose and what you think. Thanks!-Yabbly Concierge"		I have been very happy with the Bose. Great sound 	I have been very happy with the Bose. Oregon Tilth and others are far more useful indicators of the actual organ	The USDA certification is not a really reliable one.  Oregon Tilth and others are far more useful indicators of the actual organic-ness than the USDA (which allows 95% organic content food to be labeled as USDA Organic).  See http://www.organic.org/articles/showarticle/article-201 for example.		"From a pure price perspective, I'd recommend buying unlocked Androids (I really like my Nexus 4) and getting pre-paid plans (e.g"	"From a pure price perspective, I'd recommend buying unlocked Androids (I really like my Nexus 4) and getting pre-paid plans (e.g. no contract, no phone subsidy). We have the T-Mobile Unlimited Everything on two lines. Since it's pre-paid, the taxes, etc are very low, so *two* lines with unlimited everything (talk,text, data) is $100.70 per month.Downsides though: (1) T-Mobile coverage isn't as good as others, so if you go off the beaten path, you'll get disappointed at times. (2) Our data plan is 4G for the first 200 MB per month, then 2G (?) afterwards. Hasn't really been an issue for me yet.I think that you can similar pre-paid on AT&T and others if those networks are better for you."		Business travelers know best and they say AmEx Starwood Preferred Guest. Really deciding depends on exactly what 'around town' and 'backc	"Those are both proven and economical bikes. Is this your first? Really deciding depends on exactly what 'around town' and 'backcountry' mean, and deciding what the primary reason for getting the bike is.Will around town include the highway? The KLR can survive there, the DRZ can't. Is the backcountry dirt/gravel roads, forest service firetrails? the KLR is fine on these. If by backcountry you mean real dirtbike riding, whoops, outlaw/powerline riding, the DRZ (or even a 250) is going to be superior.My first bike was an NX650, a 650 single quite similar to a KLR. The 650 will be better if you ever have a passenger and is a great do-it-all type of bike. People can and do take 650's on real offroad adventures, but smaller bikes just make more sense here. If the main purpose of the bike is to spend all weekend in the woods (and you don't have to take the highway there), get a smaller bike like the DRZ."		"Can't figure out how to edit my response, but I noticed you said it's your first bike. Additional advice then:Sit on them. R"	"Can't figure out how to edit my response, but I noticed you said it's your first bike. Additional advice then:Sit on them. Ride them if you can. Depending on your height/weight, the KLR might feel too tall or the DRZ too short. This can be a dealbreaker. Lowering a bike isn't that difficult or expensive, but you can't really raise one.Neither of these is likely to be too powerful for you, so don't shy away from the KLR for that reason. Take the MSF basic rider course if you haven't! Usually very cheap. Skills you need. Also an easy way to get some saddle time and decide if you want to buy your own machine."		"Question: when the  Brother MFC-J835DW  scans photos, does it show dust/spots? I have a very nice brother color inkjet printer as well.  I bought it really cheap at Staples.  It's multifunctio	"Hi @Charleen.  I have a very nice brother color inkjet printer as well.  I bought it really cheap at Staples.  It's multifunctional/All-in-on:  printer/copier/scanner/photos.  *** A word of advice:  be careful with these printers,b/c although they may be sold at a good price, they get you with the ink cartridge replacements.  For example on my Brother printer once 1 color cartridge finishes, I can't print at all.  Not even just black and white!  I think this is a major consideration when looking for a printer.  Hope this helps."		"Being a father now- I would ride so tentatively, it wouldn't be any fun. "	"Being a father now- I would ride so tentatively, it wouldn't be any fun. If that's the case, according to the government crash "	"I love car questions!  OK, so it sounds like safety is important to you.  If that's the case, according to the government crash testing http://www.iihs.org/ratings/summary.aspx?class=15 the two top picks are the Acura TL and Volvo S60.  It's interesting to note that cars like Mercedes and Audi which you'd think would do well do not as well on the govt's new partial overlap frontal tests.  Perhaps the TL and S60 were just engineered in time to optimize for that test but that probably doesn't change your decision.Now that we've got safety down to those two mid sized, four door sedans, I ignored smaller cars like the TSX because of your great interest in safety, it comes down to reliability.  As a Honda man, you probably know Acura is owned by Honda and enjoys great reliability.  The Volvo S60 is not as well known for its reliability (it's not horrible, just average).The only thing I'd add is spring for the TL AWD model if you want more safety when driving in the rain.  I will add one curve ball that just occurred to me.  Have you thought about a small SUV like the Acura RDX?  It's a couple hundred pounds heavier than the TL, is a crash test top pick, and in general SUV's are said to be more survivable than sedans with equal weight due to the height advantage (SUV's have a 30% higher survival rate than same weight sedans).  http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1061355_latest-safety-stats-new-suvs-are-safer-than-sedansThe one slight drawback is the RDX is super reliable but probably not quite as reliable as the TL and is 2 MPG less efficient."		"I second:Walking on the Highline (from 34th street to lower Manhattan) - lots of places to nibble but I am not able to speak t"	"I second:Walking on the Highline (from 34th street to lower Manhattan) - lots of places to nibble but I am not able to speak to it first hand.IF YOU want to walk over the Brookln Bridge (take the 6 train to end) into Brooklyn Heights- 2 places you should NOT miss ( ok maybe 4)Noodle Pudding ( gnochis to die for - all cash, reasonable)The Vinegar Hill House ( reservations for 4 or more, but you shoudl be able to get right in before 6:45 PM) - take the F train from Manhattan, or the A, C, into Brooklyn, first stop into Brooklyn. Use www.hopstop.com for best transport directions.3, 4 place: Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory ( easy walk from Noodle Pudding): bring your camera for great viewsand - Grimaldi's Pizzeria ( cash only too but great NY style pizza): take 2,3 to Clark Street and walk towards the water for about 6 mis - on the right.I personaly LOVE The Modern - amazing retro cocktails on 57th and 5th. I also love a wonderful British Colonial Retro Cocktails bar ( read: hidden bar) in lower manhattan called The Pegu Club ( go for the gin infised Earl Gray Martini) and within easy hike, a hole in the wall called Pedro's ( amazing homemade Italian - really small and not pretentious place.)"		@Joe: I found it- sort of - online - a place in FLA who imports it from - you guessed it- Jamaica! :) thoug I would love to purs	"@Joe: I found it- sort of - online - a place in FLA who imports it from - you guessed it- Jamaica! :) thoug I would love to pursue your idea of begging some snooty French Chef in NYC for help :) www.purelifeherbs.comExcept now I have to wait fo rtheir NEXT import of leaves from Jamaica :) But it seems well worth it!"		IF you are sourcing for duck foie gras ( raw or cooked)- few places in East and West Coast - if you can shop on the East Coast (	"IF you are sourcing for duck foie gras ( raw or cooked)- few places in East and West Coast - if you can shop on the East Coast ( tey have reasonable and reliable overnight shipping) I recommend the NY finest - Hudson Valley Foie Gras. I make my own foie gras and I love them. The one I chose for my vacation home is the Honeywell model RTH8580W	Funny - Steven and I have had this chat between ourselves. The WF stands for WiFi and it easily hooks up to your wireless and can be set and controlled remotely through a free website they provide.  I can even do it from my old Blackberry.  It is an easy set up and costs about $140 at Home Depot.  That is about half the cost of the Nest.  If you don't need the thermostat to automatically change settings based on your pattern of use then this is the one I would recommend for sot and ease of use.		"I agree with @Gary and @Tom. The more you see, the worse everyone's performance will "	"1: when you turn on a machine, how many other networks are you seeing?  The more you see, the worse everyone's performance will be due to interference.2: wireless phones compete in both frequency ranges.3: Microwave ovens (see http://xkcd.com/654/) interfereIf any of those are issues for you, you can usually set interference robustness"" to help with such complications."""		I have Comcast cable modem and use the Netgear NRW350v2 wireless router. Here is what we found: Redwood Security Systems (https://redwoodsecurity.com) is one of the largest Bay Area-based security companies. They do offer installation and servicing, and they?re certified by a lot of organizations (check the bottom of their homepage for the entire list). In the last 3 years, they?ve had 0 complaints against them according to the Better Business Bureau (they?re A+ rated). However, it seems that some customers have had problems with rude customer service. Something to look out for if you decide to go with them.Escobar?s Security Plus (http://www.espalarm.com/) is also Bay Area located and has been around for over 50 years. Their webpage is pretty bare right now (they say they?re currently developing a new website), but based off the services/features they list, it?s worth an email if not a call. They do partner with national security company Bosch, so they may not be able to meet your local need.Bay Alarm (http://www.bayalarm.com/) seems to be more contemporary than the other two (just by the look and functionality of their site). They?re local and they say they will customize your security system to fit your needs. However, a lot of customers seem to be having problems with them raising their prices mid-contract. That?s something to make sure you establish before you go with them (if you do)The Bay Area is huge and there are a lot more companies that can offer an alarm system, but we hope this helps you find a few potentials. Let us know which company you eventually go with!-Yabbly Concierge"		"Amex has one account, but separate card numbers. Do I get extra points for agreeing with the CEO?  j/k   My personal choice is a dedicated PC wit	"I'd avoid the 360 for blu-ray.  Do I get extra points for agreeing with the CEO?  j/k   My personal choice is a dedicated PC with PowerDVD to play blu-ray movies.  That way any source from the PC can go through the nice display.  Also, PowerDVD does some smoothing and up-sampling to make DVD's look better.One big thing to remember with blu-ray is the need to update the player constantly, as there's an arms race between them and software like AnyDVD that decode the keys to allow full features.  So the keys are always being updated, and whatever you're playing them on needs to be up to date.My second choice would be a Sony PlayStation, as they are the originators of the blu-ray format, their updates tend to be the fastest."		"Thanks Tom, will look into that more. Side note, noticed Yabbly is in the Seattle area, glad to see people from this area comi"	"Thanks Tom, will look into that more. Side note, noticed Yabbly is in the Seattle area, glad to see people from this area coming out with quality products."		"Not a specific restaurant, but the restaurants and bakeries in the Latin Quarter are really amazing. The yabblers above raise some good points though.In general, larger firms have a marketing person"	"Overall, I like the idea.  The yabblers above raise some good points though.In general, larger firms have a marketing person to handle social media issues (bad review of a product, poor experience, general customer complaints).  These are usually met with a marketing-biased response, but it *is* a response from the company.  Unless it's total BS, you want a company that cares enough about their customers and their image to make this effort.Smaller firms use social media as a way to get their messages out there (their budget is far smaller, and social media is essentially free).  I would really love to hear back from a small firm on a post I make, whether it's positive, negative or inquisitive.  It gives me a sense of how well the product/support will be.*This mechanism should be used for responses only*.  Companies should not post as users on yabbly.  It dilutes the quality of the community.  Facebook is now doing this with Suggested Posts"".  I've met nobody that likes this and sees it as an intrusion.  Sure, FB may get some clicks out of it, but it changes the fundamental nature of the site."					"I appreciate it when a business responds to my Yelp ratings (so far only businesses on Yelp do this, I've not gotten responses from rating anything on Amazon, or other online stores)."""			I recommend keeping things as components like you have now. The fix is going into control panel, correcting the default audio device, then setting the right audio back again in PowerDVD for blu-ray output.  Universal remotes don't do that."""			shared	shared		"Thanks Bryan, looks like an interesting competitor."
