The number of modules is self explanatory.  The module rating is the name plate rating on the modules which indicates how much wattage that module generates at any given moment when it's exposed to the sun.  The peak sun hours are site specific.  It is a measurement of the amount of sun that your area gets on a daily basis over the course of the year.  More specifically, how many hours per day do you get the equivalent of noon day sun, (I am assuming Seattle, WA in this case).  Finally, the de-rate factor. Solar modules and inverters are not 100% efficient so you have to account for some losses.  All PV systems also lose 2-3% due to wire runs.  The de-rate factor is taking into account all of these losses from when the electricity is generated at the module until it is back-fed at your utility meter.Since you've given me your average daily kWh consumption I can dummy this pretty easily for your house.  It would look like this: (136 modules) x (Yingli 245) x  (3.76 peak sun hours) x (0.79 derate factor) = (136) x (245) x (3.76) x (0.79) = 98,973 Watt Hours/Day or 98.97 kWh/Day.  Therefore a 33kW system (136 x 245 = 33,320) using 136 Yingli 245 modules would off-set your entire usage (provided it stayed the same as it is now).  Since I have never seen your roof I can't imagine you could accomodate that big a system.  The average residential system in the US is only 5kW.  A 30kW system is a small commercial system- unless you have a Hollywood sized home.  That said, roof space is usually the limiting factor for most solar customers so it's common that solar customers don't zero-out"".  "					"In addition, a lot of the buying decision depends on finding ""the sweet spot"".  This is usually the point at which you are maximizing the available incentives under the prevailing billing structure from your local utility.  For example, many utilities establish a baseline usage at a specific price and then increase what you pay per kilowatt hour as you exceed certain consumption targets.  This is a tiered system- very common here in California.  For example, a customer might pay $0.12/kWh for the first 250 kWh they consume each month.  For the electricity they use between 250kWh and 400kWh that price might go up to 0.15/kWh.  Any kilowatt hours they consume above 400 kWh might cost them 0.30kW and so on.  Down here many utilities have 5 tiers like this and customer find that if they can eliminate whatever they consume in tiers 3-5 they can maximize their savings.  In other words, they may purchase a PV system that only off-sets half of their consumption but lowers their bill by 75-80%."						"I am launching my own solar company that will be doing residential and commercial systems.  I'd be happy to give you a full fledged proposal if you're interested.  And I could use the practice.  If so, let me know.  I would need a few other bits of info from you."""			"Wow @Philip, that is tremendously helpful. And you can have a dual-band, so the 802.11g devices c"	"As @Tom says, using a dedicated router will usually give better results.  And you can have a dual-band, so the 802.11g devices can be kept on the 2.4GHz channel, and the 802.11n 5Ghz won't be slowed by them.  This is because a single 802.11g device forces an 802.11n network to fall back to 11g speeds.  You can also get an external antenna to increase signal propagation distance: http://www.radiolabs.com/Articles/wifi-antenna.html is a very good writeup on the topic.  Note that 802.11ac is coming soon too, which will give far greater speeds than what we have today."		"It's hard to find discounts to the Grand Californian, and it's an expensive hotel. I suggest booking directly through Disney using an auto club discount."		Here it is @tom	Here it is @tom		"If your destination is Munich, be sure to reserve a hotel room in advance. Here's my thoughts on it...1) I get mixed reactions from people on the other end of the line - sometimes I have to just pick up my phone.  I've never owned anything but Jawbone, so this may just be something about bluetooth - it's never as good as wired.2) I have a beard (trim, but there) which may be causing issues with the mic as it touches the skin.3) I use it frequently for just listening (I listen to a lot of audio books) when around the house, working out, driving while the kids listen to something else, etc.  For this it's awesome - good sound quality, solid connection, long battery life (the ERA gets a solid 5 hours and charges in no time at all).4) Their support is TERRIBLE.  I had one that was 6 months old peter out on me, and they denied the warranty claim because they said it was purchased from a non-authorized seller (I bought through Amazon and apparently through a 3rd part seller although it was Amazon fulfulled).  I shamed them on twitter and got a replacement. All that was after fighting with customer service for 2 weeks.Honestly given the support issue I may switch next time I buy a bluetooth, but since they replaced it in the end I'm keeping what I have.  Just make sure you keep your receipt and buy from a proper seller - which means you'll probably pay full retail."		+100!  Kudos to @heatherchristo!	+100! Swordfish for instance generally has very high levels of mercury and if it is imported is generally not caught in a sustainable way. The Monterey Bay Aquarium has a great web site and mobile app that ranks fish from different sources according to their sustainability if that is at all a factor in your decision: http://www.montereybayaquarium.org/cr/seafoodwatch.aspx"		"Just curious why a few people said to avoid eating farm raised fish? Depending on the type of fish, where the farms are loca"	"Just curious why a few people said to avoid eating farm raised fish? Depending on the type of fish, where the farms are located, and the methods used, farmed fish can be both healthy and sustainable. And conversely, some wild caught fish are neither healthy nor sustainable. I am a software engineer and 	"I totally agree with the answers posted here. All my life I used and worked with Windows machines. I am a software engineer and work on a daily basis with windows computers. Couple of years ago, after I saved up the money, I bought a MacBook Pro to test it. I totally fell in love with it. There is a little learning curve to it, especially if you like to use hotkeys/shortcuts. I find the whole system way easier structured, especially if you are looking for certain settings. In my opinion the whole system runs better than Windows. Upgrading to a new OS doesn't cost a fortune (for example in windows from Xp to Vista, Vista to WIndows 7) .. with around $30  (don't quote me).You always can dualboot the computer with Bootcamp and run Windows or even use a Virtual Box.The real question is what do you expect of that mac or what you want to do with it? For example: Playing games, Video Editing, just surfing the web and office use?There are different Apple products from MacBook Air to iMac and I wouldn't recommend using a MacBook Air for Gaming purposes and or Video/Graphical work (not powerful enough)."		Thank you all for all the really great tips. We?ve compiled three of the most unique & fun sounding attractions for kids as well as adults:Castaway Cay is Disney?s private Bahamian island ? it has snorkeling, bike rides, parasailing, glass-bottom boat tours, and rentable inner tubes. It also has a water slide and open-air barbecues. Out of all the things to do, this seems like one of the most cruise-unique attractions to check out.The live stage shows are something to not miss ? check out Disney?s Believe live show for an once-in-a-lifetime (unless you go on the cruise again) musical starring Disney characters from multiple movies. You should be able to find a schedule for the showings once you?re actually on the ship or online.Animator?s Palate, one of the restaurants on the ship, is actually not an ordinary restaurant ? it has screens all around that immerse you into the world of ?Finding Nemo.? The sea turtle Crush ?swims around? the restaurant by way of the screens and actually interacts with diners. A fun show for the kids, a great meal for adults.Here?s an article to look over to find things for the adults to do:Top 10 Things to do on a Disney Cruise for Adultshttp://www.everythingmouse.com/top-10-things-to-do-on-a-disney-cruise-for-adultsWe hope this helped you get some idea of some must-check-out venues for the kids and adults on the Disney Dream Cruise. The fees are pretty high (though they do try to make them sound low) and the 	"I think it's a poor choice of investment vehicle.  The fees are pretty high (though they do try to make them sound low) and the diversification they give you isn't that amazing to pay what they're charging.  In addition, they make some questionable fund choices that lead to higher fees as well.The betterment fee is on top of fund fees (so your total rate can exceed 1%)...  and .35% (just betterment's fee for their entry level account) is pretty steep.Hypothetically given $10k invested for 30 years, earning 6%:- you're paying $6k in fees to betterment alone- their total fee structure reduces earnings by over $12,000 in that time span (or, 26% of your earnings are being eaten by fees) compared to a target retirement fund, which is just as easy to invest in.If you don't want to actively manage your money, Vanguard has a lot of low-fee funds, including some funds that don't require you to re-balance/etc.  More info here: https://personal.vanguard.com/us/funds/vanguard/TargetRetirementListAlternatively (though, depending on your age) you can just dump it in the S&P 500 index fund which has fees of 0.05%.  Very few actively managed funds outperform the S&P500 long-term (especially when considering that managed funds are significantly more expensive)."		@tedb just send/receive. In my experience a toothbrush, clorox and elbow grease does the "	"I m not sure why a steam cleaner would work better than bleach? In my experience a toothbrush, clorox and elbow grease does the trick every time. If the stains are of a mineral nature (like rust from a faucet) then there is a product called Whink"" that is basically muriatic acid. It works like gangbusters on grout and also porcelian. If all else fails and the grout is technically clean but retains some staining for whatever reason, there are grout whiteners....they are like ""white-out"" for grout. They come in a pen form and you just apply them to the clean, dry grout and it whitens the grout up."""		p.s. Soft Scrub with bleach is basically useless. Just sayin.	p.s. "	"One caution: never, ever put ammonia and bleach (hypochlorite) together.  The resulting fumes are a mix of nasty, toxic gases.  Including chloramine, dichloramine, and nitrogen trichloride (which is also an explosive of note).  And be careful with Muriatic acid, better known as Hydrochloric acid.  Follow label directions for diluting it for use."		Check with your insurance company - they may only provide coverage if work is done by licensed contractors on critical things li	Check with your insurance company - they may only provide coverage if work is done by licensed contractors on critical things like gas connections.		"it is a latte colored grout that has turned black/brown/gray...have tried a grout brush, couple different types of cleaners (pro"	"it is a latte colored grout that has turned black/brown/gray...have tried a grout brush, couple different types of cleaners (professional tile and grout cleaner and soft scrub with bleach) and elbow grease.  they are sending me some grout stain if i cant get the dirt out.  just frustrating because this was supposed to be the high end stuff that was easier to clean"		"Thx guys. You'll want to use a poultice to clean the grout. It's a paste which you put on the affect	"I previously did stone and tile work. You'll want to use a poultice to clean the grout. It's a paste which you put on the affected area and the cover with painters plastic, plastic wrap etc. The poultice actually pulls the stain out of the grout and holds it in suspension until it is brushed away. I've used this brand in the past with great success.http://www.stonetooling.com/Miracle-Sealants-Liquid-Poultice-A-B-Quart-p/30.10560.htm?gclid=CNPW8-TF_7UCFelaMgodHHYADw&Click=3227"		i wish the targeting could be done less by age/gender and more by subject matter  (frequency of certain types of posts made or r	i wish the targeting could be done less by age/gender and more by subject matter  (frequency of certain types of posts made or repsonded to). If I had to make a recommendation, based on brand alone, I'd go for the B&W Zeppelin just because B&W makes speakers that my ears love.  However - and this is a vital point - when it comes to speakers, do NOT take my advice or anyone's.  Everyone has different auditory sensors and tastes.  A great audio engineer I know loves a completely different type of sound system than I do; neither he nor I are necessarily wrong, it's just taste.  So if YOU like the B&W, they're a good brand.  If you don't, then avoid them."		"Remember you're putting something very near your brain when using something like this. If you want a long range and good speed, then you should spend a little extr"	"I personally use and really like Netgear's routers. If you want a long range and good speed, then you should spend a little extra to get a good one. I currently have the model WNDR3700v2....also called the N600 wireless dual-band gigabit router. Mines a couple years old and was expensive when I bought it, however you can find them on sales now for around $70 to $80 ( like on Amazon). I find Netgear's products more user friendly and easier to set up than some others. I am pretty tech savvy, but don't know all the ins and outs of networking. This one uses a set up wizard to guide you through set up. Someone with no tech knowledge might require some help, though. I don't remember the exact range, but I live in a two floor home and the signal reaches all over no problem. It is a smaller ranch style home, though, not a very large home. I also have a 89 x 100 lot and am able to get my signal out in my yard anywhere. Please note, though, that there are things that can cause interference..I got a new glass sliding back door that has some special coating for energy efficiency and that doors weakens my signal outside. I installed an access point near a downstairs window that is old, so this gave me back my strong signal. I've used several Netgear wireless routers over the years and bought & installed them for my sisters and we are all very happy with them. There are other newer models with longer range and more features, but they cost MUCH more. I think the model I suggested would be a good choice."		"@tom we have a seldom used breville juicer, http://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B000QBFFU8 , is a masticating juicer different/better "	"@tom we have a seldom used breville juicer, http://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B000QBFFU8 , is a masticating juicer different/better than this?  i have not used it often because it takes a long time to cleanup."		"B&W for a home theater is a great choice for my ears (and my wife!). But I also believe that	I agree with those above who've said that design should be a full sprint ahead of dev for most features. But I also believe that there will be big picture features that design should take time on where a structured sprint may be too fast paced for the type of exploration needed to address the full picture. In these cases I think design should be two sprints (assuming a 2 week sprint time) out from dev at least to allow time for more iteration and prototyping. There are also exceptions in the other way. Some features can be small enough that design can front load that feature at the beginning of the same sprint in which the devs implement the feature. 		I think you can't have it all for just $3000 ;) proper equipment would go beyond $6000. Whatever camera you get, audio is not something you want to compromise. The VG900 does have an audio input, just not the ideal one. You can make it ideal with a couple hundred dollar adapter. All in all the VG900 looks good, I have not used it, but from my experience and what i can read on the Sony website about it, it might not be very versatile. In controlled production productions this is not a big deal, but for your everyday shooting, this is not a grab and go"" camera. I'll give you an example. I have four cameras: canon xf305, panasonic hvx200, panasonic dvx100 and a canon 5D mark II - for beauty shots I use the Canon 5D, but for event coverage and general stuff, I use the xf305 because it's versatile, has audio inputs and i can control it how i want to. - it's very hard to get OnE camera that does all you want"		"Also"""			"Thanks Alex, though I had wished there was something new I could pick up.I'll echo your preference for balanced microphones."	"Thanks Alex, though I had wished there was something new I could pick up.I'll echo your preference for balanced microphones.  The signal from a microphone is pretty low voltage, so a small amount of interference from surrounding electronics is more likely to generate noticeable interference on a single-ended (unbalanced) connection.  The balanced connection (typically on an XLR connector) means any induced signal in the wire between microphone and electronics will be induced pretty much equally in both sides of the signal, while the microphone's information is the differential between the two signal wires.  This effectively nulls out the interference when using a balance connection.  A single-ended or unbalanced, while cheaper, is more prone to carrying the interference all the way through."		The Q5 repeatedly wins top compact lux SUV awards.  One other option you may want to consider is the X1 which has been the categ	"The Q5 repeatedly wins top compact lux SUV awards.  One other option you may want to consider is the X1 which has been the category leader in Europe for years before we finally got them here in the US.I don't think you'll like the drivability of the RDX or RX coming from a MINI.  We own and RDX and my wife, a Realtor, likes it for driving clients around but it's really not a driver's car.The X37 is great, good performance, but not as refined as a the Q5 and X series.  Net, net I'd test the Q5 and X1 and if I were you I'd get the X1 just because it's smaller (with the same horsepower as the X3) and you don't see as many on the road."		I second the Q5 recommendation.	I second the Q5 recommendation.		"Knowing how to read music is a huge plus.  That will certainly help you through the entire experience.  That being said, it "	"Knowing how to read music is a huge plus.  That will certainly help you through the entire experience.  That being said, it depends what you're going for.  If you're looking to learn the real way (interested in theory, making your own music etc.) nothing beats one on one lessons or classes.  If you're just looking to pick up and play for now, I would recommend learning tablature first (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tablature).  It's very self explanatory and is easily self taught.That will help you start playing right out of the box.  Once you start getting your fingers used to the movements (and you've learned the basic scales and chords) you should check out a book that explains the theory and notes.  That's the road I would take if I didn't want to sign up for one on one lessons (as they can be costly).  The guitar is very easy to navigate once you learn the basics and adopt regular practice routine.You can start here: http://www.songsterr.com/a/wa/howToReadTabhttp://www.ultimate-guitar.com/http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/lessons/for_beginners/http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/entertainment/top_10_songs_for_six-string_beginners.htmlHope that helps!"		I can't imagine anything being more exp than Whole Foods. The "	"A couple of months ago, I purchased the EasyAcc 4 x USB output. 12000mAh external battery pack, and I'm very happy with it. The price at the time was only $40. The model # is PB12000A. Its powerful enough to charge 4 devices at once. You can charge phones and tablets with it. It does come with several types of connectors, though if your device uses a standard sized USB cable, you can just plug that into the battery. I have used it to charge my Galaxy Nexus smartphone and my iPad. The last time I charged my phone with it, the phone battery was 19% and it took a little over an hour to fully charge."		"QuoteAPhotoQuoto"	"QuoteAPhotoQuoto"		Four 5's and the right Jack. The tech has a lot of promise and I'm a big advocate, but my few purchases have revealed that you need to pay attention to color temp (go very, very warm even though it might seem excessive when you are demoing in-store) and quality (usually manifested as cost). In my experience, cheaper bulbs have had low output and spendier ones have had more lumens. Keep in mind these bulbs last a loooooooooooong time, so spend a bit more and get the name brands. "		I've always loved Santa Cruz ... I had gone to their website to get pricing for internet plans. In order to get pricing, I had to enter my address... but it kept giving me an error that it couldnt find my address. I had to call them instead and it turned out that their system wasn't recognizing Ave or Avenue. I can't remember which it was now, but the issue was that simple. For example, if I was typing in AVE on their web site instead of Avenue, their system didn't find it. Then I would be curious to see the results of the following very simple test you can run. Browse to speakeasy.net and run their speed test.  You can't miss it on their website, it is very easy to run.Run the test 5 times selecting the city closest to your location.   Repeat the test 5 additional times using the city furthest from you.I'd like to find out what the upload and download speeds are for both cities.  These speeds will vary sometimes but you should get a general sense of the speed and performance you are getting."		I'd take a look at Virgin Mobile. When we had t"	"We just had our floors re-done last fall, the whole first floor in our house is hardwood (it's not a tiny house).  When we had the ducts cleaned out recently, there was a pretty significant amount of dust in them despite having been bagged off.Our builder had done a cheap water based finish, it was worn off in many places after 8 years.  And we had a cupping/warping problem after a dishwasher leak, so the refinish was covered by the insurance company.Doing a full sand down, stain (not all people stain at this point), then three coats of Swedish finish produces an amazing end result.  And the fumes are strong enough that any bugs considering taking up residence in the house will cease to be a problem.The longer you can keep traffic off the floor after the final coat, the better.  We stayed completely off for a week, then stocking feet only for another couple of weeks.  It was a couple of months before this guy got back on the floors:"		"Oh and if you're in the Seattle area, http://heartlandfloors.com/ is an awesome company to work with for hardwood floors. If you want to buy a new iphone for a prepaid plan it's a good way to go, though (bear in mind you're getting a kinda-old-but-not-terrible iphone).Straight Talk is, generally, pretty good.  It runs on T-Mobile's network so you'll have similar coverage compared to what you have now (though you won't get roaming, so it will be a somewhat smaller network).Another provider to consider is Simple Mobile (www.mysimplemobile.com).  I've used their $40 plan (which includes all taxes, so it's $40 out the door) in Seattle and it's pretty solid.  Similar to ST, it's on t-mobile's network.I believe you can use either of them with an unlocked iphone (if you're out of contract I -think- AT&T will unlock it)...  but I'm not sure about how well 3G will work.  You may only get edge because they run on t-mobile's network which uses different frequencies than AT&T.  I have heard there are changes afoot but I'm not privy to them so I have no idea if it's still true.One other thing to consider *if you don't care about talk minutes*, t-mobile has a prepaid plan that's $30 a month that includes 100 talk minutes and unlimited text/4G data.  It's a killer deal...  for introverts :).  I'm on this now and have tried pairing it up with voice over the data network and have had pretty poor success, so I'd really only suggest it if you intend on using <200 or so minutes a month.  Otherwise paying the extra $10 or $15 for Straight Talk or Simple Mobile is likely worth it to avoid the hassle.If you're getting a new phone and willing to try something different, the Nexus 4 works perfectly on both of the networks above (4G and everything).  It's only $299, and comes unlocked so you just pop the SIM card in and things work.I do encourage you to switch to prepaid...  there are some HUGE savings compared to legacy plans."		"@Jim Thanks for your response!Straight talk runs on Verizon's network, which means I'd have really good coverage across th"	"@Jim Thanks for your response!Straight talk runs on Verizon's network, which means I'd have really good coverage across the country (great for road trips through the middle of nowhere in Idaho and Montana). I have a Nexus S, and like it, but it's slowed down and battery life has dwindled as the operating systems get bigger. I don't personally have a Lenovo, but they do offer many lightweight, portable options. One of the newest is the IdeaPad Yoga 13, which is both an ultra book and tablet combined into one. It's less than 3 1/2 lbs, up to 8 hour battery life and the screen can physically flip into 4 different modes. One mode is like a standard laptop, another flips it into tablet mode, and there are two more positions in which it can be positioned. It also comes with Windows 8. There are also the ThinkPad Carbon X1 and ThinkPad T430, which are the ultra books. The Carbon is more of a premium model. The T430 is very popular with businesses, though Lenovo will soon come out with its updated model, the T431. These are similar to standard laptops, though smaller at 14, and usually come with an SSD instead of an HDD (types of hard drives)."""		"I agree with air_conditions. Some are online photo albums, such as Shutterfly Share. With this, yo"	"There are quite a bunch of ways to share photos privately. Some are online photo albums, such as Shutterfly Share. With this, you can choose to share with whomever you want. You can also write messages, share videos, and share calendars on this site. There is also PhotoBucket, DropShots, and PhotoRocket, among many others.You could also use one or more of the many file sharing apps out there, such as Google Drive, Box, DropBox. You just save or upload photos ( or any other types of files) to the service and allow sharing of folders with whomever you want. I have all three of these apps, but use Google Drive and DropBox the most. They all come with a few free GBs of storage space for free, and if you need more, you buy more. Google only charges $2.49 per month for 25 GB of storage. They have easy to use desktop clients as well and you can sync your files between devices. The desktop clients of these apps install a Windows a explorer type of interface....you click open the desktop app and navigate through your files as you would on a desktop drive. I know with Google Drive, you can choose to save files directly to it just the same as you would save to a CD, flash drive, etc."		"I use a folder on Dropbox for this purpose. You will be driving against the return traffic if yo	"Most people drive the road out in the morning and come back mid afternoon.  You will be driving against the return traffic if you drive toward Hana in the evening.  The road really is narrow with hairpin curves and one you want to drive with the traffic flow.  Also not a road you want to drive at night unless you are a veteran road tripper.If you plan to stay the night, the better places to stay involve high $$$$.   My viewpoint is the drive itself is the destination"" not Hana.  "					"Hana itself is not very big at all.  Study the websites before you go to understand the highlights along the highway, near Hana and beyond.  I didn't on the first trip and just flat out missed 3/4 of the highlights when I went out as a tourist.  They are too numerous to write about up here.  Find a milepost guide online and study it.  The road has few turnouts and missing a spot can mean driving quite a way beyond to find a safe turn around point."						"If you plan to do the trip strictly as a tourist day trip, I would consider one of the tour buses."						Study the history and you will enjoy the drive more. They?re legally licensed to conduct visitors around the park for a fee (supposedly the ONLY individuals allowed to do this). Expect this tour to be heavy on the history ? and maybe a little more serious than other tours.SegTours offer Segway tours of Gettysburg (http://www.segtours.com/), and they have two different packages: the Western Battlefield, recommended for those who want to learn more about Gettysburg and the battle, and the Eastern Battlefield, for those who are already familiar with Gettysburg. The tours are 2-3 hours long, and cost $50 - $70 per person. You may miss out on the experience of walking around the actual battlefields ? rather you?d most likely be segwaying roads around the fields. It?s no golf cart, but a Segway is pretty unique!The Gettysburg Foundation (http://www.gettysburgfoundation.org/14) offers bus and car tours of the Gettysburg battlefield. The tour guides will stop and explore specific locations during the tour to allow you to walk on the battlefield ? a good balance between walking and relaxing/sightseeing. Walk up prices are around $13/adult and $9 for kids ages 6-12. Children 5 and under are free.Hopefully this helped you find a few resources for your summer Gettysburg trip. Yabble on!-Yabbly Concierge"		"Hi @JeffK,We decided to look into this for you and found a few unique tour guide companies that you could look into.The As"	"Hi @JeffK,We decided to look into this for you and found a few unique tour guide companies that you could look into.The Association of Licensed Battlefield Guides (http://www.gettysburgtourguides.org/index.html) offers two hour tours around Gettysburg for $55 (from 1 to 6 people). I don't monitor my sleep but there are apps available that use your smartphone's motion sensors, mics, and vibe motor that work the same as the wristbands. Wahoo fitness offers BT4 heart rate monitors. I use MapMyRide to track my walks & rides, calorie count, heart rate, etc and it offers full location data with GPS location based elevation changes to track inclines and declines throughout my route. (obviously the only exception to this is if your router is slower than the speed of your internet connection)since you cant seem to get a wired broadband internet solution, your next best bet would be to check out Verizon Wireless or AT&T Wireless to see if they offer 4G LTE service. LTE based 4G is much faster compared to WiMAX (the system you're currently using). these are the only 2 providers with widespread, nationwide LTE coverage at this time (Sprint and T-Mobile are only in a handful of cities for now). if it's available in your area, LTE speeds consistently reach 10Mbit/sec in solid coverage areas and can be as high as 50Mbit/sec with near ideal conditions (these speeds are between 5-20 times faster than your current solution).for example, i live in downtown Seattle and during peak hours i average 10-15Mbit/sec, off-peak hours i usually get around 35-40Mbit/sec on LTE.hopefully this will help give you another option."		"just one 'M' in SIM as it stands for Subscriber Identity Module."""						"and you're right, they can wear out. however, with regular u"""	"just one 'M' in SIM as it stands for Subscriber Identity Module."""					"and you're right, they can wear out. however, with regular usage (insert into device and leave it there) they usually don't for 99.996% of SIMs. but like any other solid-state memory, they are sensitive to stray electrons and magnetic fields, thus they're more likely to fail if reinserted a lot, subject to moisture while powered, the device it's in is defective, etc. "						"for anyone with reception issues, replacing the SIM card with a known good card is usually the first step in the troubleshooting flow chart. """			"buckles, buttons and laces are 19th century. Velcro, ratcheting and inflatable are 20th century. there has yet to be a 21st cent"	"buckles, buttons and laces are 19th century. Velcro, ratcheting and inflatable are 20th century. there has yet to be a 21st century alternative to hit retail. as for auto laces,"" a la BTTF, don't count on it. those who would need them, i.e. mobility impaired, don't have much use for a secure fitting shoe for sport. and those who would want them will only complain about the inherent weight required for proper torquing of the lacing component. maybe somewhere in the mid to latter 21st century will we see miniaturized servos capable of high torque with an acceptable failure rate while being subject to dust, shock, liquid and wide temperature variations. "		"I prefer Sharpies so it doesn't rub off when I rub the side of my palm, or anything else for that matter, against the board as I"	"I prefer Sharpies so it doesn't rub off when I rub the side of my palm, or anything else for that matter, against the board as I write. just kidding. I use these cheapies from Daiso. $1.50 for a 6 pack of fine tipped with magnetic eraser caps. works great for me in the kitchen; they stay put against the board and each fresh pen comes with a fresh eraser. I'd recommend 2% or 1% orga	"children need fats along with protein in their diets for complete nutrition to aid in proper growth. I'd recommend 2% or 1% organic milk as all organic milk is rBST (hormone) and antibiotic free. for yourself or other adults in the household who have cholesterol issues, I recommend skim if 2 or 1% is too high for your diet. I recommend getting a referral to a dietician from your primary care physician for proper recommendations on diet, especially if you're unsure what to feed your kids, to prevent the possibility of stunting their growth due to malnutrition. sometimes parents will assume what's good for them at their stage in their life and health is also good for kids who are growing, which in many cases is not true. in regards to phytoestrogens, realize that half of yours and your kids diets contain elements with varying levels of phytoestrogens, and even higher than average if your diet is higher in vegetables. plus, there are no studies that consistently prove any adverse effects in either males or females be it adults or developmental growth. I think people kinda freak out because they see estrogen"" but phytoestrogens do not affect the human body in the same way. drinking soy milk daily is not in any way like feedingsomeone birth control puills"""		"For eating, make reservations ahead of time for the Dobbin House Tavern. I'm not really a fan of soy, almond or coconut milk (unless it really comes from the coconut in a small amount). Also, our nutritionist recommended whole milk (in moderation) because it helps with a lot of other digestive functions that skim milk doesn't--and you can drink more water to balance out the whole milk.  I'm recommending a tour of your local dairy and if possible having kids actually milk a cow and churn butter like Waldorf schools do. Humans 	"Cow's milk is a substance produced to turn a 50 pound calf into a 1000 pound cow in a year.  It's not a slimming agent.  Humans are the only creature to consume milk after infancy.Cholesterol is produced in human livers, it's a vital ingredient in, among other organs, the brain.  Toxic forms of cholesterol are highly associated with elevated refined sweetener consumption more than dietary cholesterol consumption.A good resource that describes both sides of the xenoestrogen issue is this one from Tulane: http://e.hormone.tulane.edu/learning/phytoestrogens.html"		This may sound crazy but I bought some nice wooden barstools for my house from allbarstools.com (which is now owned by Wayfair.c	"This may sound crazy but I bought some nice wooden barstools for my house from allbarstools.com (which is now owned by Wayfair.com) and I gotta say I was surprised they've held up so long. On Org	"I'm not sure there is any one answer that is perfect.  Just a few facts here to keep in mind as you weigh pros and cons.  On Organic cow's milk - there are two types: ultrapasteurized and regular pasteurized.  Of course there's non-pasteurized or raw"", but I'm not going there.  Ultrapasteurized really nukes the crap out of the milk (which is why you can leave it out of the fridge and it doesn't spoil).  Regular pasteurized heats it enough to kill the most harmful bacteria, but still leaves some of the others in there.  The latter is the kind we buy because I wasn't sure I wanted that much done to my milk.  The thing to be careful of with the other milks is added sugar.  Some of the almond milks or other such will add sugar to make it taste good, so you're getting one benefit but at the cost of more sweetener.  Again, no easy answer here, but considerations as you weigh."""		"A little perspective I was offered on this issue by a dear friend who is  a urologist.  He told me that at age 5, 10% of kids ar"	"A little perspective I was offered on this issue by a dear friend who is  a urologist.  He told me that at age 5, 10% of kids are bed wetters; at age 10, 5% of kids are.  So, even at age 10 it's not all that uncommon (5% is a decent percent).  Just to help mom and dad de-stress a little.  We had great success with the pee alarm (Malek, I think is the name?).  I worried and worried over it because it seemed almost medieval (you clip a sensor into the underwear which senses moisture and then sets off an awful alarm).  I worried we were scarring him for life.  But, it really ddi work.  He did not enjoy the month of using it, but he stopped wetting.  So, pick your poison as far as emotional scarring goes.  =)"		"Update: just tried where I have a decent signal, getting 11.15 Mbps down, 4.17 Mbps up. That changes the structure of components in a major way - essentia	"Great points @Faith - especially about ultra-pasteurization.  That changes the structure of components in a major way - essentially, ultra-pasteurization turns a food into a non-food in many ways.An example: I once tried to make whipped cream and had a hard time getting it to transform into the fluffy whipped state.  I noticed I was using Organic Valley, and that they had recently started Ultra-pasteurizing.  I then tried Horizon, who didn't at the time (don't know about now), and it whipped in seconds where minutes were not getting the OV to work."		Refinishing by sanding is discouraged by most experts on caring for wooden floors as it continues to thin out the wood over time	"Refinishing by sanding is discouraged by most experts on caring for wooden floors as it continues to thin out the wood over time.  Years ago, I did it the hard way.  I used finish remover, which is tedious and you have to wear a mask and do it patch by patch.  Then a very light sanding to smooth it out, nothing that takes too much material off, then you can seal it, do the light sanding again and put another coat of sealer on.  My floors really came out well and preserved their integrity."		"I did studies on water in a class in college (I was a Chem major).  First, if you're in a house with old (pre-WW2) copper pipes,"	"I did studies on water in a class in college (I was a Chem major).  First, if you're in a house with old (pre-WW2) copper pipes, there is a chance you have some Cadmium in your water (from the flux used to help solder the pipes).  That is very strongly correlated to heart disease.  If you're in that age house, it's worth getting the water tested for Cadmium.Second, fluoridation.  This is a huge hot-button topic.  Many people claim large cavity benefits for teeth, others point out the toxic impacts.  Some things are certain: Fluoride will compete with Iodine and can cause Thyroid problems.  It can stain teeth (my wife's are permanently stained from childhood Fluoride addition to her municipal water supply, and her thyroid is basically non-functional).  See http://thyroid.about.com/cs/relatedconditions/a/flushot.htm for example.Third, THM (tri-halo methanes).  Nasty byproducts of chlorinating water, these are highly reactive and can have a variety of ill health impacts.One possibility is to use RO (reverse osmosis) water, which removes just about everything, and does it close to on-demand at the sink.  There are several vendors who provide RO systems."		"I currently use Hemp Milk. http://www.livingharvest.com/products/milk I used to drink Raw Goat Milk. It is terrific, especially fresh from well cared for goats.http://www.mtcapra.com/benefits-of-goat-milk-vs-cow-milk/.I think it is important to find a good source of fresh milk that you know is coming from healthy, clean animals.  There is likely a good source from somewhere in Seattle area."		"Thx everyone! It is a good place to eat, but we prefer to spend our time in the parks.We usually save Downtown Disney for a half day activity. For example, go to a smaller park like Animal Kingdom, in the morning , then spend the evening and dinner at Downtown Disney. On your last day, if you have a late flight out of town, you can make this your last stop of shopping.It also depends on the ages of the people in your group. Teens and young adults will find more to do in Downtown Disney more than will younger children. For example, the Disney Quest Indoor Theme Park is more for Teens and Tweens. We eat a balanced diet and I think you are better off with eating other proteins and fats.  Here were our concerns:Dairy makes some kids really phlegmy.I'd stay away from the growth hormones in Dairy also.Soy does have hormonal implications for boy girls AND boys.Rice milk actually has a warning on it that it should not be used with children under 5 years old and there were recently articles about arsenic in rice.So my daugther drinks a little lactose free organic milk each day.  One of my sons drinks almond milk.  The nut allergic one drinks calcium fortified OJ twice a day."		"Thanks for this thread everyone.  Learned a few new devices to consider. I use the GPS tracking mo"	"I own 3(!?!) different models of Garmin GPS watches / heartrate monitors (Forerunner 301, 305, & 405). I use the GPS tracking more for my training than the heartrate sensor, but if you're looking at overall product quality, I think the comparison is fair.The 301 & 305 are workhorses. The 301 has some GPS accuracy issues (particularly a long startup time), but I still run races with it from time to time. The 305 is probably my favorite and seems to be indestructible.With the 405 & later, they really made a design push to be more like watches you would wear all the time. I'm not a fan of this because it seems like the 405 is a battery hog. Additionally, the 405 seemed to get some really bad firmware updates.A friend of mine who competes in triathlons also swears by the 610.All that said, I'm really considering getting the Nike+ SportWatch. I'm also a big FuelBand user and just love how seamless the integration & syncing is from watch to device to servers."		"ya, like tedb said, you are not saving much, if any, by going with a previous model.  we sell our old phones to amazon or a site"	"ya, like tedb said, you are not saving much, if any, by going with a previous model.  we sell our old phones to amazon or a site like gazelle when we get new phones, if you do that you will make up about half of the extra cost now when you sell it (because the newer model will be worth more 2 years from now).  over 24 months, you might pay an extra $3-$4/month net for an extremely better product.  better camera, bigger screen, faster clicking around, faster internet connection, etc."		"I use Remember The Milk. After *much* trial and error, starts and stops I've discovered the following (note tl;dr "	"A question near and dear to my heart!  After *much* trial and error, starts and stops I've discovered the following (note tl;dr at bottom for a direct answer):0) The System is waaaay more important than the app. Have your system be driving  your app, not the other way around. Putting this at the top because its the most important part. 1) Nearly any system will work fine. The critical component is maintaining the system and always following it. You are a smart person, so the system is just an aid, not a personal secretary. On the flip side, if you don't follow your system, it makes no difference how good it is.  At any given stretch of time, you will have amazing powers of organization and follow through. Other times you will fight it and flail.   Whatever process you choose, it must support both when you rock and when you don't. To maintain doing a system, it needs to be simple to understand as well as easy and fun to use.  If it takes too long to input and organize an item, you will lose interest quickly, regardless of the benefit. 2) Project/Team/Business systems and apps are not likely to meet your personal to-do needs.   They are built with different users in mind and the complexity increases exponentially. Find a personal to-do manager. 3) Any app you choose must be ubiquitous to what you do naturally. If you sit at a desk most of the day, desktop/web software is fine. If you go to meetings or are on the road, it's important to have a mobile way of managing your items. If you're driving and something on the radio reminds you to call Josh, or a show you want to see, you need a way of entering it through voice.  A very important step is to get it out of your head and into your system ASAP. . You don't want to have to pay emotional rent to something that you don't need to.  This causes stress over time. 5) Have a goal when evaluating. Are you looking to build a single project or are you looking for an every day manager?tl;dr  I finally settled on Getting Things Done (GTD) as a system and Omnifocus as my core app. GTD emphasizes the need for a 'Reference' location to store things away from your desk. I use Evernote for digital things and a file cabinet for papers. I tried using Omnifocus without reading the book and it was OK, but see 'Part 0' at the top.  Once I developed the system, the app just fell into place.   Your mileage will vary and it's really a match of how you do things and your organizational strengths/weaknesses. Good luck!use the end state in mindlooking for a tmanager "		Find the best here: http://breakingnews.ewg.org/2012sunscreen/	Find the best here: http://breakingnews.ewg.org/2012sunscreen/		From what I read the PS4 ditches the crazy Cell architecture setup of the PS3 and relies on more off-the-shelf parts.  It should	"From what I read the PS4 ditches the crazy Cell architecture setup of the PS3 and relies on more off-the-shelf parts.  It should function like a PC, like the xbox 360 (and upcoming 720/Durango).This means that porting should become an easier task for developers as all three platforms will have the same underpinnings, just different RAM/V-RAM/and other on-board assets.  If it make sense from a launch perspective I'm sure DICE will just port the PC/xbox version of BF4 to the PS4."		"I started doing crossfit ~5 years ago and I love it. Here's what I love:* Community - it's easy to meet folks as you all do the same thing together* You're guaranteed to get a great workout* It's whole-body fitness. It works strength, agility, flexibility, and conditioning.* There is a trainer who helps you with your form and work levelYou can do this on your own, but it's tough. I've tried to do crossfit-style workouts at normal gyms, and it generally does  not go well. There are many movements you simply can't do because of a lack of equipment (especially a pull-up bar that allows for kipping). Many gyms have little or no free weights. Finally, the trainers will generally not like you using their equipment in ways that they are not used to."		"Hi @Vlada,We appreciate your question and decided to look into it for you! We looked around on the web for feedback on different Garmin heart rate monitor models ? what follows are some pros/cons about each (along with estimates on price). Garmin ForeRunner 305 ($280):+Large amount of displayed information, good for easy tracking+Can track runs on map through the GPS featureGarmin ForeRunner 405 ($150):-Humidity/sweating on it will cause it to go haywire, causing touch-sensitivity to diminish (a big problem when exercising)Alternative: Garmin Forerunner 310XT ($250)+The 310XT is built ruggedly and countered against rain/sweat/falls, etc. (won't have problems with sweating)Garmin Forerunner 205 ($250):+Can track distance, pace, splits, etc. for future review +Can create and upload routes to it +?This is great for those 20+ milers which wind all over the place. That way I can feel free to explore new routes without wondering how to get back or getting completely lost.?Alternative to Garmin:Motorola's MotoACTV ($250):+GPS, heart rate monitor, music player, designed for cycling and running +Looks and color+Updateable in a meaningful way+More customizeable+Plays music via low-powered bluetooth, no cords+Works with everything the Garmin will work with-Doesn't have an altimeter, so GPS is a bit less accurate-Not currently supported by Strava (but coming soon)-Lower comparative battery lifeHope this helps you get some bearing on the various Garmin heart monitor models. And then you have to keep said rack from moving around, and you have to try to make sure your load is somewhat balanced left-to-right, and you don't have pannier straps loose and in your spokes, and so on. A good backpack is almost as comfortable as panniers (i.e. carrying nothing on your body), and you put it on, secure the waist strap and go. """			Never tried it but it sounds brilliant. Here?re our conclusions:The D7000 and D7100 have substantial differences in their picture-taking abilities. More specifically, D7100 images are much easier to post-process, and the camera has better color accuracy and depth, as well as an AutoFocus (AF) module that is leagues better when compared to the D7000. A quote we found: ?In terms of image quality, I don't think the D7100, or even the D7200 [that doesn?t exist yet] will make sense to upgrade to for most D7000 owners.?Since you're not a D7000 owner though, you will find that the D7100 is amazing compared to your current camera. Here's a site that has visualistic comparisons between the two cameras - something to check out:http://snapsort.com/compare/Nikon-D7100-vs-Nikon_D7000The bottom line:If you?re willing to spend the extra money on the D7100, go for it. The quality of pictures you will take with the D7100 will surpass the D7000?s pictures. When/if you upgrade in the future, the D7100 will also net you a higher resale value than the D7000. However, if you will primarily use the DSLR to take video, the D7000 will suffice ? it?s not worth it to spend the extra $200. (Here's a video on the D7100's Movie Mode: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_gbf-CDd-AY)We hope this helps you get a bearing between the D7000 and D7100 for your situation. Yabble on :-)!-Yabbly ConciergeP.S.A little nitpicky, but an issue that came up with Nikon DSLRs is that autofocusing while taking a video will be quite noisy:?This is a limitation of AF in video on all Nikon DSLR's. I generally only use AF to pre-focus before a shot and will track focus manually in video mode."					"To avoid this, you can use single AF in video and just manually activate the AF when you need it. Or use a lens with quieter AF or buy an external mic. You've got many options :-)"""			That's fantastic! Thank you! I decided to drop the extra cash and go for the D7100. Instead I would go for 128GB SSD (primary boot HD) and secondary 2-3TB 7200 RPM HD (where all the games would be stored). You can continue to add more secondary drives in the future if you run out of space. I think that would give you most for your money."		"I think the word porting"" is incorrectly understood. From there, you can either take a shuttle or rent a car and drive straight down south on the highway about 45 minutes until you land in Playa.  The main avenue is 5th, which has tons of shopping, restaurants and bars.  If you are into scuba diving, there are great spots around Playa, or just take the ferry to Cozumel.  Plenty of condo rentals (check vrbo or something similar), so you can get great prices and all stay together.  Nightlife is as relaxed or crazy as you want it to be - there is a great assortment of bars/clubs/beach clubs you can visit.  If you prefer a mega resort that has everything you want, you can look along the stretch between Cancun & Playa along the Riviera Maya.  Good luck and have fun!"		I'd recommend the Canon MX series. Their biggest plan of $65 for 25 tasks brings the rate down quite a bit if you need them.  I like how you can submit the request by a simple voice recording through their app, or through typing. Communication seems like it will be simple, no issues with the CSR understanding my instructions. the biggest drawback i can think of is figuring out how to make good use of their time.  you are not guaranteed to get the same rep each time, so it cannot be a task that requires training, and therefore plenty of detail needs to be communicated (taking some of the 15 minutes you hope to save).  that said, i am looking forward to trying it more and figuring out how to best use it."		"Not sure why Amazon flagged it.. It's embarrassing to know that you have a typo out there for 	"Agree that it would be nice to be able to edit your original post. It's embarrassing to know that you have a typo out there for the world to read, but you can't fix it. I can see an issue with this once the thread gets going - e.g., substantially altering the original post may make the replies below it out of date/not on target. Perhaps only allow editing before a reply comes in? That way the latest post is always editable, but previous posts are locked down like they are now. "		"Most of the things you are looking for in a daycare will vary between individuals.  Most importantly, you want to make sure it's"	"Most of the things you are looking for in a daycare will vary between individuals.  Most importantly, you want to make sure it's certified, licensed, accredited or whatever the standard is.  Usually, that takes care of the minimum requirements regarding the facility and the providers (infant to teacher ratio, emergency procedures, safety, cleanliness, etc).  You will learn the most by visiting and reaching out to other parents around you to see what people recommend.  Try and get some feedback from existing parents at any particular facility.  Sit down with the owner/administrator and take a tour.  Look at the classrooms in action to see the size, how they are interacting with the children, the noise levels, interactions with older kids, cleanliness, staffing, etc.Ask every single question that pops into mind.  Don't worry - they are used to fielding those types of questions.  Everything from scheduled diaper changes (how often? minimum schedule?) to feedings (when, where, what, how much? what if baby won't eat?  what if baby eats all the food early?) to napping (scheduled naps?  do they rock them or just put them down?) to interactive/playtime (who interacts? what toys? do they teach sign language to help communicate? what other things do they do/teach?).   Special needs or instructions and how they deal with those?Dig in a bit about the care providers, their backgrounds and experience.  Figure out their schedules and if they rotate providers during day or do they work staggered schedules or are they there all day long.  Most places do, but just ensure everyone is CPR certified (and infant CPR certified).  Discuss their emergency preparedness plans (disasters/emergencies - where do they go? how do they contact you?), schedules (inclement weather or winter/spring breaks - if it is a center that has older kids as well, often times they have scheduled breaks).  Sick kid policy, allergies, etc etc...  Proximity to hospital is an added bonus."		"OOPS. wrote too much.. here's the rest... sorry so lengthy.  Pricing can vary dramatically depending on your location and fa"	"OOPS. wrote too much.. here's the rest... sorry so lengthy.  Pricing can vary dramatically depending on your location and facility.  Hard to give a decent range.  Around where I am in the metro DC area, I've seen pricing as high >2K/month to as low as <1K/monthVisit as many places as you can (at the minimum 2-3), because you will get a different feel for each daycare.  It might all seem like overkill and you probably don't need to dig in that deep.  But, better to be overprepared.  Leaving your infant in a day care can be quite difficult emotionally, so finding a place you are most comfortable with will be crucial to an easier transition.  Good luck and CONGRATULATIONS!  Kids are amazing and will rock your world... don't worry... sleep is overrated! :)"		"I have never purchased apple care, if you buy your mac from best buy the geek squad warranty is not a bad deal just really costl"	"I have never purchased apple care, if you buy your mac from best buy the geek squad warranty is not a bad deal just really costly upfront. You will have two weeks to buy it after your laptop purchase. "		Keep in mind that your new Mac already has a 1-year warranty when you bought it.   AppleCare extends this to 3-years.  If you ha	"Keep in mind that your new Mac already has a 1-year warranty when you bought it.   AppleCare extends this to 3-years.  If you have faulty hardware, you'll know it immediately and it will be covered in the default warranty.  Otherwise, it is an issue that will happen much later (usually a hard drive failure well after the default warranty expires). AppleCare shines with its coverage though. It will cover other apple wifi base stations, SuperDrives, power chords and external displays for three years (though they each have default warranties too). I've had one incident in the last 8 years that required AppleCare.  My secondary display was a *little* wonky (very slight waviness) so I took it in and they replaced it no questions asked because I had coverage on my Mac. Also keep in mind that any software problem you have will likely be addressed at the Genius Bar for free without even asking if you have AppleCare. I'd imagine this is the biggest probability. In the end, this is insurance. Do the math. Is the $ risk amount exceeding the cost of the coverage and the probability it will happen?Use an example of a hard drive failure. Is the cost of replacing it more than $250?  What is the probability it will happen within 3 years?  If the cost is more and the probability high, then get the extended warranty. Otherwise skip it. (Also keep in mind the other possible failures and costs too). Tl;dr: get it on the Mac if you have other apple products that are covered by that Mac's AppleCare.  Otherwise skip it. Coverage explained here:http://www.apple.com/support/products/mac.htmlThe coverage is explained here: http://wwwhtml"		steak	steak		"OK, I just spent like an hour trying to cross check three sites to find one that satisfied Stella's organic no-toxin site, Consu"	"OK, I just spent like an hour trying to cross check three sites to find one that satisfied Stella's organic no-toxin site, Consumer Reports testing of actual UV protection (note they only tested 12 types so it could be that others are better but they just didn't test), and finally scanning Amazon user reviews.  And the winner is.... Eco Logical.  That seems to be one that rates high on Stella site, Consumer Reports, and Amazon (though some people did complain on Amazon -- it was interesting that every option has haters on Amazon but this one still had around 4 stars).  I should get like 250 karma points for this."		"Getting closure on a yabble would be awesome for both the OP and the repliers. Bug: when entering a long yabble/reply on the i"	"Getting closure on a yabble would be awesome for both the OP and the repliers. Bug: when entering a long yabble/reply on the iPhone, you can see what you're writing after a while. Decide if you want in-home care ("	"You probably know this but rule one is to start looking early, as wait lists can be very long. Decide if you want in-home care (usually a Mom doing daycare on the side - cheaper if she's sick or on vacation then the daycare is closed) or a facility. For a facility, find out how long the teachers have been there - daycares have high turnover in general, but it's a big adjustment for you and the child when teachers change in the middle of the year, and a good signal when teachers stay. Make sure there's a match between your parenting preferences and what the daycare provider is willing to do - e.g. if your child has unique feeding or napping schedule, will they be able to accommodate that. Taking care of infants is pretty basic, so you don't have to worry much about teaching philosophy and such at that age, but if there's a preschool at the center too, see if their philosophy matches what you want, because once they're at a place they're more likely to stay there longer term due to difficulty switching providers with wait lists and such.In Seattle, I believe infant care at a center was $1500-$2000 per month. It gets cheaper as they get older.Good luck!"		The MacBook Pro is very powerful enough to replace your desktop. These games work better with even more people.For more complex gaming, House on Haunted Hill and Last Night on Earth are pretty good. The new iMacs made the decision for me.I was leaning towards the iMac due to upgradability. The new iMacs are not upgradable. I would rather build a Hackintosh if I want pure power then. The only plus point for the iMac now would be the Fusion Drive which allows more disk space on the iMac than the MBP. However, you can just attach a USB drive for more space with the MBP. The retina display is nice but not critical unless you are a designer working with retina graphics. You can connect an external monitor to get more screen estate with the MBP. Screens can be cheap if you're not getting an Apple monitor but you get what you pay for.The only difference left then would be the price point. You could possibly get more juice for a lower price point with the iMac. But you're going to have to carry a lot more weight and size then."		"A great external screen, same size as the Apple 27, but more crisp, cheaper, and with a lot more connection options, is the Dell"	"A great external screen, same size as the Apple 27, but more crisp, cheaper, and with a lot more connection options, is the Dell U2713HM. It's a ton of fun and you will be able to dive for years and years to come.  Also, the greatest thing is tha"	"Firstly, congrats!  It's a ton of fun and you will be able to dive for years and years to come.  Also, the greatest thing is that you can continue learning more and more and get more certifications if you want to really advance your skills.  My personal opinion is to forgo the BCD & reg for now.  To your point of packing light, maybe just invest in mask, fins & a wetsuit for now.  Take some time to get comfortable in the water and see how it feels since there are so many factors in determining your BCD (vest, back inflate, weight integration, etc.)  Once you're ready, it's going to be all about the fit/comfort, so maybe visit the dive shops and try on as many as possible.  Congrats again and have fun!"		"Also, check out this similar thread on solo beach-vacation ideas: http://yabb.ly/shj9WZ. For example,"	"Some tips from a former PADI instructor (me): Most important - always know how the air in your tank got there.  For example, I once dove in Lake George (NY) and got a funny oily taste partway down.  I grabbed my dive partner and we got out of the water quickly (we were nowhere near needing decompression).  Turns out the compressor air intake was downwind of the exhaust for the gasoline motor driving the compressor.  If we'd stayed down a bit longer, carbon monoxide likely would have killed us both due to the elevated partial pressure.  Check out every facility that charges your tank, your life is worth it.Second - know how deep you're going, and what the maximum depth & time are, and how that works out on the decompression curves.  Don't try to cheat.  I worked in a hyperbaric chamber for a while, the bends are not fun.Third - always, always have a dive buddy.  Always.Fourth - HAVE FUN!"		There are great reviews of www.amazon.com/dp/B000HAVRZK - it has models that go up to 2900gph.  http://www.amazon.com/dp/B000V7K	"There are great reviews of www.amazon.com/dp/B000HAVRZK - it has models that go up to 2900gph.  http://www.amazon.com/dp/B000V7KM2I/ also gets great reviews.Try checking out http://www.amazon.com/gp/top-rated/lawn-garden/13764351 for more ideas. You want to definitely ask what their ratio is. Make sure it's no more than 5. This mea	"Congrats! I've worked at many day cares. You want to definitely ask what their ratio is. Make sure it's no more than 5. This means for each staff, they can't be alone with more than 5 babies at a time, and for each group of 5 babies they have one staff member. Also the obvious: cleanliness and ask how often they feed and change diapers and what their schedule looks like. Make sure they aren't just ignoring the babies because they are babies. They should be interacting with them. I worked at a home daycare that had nap time in the same room as 2 cats were being isolated  and it smelled of cat urine and litter in there. I had to quit cuz I didn't want to be a part of that."		Cards against humanity is the best adult game ever made!!! It's like apples to apples but with adult topics and language. We cut the cable and only have Hulu Plus (for current shows) and Netflix (for older	"Just a different thought for saving on TV... We cut the cable and only have Hulu Plus (for current shows) and Netflix (for older shows we never had a chance to watch the first time around).  While we have no DVR, most things we watch are on demand on Hulu (we have both Rokus and Apple TVs for streaming).  You can check online if the shows you watch are on Hulu Plus.  We also have an antenna for local channels so we can see the news. Downside if you are a sports fan: no ESPN, but that isn't an issue in our house."		"Not familiar with that but if ur Internet connection doesn't work 1/2 time and this requires Internet, you might be hosed regard"	"Not familiar with that but if ur Internet connection doesn't work 1/2 time and this requires Internet, you might be hosed regardless of how good the device is?"		After ready a few questions they are bit too long for me. These are additional strips of wood every few feet vertic	"David's idea works very well - if the house does not have fire stops.  These are additional strips of wood every few feet vertically between the studs.  With fire stops it's still possible, but it takes a whole lot more holes, thus costs more.  A house I grew up in was built in 1908 and had fire stops, when my sister moved in they had to put a lot of holes in to get the insulation in.The other big area you'll have heat loss in a nice old house like that is the windows - if you can get those replaced that will also make a big difference."		"Good question in there - what so special about Apple.  I'll answer from my personal position, which may well not overlap with ot"	"Good question in there - what so special about Apple.  I'll answer from my personal position, which may well not overlap with others.First, the Macs.  (Warning, this paragraph is high geek factor.)  I started using Unix back around Berkeley 4.0 through 4.3, and compared to ATT System 3 & System 5, BSD was absolutely my favorite.  I still use OpenBSD a lot, I greatly prefer it to Linux, HP/UX, AIX, etc. when I have a choice.  Thus when Mac went from MacOS to OS/X I took a look at them - I never actually used a Mac running MacOS.  But OS/X is based on BSD; I can single-user boot any OS/X machine and get full control.  I can SSH to it, use terminal on it, that's a degree of control that's difficult to impossible with Windows.Second, the iPhone.  I have both iPhone and Galaxy S3.  The 5 is just completely intuitive to me.  A phone for me needs to be a highly reliable appliance that takes as few brain cycles related to it compared to getting something done.  Android, for me, requires more thinking about it in order to get something done.  So the 5 wins just for ease of use."		"Whatever you get, I would opt for whatever is the least processed, preferably from a local farm. Stay away from ultra pasteurize"	"Whatever you get, I would opt for whatever is the least processed, preferably from a local farm. Stay away from ultra pasteurized. Milk should not have a shelf life of a few months in my opinion. If you have access to a farmers market, start there.  Corn and soy aren't bad when pure but when highly processed they lose all the benefits and become something else entirely. (ie. high fructose corn syrup)"		What are you looking for? Will your husband use it too? Does it have ample space for diapers, wipes, clothes, ointment, sanitizer,      toys, burp cloths, etc? What about an accessible pouch for your keys, phone, and wallet? Is there an insulated area for bottles? Does it come with a pad for laying the baby on for quick changes on the go? Does the strap stay nicely on your shoulder, or perhaps you prefer a backpack style.Decisions regarding stroller, swing, and carrier also important. More to come on those.I absolutely do not recommend sleepers with snaps in back or a pouch instead of legs. You need easy access to messy diapers."		"+1 to a 13 Air, love it.  powers up super fast due to SSD, lightweight, travels great, etc.  And, it's not windows 8!  =P  Offi"""	"+1 to a 13 Air, love it.  powers up super fast due to SSD, lightweight, travels great, etc.  And, it's not windows 8!  =P  Office for Mac is fine, though it's not exactly like Office for Windows. It's widely used as a thicken"	"@Tom, the only concerning thing to me in that Almond milk article is the presence of Carrageenan.  It's widely used as a thickener and consistency modifier in foods.  And it's very bad for humans.  Here's an article on it with some good research paper backing:  http://www.notmilk.com/carageenan.htmlAn article about many unsafe things that can be added to foods and still call them organic"" is here: http://articles.mercola.com/sites/articles/archive/2012/05/20/kastel-organic-foods.aspx  On that page is this very concerning point about Carrageenan:"					"A number of peer-reviewed published papers that should have been cited indicate that degraded carrageenan causes inflammation and can cause serious intestinal abnormalities. Degraded carrageenan is also considered a possible carcinogen, and it's in organic foods! There is no doubt that carrageenan is an inflammatory agent. In fact, in testing anti-inflammatory drugs, laboratory animals are given carrageenan to produce inflammatory symptoms. There's no secret in the medical community that this is a problem."						"Note that in this context, ""degraded"" == ""partially digested"""""			"Thanks for the input, All. Whenever you take a pic on your smart phone, it will automatically upload it to your Drop Box account which you can have shared permissions with your wife. It uploads whenever your phone is connected wifi. If not connected, it will wait to upload automatically when connected. CON: it will upload everything in your photo gallery, so you have to keep it cleaned up of those photos that are blurry, etc., or else it will clog your Drop Box with a lot of unwanted photos and videos."		"Two of my kids learned susuki violin -- they started when they were 3 and 5 and stopped when we moved away, about 4 years later." Blown cellulose, which is essentially shredded up paper with fire retardant chemicals added and blown f"	"There are two varieties. Blown cellulose, which is essentially shredded up paper with fire retardant chemicals added and blown firberglass. Cellulose insulation is made of about 75% recycled material while fiberglass only contains about 25% recycled material. From an environmental standpoint cellulose wins out. I have also heard that cellulose will maintain it's R value over a longer period than fiberglass which means from an effectiveness standpoint that it wins as well.Costs for both are about the same which when taken all together means that I would go with cellulose insulation."		Thanks David!	Thanks David!		"Also, my mom will be with me so we don't need it to call the US, just to call around Ireland "	"Also, my mom will be with me so we don't need it to call the US, just to call around Ireland "		We stayed at the Excellence Riviera Maya in Mexico last October. The verdict? Get the Roku 3. Here?s a comparison between the two:Roku 3+Interface customization (move channels, interface themes)+Multi-content search function that will list price of content across different channels+The MicroSD slot and USB port can be used to import your own content (plus it plays video files in multiple formats)+New remote w/ audio jack for private listening+Remote doubles as motion controller-Doesn?t play very well with the Apple ecosystem-No dedicated YouTube app-Roku smartphone app can only push music/photos stored on phone to TV-Onscreen keyboard isn?t amazingApple TV+Shines if you're an avid Apple/AirPlay user+Has YouTube+Easy-to-use, uncluttered interface (as we should expect from an Apple product)+AirPlay streaming support + screen mirroring+Access to iTunes store/library-Little to no interface customization options -No search across multiple content sources-USB port doesn't support all types of contentHere?s the bottom line: the Roku 3 offers a better interface, search function, remote, and content sources. However, if you?re an avid user of AirPlay and Apple devices, you?re going to find that the Roku is a little weak in providing for these. It?s not a huge problem, and you can use the Roku smartphone app to send music from your phone?s iTunes library over to the box, but it won?t be the greatest experience. Here're some videos to check out:CNET Prizefight - AppleTV vs. Rokuhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-sToSy_-Zk4Roku Interface Walkthroughhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=iY2xMW1vbfY#at=15We hope this helped. Let us know if you go with the Roku 3 and how you like it!Yabble on :-),-Yabbly Concierge"		"Check crash ratings.  There's a NHTSA site, I prefer the IIHS (Insurance Institute for Highway Safety) site as they have a direc"	"Check crash ratings.  There's a NHTSA site, I prefer the IIHS (Insurance Institute for Highway Safety) site as they have a direct monetary interest in having people in safer cars.  The IIHS ratings are at http://www.iihs.org/ratings/default.aspxThe car connection http://www.thecarconnection.com/ is useful for general research.Look for forums based on the makes and models you're interested in - get a feel for the problem areas for each candidate vehicle.  Then concentrate on that when selecting an individual vehicle.  For example, if the forums say fenders rust after three years"", check the fenders."					"Obviously use http://carfacts.com/ to check on the history of the individual car."""			This link may be time limited: http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/templates/results.aspx?qu=survey&av=zpb140&avg=zpb&queryid=377b	"This link may be time limited: http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/templates/results.aspx?qu=survey&av=zpb140&avg=zpb&queryid=377b67b5-f30e-425f-819e-8206235c3296It shows the MS Publisher templates for creating surveys. That being said, I'm pretty sure every Mac laptop I've ever had dating back to a 12 iBook G4 at some point has been in to the GeniusBar for repair. I'm right now awaiting parts which they think may or may not solve my 15"" MacBook Pro randomly going to sleep. It's possible it has something to do with their repair a year ago for some reason which I can't even remember now. Either way, I don't have to think about it and usually the repair is done by the next day. "					"Having taken some of these machines apart myself to do repairs (including the crazy difficult 12"" PowerBook), it's generally not the easiest thing to do and if you're don't do it right you could easily cost yourself even more taking it in to have someone fix your new issues (whoops that tiny ribbon broke...too bad it was connected to your keyboard!). "						"It seems like a lot but if your machine is going to do more than just sit on a desk I would highly recommend it. The name comes from the lack of a mirror for shooting the image that allows both the camera bodies and the interchangeable lenses to be much smaller.When I made the jump to a more serious camera (and especially the flexibility of interchangeable lenses), I looked at many systems but eventually settled on micro four/thirds.  Their lens selection is the largest of all the mirrorless systems (dwarfing competitor Sony's NEX, Samsung's NX systems, and Fujifilm's X systems).A great article on which camera to buy (with different choices at various price points) is on one of my favorite sites, Wirecutter:http://thewirecutter.com/reviews/best-mirrorless-camera-over-1000/"		"Rent before you buy. Neither of us is right and the other wrong; we each picked what's best for us.In Seattle we have http://www.glazerscamera.com/rentals for renting camera gear.  I suggest you either go there if you're in this area or find a local place near you.If that's not available, find a local photographer's club or something and spend time with people who are strong Canon or Nikon or Olympus or Leica or whatever advocates."		My step-sister-in-law is a Redfin partner if you are still looking. http://www.redfin.com/real-estate-agents/khamb  Haven't sold	"My step-sister-in-law is a Redfin partner if you are still looking. http://www.redfin.com/real-estate-agents/khamb  Haven't sold a house myself, but I know she is definitely a hard worker."		"Just to drive my last point home, here is the organization that was set up by PCC that's dedicated to preserve Washington farmla"	"Just to drive my last point home, here is the organization that was set up by PCC that's dedicated to preserve Washington farmlands. http://www.pccfarmlandtrust.org/"		"thanks so much @texan! please continue to give us feedback, i love it!"
