But "	"If your primary use case is short trips, and of they're more or less flat, then a fixie or a singlespeed is a great choice. But if you want it to look cool, I'd advise against buying it online--pretty hard to tell what the fit and finish of a bike is from an Internet ad. In general, those bikes are built as cheaply as possible, minus a couple of brand name components that they can call out in an ad (in this case, the grips). There are a bunch of great bike shops in town that will let you actually ride the bike; they'll also get you closer to a bike that fits you size-wise. For what you're looking for, I'd avoid the bigger shops (like Gregg's or Performance). Try counterbalance in the u district, or keep your eyes peeled on Craigslist--because unless you know EXACTLY what you're looking for, you'll find something a lot cooler in person than what you'll pull out of a box from an online retailer."		"I lived in Panama for two years and have traveled thru most of Latin America for work and play.I loved Colombia and felt safe "	"I lived in Panama for two years and have traveled thru most of Latin America for work and play.I loved Colombia and felt safe despite the reputation. Brazil is amazing but note you need a visa.  If you do Peru most people are underwhelmed with Lima but spend at least a day just for the food.  Macchu Piccu is incredible and definitely     plan time to hike the trail.When traveling by bus always consider the lujo version but ask if it really does have ac and reclining chairs.  Make sure to get some cipro."		Consider Bocas de Toro in Panama.	Consider Bocas de Toro in Panama.		"4. A good thing to do is to go online and figure out what the lowest interest rate for your credit score is, that way you know if the interest the dealer is giving you is fair.Research the car and go to the dealership knowing exactly which car you want. Specific model, year and acceptable millage, instead of the usual:  but this one would be great for you"" trick. :)"""		"Hard Rock in punta cana... Best ever!!"	"Hard Rock in punta cana... The porters go ahead of you and set up tea time for mid day stops then set up camp for you before you get there. They also break down the camp sites in the mornings. All you carry is your daypack.  One guide goes to the front of the pack to lead, the other is at the back and will always remain behind the slowest person so no one ever gets lost. We ran into a couple of people on the trail who lost their groups. I just checked the site to see if they were still in business but turns out they are fully booked for the remainder of this season. I found them on the thorn tree forum on lonely planet.  From what I remember there was only about 3 really reputable companies to go with. Check thorn tree for the names of the other ones. Have fun!!!  Great experience!!! """		"and if they don't want to run Bootcamp, they can run an emulator like Parallels, which allows for a full Windows desktop to oper"	"and if they don't want to run Bootcamp, they can run an emulator like Parallels, which allows for a full Windows desktop to operate within a window in the Mac environment. but the amount if time to adjust will depend greatly on what they plan to use the Mac for and how in depth they go into the operating system for their solutions. generally if it's just software, it'll just be like I said, a nomenclature adjustment and becoming accustomed to the menu bar always being at the top of the screen for whatever application they have active. again, it's all explained in their free introductory courses if they can be bothered to sign up for one or more. "		"Three possibilities: 1.  Run Bootcamp.  This is using the Mac to run full native Windows.  Anything that runs on Windows run"	"Three possibilities: 1.  Run Bootcamp.  This is using the Mac to run full native Windows.  Anything that runs on Windows runs on this, and since Mac hardware is pretty state of the art, it runs nice and fast.  As @notoakie mentions, this is the software needed to make Windows boot on the Mac hardware.2.  Run a virtual machine.  Parallels and VMWare Fusion both do this.  Note you'll need enough RAM to run both OS/X and Windows to do this effectively.  I've tried both Fusion and Parallels and personally prefer Fusion, but both will work.  On the machine I'm working on right now, I'm running two virtual machines each with Windows 7 simultaneously while running OS/X as well.  It's transparent; things run great on all the systems.3.  Try Crossover by Codeweavers and see if the application runs under emulation.  Some very compliant things run flawlessly under Crossover, I use this for some things.  Others don't work as well or not at all.  Take a look at http://www.codeweavers.com/compatibility/ and see if someone's tried that program before."		Just got my Harry's in the mail. But I have sold several homes, both wit"	"I've never used Refin -- it looks like an interesting alternative to traditional agents. But I have sold several homes, both with agents and also by myself. As you might guess, in a seller's market, I did quite well selling myself. The hard part is that you get a lot of lookers, so screening for qualified buyers is important, and that's what traditional agents do. In a buyer's market, and in depressed times when I thought I wouldn't be able to sell my home, I sold with a traditional agent, but here's the tip I learned: there are only a handful of agents in your community -- sometimes as few as 2 or 3 -- that are selling the most (as much as 80%). These are uber connected agents that really know how to sell! So, in tough times, I've asked around to find out who these agents are, and then land with one, and I've never been disappointed. You make more selling yourself or through some of the alternative methods out there, but a really effective traditional agent will get it done quickly for you in a slow market. That's my experience."		I know you said you briefly looked into recording TV with a computer. There is a lot of information out there and it can get con	"I know you said you briefly looked into recording TV with a computer. There is a lot of information out there and it can get confusing. The MythTV project (http://www.mythtv.org/) has been around forever and I used it years back when it was much less developed and it was still a breeze. You have to make sure to get the right kind of hardware (i.e., linux compatible TV tuner, etc). But the overall requirements are pretty low and any old PC with a few upgrades can likely handle TV recording quite well (depending on your HD needs). They even have pre-made full OS distributions with MythTV already installed. (http://www.mythbuntu.org/)If you're in for a fun project that will end with an awesome DVR, I can't recommend Myth enough. Check out the wiki at (http://www.mythtv.org/wiki/MythTV-HOWTO#First_things_first) and give it a read. Might a bit complex but if you do a little bit of homework, it isn't terribly hard to grok.Anyways, I know its a bit more on the technical side, but as I mentioned, maybe you can see it as a fun learning project with the added benefit of building your own technology that does exactly what you want it to :)"		kindle!	kindle!		Sonia u need to agree w my answer above. On the other hand, though, the trade-off between brushing & spraying comes clos"""	"I second the don't skimp"" advice from @Loading. On the other hand, though, the trade-off between brushing & spraying comes close to a dead heat depending on your priorities."					"Spraying uses a lot more paint. If you follow the ""don't skimp"" advice, which I advise you to do, you're also going to need a lot more paint if you're spraying."						"Time-wise, you're going to need to do a lot more prep work for spraying. A lot of people opt for spraying because there are places on their exterior where they can't reach, but, to get a clean finish, you'll need to be really thorough with taping and masking."						"A nice compromise is a pump-handle roller. They're cost-effective enough so that you don't have to go through the cleaning headache (throw away the rollers), plus, the ""reach"" issue is accommodated by the long handle."						"That doesn't answer your question, though. Try a tool lending library if there's one near you to try out different products. For exterior painting, which you don't need to do frequently, paying for an expensive sprayer that will have quirks might be frustrating. Another option is buying a compressor, which is useful for a large number of projects while the sprayer nozzle is cheap, so you can't experiment."""			"I sold a house using Redfin, and I think my bad experience might have prompted some positive change in their organization. W"	"I sold a house using Redfin, and I think my bad experience might have prompted some positive change in their organization. When I sold with them, about 6 years ago, I really felt like they left me on my own and signed up primarily for paperwork. I had to host my own open house, and they were being cease-and-desisted by Windermere for allegedly misappropriating the local MLS. Their agent assignment was really poor. My agent went on vacation without notice and left me hanging, I had to call the office blind to get help from someone.That said, I see a lot of good improvements. My advice would be to get a good referral from someone without skin in the game (sorry @Marita). If someone got great service from a specific agent, use that same agent.Also, and this is probably more important than any other choice you make, develop a criteria for what you need in an agent. The acts of listing vs selling a house are two very different things. Listing is basically adding a house to the MLS and waiting for someone to notice it. Selling involves staging, open houses, advertising, all of which imply using a portion of the commission on the act of selling. Since all agents charge roughly the same, good support from an agent isn't necessarily an assumption."		"I like drinking tap water. It's like being one with the earth for me, at the city level. While the baby is in one of the convertible carriers, buy the 2nd dock. Once he/she graduates into the traditional car seat, work through friends and family whose kids grew out of theirs. The industry deprecates models based on wonky hazard stats, but they're splitting hairs. Year over year, the seats change very little, so using an old one is usually fine."""			I have a pump roller that I use as well and I do love it. It's really an indoor tool only though. It does take more paint as well as a little more prep but if you spray the whole house one color than come back and paint the trim by brush your set. It's really just a case of masking the windows. If you get some paint on it it comes off super fast and easy with a razor blade... which oddly enough is kinda fun and satisfying? Some do opt for an independent rou"	"Depends on your financial situation, what type of kid you have and what are your priorities.  Some do opt for an independent route despite a strong ps available.  Are you guaranteed a spot at PS or is there an overcrowding issue like in NYC?  How strong is exmissions for your independent vs ps? The national electrical code in fact forbids insulation added to K&T wiring, since the intent of K&T was to have wires in free air to dissipate heat.  Adding insulation would mean increased fire risk.  So if you have K&T, think seriously about getting it out as you get the insulation in."		"TB to VGA is pretty simple, the problem is that mini-DP to TB would require adding signals not present in mini-DP to come up to "	"TB to VGA is pretty simple, the problem is that mini-DP to TB would require adding signals not present in mini-DP to come up to TB.  For example, with TB the display could support USB 3 connectors with no additional wiring needed."		"This isn't as elegant as the others (I'm a recent college grad), but camping on the North Padre Island National Seashore is exce"	"This isn't as elegant as the others (I'm a recent college grad), but camping on the North Padre Island National Seashore is excellent. They are absorbent, hold up after numerous washes, soft, dries quickly. 2) Medela Breast pump, Lansinoh nipple cream, Lansinoh breast milk storage bags, Laninoh breast pads 3) Ergo baby carrier - Back support is really good plus there is a thing that goes over the head for sun protection so you don't always need to carry a hat4)  Quinny stroller - lightest/smallest on the market. We put it in the overhead compartment of the plane a few times when we flew5) Bouncer - Our was so simple as it was a hand me down, the toy bar was gone. You just need a place to temp. put baby down while you use the bathroom or quick break. 6) Clothing that close in the front (buttons) versus overhead. Sometimes it's annoying for kids to put clothes over their head. 7) Halo sleep sack. Perfect once they are out of swaddle. Zip up and don't worry about being too coldYou will likely get a lot of toys, books, clothings too even if they are not part of your registry. Lots of cute things for your little one. All the best!"		"I live in Ohio,  :)  I like the sock Idea,  I may use that for the bathroom floor dusting." I don't know why there is a variation "	"Only advice, make sure the CFM (Cubic Feet Per Minute) is high enough for what you want.  I don't know why there is a variation from PSI and the CFM ratings, all I know is that certain compressors don't have a high enough CFM to run certain tools.  If you ever wanted to use the compressor to use a paint spray gun or nail gun for your house, you are going to need a higher CFM than some of the cheapest on the market.  Any tools you look to by will have a minimum CFM requirement rating."		You should also check out the mid 80s Mercedes 190D. One creative alternative is to use the annual gifting amount per spouse/per child (approx $13K) and use that toward the premium for life insurance on the child (i believe it's whole term, the kind which the premium is fixed for 10 or 20 years).  Sounds weird to take out life insurance on a child but you lock in a good premium, can borrow/draw against the death benefit for not just college, and the benefit is a protected asset.  Choose a good mutual company insurance provider (Guardian, Mass mutual, etc) and they usually provide about 3-4% guaranteed annual growth. Look around, look at the children's faces, at the daycare workers, "	"I would echo all of things above and add this: take a tour.  Look around, look at the children's faces, at the daycare workers, just look at all of the things that they aren't telling you about.  Your gut sometimes is the strongest indicator of if a place is right for your child or not.  If you're uncomfortable there, chances are your child would be too.Also, check out the government website for ratings on all of the daycares--I think our state groups it under Child Protective Services website, and it lists the scores"" good or bad, that the daycares receive, all the incidents that may or may not have occurred, and how and when they resolved them.  Handy research to do before you tour a facility."""		"Keep hanging in there! You're doing a great job.  One of my friends had this same problem with her son, and she ended up doing"	"Keep hanging in there! You're doing a great job.  One of my friends had this same problem with her son, and she ended up doing something creative--they had to grow the veggies (or fruit/food group) that she needed him to eat.  So, they picked out the plant (I believe they started with tomatoes) and watered it each day together, etc., and before she knew it, he was eating the tomato off the plant before it was even ripe! It's a long-term answer, but getting him invested in the get-go helped her son.With us, it was hard at first, but we just said that this is the food we're eating, and if you don't like it, that's fine, but you're not getting anything else and/or speciality made just for you.  Sounds cruel, I know, but they get the picture and soon come around when they realize this is dinner. And my only chance to get food before the morning.Also-cute containers helped too-put small portions of whatever the meal is in a cupcake pan, small bits of fruit, etc., and let them pick and try each little container"" of something."					"Good luck!"""			@james-empowered that link is awesome thx!	@james-empowered that link is awesome thx!		"Thank you, everyone for all of these tips! I don't know what device(s) you'll be using this with, but if its not an Apple device, you might want to menti"""	"Great idea, @Tom! I don't know what device(s) you'll be using this with, but if its not an Apple device, you might want to mention that. I have noticed that many Logitech Bluetooth devices are advertised to pair with iPhones, iPads, etc....whether it be from Logitech or another company that sells their product, but not necessarily advertised to work with non-Apple devices; however, most of them do work with other devices.I bought a Logitech Bluetooth boom box maybe a year and a half ago and noticed this. I had assumed that it should work, but since I couldn't find any mention in ads that it would work, I wanted to be certain. I read through a bunch of reviews and relied on those reviews stating that it would work with my Android phone and tablets."		"I think that you should try to open a savings and checking account at a credit union, if possible, that also offers secured cred"	"I think that you should try to open a savings and checking account at a credit union, if possible, that also offers secured credit cards. Credit unions, at least in my opinion, are the best places to do your banking. They generally offer lower interest rates on most services. For example, lower interest rates on credit cards, car loans, mortgages, personal loans, etc...They usually also charge lower fees (sometimes no fees) for account services, such as ATM withdrawal fees, minimum balance fees, etc.Put some money into accounts for a while to establish yourself, then open a secured card, if you are not able to open a regular credit card. Usually you would have to put an amount of money into the account that's attached to the secured card, and that would be your credit limit. After establishing a good payment history, the credit union (or bank) should let you open a regular card account. There are many credit unions out there. I had availability to one through my job. That one is out of state for me, however, I do my banking with them online. I have no problem doing online banking, but I'm not sure if you would be comfortable doing so.. If you are, then that expands your options as to what credit unions are available. There is a government website called www.NCUA.gov where you can search for local credit unions or do an advanced search to see if you might qualify to join any specific credit unions. If you go to this site, go to: http://researchcu.ncua.gov/Views/FindCreditUnions.aspx You search by area code, name, type, region, There is a dropdown called Field of Membership"" where you can find different types of credit unions. Generally to join a credit union, you have to be part of some certain group. For example, if you belong to a certain church, business, organization, military, or other group. You really have to look at each credit union's eligibility requirements."""		"Oops, I ran out of characters on my first reply.Here is another resource that I would highly recommend. It's a website and f"	"Oops, I ran out of characters on my first reply.Here is another resource that I would highly recommend. It's a website and forum for credit: www.creditboards.comI really think anyone should check this out, not just those looking to build credit or rebuild their credit. It's an excellent resource for everyone. I have learned so much on this site about credit...things I would have never known about. Things that no one gets taught in school but that everyone should know since just about everyone uses credit and has or will have a credit history. It's a great place to ask questions and get advice about credit, credit cards, loans, credit reports, credit scores, etc. They even give all the advice you would need to repair your own credit...for free. (there are many companies out there that claim to repair one's credit for a fee, when in fact, one can do it all for free themselves. I found some errors on my own credit reports and was able to get them all fixed using the advice & resources on CreditBoards.com."		"@Bikegal mentioned setting up a registry and getting everything from Amazon. This reminded me that Amazon has a service call"	"@Bikegal mentioned setting up a registry and getting everything from Amazon. This reminded me that Amazon has a service called Amazon Mom"" that you can sign up for. The service will get you free shipping on lots of things mom/baby related, and also lower prices, sales, etc. For example, you might find diapers on there that are cheaper than elsewhere, you could even sign up for auto-delivery where they send you the diapers on set periods, like every month, and if you do that, they give you an additional discount, anywhere from 5 to 15%  more off of their price. You could even sign up for auto-delivery and then cancel it whenever you want. I use auto-delivery for my K-Cups and a few other things I use a lot. There have been times I had to either cancel my upcoming delivery or just change the date. It is NO hassle and very easy. They even send you a reminder before your next shipment is due to ship in case you want to change it. Joining this service is free as well. It gets you free shipping on many baby-related items and some extra discounts. They send you a weekly email with deals and things for mom, and they let you know what products qualify for Amazon Mom service."""		It certainly is cool looking and it at least has a front break (no rear). From our research, we discovered that there?s some competi"""	"Hi @Loading___,Great question ? we?ve decided to have a go at it! From our research, we discovered that there?s some competition between Milwaukee portabands and DeWalt portabands, but we also found out that people seem to be loving their DeWalt a lot more. Here?s a general comparison (we?ll leave it to you to find the best model that best fits your needs):DeWalt Portable Band Saws:+Higher quality+More compact+Built in LED light+Rubber bumpers (better rubber fall protection)+Costs less than a Milwaukee+Hanging hookMilwaukee Portable Band Saws	+Greater power compared to similar DeWalt portabands+Better suited and hold up better in work environmentsHere?s a quote we saw on an online board regarding this topic, it may help sum it up: ?Dewalt is like the Chevy, better ergonomics, lighter weight, smother fit and finish.Milwaukee is like the Ford, a bit more rugged, clunker and you are going to find more of them out on the job site.?Beyond these two brands, here are two other options for you. Porter Cable 9750 Variable Angle Reciprocating SawThe Porter Cable is a reciprocating saw that has variable angle functionality. The blade end rotates 360 degrees with 12 angle stops and the forward section swivels 180 degrees up and down with 13 angle stops. Quite nifty, but also quite heavy for a portable saw (according to reviewers).http://www.amazon.com/Porter-Cable-9750-Tiger-Reciprocating-Variable/dp/B0000ASDMKHarbor Freight Portable Band Saw If you're looking for a less-name brand, lower-priced saw, check out the Harbor Freight. It's definitely no DeWalt or Milwaukee, but it'll get the job done (not as well though).http://www.harborfreight.com/portable-variable-speed-bandsaw-47840.htmlWe hope this helped you a little bit in your search for a new portable band saw. All signs point to the DeWalt as a better tool, but we'll leave it to you to make the decision. Let us know which one you end up going with. Do you want advi"	"I've run a couple marathons, a few more halfs, but now focus 10ks.I'm a bit unclear as to what your asking. Do you want advice on picking between the two races, or are you curious about trying to run both races?If you're wondering about doing both, I'd point out that 5 weeks prior to a race is typically your last week of really hard work before you being tapering off to [ideally] peak on your race date.If you're an experienced runner, I'd say that there's enough time between the two races to push it pretty hard in the 12k and still have more than enough time to recover/expect a good showing in the half marathon.If you're not as experienced, and your training plan has been working for you, then I'd caution to stick to your original plan.If you're trying to pick between the 12k and 13.1 distance, my personal pick would be the 12k. I focus on 10ks because due to work, kids, etc, I just don't really have the time to properly train for a half or full marathon.10ks & 12ks are awesome because you can typically fit more than adequate training (for the distance) in a rather concise block of time."		"Here are a couple of ideas:-Triscuits with Salami-Carob Nuggets, available in bulk section of most grocers-Tamari Almonds"	"Here are a couple of ideas:-Triscuits with Salami-Carob Nuggets, available in bulk section of most grocers-Tamari Almonds-Sahale snacks are great but priceyI also recommend making your own energy bars using an assortment of dried fruits/nuts that are held together using arrowroot powder and brown rice syrup.  Basically, you heat the brown rice syrup (or agave nectar) until it gets more viscous, add in the arrowroot powder, and then pour it over the nuts/fruits.  The arrowroot powder acts as a hardening agent giving you a nice delicious hard energy bar."		"Thank you, @Maven_88! I have heard of Monoprice and did find some of these cables there. Two of the times I went solo, the third time I went with my "	"I've been to Thailand three times, each for almost two months each. Two of the times I went solo, the third time I went with my husband.I have a friend who was going for 2 weeks and here's the advice I gave them... in several parts:The North: Chang Mai    Chang Mai --        Definitely elephant trek -- They're all pretty much the exact same and I'd trust your hotel to set one up for you. They usually come pick you up in a van and bring you to the trek, feed you, and then bring you back at the end of the day.        Night Market -- If you just say Night Market, everyone knows what it is and where it is. It's HUGE and there's so many cool things to buy that are cheap. And if my memory serves me correctly, it was a bit cheaper than some of the other night markets/bazaars in Bangkok.  I bought hand-made silverware that I still use to this day and it still looks brand spankin' new and it was significantly cheaper in Chang Mai.        Since you have so many days in Chang Mai, I'd take a cooking class somewhere.I'm a beach person - so for me 6 days in Chang Mai would be too many days since there's not THAT much to do up there unless you go check out Pai and Chang Rai -- but both cities there's about the same amount of things to do."		"If it were up to me, I'd bring Chang Mai down to 3-4 days and increase the amount of days you're in the southern portion -- you'"	"If it were up to me, I'd bring Chang Mai down to 3-4 days and increase the amount of days you're in the southern portion -- you'll find a week at the beach down south won't be nearly enough.  Especially because there are so many islands around there -- Railay is worth checking out if you're staying in Phi Phi - one of the more gorgeous places we visited.  Beaches aren't AS quiet... but it's still pretty ridiculous. Check out my links below.If you like snorkeling, beaches and relaxing, Phuket and Phi Phi will keep you busy for weeks.  Down there you can rent mopeds (or an actual car for ridiculously cheap) and make your way around from beach to beach. We loved the beach Nai Har on Phuket (link below) - just really gorgeous and not many people. The beaches are all accessible by car or motorbike and I highly recommend you rent one for the entire trip. It's like 6 bucks a day if I can remember correctly and you can find them by just driving around on a moped to see if someone has a car for rent outside their house. It's legit if you can believe it and suppper nice people. super nice. just be careful on the motorbikes. everyone crashes them b/c they go too fast."		"** Phuket - http://www.phuket.com -- is very pretty, there's a ton to see, it's close to all the other islands that are cool (li"	"** Phuket - http://www.phuket.com -- is very pretty, there's a ton to see, it's close to all the other islands that are cool (like Koh Phi Phi, Railay, Krabi).        Patong is where all the action is and is the busiest part of the island - I wouldn't stay here, but I would go there for a day to check out the shops and the beaches.  It's crazy busy, packed, and it smells, but it's worth checking out.  All these beaches are where the tsunami hit, so you'll still see some construction, etc.        Nai Harn - I'd recommend staying in this area and you can take a taxi or rent a car for cheap to get to Patong.            Nai Harn Beach - http://www.phuket.com/island/beaches_nai_harn.htm        Karon Beach - gorgeous (can get here by motorbike from Nai Harn)        Kata & Kata Noi - gorgeous and close to the others. You can easily get here with a motor-bike.   **  Railay Beach - http://www.railay.com/railay/intro/intro.shtml- I really liked Railay because of it's huge cliffs and gorgeous views.  It's a little busier than I'd prefer, but there are tours to get you to Koh Phi Phi and Hong Bay that are worth checking out.  If you like rock climbing and kayaking, there's a ton of it here.        Getting there info - http://www.railay.com/railay/intro/getting_there.shtml        Hotels on Railay - http://www.railay.com/railay/accommodation/krabi_hotels.shtml            We stayed at Railay Princess (a bit pricey, but it was nice with A/C and no bugs and a nice pool) - http://www.railayprincessresort.com/"		"Krabi (way southern part of the country) - This is where are the really pretty, less crowded beaches are.    Hotel in Krabi "	"Krabi (way southern part of the country) - This is where are the really pretty, less crowded beaches are.    Hotel in Krabi Town (if you need a place to stay on way to/from Koh Lanta) - http://www.howdy-relaxingkrabi.com/en/home_en.htmlKoh Lanta - Gorgeous laid back island, not much going on except gorgeous beaches/relaxing - One of my favorite relaxing places. Clothes, knik knaks, gifts, handcrafted artisan crafts that are actually really nice, bootleg DVDs, purses, shoes, jeans, etc, etc."		"           - Patpong Night Bazaar (they say Baza) - a market with strip clubs on the perimeter, one called ""Super Pussy"", where women literally shoot ping pong balls out of their hoo-haas, blow bubbles, shoot bananas, etc, etc.  Impressive and disgusting, but actually a really well priced market compared to others."			"           - MBK - It's a ridiculous shopping center that is hectic, busy, and disorganized, but if you want cheap (but nice looking) accessories like jewelry, shoes, purses, clothes, this place is worth the trip.  I skipped it my first two trips because I was overwhelmed, but the most recent trip we shopped and I have so many nice pieces of jewelry I wear all the time."			          -  Suan Liam Night Bazaar (I call it the Lumpini Park Bazaar since it's next to it) - more good shopping like the other places above.			          -  Siam Discovery - big American-like mall with a movie theatre in it - I've seen probably 3 or 4 movies in this mall.			        Things to See -			"            This is a pretty good list of things to see & do. http://www.bangkok.com/most-popular-historical/index.html  Chinatown is worthwhile, the Grand Palace, the waterways (I'd just take a river taxi and you'd see it)"			            -There are Wats (Thai temples) everywhere you go			       -- We stayed here on our first and last nights in Bangkok http://www.grandwatergatehotel.com/			"      -  I'd stay in the ""Siam"" area of Bangkok - it's close to everything, not too far from the airport, and easy to get places on the Sky Train."""			"if you want more about Koh Samui, Koh Tao, Koh Phangan, let me know, I've got just as much stuff. :) Sorry if this was long!! Could be  simple wiki-style markup)3)Bug: when composing a reply from the iPhone app, the formatting is ignored when viewing from the web.Expected Result:- Write a reply from the iphone app.  Write multiple paragraphs, with a line separator between paragraphs.- View reply on web.  There is a line separator between paragraphsActual Result:- Line separators are ignored, yielding a large block of hard-to-read text.Example: http://yabbly.com/question/1556/what-to-do-app-system-works-best-for-you4)As a Yabbler, when I post a link to a product, I see a thumbnail of the product in the reply, so others can see the meta-info.Acceptance Criteria:- The title/summary of the product is shown- A rating (if available) is shown- Contact info is shownExample 1 (Google): Type in Gary Danko"" (it's a restaurant).  The meta-info shows a rating, phone #, directions, etc.  All the stuff you want when going deeper into that product/service."					"Example 2 (Yelp): Search for ""Restaurants"" and ""Near Fisherman's Wharf"".  Mouse-over Gary Danko's and you'll see hours, phone, rating, etc.  Very useful."						"Example 3 (Facebook): In the ""What's on your mind"" field, put in ""http://www.garydanko.com"" but don't submit the form.  It shows some basic info, thumbnail and blurb from the site"""			Example 4 (Amazon): http://snap.stanford.edu/data/amazon-meta.html	Example 4 (Amazon): http://snap.stanford.edu/data/amazon-meta.html		I have both and Roku and Apple TV. It is increasingly becoming very popular for tourists who wish to escape the crowds.My husband and I went there 2 years ago. It was one of the most memorable beach vacations we've had. We stayed at the Blue Wind Resort. Small hut bungalow, air-coned, clean bathroom and well-kept surrounding. A 30sec walk to the beach. Quiet by day and night. The loud evening entertainment was hardly audible from where we stayed.The Sairee Beach is the longest and most popular beach on the island. And because of it's length, the privacy is great too.The water is clear and beautiful by day.When the sun sets, outdoor dining and fire show emerging and lights up the coast line. It is probably the busiest it can get. And if you like the bustle, the BBQ seafood here is superb and really value for money for it's freshness and size. For quiet dinner, head over to Rim Lae Restaurant( part of Cabana Resort) which is a 12 min beach-walk for BBQ stuff, thai food and cocktail. It is slightly high end but the atmosphere definitely make up for it. The restaurant is set overlooking the bay. We went there 2 times for both afternoon cocktail and BBQ dinner. There are many resorts to choose from. We went with Blue Wind because our friend works there. We were ready to move to another resort if it was below our expectations.http://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/Hotel_Review-g303910-d1116162-Reviews-Blue_Wind_Bakery_and_Resort-Koh_Tao_Surat_Thani_Province.html"		We usually rely on the resort/ hotel to recommend a day tour or snorkeling trip. Then we tend to compare packages and prices whe	"We usually rely on the resort/ hotel to recommend a day tour or snorkeling trip. Then we tend to compare packages and prices when we come across tour agencies in town.Our snorkeling trip consisted of 5 snorkeling sites,  equipments and lunch at about $1000baht. Overall, very enjoyable experience, as promised.A must-visit is the Nang Yuen island. A very lovely island not to be missed. Picturesque and beautiful. Very few people know about this secret island. It is a short distance away from Koh Tao. A private island which emphasizes on friendly environment, no plastic water bottle allowed. Visitors must wash their feet before and after they leave the beach. The water is almost transparent with many small fish swimming around. You can walk into the sea. Perfect for snorkeling.And if it's not entirely an island trip, Bangkok is another good choice- only if your daughter is not too little. 1. Platinum Shopping MallThis is a heaven for crazy and cheap shopping. You will find wholesale latest fashion, kids', menswear,accessories etc at very good bargains. Not necessary to buy in wholesale though, it is just a wholesale marketplace for business owners. Bargaining not appreciated( according to my thai husband) but being Singaporean, we just love trying our luck. Shops open from 10am by 7pm.2. Jatuchuk Weekend Market- aka JJ MarketTo pick up some unique and local-designed pieces. Clothes, pets, shoes, art work, food stores. You need it, they have it. Home and decor stuff are known to be the cheapest here. Endless of mini stores tucked in the tiny lanes. You will need at least half a day here. It can get really hot in between the small lanes. The whole of JJ market is like a huge maze and it can get really hot, therefore I do not recommended parents bringing their young kids here. When I saw many foreigner parents carrying the kids in their arms, I empathize both the little ones and the parents. Shops open from 10am to 6pm."		Thx Tom!! Super helpful =)	Thx Tom!! We love Amazon - we have Prime a	"I'd like to add something about our registry in Amazon that I wished I had known ahead of time. We love Amazon - we have Prime and pretty much order everything from there and often... HOWEVER the baby registry I very much regret using because their return policy is AWFUL. even tho it says you can rerun as easily as you would if you bought something yourself, that is not the case. If someone buys something that is fulfilled by Amazon, you can return it yourself, and even if you specify exactly which item to get from exactly which store on amazon, we found our gift givers searched high and wide for the best price (naturally, right?). What that resulted in us having to go back and forth with the non-amazon store who sold thru amazon and they couldn't give us a refund, only a store credit to their store, which happened to carry nothing of what we'd want. Shipping cost was also an issue bc again unless it was fulfilled by amazon it wasn't free reruns. We lost $80 on a stroller bc we decided we didn't want it after we tried it and the store would only take it back if we paid for return shipping. "		"@Andy-friendly, what is performance"" for you? For a bike seat, both Sunlite Cloud 9 series and Schwinn have worked for me.  I prefer gel.  One idea for you is to try gel seat covers first before getting an actual seat/saddle, not only as a possible cost savings (not much actualluy) but to see if you like the feel and comfort. There are some pros to having only the cover to transport. It can also be used at the gym as well (spin classes), and you can bring with you on trips or anytime you use someone else's bike or rented bike, etc."		Nice!  It's like a new world! A previous trip cost us astron	"We called our wireless provider right before we crossed the border and got an international plan. A previous trip cost us astronomical amounts of money for data and roaming. Be sure to watch the data, it will add up quickly. We had difficulty accessing ANY wireless hotspots, we never did figure out why. If you can get that to work it should help. Also, if you have a separate GPS device, bring that and make sure you do any needed updates prior to your trip, this will cut down tremendously on your data. Make sure you call your wireless provider as soon as you leave Canada so you don't continue to get charged for an international plan! We decided to look into this for you and have come up with 2 reasonably priced options for"	"Hi @Andy-friendly,Great question! We decided to look into this for you and have come up with 2 reasonably priced options for 70-inch HDTVs. Our Pick:The Vizio Razor 70 LED E701i 1080p (http://store.vizio.com/e701ia3.html) is abut $1,700, which is a great price for such a large name-brand TV. It has all the bells and whistles you?d expect (even the one you may not want, Smart TV) ? it's an LED TV, it has 4 HDMI inputs, it has USB inputs, and it is 120Hz (not the greatest, but not the worst). Vizio is not known for the best reliability ? but the warranty should cover any out-of-box problems. (You should also know that CNET calls the Vizio E701i the Best 70-inch LED TV value - just something to keep in mind!)"					Great Second Option:			"The Sharp Aquos 70? TV line also seems to be another line of great value TVs which you can find for around $2,000-$3,000. Specifically, the Sharp Aquos Quattron LC-70LE733U TV (http://reviews.cnet.com/flat-panel-tvs/sharp-aquos-quattron-lc/4505-6482_7-34851078.html) received CNET?s Green Pick award, so you?ll be using less energy when you run it (always a plus). It runs at 240Hz, and also has 4 HDMI ports, and includes the extra bells and whistles (Wi-Fi connectivity, Smart system). The benefit this TV has over the Vizio is that its 240Hz refresh rate means that it may run a bit better in clarity, though you?re paying extra for it. Generally, the Sharp Aquos line is one to consider, even if you?re looking at non-2013 model year TVs. A great secondary option to the Vizio Razor depending on where your preference and price range lies."						"Though you don't want Smart TVs, these both will give you a run for your money. Our research helps us conclude that the Vizio would be a good product fit for your situation, though the Smart TV functionality may be a detractor. Thanks for your question, and we hope this helped. Let us know what you think and which TV you ultimately go with. Yabble on :-)!"						"-Yabbly Concierge"""			"It may be worth waiting at least one more year. 18 months is a bit young. Thailand is super tourist friendly, so you always have options.  Lots of region specific websites for hotels, air, etc (i.e. wego.com).  Don't limit yourself to Expedia.  Research multiple sites and agencies if you are a budget traveler."		I'm on tmobile and have an iPhone. I think this is a perfect destination for 4 & 6 years old. Kids loved it. Few tips from th	"My family ended up going to Legoland. I think this is a perfect destination for 4 & 6 years old. Kids loved it. Few tips from the visit. Buy 5 days for 1 day price tickets. They are available while there are no local school breaks and valid for half a year. So buy them in advance. I'd also recommend going there after your kid reached 42. This way he/she can try all attractions. I'd not pay for water park if you don't have combo ticket. It does not worth extra pay. At the same time aquarium is cool and worth extra dollars. I've lived at Carlsbad by the sea resort. It has free shuttle the park and only 20 min walk from it (the sign at the hotel indicates 10 min working, but this is a big stretch)."""		I don't recommend the Ikea Billy. It's thin particle board with a nice looking veneer. I really liked mine for the first couple 	"I don't recommend the Ikea Billy. It's thin particle board with a nice looking veneer. I really liked mine for the first couple of months, but it has an incredibly short lifespan.  Chips became evident quickly and the back separated from the sides. Ok for a short-term solution (if you rent, dont expect it to make the move) but I'd go with a sturdier unit from a real furniture store if you own a home. I went to one shower where everyone was asked to bring a pack of diapers instead of a regular gift. Don't ask for clothes, you will get so many anyway (people cant resist those cute outfits) and the way your little one grows in the first few months is crazy so many they will only wear a couple of times.Another idea, ask one of your friends to co-ordinate a meal delivery service for you for the first few weeks you are back home from hospital. www.takethemameal.com works great. Also keep in mind these are all Smart TVs, if you're okay with having the features but opt not to use them. I personally find that it's becoming increasingly harder to find a big high-performance TV that doesn't have any Smart features.In terms of performance, what I usually look for in a flatscreen are viewing angles (how much they affect the TV's picture quality) plus the level of blacks, resolution and sharpness of the picture. Everything else can be calibrated to your liking (colors, removing soap-opera effect, etc). If these are product aspects that you care about, then Sharp LC-70LE640U and the Sharp recommended above by YB Concierge actually performs extremely well in the aforementioned areas. You also typically get a lot of HDMI ports with Sharp (4 slots), plus the pricing is usually below $2500. Right after Sharp, I'd personally consider a 70-inch Samsung LED. However, as much as I love my recently purchased Samsung Smart TV (55 inch), I do have to admit it's extremely pricey (starting @ $6000) when you're considering one at 70 inch. You also may want to pay attention to whether a TV is an Edge-Lit or Backlit LED with local dimming. Typically Edge-Lit TVs (most common type) are extremely susceptible to clouding effects when you're watching in a dark room (http://guide2lcdtv.files.wordpress.com/2008/10/clouding.jpg) and also screen uniformity issues (things are brighter on the edge of the screen) while Backlit LED TVs do not have these problems. All Samsungs are victims of this problem, and it took me a long while to get used to it with my current Sammy. If I were to purchase my next TV, I'd make it a Backlit with local dimming a top feature to have."		"@Tom, just visited it, but did not pay.  It is excellent. Very well managed and presented. W"	"I started off with a low end model (I cannot remember the brand, but it was inexpensive), and it was difficult to exercise on. Wobbled, noisy, I constantly felt I needed to try to tighten bolts, and so on - being so irritated impacted the workout itself. A few years later we upgraded to a Precor, and it is fantastic. Smooth, great exercise programs (hill, random, etc that changes resistance and sets duration), and low maintenance. Essentially, we just need to dust it of pet hair from time to time. If you're able to invest in a better machine, it is definitely worth the money in quality of workout and how many years it will last overall. For features I'd recommend one with moving arms, *not* stationary arms. You get a better workout. I do use heart rate monitoring, but this is easy to find nowadays on other gadgets so not worth being built in. If you have the chance, may be worth doing a free gym trial or two to try the different machines/brands/features to give you a comparison between models - may help you decide on what calibre of machine to invest in, and what features are important to you.Good luck!"		"If you decide to seek out a diy template, the organization SCORE has one on their website (score.org). Also, in the book Business Model Generation by Alexander Osterwalder, it is suggested that one write a business model canvas, which is a snapshot of all of the elements of your plan in one place.  We did this, and it really helped us sharpen our desired position in the market.  As I understand it, it's not so good for sharing with potential investors who will be looking for your detailed plan."		Generally I prefer Android - much more availability in terms of phone variety and if you're a big user of Google services (e.g. 	Generally I prefer Android - much more availability in terms of phone variety and if you're a big user of Google services (e.g. Maps) the system will be optimal. If you are "	"Lynda.com is amazing, and quite cheap for the amount of knowledge available. However, not all tutorials go in-depth. If you are already familiar with coding, try udacity.com/courses or if you are a beginner, try codeacademy.com. Lynda.com has a trial subscription: http://www.lynda.com/promo/trial/default.aspx?lpk35=1908There are lots of free tutorials out there too. The paid libraries are obviously more structured and also a bit academic. Lots of programmers or avid software users learn the basics through a simple tutorial, and then spend the rest of their time on stackoverflow.com or other rapid-response forums. No library will answer all your questions, so it really depends on what your motive is for learning a programming language or a software."		"I've made sets myself, helped build the original system and QA the Adobe Creative Suite videos (CS4), and managed sets for other"	"I've made sets myself, helped build the original system and QA the Adobe Creative Suite videos (CS4), and managed sets for other products. I think they are great for highly visual concepts (I use them all the time myself now that I'm learning to sew - essential for the visual nature of this activity!)Personally I prefer written tutorials for many technical subjects that aren't highly visual, despite being quite involved in many video tutorials for work and being a visual learner. Then I prefer videos for subjects that are difficult to explain or understand in words (animation, controls that don't have names, etc). But there are people who are the types of learners where video makes sense regardless of subject. For example, videos about coding - doesn't work for me, but does for my husband. I'd find it worth the money if you are that type of learner, or looking to learn a program where it is particularly difficult to follow written tutorials. Many high quality sites mentioned in answers already. Another quality option to check out is DigitalClassroom.com."		I think that's a good idea. Many companies make Android phones, so they are some really brilliant and competitive products out there"		"If you're interested in going with a cheaper and more creative route, my wife and I repurposed old dresser drawers into a bookca"	"If you're interested in going with a cheaper and more creative route, my wife and I repurposed old dresser drawers into a bookcase. It has the ability to print from just about anything, and it doe"	"I have a  Canon Pixma MG8220 all-in-one and absolutely love it. It has the ability to print from just about anything, and it does include AirPrint (as well Google Cloud print, wi-fi printing, and Pixma cloud print). This printer has just about everything imaginable. It prints photos VERY quickly and the photo quality is outstanding - I am not a photographer, nor very familiar with photography, but as an average person, the photos look great. It has 6 individual ink tanks, which I love, so that you only have to change one color of ink at a time. It also has a memory card reader, double-sided printing, scanning, and you can even scan slides & negatives into it for saving or printing. If  you also have a Canon camera, there's this really cool feature where you can print still photos from a movie you filmed on that camera. The only thing it doesn't have is a fax. This may be a dealbreaker if you use a fax a lot. I personally only use a fax when job hunting and for very few other occasions. When I need to use a fax, I just use FreeFax online. Many years ago, I used to buy HP Printers, but every one I owned only lasted about a year or so. Something always ended up breaking down so that it would no longer print. I got sick of buying a new printer every year, so I read rave reviews about Canon printers, and bought one. I can't even remember how old my first Canon is, but I still have it and it still works, however I did buy the MG8220 late last year just to get updated features. Canon inks DO cost more, though, so that is something to take into consideration. However, in my opinion, the ink cost is worth the price. I usually stock up on my inks when I find a good sale. Sometimes NewEgg has big ink discounts on Black Friday, so I tend buy a bunch then."		Thank you everyone! I think I may at least try the free trial of Lynda.com. It's a nice, thick cable, though not super t"	"Update: I received my 10' Amazon Basics USB extension cable and it works perfectly. It's a nice, thick cable, though not super thick and seems very sturdy. I had read reviews about other brands being flimsy or not being able to charge as fast as with the OEM sync cable. I do not see any difference in charging time using the Amazon extension cable and it's long enough for me to plug in and use while in bed, which is what I wanted. Both ends of the Amazon cable fit perfectly inside the ends of the iPad's sync cable and charger. It's a snug connection, so the connections won't come apart easily like if you accidentally tug the cable."		"I have an Android phone and absolutely love it, though I would probably love an iPhone just as much. I do have an iPad, so I hav"	"I have an Android phone and absolutely love it, though I would probably love an iPhone just as much. I do have an iPad, so I have nothing against Apple. What I do like about Android is that there are more customizing options, plus I do use many Google services such as GMail, Google Drive, Google+, etc. For me, the main reason I went with an Android phone over iPhone was screen size. I do A LOT of web browsing and shopping with my phone, and I felt that the iPhone screen was too small. I had purchased the Samsung Galaxy Nexus when it first came out because it was the largest screen size available at that time (if I remember correctly). Now there are even larger screens available and upcoming, and I definitely want to get a larger one as my next phone. I'm female and always carry a handbag, so size doesn't matter to me. I don't have to carry it in my pocketI like my screen as large as possible. There are some shopping apps where you can't even pinch to zoom the images, not sure why, so it helps to have a larger screen to see the product images. I also like a larger screen for use with GPS apps.I can't compare iPhone to Android since I don't have an iPhone; however, I have an iPad, so I'm sure it's a very similar experience. I personally find both operating systems easy to use and learn. Another thing I like about Android is the ability to use custom home screens (Launchers). I use one called SPD Shell 3D and it adds a 3D look as well as tons of customizing options for your home screen. If you buy a Google phone directly from Google (such as the Nexus 4), the price is unbeatable and the phone is unlocked, which means you can use it on other carriers. The downside, though, is that it doesn't fully support 4G LTE speeds."		"Thanks Jim. Every racket in this lineup is light, and their focus is to maximize power while also allowing great control. Dunlop has a bunch of different types of Aerogel rackets, and our recommendation is to look at the Dunlop Aerogel 4D Max ? it?s not too pricy yet offers everything you?re looking for.Beyond this recommendation, we know that every player has their own racket preference and needs. Check out this website which rates 2012-2013 squash rackets based on these preferences (such as durability, manufacturer, best value, court control):http://www.squashgalaxy.com/SG/category/racquetratings.htmlAnother cool resource is SquashHero, which presents you with a list of rackets based on the type of racket you?re interested in and your budget. We caught them with a live trap (apple slices with peanut butter inside the trap "	"Eww! No bueno. We had squirrels in our attic. We caught them with a live trap (apple slices with peanut butter inside the trap to entice them).  Then we drove them several miles away to release them so they couldn't find their way back. It worked well, no squirrels in attic since and that was a few years back. I would give it a try if I were in your situation. Mostly because I would prefer a rat to be several or more miles away than in my yard or home "		I'm always up for beta testing new apps. Let me know if you guys need me! This would allow you to give her all the great iApps out there for kids (err and shows and movies too) while limiting the risk of the Internet popping up.  This is what we did until we were gifted the leap pad since we had an old phone laying around.  I suppose you could do the same thing with an android or a tablet but price wise I don't know who has spare iPads laying around!  It's smaller but we all know their tiny fingers are better on iPhones than ours. "Ooh, that's a good idea too!"		"The LeapPad is an excellent starter tablet for a young child. I bought one for my niece when she was two, and she absolutely lov"	"The LeapPad is an excellent starter tablet for a young child. I bought one for my niece when she was two, and she absolutely loves it. She has use of an iPad now, but still likes to play with her LeapPad since it's her own tablet. It's very easy to use, though regular tablets and iPods are pretty easy to use as well. The only drawback for LeapFrog products are the price. I think the LeapPad's price has gone down over the past few years, so that isn't too bad, but the games are expensive. The game selection is quite limited as well. I always find games when they are on sale at Amazon or elsewhere.The games are on memory cards which have to be inserted into the LeapPad, so these can be lost very easily. I think there are more activities that can be done one LeapFrog's website as well. What I do like about the games is that they are all educational, they all teach something, whether it be motor skills, counting, or reading. If the child is too young to read, the tablet can read stories to them while the child watches a video of the story. My niece got hers a couple years ago and it still works fine, even after being dropped and sat on. It's built specifically for kid's use. You could also consider a Kindle Fire tablet or a Google Nexus 7 tablet and just get a good case for it. You can get the original Kindle Fire for just $159 on Amazon (8GB) or the Nexus 7 (16GB) directly from Google for $199.  (The Kindle Fire is much heavier and bulkier than the Nexus, though) There aren't as many apps/games as there are in Google's app store, but there are still tons of them. You can get games on Amazon's and Google's app stores for much cheaper or even for free. Both of them also have tons of games, books, learning apps for kids. As long as you have a decent case, it should protect the tablet from drops."		"Also, most regular tablets these days have either built-in parental controls, or apps that allow you to control your child's act"	"Also, most regular tablets these days have either built-in parental controls, or apps that allow you to control your child's activities. I had also bought my niece a Kindle Fire to use when it first came out. It did NOT originally have parental controls, but they quickly updated the operating system to include these controls. I know with the Fire, you can turn off wi-fi while the child is using it to prevent purchases or web surfing."		"Sorry, one more comment that I forgot to mention. As far as model selection of the LeapPad, there are only two, and the options "	"Sorry, one more comment that I forgot to mention. As far as model selection of the LeapPad, there are only two, and the options are only between colors - pink or green. Also, I think there are other games on LeapFrog's website that kids can play to their LeapPad, however, they don't actually download onto the LeapPad. However, they do have a memory card available to purchase (very expensive as well considering you can get a much larger capacity standard memory card for WAYYY less, but the LeapPad uses a much larger & thicker memory card that is proprietary, meaning you can only use theirs in the LeapPad, not just any brand memory card. You can buy theirs onto which to download LeapPad's other web site games."		"FYI...I have no idea how good this might be, however, you might want to check into it. It looks like internet/mail/telephone orders are charged at 1.99% plus a 25 cent transaction fee, which I think is quite lower than most others. If it's on a pole or 	"The number one suggestion is just to hang the bird feeder somewhere out of reach of earth-bound creatures. If it's on a pole or tree, they will find a way to climb, but you can mount it under a soffit on your house or hang it from somewhere impossible to reach.Shop around for specialized bird feeders that make rodents' attempts futile. It's really easy to find specific feeders that have steep-sloped access, so only hovering birds can find their way to the food. Something else to consider is that birds will drop some of the seeds, and that will bring the rodents to your patio/garden/etc.If all else fails, you can get a cat or sprinkle your yard with predator pee. The 2nd suggestion sounds funny, but the smell of the predator urine will keep pests out."		"I've had both, and went running back to iPhone after a long 2 years on an Android phone. Android is definitely better now than i"	"I've had both, and went running back to iPhone after a long 2 years on an Android phone. Android is definitely better now than it was when I abandoned it, but I would not go back.The asset to Android is that you have a much better opportunity to customize your phone. The overall platform is far more open, and there are apps to change things that you just have to live with on iPhone (like the clock, the phone UI, text messages, web browsing, etc).If, however, you just want to pull a phone out of the box and start using it, the iPhone beats everybody."		"I wanted to switch to TweetDeck, but there are a couple reasons I haven't made the switch yet (although I may be missing feature"	"I wanted to switch to TweetDeck, but there are a couple reasons I haven't made the switch yet (although I may be missing features on TweetDeck after my brief trial!) As far as I can tell, it lacks some features I need. For example, managing Facebook Pages - I have a number of those, and I didn't find a way to add a Page stream in TweetDeck. That could be the main deal breaker for me switching over to TweetDeck. I have very little activity on G+ or LinkedIn streams, but if you do then there wouldn't be a way to manage that in TweetDeck. I don't monitor the other social networks that HootSuite supports, so that's a non-issue for me! Then there's the hootlet button. Although it's a good idea to customize your messages based on where they are going to, even across the same audience, I find it handy for certain posts that are appropriate for multiple accounts. I'd miss that if I switched.HootSuite is very clunky, but I suppose I'm fairly used to the UI now and do like being able to add tabs with multiple streams (which sadly, I've managed to max out). I can order my tabs based on how often I use them, and have certain tabs dedicated to multiple related searches. This works well for me because I manage activity in very different realms (tech, dogs, sewing!)  If you don't need to do this, TweetDeck would be preferable with the nice and simple column layout. But there's no way I could replicate the number of tabs/streams from HootSuite in TweetDeck and remain sane.I definitely agree that HootSuite needs a UI overhaul, especially as it is a paid service...There are a few other free options out there, such as GrabInbox."		I'd suggest going somewhere that has a wide selection and friendly staff that will let you try it out on a tester bike. So I went to the pet store where they sold ferrets and asked f"	"Believe it or not, I heard about ferret poop as being a deterant. So I went to the pet store where they sold ferrets and asked for, yep, poop. They were stunned but obliged, and with gloves, I put it in areas that I knew the rats were coming from, and it worked! Of course the ferret poop odor isn't the greatest and it does go away after about a week, so I was going a couple of times a month for about 2 months to get 'fresh' stuff from the pet store. Once the rats seemed to think ferrets were living there, they went elsewhere. I should mention that if you put the poop about 20ft from your house, you won't smell it. It's not that strong. Good luck."		I've had my Vitamix for over 12 years and still love it. I always suggest friends buy one. They're amazing.	I've had my Vitamix for over 12 years and still love it. If there is food, they always seem to "	"I haven't found a way to deter squirrels from feeders yet, and I've tried so many things. If there is food, they always seem to find a way to get to it. I've tried many of those squirrel-proof feeders, but they get in anyway. I even hung a thin wash line across an area and hung a feeder in the middle of it....squirrels were still able to literally hang onto the line and make their way to the feeder. Once on the dome, they seem to be able to dig their claws into it, hang on, hang upside down, and get onto the feeder below the dome.I think if there was a way to stake a feeder in the yard away from trees and have a glass tube surround the stake, that might work. I don't think they could dig their claws into glass to climb up."		"the 3M uses a non-marring, contact silicone adhesive just like other screen films. just remove the protective film and lay over "	"the 3M uses a non-marring, contact silicone adhesive just like other screen films. just remove the protective film and lay over the screen. If the property owner wants to be a pain about the d"	"A word of caution regarding VRBO, or any vacation rental service I suppose. If the property owner wants to be a pain about the damage deposit they can fairly easily fabricate a claim and make things difficult.I've had two great experiences with a property in Lake Chelan and one lousy experience with a property in Arizona. The owner of the AZ property misrepresented the quality of the house and the furnishings to some degree, but my family rolls with it so that wasn't a deal breaker. The place was clean and it's really about the location.The problem arose when, after we'd returned home, he sends me an email full of fuzzy photos of alleged damage to a couple pieces of furniture and a picture frame. In the email he tells me he will have to send the stuff out to a furniture repair shop for an estimate.Conceptually, that sounds reasonable except that being respectful of, and careful with other people's property is a family value we actively teach our kids. And more to the point, the home was furnished top to bottom with WalMart rejects that looked like they'd been delivered to the house in a dump truck. It would have taken hours to catalog every nick and scratch when we first arrived.I never could get him to respond with his repair estimate and in the end I just let it go. It's one of those situations where I could have fought the guy, but it would have been time consuming and extremely contentious. I was satisfied knowing he was a jerk with horrific taste in furniture."		Android vs iPhone is essentially the same debate as Windows vs. Mac. It was the most comfortable one I tried on at "	"I actually have the pack in the photo, and took it on a month long trip to India. It was the most comfortable one I tried on at REI, and I do recommend it for quality and lightness.  It survived 24 hours of flights there and back, and still looks relatively new. They all fit a bit differently though, so I'd certainly recommend trying several on and having someone help you with the fit if need be. They threw weights in the pack, tell you to walk up stairs, and so forth so you can actually test how it will feel when loaded with stuff and you're trekking up a hill. It will at least help narrow down brands, size, and quality you're looking for."		Still loving it!  We're having one of those crazy run around days. There's a small chapel at the top, and an area marked out where st. Patrick was said to have slept. Beautiful view from the top. There are also fishermen who will take tourists out to fish with them on the bay.You'd also be likely to find a football (soccer) game to attend--weather might possibly be decent in July, and there are local teams everywhere! The train ride from Dublin to Belfast is fun too, only about 3 hours long I think, and a newer fast train, so I heard it was faster to take the train then drive. Um, and if you are driving around the country--do you know the game Hey Cow""? It will mak	"If he hasn't learned to ride a bike yet I highly recommend getting a scoot or something similar without any pedals.  It will make him learn how to balance first.  Whatever you do don't start with training wheels because they learn to balance against them and then need to unlearn it once you take them off.Once you move to a bike with pedals get something light.  Many of them are really heavy.  We got one from specialized that worked out well for us."		"My kids learned how to ride a bike at 4-5 years old on Target/Walmart bikes.  Kids grow a ton between 4 and 8 years old, so unle"	"My kids learned how to ride a bike at 4-5 years old on Target/Walmart bikes.  Kids grow a ton between 4 and 8 years old, so unless you are a really intense biking family or you have bunch of kids coming down the line, I wouldn't spend too much on the 1st bike.  Once he can ride and is showing interest in going longer distances or on trails then I'd invest in a Trek or a Specialized.  We have both, I think we like the Trek marginally better.  We have bikes in all sizes, but each size only seems to get used for a year or at most a year/half until they move up to the next size, especially boys who get big fast during that age range.We tried the scoot bike for my youngest and he didn't want anything to do with it because it didn't look like the big kids' bikes.  What has worked well for him to get a sense of what it feels to ride on two weeks is the tag along."		Try rugsusa.com	Try rugsusa.com		"Our family uses VRBO to rent out our vacation homes both domestically and internationally, so +1 recommendation for VRBO as our "	"Our family uses VRBO to rent out our vacation homes both domestically and internationally, so +1 recommendation for VRBO as our experience has been favorable.  Our issues are actually related to the particular mgmt company on site that may handle guest relations.  We appreciate the comments on Airbnb and will look into it, so thank you Yabbly :-).  In response to @seattle-chase, sorry that happened to you.  We had the opposite happen where guests have damaged furniture, broken appliances, and stolen playstation games/dvd movies, but because the mgmt company did not realize immediately, we never charged the guests.  Nor did we want to accuse any guests.  Also, VRBO does have traveler's review section where you can see others' experiences.  So that can help you with determining your rental but from an owner's perspective it can possibly work against you as you want a good review and therefore may not want to pursue damage claims against former guests for fear they will badmouth your place.  Just wanted to give you an owner's perspective as well.  Always 2 sides, or is it 3 sides :-)"		"Congratulations!! Hope you've been feeling well!  We love consignment shopping--here are my general rules:If it can go in the "	"Congratulations!! Hope you've been feeling well!  We love consignment shopping--here are my general rules:If it can go in the clothes washer and drier (clothing, boppy covers, blankets, covers for bouncy chairs, etc) and looks in good condition...If it can go in the dishwasher or be sprayed with bleach water and wiped down and sanitized (bouncy chair frame, plastic toys, exersaucers, etc) and looks in good condition...Things I wouldn't buy used: anything I cannot clean, or doesn't look like it was well-cared for.  A lot of baby accessories (swing, bouncy chair, exersaucers, high chairs) are easy enough to sanitize the plastic parts and have removable covers that can be washed and dried. So as long as they aren't broken or too used, you can find some great deals on only slightly used baby gear.Things I would not buy used: anything I cannot clean or sanitize well (Mattresses, boppy pillow, etc). Personally, I wouldn't buy a used breast pump, but I know people who have and don't have any issue with it. And I wouldn't buy a used car seat. Even if it looks pristine, there's really no way of knowing it's treatment, and if it's safety has been compromised in any way. Hope that helps! "		@tedb have a 240v outlet in the garage (same as washer/dryer) that delivers 30 miles per hour of charge. So if I'm at 25% = 50 miles of charge left, it would take 5 hours to get back to full. Tesla is building a network of charging stations that are about 5x as fast; only in CA and a couple places on the east coast at the moment. Basically the child runs while on the bike and when they feel comfortable they simply lift up their feet and coast. It happens almost instantaneously. We have a 6, 8, and 10 yr old and all three learned on one. The kind we had wasn't a stride brand as their astronomical in price. We went with a toys r us special that actually had the crank and chain attached but covered. We looked into it and found a few Bluetooth speakerphone options for you to stream music in your "	"Hi @Wesley,Great question! We looked into it and found a few Bluetooth speakerphone options for you to stream music in your car.Top Pick:Jabra Freeway (http://www.amazon.com/Jabra-FREEWAY-Bluetooth-Speakerphone-Packaging/dp/B004XZHY34)Though @Loading___ has had a bad experience with a Jabra hands-free Bluetooth, the Freeway seems to be a good fit for your situation. Here're the pros (+) and cons (-):+Can pair with two devices+Has three speakers inside (one of the loudest Bluetooth speakerphones on market)+Impressive music playback for a visor-mounted speakerphone+Option to stream to FM car stereo-Must tap Voice button and then say a command, instead of simply speaking (presents a safety problem)-Audio quality/noise cancellation isn?t the bestOther Options:bCODA CODA One (http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=9SIA1HU0NF0385&nm_mc=AFC-C8Junction&cm_mmc=AFC-C8Junction-_-na-_-na-_-na&cm_sp=&AID=10446076&PID=6147229&SID=xo9pyz9kkbng)The CODA One isn't the top pick, but it goes beyond just being a Bluetooth speaker: it can also be used as a wireless handset for your smartphone.+Bluetooth speaker, wireless handset, music player+Two speakers, two microphones, audio streaming+Linkage with Siri/Vlingo to send messages and complete tasks+Ergonomically shaped like a traditional handset-No audio jack-Only average for music with okay bass ? ?its audio quality is only good enough for occasional personal use? -CNETPortable Bluetooth Speakers Another possible option (albeit inconvenient) is to use portable Bluetooth speakers for in-car playback. Here's a recent Yabbly thread on a possible option (the Logitech Mobile Boombox): yabb.ly/NeK6fIThere are a lot of options for in-car Bluetooth speaker systems, but not a lot offer great sound for music playback. The Jabra Freeway is an exception, though we'd recommend that you go in-store and see a product demonstration. We hope this helped, let us know what you end up doing!-Yabbly Concierge"		"Mini is great, but I find myself preferring to pick up the iPad more often. First, for the most powerful machines, you'll need a desktop rather th"	"@Andy-friendly, you've got a few different alternatives.  First, for the most powerful machines, you'll need a desktop rather than a laptop.  The heat of the most powerful CPU chips needs more space to dissipate than a laptop has.You could get another Dell; if you're really into gaming, the XPS or even more powerful Alienware lines have a lot to offer.The Dell Workstation line is their other alternative if gaming isn't your primary use case.  All of those can be found in their Outlet store for less money and greater value.  You're more limited in customizability but you do save some bucks.When selecting SSDs, be sure to watch their transfer rates.  Go for SATA III or 6Gb/s transfer rates.Think about getting mirrored hard drives; there are 4TB drives now.  A sweet setup would be fast SSD for the OS and programs, and big mirrored drives for data.If Dell is off the list, you could consider getting a machine custom made for you; this opens up super-quiet, or liquid-cooled, or other more exotic alternatives.  My favorite for this is http://www.pugetsystems.com/, I had them build me a theater PC that is inaudible, fast, and reliable.Be sure to get a number of USB 3 ports, you'll use them with the peripherals starting to utilize the bandwidth available."		"You could also try Dell's outlet store http://www.dell.com/outlet - look for the XPS gaming systems, go a couple of levels below"	"You could also try Dell's outlet store http://www.dell.com/outlet - look for the XPS gaming systems, go a couple of levels below top grade, and you'll have a very capable system"		@Daniel that's awesome feedback. They may refund you the annual fee or prorate it."		"I too am looking to get an iPad, or iPad mini.  iPad mini: more portable, lower price.  iPad: better screen and CPU.
