In a way, we might be redefining the word friend"" in social media from people you went to school with to people who helped you out when you needed it and with whom you've reciprocated with over the years..."""		"As always... It depends""."						I like to break it up into 3 parts	" lo-fi, med-fi and hi-fi, so it depends on what you're looking """	"As always... It depends""."				I like to break it up into 3 parts	" lo-fi, med-fi and hi-fi, so it depends on what you're looking for.  (note: I'm approaching this from a product perspective, not a front-end engineering one)"					"For lo-fi mockups, nothing beats a white board.  Draw it out and take a photo to share and explain.  Same can be said for pen and paper.  Brainstorming and flexible exploring (flexploring?) are the goals here."						"For med-fi, I like to use Omnigraffle, Visio or Google Drawings.  This allows you to block out the interface and easily reproduce similar screens.   Xcode has a good interface builder for this as well if you're building a mobile app.  Balsamiq and Sketch are ok, but I find them a little clunky.  (IMO Quartz Composer is a great technology in search of an applicable use case.)"						"For hi-fi, I've had the good fortune to be teamed up with talented HTML/Dreamweaver people.  They were able to create rapid prototypes for me without the functionality."						Check out this article on rapid UI prototyping from smashing magazine for more info: 						http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2010/06/16/design-better-faster-with-rapid-prototyping/									Some other thoughts:			"- There was a company called Tiggzi, which allowed you to mockup an entire mobile app through their web site (complete with API connections).  At the hackathons I've been to, most people used that.  It's called Appery.io now.  Haven't used it in a year or so, but it was pretty nifty: http://http://appery.io"						"- I've heard some decent things about Picodo, but haven't used them personally: https://pidoco.com"						- Proto/Moto has put together a list of companies that offer rapid prototyping tools: http://protomoto.com						"Good luck!"""			"Printers of the description you provide are considered commodities.  If you're buying a la carte, simply choose your price point"	"Printers of the description you provide are considered commodities.  If you're buying a la carte, simply choose your price point and pick one up.  No need to spend more than $100.Two thoughts:- Ink compatibility.  Your costs will come from ink in the long run (maybe even within a year).  Check what type of ink the printer takes, how many pages you can get and how much it costs (with a little math, you can get a cost-per-page).- If you buy a new computer, the store will usually throw a printer in for next to nothing.  The printer shouldn't drive your purchase, but if you're thinking of upgrading systems, this is something to keep in mind."		"Bah. Just pull the band-aid off and do it. Nowadays, most things are web-based and the switching cost is minimal. If there are specific apps you need on a pc, such as a VPN, software to support legacy projects or compliance software, think twice. Otherwise don't pussyfoot around :-)"		"Thanks for the response.I have the lo & med-fi parts of my process pretty much where I want them. I do a lot of hand sketchi"	"Thanks for the response.I have the lo & med-fi parts of my process pretty much where I want them. I do a lot of hand sketching and then jump to Balsamiq when it is time.The challenge is that I also do the final UI on several projects. So when I use Sketch I'm not blocking out interfaces, I'm building final assets.What I'm looking for is a fresh take on what I guess would be the super hi-fi end of your spectrum. So much of whether or not an app makes it these days is in the final flourishes that get added to an app, and I'm looking for a tool that lets me quickly feel out whether something you be a slide transition or a 3D transform.The best candidate I've found thus far is http://www.purpleanimator.com/ and I'm on the fence about just dropping $20 to try it.A quick note on Quartz Composer: I think the work the Facebook Home team did with prototyping their IXD in QC is amazing. I just wish QC was a little less steep of a learning curve."		I would second Ikea. Or perhaps you can use a door/filing cabinets.	I would second Ikea. GTD is for organizing what the work you're going to do and Pomodoro for how you're going to do the work. My biggest pitfall with GTD was that it didn't give me much of a system to actually do the work that I carefully organized/categorized. It gave me a great way to manage what I needed to do. Pomodoro helped give me a framework to actually do the work."		You might consider forming a mascot or other logo from the collection of many smaller mascots/logos. If you expect to have a fun vacation in which you 	"We've found that travelling with toddlers really boils down to expectations.  If you expect to have a fun vacation in which you take advantage of all that Disney offers, etc., you will likely have a frustrating experience.  On the other hand, if you expect to have choppy sleep, limited time at the Park, abrupt departures from otherwise fun activities, etc., then you may just be pleasantly surprised if things go a bit more smoothly than expected.  But all of that said, I would probably opt against Disney with kids that young if I had a suitably attractive alternative."		You can get great deals on these Ikea bookcases through craigslist. I have 2 kids of my own, ages 2 and 4. "	"Hello Franciskim,I think your best bet would be the Graco Nautilus 3-in-1 Car Seat.  I have 2 kids of my own, ages 2 and 4.  I had bought a Britax for my older one when he was younger not knowing much about car seats and that everyone had the Britax which they all thought was the best.  Since having my 2nd child, I bought the Graco 3-in-1 car seat and now I have 2 Graco's because we do car pools.  The Graco seat seems to be holding up better than the Britax. It handles spills very well and is not too hard to clean.  It is also very easy to install and remove, which I seem to do a lot.  I would also suggest that you take the car seat to the local police station and have them install it the first time so you can see how it is correctly and tightly installed.  Most local police stations offer this as a free service but not too many people know about it.  The police just want to see that kids are safe in the car they ride in.  The Graco Nautilus is currently on amazon for $139 (with free Prime shipping if you are a prime member).  Also, with amazon prime membership if you are not happy with the car seat, you don't have to pay return shipping.I hope this helps.Adam"		Just wanted to add and say thanks everyone! There are models that are below $100 and/or you could get an o"	"If reliability is a main concern, then I would recommend a Canon. There are models that are below $100 and/or you could get an older model versus the latest model. The ink is more pricey than others, but if you don't print much, it shouldnt be a big concern. You can always print using black and the lowest quality, which is fine for printing documents. I personally don't mind paying a little more for Canon ink because the printer itself, at least in my experience, lasts so much longer. Canons always come out on top in reliability surveys and are usually highly rated. I have never had a problem with my Canon printers. The only reason I recently bought a new one was for the upgrades, such as AirPrint, e-print, and other capabilities. HP printers, in my experience, have been least reliable. I have had several over the years and every one of them broke down in just a little over a year. This is why I think spending a little more on ink for a more reliable brand is well worth it, considering that I was having to buy a new printer every year. I decided to go with Canon years back and my first one still works."		Great idea! Maybe you could include a link to it in your menu? They are pricey, and huge...which I don't love, but they do have consistent and good safety ratings, which was important to us. And, they have a good weight range (my 1 year old only weighs about 6lbs less than my tiny 4 year old) and ability to keep the child rear facing longer. In my husbands car, however, we used two Cosco Scenera car seats because they also scored high on safety ratings, (my apologies, I am not certain where we looked to compare ratings--either a car seat comparison web page or Baby411 or both), and they fit both our girls in the height and weight ranges (and we have one forward facing and one rear-facing). We have both, and the lack of retina on the mini is noticeable, but not awful.  The cameras on both are very poor compared to the iPhone, so you may want to wait for the new ones (cameras are updated every iteration).  Photo editing will be a much more positive experience on the larger display.  My wife swears by her mini -- primarily since it fits in her handbags easily. If u like hassle free new cars every 3 years, low monthly payments, and don't need to mod th"	"I leased many cars over the years.  If u like hassle free new cars every 3 years, low monthly payments, and don't need to mod the car, a lease is a great option.  If you plan to keep your car for a few years, want to minimize your long-term spend on cars, and want to mod the car, purchase works well.  It also depends a bit on the incentives.  My first lease was an Audi A4 for zero down and $299 a month.  Those were the days of awesome leases.  Nowadays they're not as crazy awesome (e.g. MINI has very lame lease terms relative to less brand loyal makes) but you should def track them."		"As Tom points out, leasing tends to be less hassle.  It's usually more expensive too, in the long run.  From a financial point o"	"As Tom points out, leasing tends to be less hassle.  It's usually more expensive too, in the long run.  From a financial point of view, the math tends to hinge upon the assumed depreciation rate (or residual value) implicit in the lease terms.  Since a buyer typically can get an auto loan for the purchase, a buyer can typically ease the monthly cash flows whether they purchase or lease (loan payments vs lease payments).  The primary difference in the math comes when you give the car back at the end of the lease (for $0) vs sell the car (for its actual residual value) or continue to hold it for additional years (further amortizing the original purchase price).  So, leasing is often a good idea from a hassle POV, but usually is only the optimal financial approach if the dealer has made very aggressive residual value assumptions and thus underpriced the lease."		"We have one, I have to look it up but we don't seem to use it much. "Thanks, Eddy. I had this article in my collection :) Any recommendations for off-the-beaten-path?"		Usually not.  Think of the cost of it as a % of the total cost of your trip.  Compare that % to the % chance the trip gets cance	"Usually not.  Think of the cost of it as a % of the total cost of your trip.  Compare that % to the % chance the trip gets cancelled.  Usually not a good ratio.  Furthermore, while any one trip could of course be subject to unforeseen external circumstances and cancelled, think about it over the life of all of your travel.  If you buy insurance on one trip, why wouldn't you on another?  And if you buy on all of your trips, is the aggregate cost really justified?  In my view, typically not.  So I'd only consider purchasing on a once-in-a-lifetime type major trip (a honeymoon, a significant anniversary trip, a really complex trip with multiple travellers to a unique destination, etc.)."		"Is it worth it? No. If the expected value of the insurance was positive, insurance companies would stop offering it.the only"	"Is it worth it? No. If the expected value of the insurance was positive, insurance companies would stop offering it.the only reason to get it (as with other insurance), is that you are willing to swallow an expected loss of money to cover the worst case"" scenario."		"For travel insurance, the ""worst case scenario"" isn't that bad (unlike with health insurance, home insurance, etc.)."			"Just Say No."""			Thanks Ken. And as a reminder, the #1 investment you can make is paying off high interest debt (if you have any). You are still very young with a lot of life choices spanning ahead of you, some of which may likely take you out of t"	"Ditto Tom. You are still very young with a lot of life choices spanning ahead of you, some of which may likely take you out of this area. You wouldn't want to be anchored with a house payment at this point which can tie up a fair chunk of your disposable income. You'll save more by renting and have a lot more flexibility. With renting, the most you'd lose if you have to move at a moment's notice is a month of rent. Pretty much peanuts compared to the potential loss and hassle that comes with a house or condo.   "		"Buying RE gets into marrying the neighborhood, so I suggest spending a lot of time there.  Get up early, drive to the potential "	"Buying RE gets into marrying the neighborhood, so I suggest spending a lot of time there.  Get up early, drive to the potential house, then see what you commute is like from there at what you figure would be your usual time.  Same for the commute home.  Then cruise the neighborhood on Saturday afternoons - who's out and about?   Check crime statistics, property value trends relative to other neighborhoods.  What's the average length of time someone's owned in that area?  How often do they have power failures?  Lots of questions to ask."		Personally I'd rather see a tax on bags that are injurious	Personally I'd rather see a tax on bags that are injurious		"I don't really question whether or not it's fair, just whether or not I'm willing to pay extra (& make others pay extra) if it m"	"I don't really question whether or not it's fair, just whether or not I'm willing to pay extra (& make others pay extra) if it means it's better for the Sound. We aren't about to go putting all our corporate email in Google's hands, when they are likely to be our long-term biggest competitor.  My domain accounts I run myself on my own qmail based server, which gives me a lot more control than gmail could ever do.  And OpenBSD is a lot more secure than any other OS I know of, which is my base OS for servers."		"Why say paper bags are bad?  They're from a renewable crop (trees regrow, dinosaurs don't).  And they decompose pretty quickly w"	"Why say paper bags are bad?  They're from a renewable crop (trees regrow, dinosaurs don't).  And they decompose pretty quickly with a bit of water, as anyone who's bagged up wet grass in them can tell you."		"Paper creates ~5x the solid waste, ~4x the atmospheric emissions, and over 17x the amount of waterborne waste versus plastic.  T"	"Paper creates ~5x the solid waste, ~4x the atmospheric emissions, and over 17x the amount of waterborne waste versus plastic.  They also use 1.5-2x as much energy to create.  (This study even factored in that paper bags hold more.)  Sort of ironic that paper bags are significantly worse for water when considering their global effect (this is heightened if bags are recycled; recycled paper is worse for water than non-recycled paper).  Source: http://plastics.americanchemistry.com/Analysis-of-Polyethylene-and-Unbleached-Paper-Grocery-Sacks"		"I used them as trash bags... now I have to buy plastic trash bags. Since the fiber lengths in the two are so dramatically different, and since newsprint requires a whiter (bleached) fiber, mills that I've been in (hundreds across US, CA, EU) do not recycle paper bags with newsprint.  Had the study reflected the reality of how Kraft bags are recycled (into Kraft bags or various paperboard products typically) the results could have been quite different in outcome.  "		"Never go to bed angry (i.e., resolve issues before turning in)."
